column2: A first edition of J.R.R. Tolkien’s 1937 novel “The Hobbit” was sold at an auction at the Bonhams auction house, London, for £60,000 ($122,000), twice its predicted value, on Tuesday, Agence France-Presse reported. Inscribed by the author and dedicated to Elaine Griffiths, a friend of Tolkien’s who helped with its publication, “The Hobbit” has sold more than 100 million copies worldwide since its first print run of 1,500 sold out. The auction also included the last known photo of Tolkien, taken in Oxford in 1973, and the first foreign-language edition of the book, a Swedish translation from 1947. “The Hobbit” was originally written for Tolkien’s children and preceded his fantasy trilogy, “The Lord of the Rings.”.

David Weeks may be best known for his spare, Calder-esque chandeliers and lamps, but he is also an accomplished furniture designer. That aspect of his work can be seen on April 3, when his first line of upholstered furniture is introduced at Ralph Pucci International in Manhattan. Sculpt, a collection inspired by the peaks and slopes of topographical maps and Barbara Hepworth’s stone sculptures, includes an armchair ($6,720), a sectional (not priced), a 10-foot sofa ($15,000) and an 8-foot sofa, above ($12,300). Each piece has a stainless steel frame gently cradling an asymmetrical seat and scooped backrest, shapes that Mr. Weeks said he developed in prototype by hacking away at huge foam blocks without the aid of a ruler, trusting his eye to create visual balance. Sculpt will be available, along with Sarus, Mr. Weeks’s new line of lighting, at Ralph Pucci International, 44 West 18th Street, (212) 633-0452. JULIE TARASKA.

A Vladimir Kagan swivel chair, upholstered in beige synthetic suede, will be $1,287.50 (reduced from $2,575); a two-door cupboard in zebra wood will be $3,350 (reduced from $6,700). The Relaxer rocking chair, covered in leather, will be $1,247 (reduced from $2,495); a queen-size lacquered wood bed frame by Cecchini, right, will be $2,987 (reduced from $5,975). Sofas and lighting fixtures will be marked down, too. Through March 31 at 131 Greene Street (Houston Street), (212) 431-7272. MARIANNE ROHRLICH.

An article on March 6 about the growing popularity of wellness coaches misstated the credentials of one coach, Dr. Julie Desch. She is a certified personal trainer, not a certified athletic trainer. Certified athletic trainers must have, among other requirements, a bachelor’s or master’s degree in athletic training. Although Dr. Desch does have a medical degree, certified personal trainers do not need higher education in the health sciences.

NOPPE--Jerome (Jerry) L., passed away on March 18, 2008. Devoted and loving son, brother, husband, father and friend. WWII veteran. Former president of Credit Clearinghouse Division of Dun & Bradstreet until his retirement in 1985. A joy to all who knew him. Shiva at family home, 3210 Cleveland Lane, Rockaway, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations to R. Taub Cancer Research Fund, 161 Fort Washington Ave., Room 922, New York, NY 10032.

ANDERSON--Patricia McGraw, died peacefully at the age of 77 on March 17, 2008 in Portland, ME. She was an accomplished architectural historian, writer, and educator who devoted much of her time to historic preservation in the State of Maine. She was the beloved wife of Richard Brewster Anderson and the loving mother of Thomson Pancoast, Philip Pancoast, Nicholas Pancoast, Teri Anderson and granddaughters Emma and Louisa. Beautiful and courageous, she will be remembered by all. Donations may be made to the Patricia McGraw Anderson Memorial for Publication Fund at Maine Preservation, 503 Congress St., Portland, ME 04101.

DORMAN--William. North Shore Country Club records with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Bill Dorman. We extend our deepest condolences to his family. N. Barry Ross, President Jeffrey Levy, Secretary DORMAN--William, jokes, smile, athlete, zest for life. Dear Phyllis and all the Dormans, we miss him already. Jane and Ron Zimmerman DORMAN--William. Dearest Phyllis, so sorry for your unexpected loss. My heart and thoughts go with you and your wonderful children and grandchildren. We will we always remember our special holiday dinners, with Bill's great gift of Hebrew tradition. Family was most important to him. Love you, Lois and Bob, Debra, Lori and Arthur DORMAN--William. It is with a heavy heart that we mourn the untimely death of William Dorman. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to his family. The Kadden and Hershenhorn Families DORMAN--William. On March 18th we lost the world's greatest husband, father, brother and Zeyda. A man larger than life, he taught us all to keep our eye on the ball. He is survived by his wife Phyllis, Jeff, Deborah, Jackie, Liana, Jelli, Ned, Ellen, Madelyn, Allison, Howard, Lori, Ben, Louis, Evan, Amy, Steven, Adam, Michael, Avram, Tema, Joan and Bob. Funeral services will be held Today, March 20th, at Gutterman's in Woodbury, New York at 2pm. DORMAN--William. Dear Billy, first drink with Alan is on me. Love, Jeanette King

SACKETT--Paul. 70, resident of Stamford, and until 1983, of Wilton Connecticut, Mr. Sackett attended Princeton University, where he was a founding member of the Ivy League Cycle Racing Circuit in 1955. He was a graduate of The Choate School and CW Post College. Paul had a passion for engineering and electronics, and was a lifetime member of The National Association for Amateur Radio. Lafayette Electronics in White Plains, NY employed him for many years as an electronics sales specialist. A member of the First Presbyterian Church and the Social Registry of New York. He is survived by nephews Alan and John Borst, a niece, Anna Benson Borst Henry, and seven grandnephews and grandnieces who will hold Paul's wit and beautiful nature forever in loving remembrance. A funeral service will be held at Wilton Congregational Church on Thursday at 1:00pm followed by interment at the Hillside Cemetery.

KOVEN--William. Our courageous Uncle Bill. We will miss sharing our lives with you. Thank you for your enthusiastic support and your gentle, unconditional love. Please make sure Grandpa doesn't drive. Pammy, Margaret, and especially Emma

HORNOR--DeWitt, 91, died February 24 in Barbados. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, March 27 at 11am at Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and 64th Street, New York. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Phillips Andover Academy, 180 Main Street, Andover, MA 01810.

ANSBERRY--Louise Stein man, 85, of Lancaster, Pennsylvania, passed away on Thursday, March 13, 2008 at her home. Known to many as Tinnie, she was the eldest daughter of James Hale and Louise Tinsley Steinman. Mrs. Ansberry was born in Baltimore, MD in 1922, attended schools in Maryland and New York City and later worked in public relations in New York as a consultant to the governments of Japan, India and Indonesia. She had a lifelong interest in Asian culture, politics and art. Mrs. Ansberry's marriages to T. Peter Ansberry and Subur Rahardja ended in divorce. Mrs. Ansberry is survived by: daughters Louise (Diane) Ansberry Rahardja, wife of Andyan Rahardja of Dallas, Texas, and Hale Ansberry Krasne, wife of Robert Krasne of Washington, DC; grandchildren James Hale Rahardja, Andrea Steinman Rahardja, William Joseph Krasne, and Margaret Duncan Krasne, and two sisters, Caroline Steinman Nunan and Bevery R. ''Peggy'' Steinman, both of Lancaster. A Memorial service will be held at St. James Episcopal Church, corner of Duke and Orange Sts., Lancaster, PA on Saturday, March 29th at 1:30pm. Friends may call at the Church on Saturday, March 29th from 12:30pm until the time of service. Please omit flowers.

GEORGOPULO--George B., 1924-2008. Born April 28, 1924, NYC. George attended Trinity School, Lafayette College, (DKE), MBA/Columbia University, began his career in Industrial Engineering/ manufacturing, aerospace and automotive industries. George joined, expanded and ran his family's second generation tobacco business, G.A. Georgopulo, Inc., NYC, specializing in manufacturing, importing, exporting, distribution, and created the generic cigarette. A Connecticut Real Estate Broker, a lifetime member American Institute of Industrial Engineers, S.C.O.R.E, C.E.R.T, and First Night in Westport, CT. George is predeceased by his wife, Margaret Bradley Georgopulo, and is survived by his daughter, Christine Georgopulo, Greenwich, CT.
TOMKINS--Mary Ann. December 28, 1944 -September 17, 2007 I think of your twinkling eyes and loving smile every moment of every day. No words can express how much I miss you. Love forever, Evan
PERLMAN--Daniel Jay D.D.S., Ph.D., 7/4/20-3/20/98 10 years of missing you. -Love Marilyn, Uriel, Sloane, Lauren and Jason

MEYER--Myra Shapiro, September 16, 1914-March 16, 2008. Passed away peacefully at age 93, on her half birthday, surrounded by her family. A caring, wise woman of infinite spirit, Myra will be remembered by all who knew her for her quick mind, her ready smile, her extraordinary kindness and her unending optimism. She saw good in everyone and will be forever in the hearts of her family and those who loved her. Her spirit and memory is kept alive by her devoted husband and soulmate of 65 years, Andrew Meyer, her loving children, daughter Constance Buerger, son Andrew, son-inlaw Alan Buerger, daughterin-law Kathy Meyer, her adoring grandchildren, Reid Buerger, Grant Buerger, Joshua Meyer, Daniel Meyer, Jessica Meyer and granddaughter-in-law Krista Buerger. She was a huge part of all of their lives. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Myra Meyer Young Investigator Fund at Johns Hopkins Medicine, to provide pilot funding for young investigators early in their career for psychiatric research, would be appreciated. Donations to the order of: Johns Hopkins University, Dept. of Psychiatry. Send to: Fund for Johns Hopkins Medicine, Dept. of Psychiatry, One Charles Center, 100 North Charles Street, Suite 410, Baltimore, MD 21201.

THOSE who are reupholstering garden or patio furniture this spring can choose from a variety of new weather-resistant textiles. Unlike the familiar outdoor canvas, many of these fabrics are textured or nubby, and they come in a multitude of patterns, not just the awning stripes and nautical designs used to cover garden furniture in the past. When it comes to the terrace floor, forget beige: outdoor rugs are more stylish and varied this season as well.

SRAGOW--Kaye B., of Rockville Centre, New York, March 19. Beloved wife of late husband, Jack, Navy nurse during World War II, then registered nurse. After graduating from Trenton State College, a school nurse in Cherry Hill, New Jersey, and in Rockville Centre, New York. She pursued an interest in nutrition after she retired. She was Chairman of the Education Committee for Hadassah in Nassau County. She is survived by her adoring children and grandchildren: William Sragow, wife Pat, daughters Rebecca, Cara, of Marlton, NJ; Roanne Sragow Licht, husband Richard, children Jaclyn, Jacob, of Westwood, MA; Michael Sragow, wife Glenda Hobbs, of Baltimore; and Larry Sragow of Long Beach, New York. Contributions to Hadassah: Attn: Miriam Levy, 50 West 58th Street, New York, New York, 10019.

The Sci Fi Channel has approved a two-hour pilot for the prequel to ''Battlestar Galactica,'' according to The Hollywood Reporter. The announcement was made at the cable channel's presentation of its new schedule Tuesday in New York. The prequel, ''Caprica,'' created by David Eick and Ronald D. Moore, the team behind ''Battlestar,'' is set 50 years before the hit show.

WEISSMAN--Seymour. July 27, 1928, died March 19, 2008. Beloved husband of Beverly, father to Larry, Debbie and David, and grandfather to 3 much loved grandchildren. Services Friday March 21, 2008 at noon at Riverside Nassau North Chapel, 55 Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY 11021. In lieu of flowers, donations should be sent to charity.
LEVY--Robert M. Goodbye old friend, my golfing brother. You were a stand-up guy and a straight arrow pal. You will be sorely missed. Dick Lembeck

GOLDBERG--Harriet. Temple Beth-El of Great Neck records with profound sorrow the passing of our longtime member. We extend heartfelt sympathy to her bereaved family. Nina Koppelman, President Richard J. Shapiro, Rabbi

TAFT--Julia Vadala. The Board of Directors, Overseers and staff of the International Rescue Committee (IRC) are saddened by the death of our colleague Julia Vadala Taft. For nearly 40 years, Julia was a friend and ally of the world's most vulnerable and impoverished people -especially refugees uprooted by war, disaster or persecution. Her creativity, energy and effectiveness were legendary, and won her wide admiration and appreciation during her service as an official of the US government and the UN and as a leader in the humanitarian aid community. As a member of the IRC board from 1990 to 1993; she traveled tirelessly in support of our international programs. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to her husband, Will, and their children, William, Maria and Julia. Alan Batkin and Jonathan Wiesner, Co-Chairs, IRC Board Tom Brokaw and Maureen White, Co-Chairs, IRC Overseers George Rupp, President
DeSANTIS--Albert. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Albert DeSantis, associated with The Times from February 6, 1959 to August 1, 1994.

IT is tempting, after buying a flatwater kayak -- which can cost anywhere from $300 to $3,000 -- to snatch up the cheapest paddle and be done with it. But on the water, this may cost you. Entry-level aluminum paddles, starting at $40 or so, are among the heaviest. Carbon paddles, which fall into the category of performance paddles, can weigh half as much and have become increasingly prevalent and ever lighter over the last decade. The downside: some cost as much as the kayak.

Correction Appended George Clooney will screen his new movie ''Leatherheads'' in Maysville, Ky., on Monday, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Clooney's father, Nick, said that the actor will visit this northern Kentucky town, which is approximately 16 miles east of Augusta, Ky., where the star grew up. Nick Clooney and George Clooney's aunt, Rosemary, were born in Maysville, and the town holds special significance for the family: it's where Rosemary Clooney's movie ''The Stars Are Singing'' was given its premiere in 1953. The Times reported Wednesday that Greenville, S.C., where the movie was filmed, will have its own premiere, probably without Mr. Clooney and the cast. More than 400 extras from the Greenville area are in the film.
The Road to Baghdad

LORENZO--Ana, passed away on March 16, 2008 at the age of 96. Born in Spain. Lifelong resident of Rego Park, Queens where she was an avid gardener and graduate of Queens College. Beloved wife of the late Olegario and loving mother of three sons; Valentin (Maxine), Frank (Sharon) and the late Olegario, Jr. ''Larry''. Devoted grandmother of nine grandchildren; Laura McNey (John), the late Lawrence ''Larry'', Dr. Robert Lorenzo (Deborah), Karen Benson (Craig), Kim Brown (Dan), Nicole Lynch (William), Mercedes Hubbard (Chad), Carolina Lorenzo, Timon Lorenzo and 13 great-grandchildren. Dear aunt of Valentine Mateos (Alice). In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Mt. Sinai Medical Center, Cardiology Unit. c/o Dr. Valentin Fuster, 1 Gustave L. Levy Pl., NY, NY 10029. Family will receive friends at Leo F. Kearns Funeral Home, 6140 Woodhaven Blvd., Rego Park on Friday 5-8pm. Funeral Blessing Holy Saturday 9:25am at Resurrection Ascension Church, Rego Park. Interment to follow at St. Charles Cemetery, Farmingdale.

NEWMAN--Frieda, on March 18, of New York City. Beloved wife of the late J. Moe Newman. Devoted mother of Phyllis and Leon Charash, Herbert and Beth Newman, Martin Newman, Toni Sachs and Michael Norcia. Cherished grandmother of six and great-grandmother of nine. Also survived by adoring nieces and nephews and by her sister-in-law, Yetta Newman, and she was a respected and loved friend to many. Services to be held on Thursday, March 20, at 10:00am, at Gutterman's in Woodbury, NY. Contributions in her memory can be made to Gurwin Health Care Foundation, U.J.A. Federation, or a charity of one's choice.

BERGEN--Carol Ann ''Cabby'', succumbed to a 31/2 year battle with pancreatic cancer at her home in Pleasantville, NY on the evening of March 17. She was 55. She was her own woman -wise, strong-willed and deeply compassionate. She is survived by her two adoring children, Peter Bergen Franklin and Sara Bergen Franklin, and her thoroughly spoiled yellow lab, Charlotte. Her memorial service will be held at the Clearview School, 550 Albany Post Rd., Briarcliff Manor, New York on Saturday, March 29 at 12pm. All are welcome. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Clearview School.

The Miami rapper Rick Ross, who made it big two years ago with a hit ring tone (''Hustlin'''), has scored his second No. 1 on the Billboard album chart with ''Trilla'' (Slip-N-Slide/Def Jam), left. Nielsen SoundScan reported that it sold 198,000 copies in the United States, significantly more than Snoop Dogg's ''Ego Trippin','' (Geffen), which moved 137,000, bowing at No. 3. The pop compilation series ''Now That's What I Call Music,'' usually a blockbuster, had notably slow sales for its 27th volume. It moved 169,000 copies to reach No. 2, the lowest opening-week sales for the series since its first volume 10 years ago. Other Top 10 debuts this week include Fat Joe's ''Elephant in the Room'' (Terror Squad/Imperial), at No. 6, and Miley Cyrus's ''Hannah Montana/Miley Cyrus: The Best of Both Worlds Concert'' (Disney), at No. 10.

ARMOUR--Yolande, passed away peacefully on March 14 surrounded by family three weeks before celebrating her 100th birthday. She was born April 3, 1908 in Pittsburgh, PA. Known to her friends as ''YoYo'', she was an accomplished artist, painting in oils as well as illustrating many books. She was a devoted mother to Frani Ridder (Mrs. Daniel H.) and Gretchen Leach (Mrs. Howard H.), an adored grandmother of seven and a great-grandmother of 18. She was a huge part of all of their lives. She was married to David L. Cooper, M.D. and David Armour and widowed twice.

MINGHELLA--Anthony. We mourn the loss of our friend and colleague who left us in such a sudden and tragic way. We are left exhilarated by his soaring vision, humbled by his gentle humanity, and profoundly saddened by his absence. Our lives are so much richer in having been touched by his. We are joined by our colleagues in Botswana in sending our love at this painful time to Tim and Amy, his tireless collaborators in No.1 Ladies Detective Agency, to Sydney Pollack and his esteemed colleagues at Mirage, to Harvey and his team at The Weinstein Company, and to Carolyn, Hannah and Max, his cherished family. Sally Morrison and the Staff of the Diamond Information Center

They call it The Eight. For in the sparkly, scary, noisy and smoky universe of the Globe of Death, eight would be the record-breaking number of motorcycle riders circling at more than 40 miles an hour in a 16-foot-wide steel sphere. The Eight would be the next thing in this classic circus thrill act, whose century-long history has paralleled the evolution of the motorcycle itself.

An article on March 6 about the growing popularity of wellness coaches misstated the credentials of one coach, Dr. Julie Desch. She is a certified personal trainer, not a certified athletic trainer. Certified athletic trainers must have, among other requirements, a bachelor's or master's degree in athletic training. Although Dr. Desch does have a medical degree, certified personal trainers do not need higher education in the health sciences.

GODIN--Ethel, age 96, passed away peacefully on March 16. Born in Brooklyn, New York on March 3, 1912. Loving wife to the late Jacob Godin and mother to the late Victor Godin. Survived by her grandsons Jeff and Eric Godin.

A PARADE of awkward TV and movie antiheros -- think Ugly Betty, Velma from ''Scooby-Doo,'' McLovin from ''Superbad'' -- has given nerdism a boost in cachet. Now come their off-screen counterparts, the crowd at Splat!, the graphic novel symposium that took place on Saturday at the New York Center for Independent Publishing in Midtown. The cartoonists, publishers, librarians and manga fanciers in the crowd elevated the overtly scholarly Poindexter look to a retro art form. Skipping the requisite gadgetry (Bluetooth headsets and the like), most cultivated an aura of benign self-neglect. Overstuffed messenger bags, weathered cords, Converse sneakers and trilbys contributed to the effect. Tousled hair, windbreakers and spectacles, too, played a part in transforming these studiously nondescript characters into brashly confident avatars of cool.

WEISS--Sam, on March 19th, 2008. Music industry pioneer and legend. Beloved husband of Twinnie (Enid). Devoted father of Deborah Glass and Michael Weiss and father-inlaw of Daniel Glass and Julie Weiss. Cherished grandfather of Sean, Maxie, Liam, Jake and Noah. MALLOY--George, Accompanist, dies at 87. George Malloy, accompanist for Blue Hill Troupe, and operatic greats Eileen Farrell, Roberta Peters, Martina Arroyo, and Elisabeth Soderstrom, died Sunday, March 16, 2008. He toured the world with Todd Duncan (the original Porgy on Broadway). Mr. Malloy also toured with Camilla Williams. He accompanied her during performances at the White House and before 250,000 people in Washington DC, Mr. Malloy played the Star Spangled Banner as Ms. Williams sang preceding Martin Luther King, Jr. as he delivered his historic I Have a Dream speech. Mr. Malloy was proud of his 31 year association with the award-winning Blue Hill Troupe. He accompanied Paul Sorvino for his television debut, appeared in several movies, and recorded an internationally selling CD at age 82, titled In Between Films. Mr. Malloy coached opera, sacred music, musical theater and other concert repertoire at his Manhattan studio. He is survived by two nieces, Mary Clare Kelso, and Nan Lazzaretto, two nephews, Patrick Russell and Tom Russell, 15 great-nieces and nephews, and 23 great-nieces and nephews. A memorial service for George Malloy will be held on Friday, March 28, 2008, at 11am Trinity Church Cemetery and Mausoleum, located on Upper Riverside Drive and 155th.

PRESCOTT--John S., Jr., born August 7, 1927, died peacefully at home in Manhattan on March 17, 2008. A memorial service will be held on Monday, March 24, at 10am at the Fourth Universalist Society at Central Park West and 76th Street. Memorial donations may be made to the Correctional Association of New York, The Greater Lovell Land Trust, The Fourth Universalist Society of New York, The Doe Fund, Calvary Hospital Hospice of New York.

Alicja Ryczek carried a cross with other members and supporters of Pax Christi Metro New York as they marked Good Friday in a walking prayer procession on 42nd Street. The group also held speeches addressing social and global issues such as the war in Iraq, the economy and health care. They stopped at what they called 15 contemporary stations of the cross, a Christian tradition that symbolizes the final journey of Jesus Christ toward his crucifixion, death and resurrection, which most Christians celebrate on Easter Sunday this weekend.

Recently Tom Wolfe visited the Book Review to sit for a podcast interview. We hoped for perhaps 30 minutes of his time. Instead he settled in and spoke to us for more than an hour - ranging over the whole of his remarkable half-century career: his years as a graduate student at Yale (in American Studies; his thesis was on literary Communism), his early newspaper days (he was posted to Havana during the first phase of Castro's rule), his invention of the "New Journalism" in the 1960s (he described the four "devices" that defined the genre) and his decision to switch to fiction, beginning with "The Bonfire of the Vanities," the subject of this blog for the next two weeks.

It was not surprising news. In fact, it was expected news. But Manager Joe Girardi made it official Friday when he named Chien-Ming Wang the starter for the Yankees' season opener against the Toronto Blue Jays on March 31. "I think he's earned it," Girardi said. "He's won 19 games the last couple of years. He's thrown the ball very well the last couple of years. I'm comfortable starting him Opening Day." Wang was supposed to start the 2007 opener, but he strained his hamstring. Carl Pavano, yes, the always injured Carl Pavano, wound up starting the opener. My hunch is Yankees' fans will be happier seeing Wang on the mound for the last opener at the current Yankee Stadium than they were about seeing Pavano there a year ago.

The superfit walk among us. They saunter or strut, depending on whether they're showcasing their magnificent agility or their oxlike strength. They ignore the chatter in the health media over treadmill technique and pedometer steps. They scoff even at seemingly rigorous practices like Mysore Ashtanga yoga and marathon training. They are America's self-styled fitness elite, adherents of a punishing online exercise regime called CrossFit, which orders its followers to cultivate a distinctly martial - not to say paranoid - ideal of "physical preparedness."

Update: Western Kentucky wins, 101-99, in a crazy finish. The final series was started by a huge mental error by Western Kentucky's Boris Siakam. Perhaps thinking his team was losing he fouled Leonard Houston out at half court with less than a minute left. But Siakam made up for it on the other end by grabbing an offensive rebound and getting fouled on the putback. He made both foul shots to give the Hilltoppers a 1-point lead. On the other end Adam Emmeneker missed a shot. In the ensuing scuffle for the ball Western Kentucky's Tyrone Brazelton fouled Jonathon Cox. Cox made both free throws to give Drake a 1-point lead with 5.7 seconds remaining. The Hilltoppers then drove it down the court and Ty Rodgers hit a 30-footer to win it in the first buzzer-beating finish of this tournament.

Mr. Jop and Mr. Gert, the editors and founders of Fan Man, also have interviews with Tobias Meyer, a funny fashion spread on pajamas in the street (this is not news to the guys I know), and a profile of Scott Schuman, Mister Sartorialist. You may have heard that the Metropolitan Museum of Art has organized a panel of (feisty) bloggers as part of Blog:Mode. It will be Sunday, March 30, at 3 p.m. at the Met. Scott, Diane Pernet and I are the panelists, and Harold Koda of the Costume Institute will be the moderator. Y'all, please come!

TAIPEI -- Politics in Taiwan are highly personal and frequently nasty, and the current presidential campaign has been no exception. Both sides have been especially wary of any last-minute ploys. The Nationalists are especially wary of any further attempts to question whether their presidential candidate, Ma Ying-jeou, is still entitled to permanent legal residency in the United States. He has said that he canceled his green card long ago. But even when the card itself expires, a person may still be entitled to legal residency unless this right is taken away by an immigration official.

Lupinis are an Easter specialty to some, but I've been cooking them on and off since Ifirst bought a paper coneful in Rome in the mid-70s. They're an odd bean in a couple of ways. They have a very tough skin, not quite as tough as favas, but tough enough so that the classic way to eat them (after cooking) is to bite the skin's tiny hole to make it a little bigger, then squeeze the bean directly into your mouth. (You can eat the skin if you like.)

Because of an editing error, an article in the Styles section on Thursday about the Mayflower Hotel in Washington referred imprecisely to Marion S. Barry Jr., the former Washington mayor who was convicted in 1990 on a misdemeanor drug charge after being accused of using cocaine while staying at the Mayflower in 1989. Mr. Barry’s possession of drugs at the hotel was described to the authorities by an eyewitness; he was not “seen smoking a crack pipe.” (That happened in 1990 when a federal sting operation caught him on videotape smoking a crack pipe while staying at what was then the Vista Hotel in Washington.).

A chart in Business Day on Thursday with an article about projected automobile sales for 2008 mislabeled the data. United States sales are forecast to be in a range of 14.9 million to 15.7 million vehicles, not $14.9 million to $15.7 million.

An article on Sunday about the legislative record and political career of David A. Paterson on the eve of his installation as governor of New York included an outdated reference to the job duties of his wife, Michelle Paige Paterson. She oversees wellness programs at the Health Insurance Plan of New York; she no longer works on its charitable activities.

An article in The Arts on Wednesday about this summer’s Mostly Mozart Festival at Lincoln Center, using information from a publicist, referred incorrectly to the debuts of the three young conductors Lionel Bringuier, Edward Gardner and Susanna Malkki. Their appearances at the festival will be their New York debuts, not their American debuts.

A television review in Weekend last Friday about “John Adams,” the new HBO mini-series, misstated the timing of the illness of one of the Adams children. It followed an inoculation for smallpox; it did not precede the inoculation. The review also referred incorrectly to the man who was tarred and feathered by a mob. He was a customs agent, not a tea merchant.

A sports article on Wednesday about Roger Federer’s resurgence at the Pacific Life Open referred imprecisely to the performances of a potential opponent, David Nalbandian, in their previous head-to-head matches. Although Nalbandian has a .500 record against Federer, he has achieved nearly all of his success on hardcourts like those in this tournament or on carpet, not “mostly on clay.”.

Gordon, a New York State assemblywoman from Brooklyn, misspelled, in some copies, the given name of the prosecutor who delivered the opening argument. He is Michel Spanakos, not Michael.

Steelers wide receiver Cedrick Wilson was released hours after he was charged with punching Lindsey Paulat, his estranged girlfriend, at a restaurant in suburban Pittsburgh. Wilson, 29, was arraigned on charges of simple assault, harassment and disorderly conduct, and freed on $10,000 bail.Wilson and Paulat were involved in a fight in January. In that incident, the police charged her with firing two gunshots after Wilson left his townhouse. Paulat, who is also the mother of Wilson’s 1-year-old daughter, is awaiting trial.

Mao Asada of Japan won the women’s title at the world figure skating championships in Goteborg, Sweden, overcoming a fall going into a planned triple axel. Carolina Kostner of Italy won the silver medal, despite putting her hands down twice on jumps. The South Korean Kim Yu-na, who missed a competition last month because of a hip injury, took the bronze medal.All three American skaters fell at least once, and their stumbles will cost the United States at next year’s world championships. The former world champion Kimmie Meissner was seventh, Bebe Liang was 10th and Ashley Wagner was 16th. That means the United States will have only two spots at next year’s championships, which will determine how many slots a country gets at the Vancouver Olympics.

SECOND GENERATION This company, currently in its 11th season, counts among its goals the development of a new generation of Asian-American theater artists. While there are other, older Asian-American companies in New York -- the Ma-Yi Theater Company (19 years old) and Pan Asian Repertory Theater (going on 31) come to mind -- Second Generation has been carving out its own identity, just as its predecessors did. According to Lloyd Suh, the company's artistic director, Second Generation collaborates with other local companies (he is even a director of the Ma-Yi Writers Lab), but also maintains an individual perspective. ''Asian-American theater is in a really interesting place right now because with previous generations there was an introspective way of looking at it, looking at an identity politic,'' he said. ''This current generation of Asian-American artists is looking at a broader range of issues from an Asian-American lens. Instead of looking inward, we are looking out.''

'REALLY ROSIE' A small boy left alone by his parents and then devoured by a rampaging lion? A gruesome vampire unleashed to drink the blood of innocents? How about a little brother suffering an agonizing death as he chokes on a chicken bone? O.K., so it doesn't sound like children's entertainment. But it is children's play, shaped by the talents of Maurice Sendak. All these scenes are enacted onstage by people under 10 -- well, young adults playing people under 10 -- to hilarious effect. They and other miniature melodramas make up ''Really Rosie,'' above, the latest production from Atlantic for Kids, the youth-oriented wing of the Atlantic Theater Company. And if you don't take your children (those older than 4) to watch these pretend disasters, they'll miss an hour of deliciously subversive fun.

MINGHELLA--Anthony. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the untimely death of Anthony Minghella, brilliant director and writer, inspiring collaborator, and beloved friend. Minghella directed the new production of Puccini's Madama Butterfly that opened the Met's 2006-2007 season, captivating the city when it premiered on the Met stage and on giant screens in Times Square. At the time of his death, Minghella was collaborating as librettist and director on a new opera for the Met with composer Osvaldo Golijov. We extend our sincerest condolences to his wife, Carolyn Choa, his son, Max, his daughter, Hannah, and his entire family. We will sorely miss him. Peter Gelb, General Manager James Levine, Music Director

The very success of immunizations has turned out to be an Achilles heel. Most of these parents have never seen measles, and don't realize it could be a bad disease so they turn their concerns to unfounded risks. They do not perceive risk of the disease but perceive risk of the vaccine. DR. MARK SAWYER, an infectious disease specialist at Rady Children's Hospital in San Diego. [A19]

SONNY ROLLINS AND GARY GIDDINS IN CONVERSATION The tenor saxophonist Sonny Rollins is one of the few indisputable titans in the history of jazz. The writer Gary Giddins is one of its most acute and insightful critics. So the prospect of a conversation between them carries weight for a certain segment of the population. Such an event isn't unprecedented -- as recently as 2005 Mr. Rollins appeared under the auspices of the New Yorker Festival with Stanley Crouch, another critic of serious repute -- but it does command fresh attention. Mr. Giddins has been one of Mr. Rollins's fiercest champions over the years. He has also described this tenor saxophonist as ''jazz's most provocatively enigmatic man.'' His assessments of Mr. Rollins, above, have not only shaped public perceptions but have also had a more material impact: a dozen years ago, after the publication of a Village Voice essay arguing the selective merits of Mr. Rollins's Milestone Records catalog, the label credited Mr. Giddins with the concept behind ''Silver City: A Celebration of 25 Years on Milestone.'' (Fans of Mr. Rollins know that two-disc compilation to be essential.)

She is survived by her son, Kenneth Andrew, her daughter, Joan Traub, her sister, Helen Bergman, her granddaughters, Anne Elizabeth Traub, Mary Catherine Traub and Margaret Jane Aguirre, and her great - grandson, Nicholas Joseph Traub Finley. Her grandson, Duncan MoodyBronston, preceded her in death. Her husband of 69 years, Milton Bronston, died in 1998. Funeral services will be held at Schwartz BrothersJeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Blvd. at 76 Rd., 12 noon, Sunday, March 23, 2008. The family suggests donations be made to United Cerebral Palsy of NYC.

DORMAN--Bill. Bill Dorman was a special person to me. I had the privilege of being part of Phyllis and Bill's cookouts in the backyard and Passover services that lasted hours because of Bill's tenacity and determination. His quick and well informed mind always supported his opinions. You may not have always agreed with his opinions but along with those opinions came a warm heart and a hug. You could count on him to always be in your corner. He was a wonderful role model who showed me as a husband, father, and grandfather what family was all about. He adored his kids and loved each of them with all his heart. He respected life and respected family. The question of ''are you better off today than yesterday'' is clearly answered no. He warmed our lives and brightened our days. I love you. G-d bless you, Bill, we'll miss you. To Howard: Dors, hang in there... so happy that you are my brother. Love ya, The Pergs. Arthur and family XXXXX DORMAN--William. Bill, your intellect, love of family and generous spirit inspired us all. Our hearts go out to Phyllis and the Dorman family on their loss. The Citrin and Lane Families DORMAN--William. Beloved brother and uncle. Thank you for all your love and support, laughter and great stories. We will all miss you. Joan and Bob Goldberg and Family DORMAN--William. Dearest Phyllis, so sorry for your unexpected loss. My heart and thoughts go with you and your wonderful children and grandchildren. We will we always remember our special holiday dinners, with Bill's great gift of Hebrew tradition. Family was most important to him. Love you, Lois and Bob, Debra, Lori and Arthur DORMAN--William. To Phyllis and the entire family: we know Bill's love of life will live on in all of you. Our deepest sympathies for your loss. The Shachat Family DORMAN--William. Con dolences to Phyllis and family. In loving memory of our dear Bill. Alice and Lou Weiss

'REX HARRISON: A CENTENARY TRIBUTE' ''Damn, damn, damn, damn!'' shouts Rex Harrison in his signature role as Professor Higgins in ''My Fair Lady.'' But that was 1964. As the roguish but deceased sea captain in the 1947 movie ''The Ghost and Mrs. Muir,'' Harrison, not allowed such invective, does quite nicely with ''Blast!'' And soon the spunky widow, Mrs. Muir (Gene Tierney, above with Harrison), is matching blasts with Harrison's Capt. Daniel Gregg, the black-turtlenecked, Keats-quoting, devilishly goateed swashbuckler-about-the-house. Harrison, who was born on March 5, 1908, and died in 1990, is being celebrated at the Museum of Modern Art. Joseph L. Mankiewicz, who directed ''Mrs. Muir,'' also directed Harrison in ''Escape'' and ''Cleopatra,'' which can all be seen in the MoMA series.

A hit at South by Southwest in Austin, Tex., the British duo the Ting Tings ''pump out danceable riffs echoing the 1960's and 1970's,'' writes Jon Pareles, who also calls them ''irresistibly catchy.'' The guitar-and-drum group just scored a major-label deal; catch them on their post-Austin swing through New York on Friday night at Le Royale. Then stay for the Robot Rock dance party, with D.J.s from the Los Angeles group the Villains, whose remixes of Hot Chip, Daft Punk and Michael Jackson get blogger love. For more SXSW favorites, check out the Scottish group Sons and Daughters, which ''has perfected its own kind of chilling murder ballad,'' writes Ben Sisario, with ''bleak scrapings of guitar'' and ''lyrics of unforgiving fate,'' Friday night at the Music Hall of Williamsburg or Saturday at the Bowery Ballroom. 'RMB CITY' Cao Fei, a young artist based in Beijing, has become something of a celebrity in the online game Second Life. (Her avatar, China Tracy, is featured in the book ''Second Life: The Official Guide.'') For her latest show she has created a virtual city within the game. The Lombard-Freid Projects gallery has been made over as a real-world sales office for ''RMB City,'' above, with a white plastic and aluminum model of the metropolis, a reflection pool showing shifting digital projections and computers that allow visitors to navigate the city. With its skyscrapers, cranes and spiraling ramps, ''RMB City'' resembles the retro-futuristic metropolis of the Jetsons crossed with a modern-day Beijing. A smokestack belches flames, a statue of Chairman Mao salutes visitors, and a giant panda balloon floats overhead.

STIRES--Judith Lohman, on March 16, 2008, of Pancreatic Cancer. Judy was born in Brooklyn on June 14, 1931 to Eugene and Martha Lohman. She grew up in Connecticut and New Jersey and attended Loomis Chaffee School and St. Margaret's School. She was an alumna of Centenary College in Hackettstown, NJ. She is survived by her husband, Sidney Stires, her sister, Gail Lohman Raleigh, her children; Wicks, Martha (Glenn Wright), Annie (John Carter), and Tom (Emily), her nephew, David Raleigh, and her 13 grandchildren. Judy was married for 53 years to her loving husband and best friend Sidney Homer Stires. They raised their family in New York City and Bay Head, NJ. For the last 20 years, Sid and Judy also lived part of the year in Venice, Italy. Over many years, Judy was a volunteer at The Boys Club of New York in the Youth Education programs. She was devoted to St. Thomas Church, and to St. Thomas Choir School. Judy was known for her joyful spirit, her great sense of style, her playful humor, and her love of music. She engaged people of all ages, and loved knowing all about their lives, their friends, their plans. Her family marveled at the energy she gave to every task, and her tasks were often labors of love that others had forgotten about or given up on. Judy was also tireless in her willingness to help the dependent know the happiness that she and Sidney had found in their life of sobriety. She volunteered in that effort for years at The Freedom Institute of New York City, but much of her work was done in the form of counsel right on her front porch. She was a gifted messenger. Judy, above all, was a wonderful wife, and mother, and grandmother, who loved those roles. A memorial service will be held at St. Thomas Church, 53rd Street and Fifth Avenue at 3:00pm on Friday, May 2nd. Gifts in Judy's memory can be made to The Freedom Institute, 515 Madison Avenue, 26th fl, New York, NY 10022. www.Freedominstitute.org.

Alan Romberg makes an important point about the need for political reconciliation within Taiwan. The toxic animosity that has prevailed for the past eight years has many causes, but the effect has been to weaken Taiwan and undermine the democratic system. The island will be better able to face the challenge of China if it is unified than if it is divided.

All parties involved in the triangular Taiwan-PRC-U.S. triangle will face a challenge to seize the opportunity presented by the Taiwan election. On the one hand, President-elect Ma will need to follow through on his commitment to work for more constructive cross-Strait relations, albeit in a framework of consolidating Taiwan's economic, political and military position. On the other hand, to be successful in these efforts, he will have to follow through on his pledge to reach across party lines to engage the opposition DPP and others in the society in creating a broad consensus to move ahead in this way.

Adam Segal and Shelley Rigger are correct that events in Tibet, and Ma Ying-jeou's statements about them, create a cloud over the future. But Ma's talk of an Olympic boycott was well hedged, and his margin of victory suggests that the public wasn't buying the DPP's claim that China's behavior in Tibet was significant for Taiwan. In substance, the two issues are very different, in part because of the economic value that Taiwan represents for Beijing (see Adam's most recent post). And if Chinese leaders wanted to improve their general image in the wake of their Tibetan crack-down, what better was to do it than to make some positive gestures towards Taiwan?

Nick Calathes’s triple-double — 11 points, 13 rebounds and 11 assists — led Florida to an 82-54 victory over Creighton in Gainesville, moving the Gators into next week’s quarterfinals of the National Invitation Tournament.Florida (23-11), the defending two-time national champions, used a 14-0 spurt midway through the first half to take a 29-12 lead on its way to a 39-19 halftime advantage.

Iowa won three semifinal matches in St. Louis and clinched its first N.C.A.A. wrestling title since 2000. The Hawkeyes’ exceptional depth piled up 102 points, ensuring the university’s 21st overall title with a day still left in the tournament. Ohio State (71) was a distant second, followed by Iowa State (68), Penn State (63), Central Michigan (61.5), Michigan (61), Nebraska and Oklahoma State (58), Cornell (57.5) and Minnesota (56.5).

Svetlana Kuznetsova ended Maria Sharapova’s winning streak at 18 matches Friday night with a 6-3, 5-7, 6-2 victory in the Pacific Life Open semifinals in Indian Wells, Calif.Sharapova’s perfect start to the season included titles in the Australian Open and at Doha.Kuznetsova, refusing to wilt after Sharapova won the second set, broke her service in the opening game of the third and went on to build a 5-1 lead. Kuznetsova will face No. 2 Ana Ivanovic in Sunday’s final. Ivanovic earned her spot with a 7-6 (3), 6-3 victory over Jelena Jankovic.On the men’s side, Mardy Fish, who had never made it beyond the fourth round at Indian Wells, added to his string of surprises in this year’s tournament with a 6-3, 6-7 (5), 7-6 (4) victory over David Nalbandian. The win over No. 7 Nalbandian put the 98th-ranked Fish into Saturday’s semifinals, where he will face No. 1 Roger Federer.

An article on March 10 about the reluctance of federal juries in New York State to impose the death penalty referred incorrectly to Mississippi’s record. The federal death penalty has not been imposed in any cases in Mississippi in the 20 years since the penalty was revived.

An exhibition review last Saturday about “John Milton at 400: A Life Beyond Life,” at the New York Public Library, misstated a line from “Paradise Lost” about the purpose of the work. It is “And justify the ways of God to men,” not “to justify the ways of God to man.” The review also misidentified the event in English history that Milton welcomed because of its promised transformation of English life and of which Oliver Cromwell was a leader. It was the rebellion, sometimes called the revolution, that overthrew Charles I and established a commonwealth; it was not the Reformation.

A report by Agence France-Presse in the “Arts, Briefly” column last Saturday about the authentication of a previously unidentified portrait of Mozart omitted the name of the Mozart expert who first realized the painting’s significance. He is Daniel N. Leeson.

An art review last Saturday about the International Asian Art Fair referred imprecisely to 583 Park Avenue, where the fair was held this year. Although the building’s owner, Third Church of Christ, Scientist, rents it regularly to organizers of events, Christian Science services are still held there; it is not a former church.

A Pop listing in Weekend on Friday about the Beatles parody band, the Rutles, referred incorrectly to the performers at the shows on Wednesday and Thursday at the Blender Theater at Gramercy in Manhattan. The performance, called “Rutlemania,” will be by the group the Fab Four; it will not be a reunion of the Rutles themselves.

A picture caption with an article on Sunday about the lack of adequate mosque facilities for Spain’s Muslim population misstated, in some copies, the day that the photograph of men in front of a garage converted for use as a mosque was taken. It was a Friday in December, not on Friday, March 14.

An article on Thursday about Idaho’s plan to teach chess to all second and third graders misstated the source of funding, based on information from state officials, for the program, which is estimated to cost $200,000 to $250,000 a year and as much as $600,000 the first year. The state’s education department will provide up to $60,000, then seek private financing for the rest. The department will not pay for the entire project.

The Second Opinion column in Science Times on Tuesday, about a young girl who received a successful experimental treatment for a brain tumor when she was a baby, misidentified the institution where the late Dr. Judah Folkman, whose work led to the girl’s treatment, spent his research career. An article last Saturday about the bicycle that investigators believe was ridden by the man who set off an explosion at the military recruiting station in Times Square, a blue Ross 10-speed, misstated the history of the Ross, a brand name that was purchased by Rand International after the original owner, Ross Bicycles Inc., went bankrupt. Rand continues to sell bicycles under the Ross name; the brand has not “faded from the bicycle market.”.

The State of the Art column in Business Day on Thursday, about a new class of inexpensive, easy-to-use camcorders, referred incorrectly to a model made by Thomson. It is the RCA Small Wonder EZ201, not EX201.

Tessa Virtue and Scott Moir of Canada got the silver medal, while Jana Khokhlova and Sergei Novitski of Russia won the bronze, edging Belbin and Agosto by 0.26 points. CBS has canceled the postapocalyptic drama “Jericho” for the second time in two years. Tuesday’s season finale will also be the series finale, the network said Friday. The series, which starred Skeet Ulrich and followed the events in a small Kansas town after nuclear attacks devastated cities across the United States, was first canceled in May 2007. A campaign by fans combined with data showing that the show was being recorded and watched outside its broadcast time persuaded CBS to order a short second season. But the show has performed poorly since the new episodes began appearing last month. The most recent episode attracted fewer than six million viewers and a 1.9 rating in the 18- to 49-year-old demographic. “Without question, there are passionate viewers watching this program; we simply wish there were more,” Nina Tassler, the president of CBS Entertainment, said in a statement. Carol Barbee, an executive producer of “Jericho,” said she was “pursuing other venues” for the series, giving credence to reports that a cable network could pick it up.

Bob Schieffer, right, the host of the CBS News Sunday morning program “Face the Nation” since 1982, has agreed to postpone his planned retirement. “Yes, I’m going to remain with the show after the inauguration,” Mr. Schieffer, 71, said Friday. He had said in January that he would step down early next year following the swearing-in of a new president. “I really had every intention of retiring then,” Mr. Schieffer said in a telephone interview. But he said that the president of CBS News, Sean McManus, had come to him a few weeks ago and asked him to put off his retirement. Mr. Schieffer, a 39-year veteran of CBS News, said there was no specific date set for his eventual departure: “We’re going to have a transition period, maybe try some people out.”.

The schedule for the fourth annual PEN World Voices Festival of International Literature was announced Thursday by Francine Prose, the PEN American Center’s president, and Caro Llewellyn, the festival director. Highlights of this year’s festival, from April 29 through May 4, are to include the Arthur Miller Freedom to Write Lecture, to be delivered by Umberto Eco; a conversation about efforts to end genocide in Darfur between the actress Mia Farrow and the French philosopher Bernard-Henri Levy; and a cabaret night. This year’s festival will include appearances by more than 100 authors and, for the first time, events in Albany, Rochester and Boston as well as New York. Among the authors scheduled to take part are Ian McEwan, Joyce Carol Oates, Mario Vargas Llosa and Salman Rushdie. The full schedule is available at pen.org.

A long legal dispute over the rights to the Beach Boys’ name has been settled. After a two-day conference in Superior Court in Los Angeles, two original members of the group, Al Jardine and Mike Love, reached an agreement over use of the name on Wednesday, The Associated Press reported. The Beach Boys were founded in 1961 by Carl, Dennis and Brian Wilson, above; Mr. Love, their cousin; and a friend, Mr. Jardine. Dennis Wilson died in 1983, and Carl Wilson died in 1998. Mr. Love had sued Mr. Jardine, claiming Mr. Jardine improperly used versions of the name while fronting his own band. A federal judge ruled in 2000 that Mr. Jardine was engaging in trademark infringement for touring under names including Beach Boys Family & Friends, and that Mr. Love, a co-founder and one of the original lead singers, was sole licensee of the name. A federal appeals court upheld that ruling in 2003. Mr. Love and Carl Wilson’s estate sued Mr. Jardine again in 2004 for $2.2 million in legal fees spent in the original litigation against him. It was that case, set for trial in April, that was settled this week. Details of the settlement were not disclosed, but lawyers suggested it could pave the way for a reunion of the band’s three surviving founders.

The death on Tuesday of the director Anthony Minghella has left the organizers of the 11th Shanghai International Film Festival without a jury chairman. The festival, scheduled for June 14-22, said on Friday it was seeking a new chairman, The Associated Press reported. Crystal Yu, the festival’s spokeswoman, also said it planned a retrospective of Mr. Minghella’s works.

NBC eked out a rare victory in Thursday’s ratings, attracting the most viewers for the night by the slimmest of margins, thanks largely to the strength of “Deal or No Deal.” According to Nielsen estimates, “Deal” drew 10.2 million viewers at 8 p.m., finishing second to ABC’s “Lost” (11.3 million) for the night’s largest audience. But that was enough to win the night, because ABC attracted only 6.3 million viewers to its new 8 p.m. comedy, “Miss Guided.” Up against “Lost” at 9 p.m., NBC’s “Celebrity Apprentice” earned a modest 8.6 million viewers. At 10, the network’s “Lipstick Jungle” (7.2 million) delivered its best ratings since its debut in February, but still trailed ABC’s “Eli Stone” (7.5 million). Despite the edge in total viewers, NBC finished third among adults 18 to 49 behind ABC and CBS, which led the night in that demographic with its coverage of the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament. Fox ranked fourth for the night.

Winners of the second annual YouTube Video Awards were announced on Friday, The Associated Press reported. The awards recognize the top user-created videos of 2007 on the popular Web site. Users voted on six nominees in each of 12 categories: music, sports, comedy, instructional, short film, inspirational, commentary, creative, politics, series, eyewitness and adorable. This year’s winners include Tay Zonday, 25, above, for his music video “Chocolate Rain,” which had been viewed 15,768,410 times as of Friday. A work by Neil Cicierega, featuring Harry Potter hand puppets, won the comedy category, while Guillaume Reymond’s “Human Tetris” took top honors in the creative category. All nominated videos can be viewed at youtube.com/ytawards07.

DEARIE--Christopher Farrell, of Old Westbury and Manhattan passed away on March 18 of natural causes. Christopher was born in Westfield, New Jersey on August 22, 1942 to John Paul Dearie and Anna Rose Farrell. 9 P.M. (Starz) THE HOAX (2007) Margaret B. Jones. James Frey. Misha Defonseca. They couldn't hold a candle to Clifford Irving, who in the early 1970s convinced much of the reading public that he had been appointed the official biographer of the notoriously reclusive Howard Hughes. In this darkly humorous drama from Lasse Hallstrom, Richard Gere (above) plays Mr. Irving as a striving writer and recovering philanderer whose big break has just vanished. So he invents one. ''The brilliance of Mr. Gere's performance -- one of his best since middle age liberated his wily charm from his leading-man looks -- is that he makes you believe in Irving without believing a word out of his mouth,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. 8 P.M. (Logo) THE LIFE AND TIMES OF ALLEN GINSBERG This updated and remastered 1994 documentary by Jerry Aronson chronicles 60 years of American culture, starting with the Beat era and Ginsberg, one of its founders. Bono, Paul McCartney, Johnny Depp, Yoko Ono, Beck, Hunter S. Thompson and Andy Warhol, among others, discuss Ginsberg's influence on the nation.

BLOW--Michael, of Greenwich, CT and Boca Raton, FL, died on March 19 of complications from Parkinson's Disease. Michael was born on May 10, 1930, in Chicago, IL, to George Waller Blow and Katherine Cooke Blow. He is survived by his wife, Diane; three children, Michael, Katharine (McGloon), and Richard; five step-children, four grandchildren, and ten stepgrandchildren. Also three brothers, George, Anthony, and John. A 1948 graduate of the Millbrook School in Millbrook, NY, and a 1952 graduate of Yale College, Michael served as a Lieutenant in the United States Air Force in Korea. He worked at Collier's Weekly, Newsweek, and American Heritage, than was for many years a book editor for Reader's Digest. Michael was the author of three books: The History of the Atomic Bomb, Men of Science and Invention, and A Ship to Remember: The Maine and the SpanishAmerican War, which was inspired by the fact that his grandfather, Lieutenant George Preston Blow, U.S.N., was a survivor of the Maine explosion which led to the start of that war. Michael was a member of the Society of the Cincinnati, the Society of Colonial Wars, the Yale Club of New York City, the Field Club of Greenwich, the Royal Palm Yacht and Country Club of Boca Raton, and the St. Andrews Club in Delray Beach. A memorial service will be held at 11:00am on Friday, May 2, 2008 at Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, CT. Donations in memory of Michael Blow may be sent to the Parkinson's Disease Foundation (www.pdf.org), Christ Church of Greenwich (254 E. Putnam Ave., Greenwich, CT), and Hospice of Palm Beach County (www.hpbc.org). Babione Funeral Home is in charge of services 561-395-8787.

SIMMONS--Grant G. Jr., Grant G. Simmons, Jr., 88, of TidePointe, Hilton Head, SC, and Upper Saranac Lake, NY, died Sunday, March 16, 2008, at his home. Mr. Simmons was born January 3, 1920, in Colorado Springs, CO. He graduated from Greenwich Country Day School, Deerfield Academy, and Yale University (1942). He served in World War II as a reserve officer in the Navy Fleet Air Wing Five in Argentina, Newfoundland, and Fleet Air Wing Sixteen in Recife, Brazil, achieving the Rank of Lieutenant with Merit Order Medal. He joined Simmons Company in 1946, and in 1957, he became Chief Executive Officer (1957-1978), a post he held for 21 years of growth in both total revenue and profits. He was the fourth generation of the Simmons family to lead the Company. During these years, Simmons Company made fourteen corporate acquisitions, all friendly. These became wholly owned subsidiaries and included Thonet Industries, Selig Manufacturing, Greeff Fabrics, Bloomcraft, Katzenbach and Warren, and three casket companies. During Simmons' stewardship, Simmons Company established manufacturing businesses in Canada, England, France, Italy, Australia, Mexico, Venezuela, Puerto Rico, Brazil, Argentina, Japan, and Morocco. For seventeen years (1962-1979), Simmons was a Director of the IBM World Trade Corporation and later the IBM Europe/ Middle East/Africa Corporation (1960-1984). Simmons was a Director of ACF Industries, Inc. from 1960-1984, and a Director of both the First National Holding Corporation and The First National Bank of Atlanta from 1974-1979. Active in Scouting, Simmons served as President of The Greater New York Council, largest in the U.S.A., from 1960-1963 and had the honor of presenting the Boy Scouts' highest commendation to John Glenn on the occasion of the New York City celebration of his successful first USA orbit of the earth. Simmons was awarded both the Boy Scouts Silver Beaver and Silver Antelope awards. A Whiffenpoof at Yale, Simmons pursued a lifelong attachment to music. He was a Director of the Metropolitan Opera Association from 1962-1975 and its Vice-President from 1969-1974, and a Director of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts from 1968-1976. Simmons was a Director of the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra from 1974-1980, a Director of the Atlanta Arts Alliance from 1975-1981 and a Director of the High Museum of Art in Atlanta from 1975-1981. An ardent bird watcher all his life, Simmons became a life member of the American Ornithologists Union in 1948 and the same year, a life member of the National Audubon Society, which he served as a Director from 1968-1974. Simmons was a member of the New York Chapter of The Society of Mayflower Descendants and The Denison Society and was, for many years, a member of The Brook Club. Simmons is survived by his daughters, Allison Prouty and Leslie Lee, his son, Grant G. Simmons III, three grandchildren and one stepgrandchild, and by a stepson, Henry Darlington III, two stepdaughters, Elizabeth ''Beth'' Darlington and Victoria Darlington Yoder, and four additional step-grandchildren. A memorial service will be at All Saints Episcopal Church, Hilton Head, South Carolina on April 12th at 11:30am. In his memory, in lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Cape May Bird Observatory, 600 Route 47 North, Cape May Court House, NJ 08210.

Some years ago when a high ranking official of the Nation of Islam was being interviewed on TV, he was challenged to denounce another prominent member of the Nation who had called Jews "bagel-eating vermin who had escaped from the caves of Europe to pollute the world." He did not elaborate further, but I understood him to be saying, It is not my job either to defend or repudiate every statement made by someone I know. Jeffrey Lewis was raised in New York City and is a maker of comic books, tragi-comic folk narratives, and lysergic garage rock. The Jeffrey Lewis Band, with his brother Jack on bass and David Beauchamp on drums, mixes 1960s acoustic psychedelia and experimental art-punk. Jeffrey uses his own illustrations to accompany some of his live songs and stories, like his ongoing "Complete History of Communism." Since signing with Rough Trade Records in 2001, he has released four albums, including "Jeffrey & Jack Lewis: City & Eastern Songs," which was selected as one of 2006's best albums in Time Out New York,The Boston Globe, CMJ Monthly and elsewhere. His most recent album is "Jeffrey Lewis: 12 Crass Songs," a reworking of songs written by the legendary anarchist punk band Crass, and his most recent comic book series, Fuff, is currently up to issue No. 7. His Web site is thejeffreylewissite.com.

The Yankees had an interesting minor league game at Legends Field on Sunday morning. Mike Mussina, who will earn $11 million this year, started for Class AA Trenton team, while Kei Igawa, who will earn $4 million, started for Class AAA Scranton-Wilkes Barre. It was probably the most high-priced pitching showdown in minor league history. There were only a few fans in attendance when the game started at 10 a.m. Mussina playfully said that Manager Joe Girardi did not tell him the first pitch was at 10 until after Mussina agreed to face the minor leaguers. But the early hour did not prevent Mussina and Igawa from dominating the younger hitters. Mussina gave up one run and three hits in seven innings while Igawa struckout eight in four scoreless innings. "It wasn't bad," Mussina said. "Ten o'clock in the morning. Full house." When the spring started, Mussina was one of six starters competing for a spot in the five-man rotation. Mussina, who has 251 victories, said that he did not deserve a spot if he did not earn it. But Mussina has earned it with a solid spring and will probably be the No. 3 starter. "I've been pleased because I've been able to throw breaking balls for strikes and pitch the way I would in May or June," Mussina said.

Shaun White won his third consecutive halfpipe title at the United States Open Snowboarding Championships in Stratton, Vt., executing a series of near-flawless runs. White beat out Kevin Pearce and Mason Aguirre. Torah Bright took top honors in the women’s division, besting the three-time champion Kelly Clark.

Scott Wimmer passed his Richard Childress Racing teammate Clint Bowyer with 21 laps to go and held on to win the Nascar Nationwide Series Pepsi 300 at Nashville Superspeedway. Bowyer took the series points lead from Kevin Harvick, who skipped the race.

Lindsey Vonn, the overall women’s World Cup champion, and Jimmy Cochran won slalom titles at the United States Alpine Championships at Sugarloaf in Carrabassett Valley, Me., in a competition delayed by rain, snow and wind.Vonn led both runs to win the event in a combined 1 minute 26.31 seconds. Hailey Duke was second in 1:28.21, and Jenny Lathrop finished third in 1:28.42.Cochran successfully defended his title with a combined time of 1:26.69, with Cody Marshall (1:27.90) second and Tim Jitloff (1:28.16) third.The day started with the announcement that Sasha Rearick would serve as the men’s Alpine coach, replacing Phil McNichol, who announced his retirement last week.
Troy Ruths scored 33 points and Washington of Missouri claimed its first N.C.A.A. Division III title with a 90-68 victory over Amherst, the defending champion, in Salem, Va.

Fabian Cancellara won the Milan-San Remo one-day classic after breaking away late from a group of riders.Cancellara, from Switzerland, made his move 1.5 miles from the end of the 185-mile race, finishing in 7 hours 14 minutes 35 seconds.A fast pace hurt the sprinters Alessandro Petacchi and Oscar Freire, whose teams had worked to keep the group together in an effort to have the race end in a sprint finish.

Sasha Rearick is the new men’s Alpine coach of the United States Ski Team, replacing Phil McNichol. Rearick was the men’s slalom and giant slalom head coach. His promotion was announced at the United States Alpine Championships at Sugarloaf in Carrabassett Valley, Me.

The opening night at the Australian swimming championships and Olympic trials in Sydney produced two world records. Stephanie Rice broke the world mark in the 400-meter individual medley, finishing in 4 minutes 31.46 seconds. Emily Seebohm broke the world record in the non-Olympic 50-meter backstroke. Seebohm finished in 27.95 seconds.

Alex Ovechkin became the first player in 12 years to score 60 goals in a season, but his focus Friday night was on the Washington Capitals’ victory that left them a point out of the final Eastern Conference playoff spot going into Saturday night’s game.“I just do my job; I don’t think about personal goals,” Ovechkin said after reaching the 60-goal mark with a pair in the Capitals’ 5-3 victory against the host Atlanta Thrashers.No one in the N.H.L. had hit the 60-goal mark since the 1995-96 season, when Pittsburgh’s Mario Lemieux and Jaromir Jagr both did it. Ovechkin’s previous best was 52 goals in his rookie season, 2005-6.

Hours after complaining of fatigue following her first loss of the year Friday, the Australian Open champion Maria Sharapova told officials at this week’s tournament in Miami that she was withdrawing. The $3.77 million tournament is considered a mandatory event by the WTA, meaning Sharapova could face punishment for skipping the tournament, which starts Monday. Tournament officials told The Miami Herald of Sharapova’s decision, which came after a semifinal loss to Svetlana Kuznetsova in Indian Wells, Calif., that ended her 18-match winning streak.

The “Your Home” column on March 2, about income-tax breaks for co-op and condominium owners, referred incompletely to the circumstances under which payments used for buildingwide capital improvements can be added to the tax basis of an apartment. In co-ops, such payments may be added to the tax basis only when they have actually been made by the shareholder to the co-op. In condos, an owner may increase the unit’s tax basis by its proportionate share of the cost of an improvement when the money is spent by the condo, even if the owner has not yet made any payments to the condo.

The “In the Region” article in New Jersey copies on March 9 about residential development in Union City misstated the distance between the Lincoln Tunnel and the Thread Building, a former embroidery factory that is now a condominium. It is about a half mile, not 380 feet.

The Mortgage column on March 2, about credit-repair services, referred incorrectly to the average credit score of 692. That is the average score of consumers evaluated by Experian — not the average for other credit bureaus or the Fair Isaac Corporation.

Because of an editing error, a listing on the “On the Market” page last Sunday about a duplex condominium for sale on Dean Street in Brooklyn misstated the cost of parking in the building. It is $295 a month; it is not free.

To the Editor: Regarding “Slum Visits: Tourism or Voyeurism” (March 9): As a parent of Indian descent who volunteers time and money to charitable organizations working in poor areas around the world, I read this piece with much interest. Jennifer McSweeney The Penny McCall Foundation was established in 1987 by McCall and her husband, David, to support contemporary artists, writers and curators. When the couple died suddenly in 1999 in a car accident while volunteering in Kosovo, Penny's only child, Jennifer McSweeney, stepped in to take over her mother's tremendous philanthropic ventures. McSweeney, who previously worked as a professional chef, has become a keen and innovative talent in the art world, known for her outside-the-white-box thinking. Under the foundation's new designation, Creative Link for the Arts, McSweeney not only oversees the prestigious Ordway Award, which presents two $100,000 prizes (to a midcareer artist and a curator or arts writer) but also is devising new and unexpected ways to utilize donors, patrons and institutions in supporting the arts. Creative Link helped Art Production Fund bring Tim Noble and Sue Webster's ''Electric Fountain'' to Rockefeller Center this spring and will contribute to the catalog for Public Art Fund's New York City Waterfalls by Olafur Eliasson. (''There is not enough support for the documentation of these ephemeral installations,'' McSweeney says.) Such ''partnership philanthropy'' is only the beginning. ''All giving is good,'' she says. ''But if you can generate relationships that are more inspired and personal, it will only encourage everyone to keep giving in the future.'' Anne Pasternak ''I didn't want to be an assistant to any one artist,'' Anne Pasternak says. ''I wanted to help multiple artists realize their dreams.'' And in fact, some of the city's most obtrusive, skyline-altering artworks owe their existence to Pasternak and the arts organization Creative Time, where she has been president and artistic director since 1994. In those 14 years, Pasternak has helped artists take over city buses, the Anchorage under the Brooklyn Bridge, the Cyclone in Coney Island and, on multiple occasions, even the skies above Manhattan: in 2001 Vik Muniz ''drew'' clouds using a crop-dusting plane; in 2003 Cai Guo-Qiang put on a fireworks show in Central Park; and on election eve 2004, planes flew banners of political truisms by the artist Jenny Holzer. ''I'm not upset when art provokes people,'' Pasternak insists. ''My interest has always been to give artists a platform to ignite the imagination.'' In 2002, Creative Time collaborated with multiple artists on ''Tribute in Light'' -- two towers of light standing in for the fallen World Trade Center buildings. Having just helped Paul Chan stage ''Waiting for Godot in New Orleans'' in the city's lower ninth ward, the Creative Time team is initiating a number of summer projects, among them David Byrne's transformation of a landmark New York building into one gigantic musical instrument that the public will be able to play.

THE artist David Ellis isn't much for art. Having spent his youth banging on a Roland 808 drum machine, he admits that music, though not his forte, is more his thing. ''Art is so institutionalized, it can make people feel not invited,'' he said. ''Music has movement. It can cross borders.'' To give his work a similar kinetic quality, Mr. Ellis, above, photographs the progression of his paintings (at right), creating a time-lapse animation that is then set to sound. ''It's my attempt to move the art through time,'' he said of his ''motion paintings,'' which have been shown at the Museum of Modern Art.

The ''Your Home'' column on March 2, about income-tax breaks for co-op and condominium owners, referred incompletely to the circumstances under which payments used for buildingwide capital improvements can be added to the tax basis of an apartment. In co-ops, such payments may be added to the tax basis only when they have actually been made by the shareholder to the co-op. In condos, an owner may increase the unit's tax basis by its proportionate share of the cost of an improvement when the money is spent by the condo, even if the owner has not yet made any payments to the condo.

Pennsylvania residents are registering in anticipated record numbers in advance of Monday's deadline to vote in the April 22 primary. Democratic enrollment is up by more than 110,000 since last year's election, an increase of roughly 3 percent, state election officials said. It is likely to surpass the record of 4 million by Monday. Republicans lost about 14,000 voters in the same period.

FAHY--Eugene F. 77, on March 15, 2008 in New York City. Gene began his advertising career in 1953 with the Robert B. Grady Agency and held executive positions with Donahue and Coe, Erwin Wasey, Bancroft, Grey Advertising and Fairchild Publications. He was Vice President/Advertising Director of Women's Wear Daily and W. He was also publisher of M Magazine. He was instrumental in the creation of W and M Magazine and was credited with the early success of both publications. Gene was a true ''Madison Ave Ad Man'', he advocated hiring women for executive positions when advertising was still very much a male dominated industry. Gene was a mentor to many with whom he shared his advertising experience and knowledge. He sang tenor and had a quick Irish wit. In music he always said: Big Band was his life and he knew every lyric. Gene leaves his wife Lauren; daughters Margery, Laura, Annie, Deirdre, and her husband Tom Washburn; grandchildren Walker and Charlotte; brother Neal and sister Patricia Frakes. A Celebration of Life Mass will be held at Holy Trinity Church, 213 West 82nd St., on Friday March 28, 2008 at 1pm. Friends are invited to visit the Church at 12pm, prior to the Mass. In memory of Gene please give a flower or do a good deed for a friend. Gene gladly followed his friends Reba and Magnolia to their new existence.

My brother-in-law Peter lives in Boulder, Colorado. Whenever I use the bathroom in his house, I heave a bucket of used bath water down the toilet to flush it. This provides a welcome opportunity to enhance my deltoids, and it can save approximately 7,300 gallons of fresh water per year. Peter usually bikes, but occasionally he'll drive his hybrid Honda from where it's parked next to his xeriscaped yard to the Buddhist meditation classes he teaches downtown. He is, in short, the quintessential Boulderite. This town practically perspires virtue. Last April, Boulder became the first city in the country to impose an additional tax on residents who use electricity made from coal (households and businesses that opt to buy power from alternative sources are exempt). About a third of the total waste stream here is recycled. The city-run North Boulder Recreation Center has one of the largest solar hydronic systems in the country. The Boulder Outlook Hotel boasts about its ''zero-waste'' policy. Pizza delivery boys drive Priuses. The city is ringed by 43,000 acres of protected open space -- that's nearly three times the landmass of Manhattan -- and laced with 300 miles of greenways, trout-filled creeks and designated bike lanes.
Art Nicolai Ouroussoff

Had two children -Aaron and the late Judith Fertig, seven grandchildren, four greatgrandchildren. A philanthropist and truly religious -my Daddy always ''accomplished the mission''. You were our hero, Aaron and Nicole

When I tell people that I'm from Racine, Wis., I tend to get two responses: either ''Cheese heads!'' or ''Mars' Cheese Castle!'' The store just off Interstate 94 (technically in Kenosha) has always been popular with tourists craving cheese curds and waxy, cow-shaped cheddars. But a lot has happened to the cheese heads since I last visited 10 years ago. Wisconsin has joined the United States of Arugula, and its cheese producers, until recently outclassed by the offerings emerging from Vermont and California, have learned the magic word artisanal. Now more than 60 of the state's 114 plants (there were 2,800 in 1925) are manufacturing at least one handmade or small-batch cheese. The state took home a third of the gold medals at the 2006 World Championship Cheese Contest. There's even a blog, Cheese Underground, to follow award sweeps and other local news. Wisconsin's cheese renaissance reached a new high in September, when a former Lands' End merchandise manager opened a shop called Fromagination in Madison, dedicated to showcasing the cheeses of the world (and the state). On its second weekend in business, the place was a hive of boho-foodies browsing and grabbing toasts topped with braised boar, chestnuts and local sheep's milk cheese from a passing tray. The counter at the back of the shop was serving wine and craft-beer pairings; among the accouterments up front were DVDs of the documentary ''Living on the Wedge: Wisconsin's Artisan Cheesemakers (the Uncut Version).''
