BEFORE voting Tuesday to ban the sale and possession of the hallucinogenic drug Salvia divinorum, Lynne C. Nowick, a Suffolk County legislator, showed her colleagues two videos posted on YouTube. In the first, a teenager waves his left arm while seated and staring blankly as someone else laughs. A voice in the background attributes the boy's actions to Salvia. In the second video, a teenager appearing to be in a daze after smoking Salvia is encouraged to sit down. He does, and minutes later crawls along the floor on all fours.

NEUMARK--Zoltan. Born in Hungary on October 13, 1914 and died in New York on February 13, 2008. Zoltan came to the U.S. in 1928 with his family settling in Akron, OH. He obtained his BA at Akron University. He served four years overseas in WWII. After the War he returned to Akron, later came to New York where he studied law, joining the School of Law at the New York University, obtaining his law degree in 1948. Additionally passed the Ohio bar in 1952. He was admitted to the Supreme Court in April 1964. He opened his law office in 1950 where he practiced law until 1997 when he had to retire due to illness. Zoltan loved the law and the challenges of the trial work. In 1958 Zoltan joined the first Hungarian Literary Society which very quickly became his second home. He was elected twice its President for an 8 year period. Zoltan's passion was classic books in both English and Hungarian which he read daily. He became a very cultured man with many other interests. For 25 years he also enjoyed the pleasure of his house in East Hampton with his beloved wife, Janine. Zoltan was a great human being and will be missed forever by his loving wife of 55 years and by all those who knew him. May he rest in peace.

GABETTI--Bettina. The Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art mourn the loss of Bettina Gabetti. Bettina, of New York and Geneva, was a cherished friend of the Museum since the 1960s. She was a beloved member of the International Council since 1990, and also served on the Museum's Architecture and Design Committee and House Committee. Her husband Gianluigi has been a Trustee of the Museum since 1970. Bettina's keen eye and wit will be sorely missed. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to Gianluigi, to her children Cristina, Alessandro, and Ann and to her adored grandchildren. David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman Ronald S. Lauder, Honorary Chairman Robert B. Menschel, Chairman Emeritus Agnes Gund, President Emerita Donald B. Marron, President Emeritus Jerry I. Speyer, Chairman Agnes Gund, President Emerita Marie-Josee Kravis, President Glenn D. Lowry, Director The Museum of Modern Art Brian Urquhart, Chairman Emeritus Agnes Gund, Chairman Jo Carole Lauder, President The International Council of The Museum of Modern Art GABETTI--Bettina. With great sadness Gianluigi Gabetti, his children Cristina and Alessandro, the ''small ones'', Ann Tuteur and her daughter Ottavia announce the loss of Bettina, beloved wife, mother and grandmother, who died in Milan, Italy on March 14th. A New Yorker at heart, Bettina expressed her talent as a jewelry designer and was proud to be a member of the Architecture and Design Committee and the International Council at the Museum of Modern Art. Her spirit, glamour, taste, wit, loyalty and strength will live on in the people who love her. A memorial service will be scheduled in the following months in East Hampton, NY, the place she loved most. Contributions may be made to The Doula Program, JBFCS, 120 West 57th Street, New York, NY 10019 or Nature Conservancy, South Fork, PO Box 5215, East Hampton, NY 11937.

Against the deadpan sameness of downtown Anchorage, a marquee featuring an Eiffel Tower and the words ''Club Paris'' in cursive neon juts out from a nondescript storefront. Anchorage is an oil boomtown that was built on the remnants of a gold and fur boomtown that was largely wiped out by an earthquake in 1964. Club Paris is that rare elderly building that survived. (Large portions of a J. C. Penney landed around it, but failed to destroy it.) I wandered over to it on a late winter morning in opalescent darkness and fog, passing trees covered in a ghostly dusting of hoarfrost and two moose -- a mama and her calf -- loitering in front of City Hall.

deCOURCY--Virginia Risley A noted benefactor of New York and New England institutions, died after a long illness on March 13 in Washington, CT. She was 88. Gina Risley, as she was known, served as the board chairman of The Forman School in Litchfield, CT and The Gunnery in Washington, CT, and was a generous donor to the Metropolitan Opera, American Ballet Theater, Metropolitan Museum of Art, the American Museum of Natural History, the Harbor Branch Oceanographic Institute, Dartmouth College, Hamilton College, and numerous secondary schools. Her other favorite causes included conservation and preservation (Grafton Pond in New Hampshire and other wild places in the Connecticut River watershed, Colonial Williamsburg, Sturbridge Village and Historic Deerfield) and worldwide tolerance and understanding through Seeds of Peace. She was born in New York City, April 4, 1919 to Dr. John and Katharine Solley. She spent her childhood in Washington, CT and Europe. She was an alumna of Smith College and Katharine Gibbs. She was predeceased by Malcolm de Sieyes, her husband of 25 years and William Risley, her husband of 27 years. She is survived by her husband, Robert deCourcy of Washington, CT, her two sons, Charles Joseph de Sieyes M.D., of Falmouth, ME, and David Conroy de Sieyes, of Hamilton, MA, and their wives and four grandchildren. She is also survived by her step daughter, Mary Risley, of San Francisco, CA, and four stepsons John Risley of Northampton, MA, Alan deCourcy of Oxford, OH, John deCourcy, of Santa Rosa, CA, and David deCourcy of Seattle, WA. She was predeceased by one stepson, William Risley. Memorial donations may be sent to Smith College, The Forman School Scholarship Fund, ASAP (After School Arts Program Summer Scholarship Fund, PO Box 15, Washington Depot, CT 06794), Society for Protection of New Hampshire Forests, or Seeds of Peace. A memorial service will be held Saturday, April 26, 2008, at 11am, at First Congregational Church of Washington, Connecticut.

For a few years now, Type A travelers have been racing off to polo matches in Mongolia and Norwegian salmon-fishing expeditions with waiting lists that can last a lifetime. But lately the idea of the trophy trip has reached a peak, as the travel industry keeps offering rarer and more meaningful ways to connect to the world. When it opens later this year, for example, the Palazzo Tournabuoni in Florence, Italy, a destination club managed by Four Seasons, will let members not only sleep in a 15th-century palace but also gain access to bespoke perfume consultations and hard-hat tours

Last fall, just days after the inauguration of the tram system in Seville, Spain, one of the cars derailed on Avenida de la Constitución, the city's busiest street. No one was injured -- the local horse-drawn carriages seem to move at a faster clip -- and the mayor rode it the next day to reassure his citizens that the tram was safe. Still, not too many people were riding it recently. Sevillanos seem to raise a suspicious brow at ''progress,'' as this is a city that has always been tethered to its colorful and religious past: bullfighting, flamenco and Semana Santa, the holy week between Palm Sunday and Easter, when the streets are crowded with velvet-draped processions. Besides, most locals would rather walk through the historic center (cars were banned in most of the district in 2006), stopping to chat with friends, down a quick sherry at a bar or bless themselves in front of the Virgin Mother. There is a shrine, a statue or a plaque honoring her on nearly every cobblestone block.
Classical Daniel J. Wakin

HAGEN--Elizabeth P., of New York, passed away at Lenox Hill Hospital on Thursday, February 7, 2008. She was 92. Born December 2, 1915, in Centreville, MD, she was the daughter of the late Charles Hagen and Katherine Hagen. Her early years were spent in Centreville. She graduated from Centreville High School and went to Western Maryland College to receive her bachelor's degree. After graduating from Western Maryland College, she served four years in the U.S. Navy and was a lieutenant at the time of her separation. Ms. Hagen then went on to graduate from Columbia University, where she received her master's and Ph.D. in psychology. She began her professional career as a high school science teacher. In 1950, Ms. Hagen became a research associate and lecturer in the Department of Psychology at Teachers College, Columbia University. From 1972 to 1976, she served as Dean of Academic Affairs at Teachers College. In 1978, Ms. Hagen was named the Edward Lee Thorndike Professor of Psychology and Education, a ranking she held as a professor emeritus. In 1960, the American Personnel and Guidance Association presented her with the Outstanding Research Award for her work as project coordinator and coauthor of the project findings of ''The Ten Thousand Careers Study.'' In 1970, Ms. Hagen was elected a fellow of the American Psychological Association. She was also elected to the National Academy of Education in 1979. Ms. Hagen retired from teaching in 1981 and afterwards was the coauthor of ''The Stanford-Binet Intelligence Scale: Fourth Edition'' and a coauthor of Forms 4, 5, and 6 of the Cognitive Abilities Test. She was preceded in death by three brothers, James Hagen, Charles Hagen, and John Hagen; and a sister, Minnie Dawkins. She is survived by her nephew, James Hagen and his wife Melanie of Hartly, DE; and three nieces Elizabeth Bages and her husband Brian of Dover, DE, Grace Donophan and her husband Clarence of Wyoming, DE, and Ann Schuman of Northfield, NJ. Services where by Fellows, Helfenbein and Newnam Funeral Home, Chester, MD.

Las Pozas seems like a myth, a kind of rain-forest mirage. The Surrealist sculpture garden was built more than four decades ago by the eccentric English artist Edward James 2,000 feet into the mountains of the Mexican jungle. It encompasses more than 80 acres of natural waterfalls and pools interlaced with towering Surrealist sculptures in concrete, including ''Bamboo Palace,'' a three-story structure with walls that look like shoots of bamboo; ''Stairway to the Sky,'' a Piranesi-like staircase that soars up several stories and ends in thin air; and ''Homage to Max Ernst,'' an outdoor aviary that is a forest of concrete columns. Las Pozas is near the village of Xilitla, a four-hour drive southwest of the nearest sizable airport, in Tampico, and seven hours north of Mexico City. Despite its remoteness (or, perhaps, because of it), the garden has long had a certain cult devotion. But since its sale last year, 23 years after James's death, to a consortium that includes two of Mexico's most prominent billionaires, Las Pozas has suddenly attracted fresh attention from preservationists and art-world luminaries intent on saving one of the world's most curious creations. The man who conceived this marvel had a curious life himself. James grew up on West Dean Estate, his family's 6,000-acre property in West Sussex, England. Having little interest in traditional English country life, he threw himself into the worlds of art and literature, writing volumes of poetry, publishing the work of Sir John Betjeman and collecting paintings from Dalí, Magritte and Picasso.

GREENBERG--Michael H. After a long and valiant battle, passed away peacefully on March 10, 2008. He will be greatly missed, and leaves behind his loving and devoted wife, Eulalia, sons, Peter and Edward, daughter-in-law, Carolina, and grandchildren, Lauren, Nicolette, Jordan and Emily. He also leaves behind one brother, David, and sister-in-law, Carol. Michael graduated with honors from Cornell School of Industrial and Labor Relations in 1955, and later on from Harvard Law School in 1958, where he was the Editor of the Law Review. He won a fellowship to Europe to travel. There, while studying International Comparative Law in Luxembourg, he met his wife, Eulalia, a lawyer from Barcelona, Spain. The following year, his wife came as a Fullbright student to New York University Comparative Law Institute. There they were married. Michael clerked in the Southern District of New York for the Honorable Judge Charles Metzner before having a long and illustrious career as an attorney and arbitrator. He was currently working as a solo practitioner, where among other endeavors, he was of counsel to his sons' athlete representation firm, Peter E. Greenberg & Associates. He was on the Board of Directors of the Spain-US Chamber of Commerce. He was very active in many community and legal institutions. A memorial service will be held on April 5th at 11:00am at the All Souls Church on Lexington Ave and E. 80th St. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Visiting Nurse Services. For additional information, please call Star of David Memorial Chapels at (631) 454-9600.

THE NEWS The Dalai Lama accused China of waging ''cultural genocide'' against his followers in Tibet and called for an international inquiry into the suppression of protests there. BEHIND THE NEWS The Dalai Lama, spiritual leader of Tibetan Buddhism and head of Tibet's government in exile, was reacting to China's crackdown on protests by ethnic Tibetans in Lhasa, Tibet's capital, and in nearby Chinese provinces. The protests were the most serious and prolonged since the late 1980s, when China violently suppressed demonstrations there, and presented a major test to the ruling Communist Party as it prepares to play host to the Olympic Games in August.

Before Borat made benefit glorious nation of Kazakhstan, the former Soviet republic had begun attracting plenty of international attention on its own. Bordering Russia and China, Kazakhstan sits on vast reserves of oil and natural gas and in the next decade could be among the world's Top 5 oil-exporting countries. Which has supplied the president, Nursultan Nazarbayev, who came to power in 1989 and whose term limit was waived last year by a parliamentary vote, with plenty of mad money. In 1997, Nazarbayev relocated the capital from Almaty (near the Kyrgyzstan border) to what is now Astana, and has since spent billions creating one of the world's strangest spectacles: an entirely new city, built almost from scratch over 96 square miles, in the center of the Eurasian steppe.

Every traveler has a landscape that, for him, contains the wonder and mystery behind all travel. It could be the beach, or a cathedral square, or the rain forest, or a volcanic island -- for me, it is the mountain pass. The mountain pass, roughly defined, is that point on the map where the winding road up is transformed into the winding road down. It marks the border where valleys meet, and often is where provinces divide, where one nation becomes another, with a corresponding change in language and road signs. To get to the mountain pass, you begin on a fertile plain, often crossed by a river, and drive through terraced fields and sleepy villages until the road gets steeper, the switchbacks get scarier and signs of human settlement fall away behind you. If you are in Tyrol -- the proud region straddling northern Italy and western Austria -- and you ascend through the Val Passiria to the mountain pass known in German as the Timmelsjoch, small vineyards and neatly tended orchards give way to a desolate moonscape fringed with ice, and the tractors from the lower altitudes, carrying bins of apples, are replaced by swarms of motorcycles. (You will later see the same bikers that passed you like movie villains in black leather warming up over plates of sausages and fries at the restaurant just beyond the pass, crowded into booths and chatting amiably with one another.)

his planet, himself Not Vital (pronounced ''Note Vit-AL'') lives and works in New York City; Lucca, Italy; Sent, Switzerland; and Agadez, Niger. Vital's search for home informs his art -- symbolically and literally. ''A home is almost like a sculpture you can go inside,'' he says. He's building a place in Patagonia, Chile, and is searching for a studio in Beijing. ''I love to travel. I need to go in order to function.'' Not surprisingly, a modern-day nomad thrives on his connections. He cites a special bond to the Wodaabe people, nomadic pastoralists native to Niger. ''If you want to give them a present, you give them a mirror,'' he jokes, ''because they really know how to put makeup on in the morning.'' In Niger, it's not unusual for a spontaneous slumber party to occur chez Vital. ''Sometimes I would wake up and there's, like, 50 people sleeping in the courtyard.'' He recently had the artist Richard Long for a visit in Africa, and the architect Norman Foster has been a frequent guest. After reading that Gore Vidal is of Swiss origin and that his ancestors spoke Vital's mother tongue of Romansch (one of Switzerland's national languages), Vital tracked him down; now, ''I call him Cousin Gore.''

What New York was in the 80s, Berlin is now,'' says Nadja Vancauwenberghe, the French editor in chief of Berlin's English-language magazine, the Exberliner. ''That's the cliché.'' She shakes her head and smiles. ''The reality,'' Maurice Frank, the Exberliner's publisher, chimes in, ''is that rents here are a third of what they are in Paris or London.'' The two of them are trying to explain why Berlin has emerged as the creative capital of Europe, if not the world. ''It's cool, its cheap, it's international,'' Vancauwenberghe says, ticking off the contributing factors.

there is nothing particularly Taiwanese about the Astoria Café. That's what made it special when Archibald Chien opened the place over a half century ago, on the west side of Taipei, the old downtown. The bakery sold fresh bread and homemade cakes downstairs. Upstairs, Chien served dark, bitter coffee, Italian style. Well, not really Italian. ''French,'' he told me. ''Swiss,'' he said, picking up a plate of perfect little cakes. Then he laughed. The coffee, the pastries and the cakes -- actually, all Russian. ''But we could not call anything Russian.'' Just about everything gets political in Taipei. Even dessert. History in Taiwan's capital has unfolded like a foreign-affairs soap opera. In the 1500s, mainland Chinese, mostly from Fujian Province, began to move here to farm. But the newcomers clashed with the locals, dozens of tribes with their own languages and cultures. Then, in the 17th century, the Dutch moved in. Then a Chinese faction, hostile to the new Qing dynasty that ruled the mainland, threw them out. Then the Qing army conquered the Chinese in Taiwan and put the island up for sale. When they couldn't find a buyer, they kept it until 1895, when Japan seized the land -- and things got really complicated.

BY DESIGN Some people are suggesting, only a little facetiously, that housing developments may need to be razed to clear the way for more farmland. That sounds crazy, but it really shouldn't come as much of a surprise: for decades, we've systematically razed nearly every patch of land we've been able to in an effort to create more room for industry, technology and people, without really paying attention to what's being lost in the process. With scores of homes being abandoned because of the current mortgage debacle, some innovative rethinking is going to have to happen around overbuilt subdivisions, master-planned communities and urban high rises.

My first visit to a favela was in Rio ... 2003. It opened my eyes to what real poverty is. Also, it showed me how resourceful the people could be. It had a profound impact on me and the way I view the world. I don't believe it's exploitive, because the people there need a way of telling their story in order for change to occur. I found the people to be welcoming, and having the same basic needs as I do. These tours should be responsible and contribute to the betterment of the community. Arthur Fuller Washington

ISN'T there any other color but green? Yes, it's a nice color -- and welcome now that spring has at least officially arrived. But given how green has come to stand for everything noble and self-sacrificing, a reminder that everything we do (like breathe) is hastening the destruction of the planet ... well, who knew that when Maggie Smith in ''Gosford Park'' coolly scoffed at a woman's dress (''Difficult color, that green. Very tricky.''), she was voicing the understatement of the 21st century?

DUFFY--Mark Joseph, on March 18, 2008 in Washington D.C. Cherished life partner of Adrianne Goodman. Devoted son of Marguerite A. Duffy of Pelham Manor, NY. Learned, loving and bighearted, Mark burned with a fierce intelligence and seized life with joy, passion and a ribald sense of humor. He attended Syracuse University, and held Bachelor and Masters degrees from New York University. He enjoyed a long and varied career in theater, film and music production in New York, Los Angeles, and Washington D.C. His fine mind and free spirit will be missed more profoundly than words can convey. His motto, from Dr. Samuel Johnson, was: ''He has learned to no purpose who cannot teach.'' He fought a valiant battle, but passed in peace, surrounded by love. Visitation Tuesday, 24pm and 7-9pm at Pelham Funeral Home, 64 Lincoln Ave., Pelham, NY. Funeral Mass on Wednesday, 10am, at Our Lady of Perpetual Help, 559 Pelham Manor Road, Pelham, NY.

Nothing symbolizes the recent transformation of Belfast, the capital of Northern Ireland, better than the Merchant Hotel (35-39 Waring Street; 011-44-28-9023-4888; themerchanthotel.com; doubles from about $430). Besides one-upping the old Europa -- once ''Europe's most bombed hotel'' -- the Merchant sells the world's most expensive cocktail, a mai tai made with hand-cut Fijian ice and rare Wray & Nephew rum, for £750. These days, peace and prosperity are in full swing. And the most danger you're likely to face is major credit card damage. ''If you had told me 20 years ago all this would happen,'' says Billy Scott, a black-cab tour guide, ''I would have taken you away in a white coat.'' The city is capitalizing on its good fortune with a series of municipal projects, including the Titanic Quarter waterfront development; the Victoria Square retail complex, which opened earlier this month; and the Metropolitan Arts Center, the cultural anchor of Cathedral Quarter, set for 2011. Cathedral continues its reign as Belfast's arts district, playing host to the city's liveliest festival, in May (cqaf.com), and cultivating some of its most original night life, like the Kremlin (96 Donegall Street), a gay bar where drag queens like Glitzy Glamour regularly hold court.
East Side Restaurant 131 Dwight Street

KAIL--Miriam (nee Hoffman), died March 19th, peacefully in her sleep after a brief illness at age 92. She graduated from Brooklyn Law School in 1939 and practiced law until 2 years ago under her professional name Miriam H. Kamen. She leaves a life where family meant everything to her and she meant everything to them. One of eight children, she leaves her devoted and loving surviving sister Roslyn Dash (of New York), four adoring nieces, Julie Ottaiano, Leslie Levi, Shiela Vincent and Rebecca Schenker, and five great-nieces and great-nephews, Marco, Christina, Lara, Athena, and Liam. Her first marriage to Dr. Max Kamen ended in divorce and she later married Milton Kail, an attorney, who predeceased her. Her sisters and brothers, who also predeceased her, were Professor Samuel Hoffman, Serena Bloomberg, Helen Lohr, Francis Mulhearn, Paul Hoffman and Milton Hoffman. In her long and successful law career she served as the treasurer of the Brooklyn Law School Alumni Association where she will be fondly remembered for many Alumni Luncheons at the Plaza that she chaired and especially for her selection of the most marvelous desserts. Her other joys in life were attending, each season, the Metropolitan Opera, the New York Philharmonic and American Ballet. Her other interests were varied-she loved to cook, garden, read, go to the movies and shows and her special hobby was interior decorating. She was a great presence that will be missed by all. (A private funeral service was held on March 21st at Riverside. In lieu of flowers, donations to Brooklyn Law School would be appreciated.) Roslyn, Julie, Leslie, Shiela and Rebecca

YOU don't flip through Acne Paper at the manicurist. Elegant and oversize, with arresting fashion imagery and interviews that read like wonderful dinner conversation, this semiannual publication is something you savor in bed. ''We wanted to make a magazine that made you forget the world around you,'' said its editor, Thomas Persson, from its base in Paris. The spring issue (which explores the idea of exoticism) does just that. A couture shoot by Katerina Jebb; a portfolio of work by Robert Mapplethorpe, Peter Beard and Guy Bourdin; and a talk with a member of the legendary theater troupe the Cockettes are among the exotics inside. Acne Paper, $8 at the new Acne boutique at 10 Greene Street (between Canal and Grand Streets).

ARONSOHN--Alan J.B. Attorney and author, died peacefully in his sleep on March 16 after a long struggle with Parkinson's Disease. He was 83. Born in Williamsport, PA to the late Micky and Cornelius K. Aronsohn, he joined the Navy during WWII and flew an F6F Hellcat off the aircraft carrier USS Antietam. After the war he attended Alfred University and Columbia Law School, where he served on the Law Review. In 1956 he joined the law firm of Robinson, Silverman & Pearce where he remained until his retirement. Warm, supportive, and highly intelligent, he will be greatly missed by his loving and devoted wife Bette, his children Lee, Judie and Abby, his seven grandchildren and his many friends and colleagues. No funeral services are planned but a Memorial may be held in the future. In lieu of flowers, his family requests donations be made to the Desert Oasis Hospice, 20815 North 25th Place, A106, Phoenix, AZ 85050. ARONSOHN--Alan J.B. The lawyers and staff of the law firm Bryan Cave LLP mourn the passing of our dear friend and colleague Alan J.B. Aronsohn. Alan was a name partner and retired senior managing partner of our predecessor firm Robinson Silverman Pearce Aronsohn & Berman, having joined the firm in 1956. He was a nationally recognized expert in partnership and federal tax law and an outstanding real estate attorney. He wrote and lectured extensively in these practice areas. He was a major contributor to the growth and prominence of the firm. He had an incredibly sharp, incisive and creative mind. His brilliance and sense of fairness were recognized and admired by clients and other attorneys. He was a master at drafting complicated documents in a clear and concise manner. He was a strong, benevolent and compassionate leader of the firm for many years. He was deeply loved and highly respected by all who knew him. Alan was also extremely loyal to clients and colleagues. He will be sorely missed. Our heartfelt condolences to Alan's caring wife Bette, his children Lee, Abby and Judie, his grandchildren and the entire Aronsohn family.

At 18, I went to Athens, and I couldn't see the stars,'' recalls Andreas Dourakis, who, like many young Cretans, left his small village to study and work. ''Later I learned about light pollution, but at the time I thought, Did they go away?'' After almost 20 years studying winemaking in Germany and working for European vineyards, he returned in 1989 to his hometown of Alikambos, a village near Chania, Crete, to turn his parents' farm into a small winery.

Now that bureaux de change are doing brisk business in rubles and yuan, it's clear there's a new world order in travel. ''People from everywhere are going everywhere,'' says Ian Bremmer, the president of the consulting firm Eurasia Group. And with new wealth come fresh stereotypes -- remember the Ugly American? Bremmer ascribes clichés to ''pure economics. It's who's spending the most money and annoying the locals.'' Here, a pop-anthropological look at the travel universe now. ANNA LOUIE SUSSMAN

STIRES--Judith Lohman, on March 16, 2008, of Pancreatic Cancer. Judy was born in Brooklyn on June 14, 1931 to Eugene and Martha Lohman. She grew up in Connecticut and New Jersey and attended Loomis Chaffee School and St. Margaret's School. She was an alumna of Centenary College in Hackettstown, NJ. She is survived by her husband, Sidney Stires, her sister, Gail Lohman Raleigh, her children; Wicks, Martha (Glenn Wright), Annie (John Carter), and Tom (Emily), her nephew, David Raleigh, and her 13 grandchildren. Judy was married for 53 years to her loving husband and best friend Sidney Homer Stires. They raised their family in New York City and Bay Head, NJ. For the last 20 years, Sid and Judy also lived part of the year in Venice, Italy. Over many years, Judy was a volunteer at The Boys Club of New York in the Youth Education programs. She was devoted to St. Thomas Church, and to St. Thomas Choir School. Judy was known for her joyful spirit, her great sense of style, her playful humor, and her love of music. She engaged people of all ages, and loved knowing all about their lives, their friends, their plans. Her family marveled at the energy she gave to every task, and her tasks were often labors of love that others had forgotten about or given up on. Judy was also tireless in her willingness to help the dependent know the happiness that she and Sidney had found in their life of sobriety. She volunteered in that effort for years at The Freedom Institute of New York City, but much of her work was done in the form of counsel right on her front porch. She was a gifted messenger. Judy, above all, was a wonderful wife, and mother, and grandmother, who loved those roles. A memorial service will be held at St. Thomas Church, 53rd Street and Fifth Avenue at 3:00pm on Friday, May 2nd. Gifts in Judy's memory can be made to The Freedom Institute, 515 Madison Avenue, 26th fl, New York, NY 10022. www.Freedominstitute.org.

Adored great-grandmother of Zach, Taylor and Brian, and dear brother Sam Leavitt and departed husband Sydney and brother Joseph and sister Hadalee. We will all deeply miss her generosity, kindness, wit and wise council.

SINCE it first landed in Vogue in fall 2004, Meredith Kahn's playfully subversive jewelry line, Made Her Think (an anagram of her name), has been a favorite of editors and stylists. Affordable prices (a brass-studded bangle for $65; a crystal-covered talon ring for $110) only furthered her success. Now she has a fine-jewelry line, simply called Meredith Kahn, with 12 Art Deco-inspired pieces, including a delicate white gold and smoky quartz charm ring ($1,218) and, above, a rose gold pyramid ring with pavé diamonds ($2,147). ''The line speaks to my more artistic side,'' she said from her Brooklyn studio. Each piece is made to order. Made Her Think is available at madeherthink.com. Meredith Kahn Fine Jewelry is at meredithkahn.com.

The Mortgage column on March 2, about credit-repair services, referred incorrectly to the average credit score of 692. That is the average score of consumers evaluated by Experian -- not the average for other credit bureaus or the Fair Isaac Corporation.

SIMMONS--Grant G. Jr., Grant G. Simmons, Jr., 88, of TidePointe, Hilton Head, SC, and Upper Saranac Lake, NY, died Sunday, March 16, 2008, at his home. Mr. Simmons was born January 3, 1920, in Colorado Springs, CO. He graduated from Greenwich Country Day School, Deerfield Academy, and Yale University (1942). He served in World War II as a reserve officer in the Navy Fleet Air Wing Five in Argentina, Newfoundland, and Fleet Air Wing Sixteen in Recife, Brazil, achieving the Rank of Lieutenant with Merit Order Medal. He joined Simmons Company in 1946, and in 1957, he became Chief Executive Officer (1957-1978), a post he held for 21 years of growth in both total revenue and profits. He was the fourth generation of the Simmons family to lead the Company. During these years, Simmons Company made fourteen corporate acquisitions, all friendly. These became wholly owned subsidiaries and included Thonet Industries, Selig Manufacturing, Greeff Fabrics, Bloomcraft, Katzenbach and Warren, and three casket companies. During Simmons' stewardship, Simmons Company established manufacturing businesses in Canada, England, France, Italy, Australia, Mexico, Venezuela, Puerto Rico, Brazil, Argentina, Japan, and Morocco. For seventeen years (1962-1979), Simmons was a Director of the IBM World Trade Corporation and later the IBM Europe / Middle East / Africa Corporation (1960-1984). Simmons was a Director of ACF Industries, Inc. from 1960-1984, and a Director of both the First National Holding Corporation and The First National Bank of Atlanta from 1974-1979. Active in Scouting, Simmons served as President of The Greater New York Council, largest in the U.S.A., from 1960-1963 and had the honor of presenting the Boy Scouts' highest commendation to John Glenn on the occasion of the New York City celebration of his successful first USA orbit of the earth. Simmons was awarded both the Boy Scouts Silver Beaver and Silver Antelope awards. A Whiffenpoof at Yale, Simmons pursued a lifelong attachment to music. He was a Director of the Metropolitan Opera Association from 1962-1975 and its Vice-President from 1969-1974, and a Director of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts from 1968-1976. Simmons was a Director of the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra from 1974-1980, a Director of the Atlanta Arts Alliance from 1975-1981 and a Director of the High Museum of Art in Atlanta from 1975-1981. An ardent bird watcher all his life, Simmons became a life member of the American Ornithologists Union in 1948 and the same year, a life member of the National Audubon Society, which he served as a Director from 1968-1974. Simmons was a member of the New York Chapter of The Society of Mayflower Descendants and The Denison Society and was, for many years, a member of The Brook Club. Simmons is survived by his daughters, Allison Prouty and Leslie Lee, his son, Grant G. Simmons III, three grandchildren and one stepgrandchild, and by a stepson, Henry Darlington III, two stepdaughters, Elizabeth ''Beth'' Darlington and Victoria Darlington Yoder, and four additional step-grandchildren. A memorial service will be at All Saints Episcopal Church, Hilton Head, South Carolina on April 12th at 11:30am. In his memory, in lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Cape May Bird Observatory, 600 Route 47 North, Cape May Court House, NJ 08210.

HIKING AT THE GRAND STAIRCASE-ESCALANTE NATIONAL MONUMENT, Oct. 20, 2007 Phil Satlof, 37, a digital cartographer from Washington. ''This hill was pretty steep and slippery, and my pack was heavy, and I was muddy and exhausted. I was really happy when I finally got to a point where I could stand up straight and walk up the rest of the hill. It was a good triumph to finally feel like I made it to the top of this thing. I was traveling with Michael, the photographer; we've been friends since childhood. You have a lot of time to talk when you're out there. We'll go almost a whole day without saying two words, but sometimes we'll be talking the entire time. We've done these trips for years, so we have running conversations that go back 10 years, that we only talk about when we get out into the backcountry. I have this theory about free will: is it more based on brain chemistry and do we have less free will than we think? Every time we go into the backcountry that comes up at some point.''

DEARIE--Christopher Farrell, of Old Westbury and Manhattan passed away on March 18 of natural causes. He is survived by his wife Direxa Dick Dearie and children Christopher Farrell Jr., Direxa Virginia, Honora Anne, William Dick and John Conner; grandchildren Katherine, Madeline and Christopher III; his sisters, Maureen Dearie Husk and Gertrude Dearie Frekko and brothers, John Paul Dearie Jr. and J. Lawrence Dearie. He was a loving son, brother, husband, father, grandfather, family member, friend and son of God. Christopher was born in Westfield, New Jersey on August 22, 1942 to John Paul Dearie and Anna Rose Farrell. He grew up in Mountain Lakes, New Jersey; graduated from Georgetown University and Fordham Law School and worked as a New York based attorney. A wake will be held at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home on Tuesday, March 25 from 8:30am-10am. A funeral will be held at the Church of St. Thomas More on Tuesday, March 25, at 10:45am. Interment is private. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made in his name to the Church of St. Thomas More., 65 East 89th Street, New York, NY 10128. DEARIE--Christopher. The Head of School, Trustees, Administration, Faculty and Staff, Students, Parents and Alumnae of Convent of the Sacred Heart, New York City, deeply mourn the passing of an exceptional friend. The Sacred Heart community will cherish the memory of Christopher's generous spirit and keep his wife, Direxa, his daughters Direxa (Class of 1991) and Honora (Class of 1993) and sons, Christopher Jr., John and William in perpetual prayer.

BROOKS--Hope Lupfer, devoted wife of Shelton and loving mother of Robert. An energetic member of the Cosmopolitan Club and an enthusiastic ''birder''. Hope's loving friendship was cherished by her many friends in New York and Connecticut. Hope's Friends BROOKS--Mary Hope Lupfer, died March 15 at Piper Shores, Scarborough, ME. Beloved wife of Shelton Brooks. Graduate of Vassar College and member of the Cosmopolitan Club. Director of St. Christopher Child Care Agency. Member of Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church. Contributions may be made to Vassar College or Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church.

HIKING AT THE GRAND STAIRCASE-ESCALANTE NATIONAL MONUMENT, Oct. 20, 2007 Phil Satlof, 37, a digital cartographer from Washington. ''This hill was pretty steep and slippery, and my pack was heavy, and I was muddy and exhausted. I was really happy when I finally got to a point where I could stand up straight and walk up the rest of the hill. It was a good triumph to finally feel like I made it to the top of this thing. I was traveling with Michael, the photographer; we've been friends since childhood. You have a lot of time to talk when you're out there. We'll go almost a whole day without saying two words, but sometimes we'll be talking the entire time. We've done these trips for years, so we have running conversations that go back 10 years, that we only talk about when we get out into the backcountry. I have this theory about free will: is it more based on brain chemistry and do we have less free will than we think? Every time we go into the backcountry that comes up at some point.''

In scrambling to patch the mistakes in their previous deal with Bear Stearns, JPMorgan and its attorneys at Wachtell Lipton Rosen & Katz may have put themselves in a newly precarious position.

It’s official: JPMorgan Chase and Bear Stearns have announced new terms for their merger deal, confirming Monday’s report in The New York Times. The new agreement raises JPMorgan’s offer for Bear to $10 per share in JPMorgan’s stock, up from $2 per share, quintupling the payout for shareholders of Bear, the securities firm that nearly collapsed earlier this month amid concerns about its liquidity.

Monday brought a rare bit of good news for Bear Stearns‘ beleaguered shareholders: The New York Times reported that JPMorgan Chase was in talks over the weekend to raise its bid for Bear to $10 per share from $2 per share.

JPMorgan Chase was in talks on Sunday night for a deal that would quintuple its offer for Bear Stearns, the beleaguered investment bank, in an effort to pacify angry Bear shareholders, the New York Times reported citing people involved in the negotiations.

Longtime readers know that toilets have been a subject of weird fascination for City Room. But just when we thought we had run out of public toilet stories, along comes Tommy Mintz, 31, an artist who works in digital photography and collage.On Sunday, as part of an art performance at the Jewish Museum, Mr. Mintz unveiled the NYC Public Toilet Map, a laser-printed, wallet-sized fold-out map that he is selling for $2 (along with 50-cent mailing charge) over the Internet. The map details locations of more than 250 public toilets in Manhattan, from the obvious (Starbucks) to the lesser-known (the Eyebeam Atelier, a nonprofit arts and technology center in Chelsea).
The takeover of public space for commercial promotion may be offensive, but it is usually legal. Occasionally, however, it is not. On Friday, March 14, it bordered on the criminal.

Two weeks after Eliot Spitzer’s role as a client of a prostitution ring emerged, and a week after Mr. Spitzer left the governor’s office in disgrace, his woes continue. In a front-page article today, Raymond Hernandez and Danny Hakim report that Mr. Spitzer was deeply involved in his administration’s efforts last year to discredit the State Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, holding detailed discussions with senior aides, ordering damaging information about Mr. Bruno released, and calling an aide at home repeatedly to check on the progress, according to several people with direct knowledge of the investigation.

Updated, 1:09 p.m. | Half of New York State voters oppose Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s plan to charge motorists for driving in Manhattan — but a majority in the city, in the suburbs and upstate would support the congestion pricing plan if the fees were used to improve mass transit in and around New York City, according to poll results released by Quinnipiac University.Skepticism about how the money would be used appears to be the biggest hurdle for proponents of the traffic fees; half of voters said they did not believe that new revenues from congestion pricing would actually be devoted to mass transit.

A friend of Sean Bell’s who was shot — five months after Mr. Bell was fatally shot — was never questioned by detectives or prosecutors as he recovered from his injuries, he testified on Monday. That led defense lawyers to suggest that he was given special treatment in exchange for testifying against the three detectives charged in Mr. Bell’s death.Mr. Bell’s friend, Johnell Hankerson, now 30, testified that in April 2007 he was eating pizza on Rockaway Boulevard in Queens when someone shot him. A friend took him to the hospital, he said. Two lawyers representing Mr. Bell’s fiancée, Nicole Paultre Bell, his sister-in-law, visited him in the hospital, he said.

More than a year after two auxiliary police officers were chased down and shot to death by a gunman in Greenwich Village, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly and Senator Charles E. Schumer are leveling harsh criticism at the Department of Justice for denying federal death benefits to the families of the two slain officers.At a news conference in Manhattan today, Mr. Schumer said the families of the officers, Nicolas T. Pekearo and Yevgeniy Marshalik, were each entitled to about $300,000 in federal benefits intended to compensate police and other public safety officers who die in the line of duty. He said officials of the Justice Department turned down applications from the two families in September, saying that neither of the two auxiliary officers qualified as public safety officers because they did “not have the power to make arrests.”

Subway and bus riders are about to feel the impact of the slowing real estate market and Wall Street turbulence. The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has postponed a $30 million package of service improvements that it had promised to riders as a way to sweeten the pill of a fare increase, which went into effect at the beginning of this month.The postponed service upgrades included plans to add more frequent service on the G line in Brooklyn and Queens, extending B and W service on weeknights to 11 p.m. from the current 9:30 p.m., and shaving one or two minutes from waiting times for evening service on the 1, 4 and 6 lines. The M.T.A. had also said it would create a new bus line, the M13, from the Lower East Side to East Midtown, and would extend the B71 and B77 buses from Brooklyn via the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel into Manhattan, where they would go to South Ferry.

Ever had an irritating pop song stick in your head so long you wanted to veer into oncoming traffic? If it's "Never Gonna Give You Up" by Rick Astley, better get a designated driver. It's gotten a lot harder to get away from that tune since the phenomenon of "rickrolling." As today's Times notes, the popular prank is a descendant of an older Internet joke called duckrolling. A Web site or blog post offers a link to something popular that leads unsuspecting viewers to a bizarre image of a duck on wheels. Or, in the case of rickrolling, the 20-year-old video for the Astley tune, or images like the above. Read more ...

The two car companies are expected to announce that Tata is buying Jaguar and Land Rover from Ford for about $2 billion, a person briefed on the negotiations said.
The White House said that President Bush, though “grieved” by the death toll, would continue to push forward and “focus on succeeding.”
Biovail, a pharmaceutical company, will pay $10 million to settle an inquiry in which the S.E.C. accuses four company officers of engaging in fraudulent accounting schemes.
Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton called on Congress to provide $30 billion to help minimize the number of foreclosures.
Mr. Aspinall became the Beatles’ road manager when the group was still a local dance band and went on to manage the band’s production and management company.
Webdenda.
The billionaire investor said that he was suing Motorola to force it to hand over documents related to its mobile devices business.
Stock prices soared in Taiwan as investors welcomed the presidential election victory of Ma Ying-jeou, a Nationalist who has called for closer relations with mainland China.
Decades ago, commercials asked, “Aren’t you hungry for Burger King now?” Today, a campaign from Burger King is seeking consumers with an appetite for work.
Accounts.
Shares soared after weekend negotiations salvaged the bailout of Bear Stearns and housing sales snapped a long streak of declines.
The offer is intended to win over angry shareholders in Bear who vowed to fight the original fire-sale deal.
High water pouring down the White River in eastern Arkansas could top levels recorded in a devastating flood 25 years ago.

The search for a New Jersey woman missing since her young son was found abandoned in a parking lot last summer led authorities on Sunday to a Staten Island pond, where human bones were discovered in a suitcase.

Kyle Jones led St. Norbert to its first N.C.A.A. Division III title, stopping 32 shots in the Green Knights’ 2-0 victory against Plattsburgh State in Lake Placid, N.Y. St. Norbert (27-1-4) finished the season with a 29-game unbeaten streak, a record for all N.C.A.A. hockey divisions. Bryan Hince made 28 saves for Plattsburgh State (25-5-0).
Former Gov. Eliot Spitzer is said to have been involved in his administration’s efforts last year to discredit the State Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno.
An abandoned warehouse on the north side of Brooklyn’s Pier 1 is being taken down, and differing ideas of what to do with the space are surfacing.

An article on March 10 about the business of surrogate motherhood in India misstated the geographic location of Gujarat, the Indian state where commercial surrogacy got its start in the country. It is in western India, not eastern India.

A picture with a report in the World Briefing column on Thursday about early elections in Kuwait was published in error. The photograph was of the country’s prime minister, Sheik Nasser al-Mohamed al-Ahmad al-Sabah — not of the Emir of Kuwait, Sheik Sabah al-Ahmed al-Sabah, who dissolved parliament and called for the elections.

A picture in The Arts on Thursday with an article about opera mishaps carried an erroneous credit. The photograph, of Ludwig Schnorr von Carolfseld and his wife, Malvina, who both starred in the premiere of “Tristan und Isolde” — he died soon after — was from the State Administration of Castles for Bavaria, not Germany.

An article in the special Museums section on March 12 about corporate cocktail parties and other special events at museums, using information from the Whitney Museum of American Art, erroneously included an event at the Whitney. The museum is not hosting Vanity Fair’s 75th anniversary party in September.

An obituary last Monday about Magda Cordell McHale, an artist and futurist, misidentified the university where her husband worked with the futurist thinker Buckminster Fuller. It was the Southern Illinois University campus in Carbondale, Ill., not the University of Illinois.

A picture with a report in the World Briefing column on Thursday about early elections in Kuwait was published in error. The photograph was of the country’s prime minister, Sheik Nasser al-Mohamed al-Ahmad al-Sabah — not of the Emir of Kuwait, Sheik Sabah al-Ahmed al-Sabah, who dissolved parliament and called for the elections.

Because of an editing error, a sports article on Friday about the prospect of more expensive seating in the new Yankee Stadium referred incorrectly in some copies, to the highest-priced box seats when the stadium opens in 2009. They will not cost significantly more than the current price of $250.

A caption on Friday with a photograph of a spotted eagle ray that killed a woman when it leaped from the water and jumped in her boat gave an incorrect classification from The Associated Press for the animal. The spotted eagle ray is not a type of stingray.

An article on Wednesday about the conviction of Cesar Rodriguez for killing his 7-year-old stepdaughter, Nixzmary Brown, misstated the number of bedrooms in the family’s apartment on Greene Avenue in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, where Nixzmary was found beaten to death. It has three bedrooms, not two.

An article in some editions on March 13 about New Jersey legislators’ criticism of Gov. Jon S. Corzine’s $33 billion budget referred incorrectly to Mr. Corzine’s planned cutback of $168 million in municipal aid. That amount would apply to all municipalities statewide — not just the 323 smallest, which stand to lose $57 million. (The error appeared on March 7 in an article about how the proposed cuts would affect small towns.) The March 13 article also referred imprecisely to a vow by several senators to restore the $168 million. The money would go to all municipalities, not just the smallest towns, although the senators expressed particular concern about those towns.

A sports article on Tuesday about the rivalry between the elite figure skaters Evan Lysacek and Johnny Weir misspelled the surname of a woman on the University of Michigan club team who admires Weir. She is Laura Sigler, not Signer.

A chart on Tuesday comparing Eliot Spitzer, the former governor of New York, with his successor, David A. Paterson, on various issues misidentified the court that in 2004 threw out New York’s death penalty, which Mr. Spitzer favored under some circumstances and Mr. Paterson opposed. It was the State Court of Appeals, not the State Supreme Court.
Maya Moore scored 17 points to lead a balanced offense as top-seeded Connecticut beat 16th-seeded Cornell, 89-47.
What the State Commission on Public Integrity once told Eliot Spitzer’s administration about travel could pose a problem for the former governor.

Georgie Wilson Welcome beat goalkeeper Dominic Cervi in the 13th minute of overtime with a shot to the top-right corner of the net, and Honduras held on for a 1-0 victory against the United States in the Concacaf men’s Olympic qualifying tournament championship game in Nashville. Both teams had already clinched a berth in the Summer Games in Beijing. Earlier, Canada beat Guatemala for third place, 5-3 on penalty kicks after a scoreless regulation.

Kimi Raikkonen comfortably won the Malaysian Grand Prix in Sepang on Sunday, immediately injecting Ferrari into the title race. Raikkonen won by 20 seconds over BMW Sauber’s Robert Kubica, with McLaren’s Heikki Kovalainen another 19 seconds back in third. The only negative for Ferrari was the failure by the pole-sitter, Felipe Massa, to finish. After winning in Australia last week, Lewis Hamilton finished fifth after starting in ninth as a result of a five-grid-place penalty for causing interference in qualifying.

Alain Bernard of France set a world record in the 50-meter freestyle, after twice lowering the 100 freestyle mark in the previous two days at the European Championships in Eindhoven, the Netherlands. Bernard finished in 21.50 seconds to beat the time of 21.56 set last month by Eamon Sullivan of Australia.

Greg Kraft shot a 70 to outlast Bo Van Pelt down the stretch, finishing at 14 under par for a one-shot victory at the inaugural Puerto Rico Open in Rio Grande for his first official PGA Tour victory. Jerry Kelly (70), at No. 63 the highest-ranked golfer at the event, and Van Pelt (72) were second at Trump International Golf Club. Kraft won the Deposit Guaranty Classic in Mississippi 15 years ago. Because it took place the same weekend as the Masters, it did not count as an official tour win.

Battling gusting, swirling winds, Stacey Cook and Kevin Francis claimed the super-G titles at the United States Alpine Championships at Sugarloaf in Carrabassett Valley, Me.Cook collected her second national title when she edged her teammate Leanne Smith by five-hundredths of a second. Cook also won the super-G crown on the same hill in 2006. Lindsey Vonn, the World Cup overall champion, finished fourth.Francis beat out Bryon Friedman for his first national title.

Manchester United, the defending champion, increased its lead in the English Premier League to 5 points, and Chelsea emerged as the main rival in this season’s title chase. United beat Liverpool, 3-0, to improve to 73 points, and Chelsea took over second place with 68 points by rallying to beat Arsenal, 2-1.
JPMorgan Chase was in talks for a deal that would quintuple its offer for Bear Stearns in an effort to pacify Bear shareholders, according to people involved in the discussions.
Serbians Novak Djokovic and Ana Ivanovic won the men’s and women’s singles finals at the Pacific Life Open on Sunday.
The finance industry was responsible for nearly a third of all wages earned in New York City in 2007, the highest in modern times.
The Tigers missed four of their last six free-throw attempts in the game’s worrisome final 22 seconds before squeaking by Mississippi State 77-74 on Sunday.
The monthly meeting of the Society of Professional Investigators often begins with red wine and antipasto.
By beating San Diego 72-63, Western Kentucky joined Villanova as the highest seeds to reach this N.C.A.A. tournament’s Round of 16.
Ambitious men sometimes do a disservice to the best in their own communities. And Barack Obama is an ambitious man.
Wherever he goes, from Algona to Zwingle, Iowa State Coach Bill Fennelly is following the path blazed by his opponent on Monday, Rutgers Coach C. Vivian Stringer.
In defeating Arkansas 108-77 on Sunday, North Carolina became the first team to score 100 points in their first two N.C.A.A. Tournament games since 1990.
With nine holes to play, Geoff Ogilvy clung to a two-stroke lead over Jim Furyk and Vijay Singh in the rain-delayed W.G.C.-CA Championship on Sunday.
China’s authoritarianism is backfiring, fueling the resentment that exploded in Lhasa and radicalizing Tibetans.
Sara Jane Olson’s return to prison in California came after corrections officials said a miscalculation had resulted in her early release.
Scottie Reynolds, a sophomore guard, led Villanova to its third trip to the Round of 16 in the past four seasons, as the Wildcats beat Siena 84-72.

Forty-two people were rescued by the Coast Guard about 120 miles west of Dutch Harbor, in the Aleutian Islands off Alaska.

The competition between Mike Pelfrey and Orlando Hernández gained some clarity after Hernández, in his spring debut, struggled with his revised mechanics.

Maryland looked nothing like a top seed Sunday while struggling past Coppin State, 80-66, in the opening round of the N.C.A.A. women’s tournament in College Park, Md.

Israel Cachao López transformed the rhythm of Cuban music when he and his brother, the pianist and cellist Orestes López, extended and accelerated the final section of the stately Cuban danzón into the mambo.
Some of the country’s biggest corporations have been complaining that American immigration policies are thwarting New York’s ability to compete with other world capitals.

MINNEAPOLIS (AP) — Old photographs of the Interstate 35W bridge show that two steel connecting plates were visibly bent as early as 2003 — four years before the span collapsed into the Mississippi River, killing 13 people.
The owner of Alcade, an aging bull who has sired many top opponents for Spain’s bullfighters, has decided to clone him.
Two episodes shed light on a bitter period in John McCain’s life, when he was drifting away from his own party.
The exhibition games are over. The regular season is about to start. And the Boston Red Sox’ jet lag is fading.
The elections in the tiny Buddhist state, wedged in the Himalayas between India and China, were ordered by the country’s royal family to end its absolute rule.
Congress set aside $2.3 billion in pet projects for colleges and universities last year for research on subjects like reducing odors from swine and poultry, according to an analysis.
Patrick Kane scored 1 minute 9 seconds into overtime after James Wisniewski tied the score in the final minute of regulation and the host Chicago Blackhawks defeated the St. Louis Blues 4-3.
So far, Hillary Rodham Clinton has won states with a total of 219 Electoral College votes, not counting Florida and Michigan, while Barack Obama has won states with a total of 202 electoral votes.
A mysterious character in the Sean Bell police shooting shows up late and under cross-examination, answers questions with smart-aleck bravado.

BOONEVILLE, Ark. (AP) — A fire and an explosion at a meat-packing plant on Sunday caused an ammonia gas leak that forced 180 people from their homes, but no one working at the plant was injured, emergency responders said.
With a new windup, Giants pitcher Barry Zito, the 2002 American League Cy Young winner, is trying to live up to expectations.
Nigel Dawes has climbed from the minors to install himself on the Rangers’ second line and now as its best shootout scorer.
Brett Gardner who batted .260 in 45 games at Class AAA last season, says he thinks he will get the chance to regularly play center field for the Yankees.
Odds seem long that Julianne Viani and the Red Foxes will extend their 22-game winning streak on Monday, but given the team’s recent play, it would be foolhardy to count them out.
An Apple computer user is told of yet another benefit that the brand carries.
With every day that Andy Pettitte is slowed by back spasms, the chance that he will miss his scheduled start in the second game of the regular season increases.
New Yorkers, even those who live next to 625-ton cranes, have a way of putting up with their neighbors.
Dirk Nowitzki was injured on an ugly fall in the third quarter of the Dallas Mavericks’ 88-81 loss to the visiting San Antonio Spurs on Sunday.
Dr. Challinor combined his career as a top scientific administrator at the Smithsonian Institution with an equally intense pursuit of excellence as a champion oarsman.
Feuding Democrats have handed Senator John McCain the gift of time, and how well he uses it may determine his chance to beat them in November.
Miami nearly came back from 17 down, before Texas pulled away to win 75-72 on Sunday. The Longhorns will play Stanford on Friday in Houston.
Butler and Tennessee tried to make up for a modest first-round in the East Region with an overtime thriller on Sunday that the Vols won, 76-71.
Stephen Curry scored 30 points, including 25 in the second half, to lead Davidson in a 74-70 upset of the No.2 seed Georgetown.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,985 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Sunday:.
A Hollywood journalist whose report of a threat led to the trial of Anthony Pellicano, a private detective facing wiretapping charges, will soon be a witness in the case.

Flu has forced Riccardo Muti out of concerts with the New York Philharmonic this week. He will be replaced by Michael Christie, right, who will make his debut as conductor of the orchestra, leading works by Elgar and Copland on Thursday at 7:30 p.m., Friday at 11 a.m. and Saturday at 8 p.m. At all three concerts Pinchas Zukerman will be featured as the soloist in Elgar’s Violin Concerto. Mr. Christie will also conduct at 2 p.m. Saturday, when the program will include Schubert’s Octet, performed by musicians from the orchestra, followed by Copland’s Third Symphony. Mr. Christie has been the music director of the Brooklyn Philharmonic and the Phoenix Symphony since 2005 and is also the music director of the Colorado Summer Music festival and principal guest conductor of the Queensland Orchestra in Australia, where he was chief conductor until 2004. He came to international attention in 1995 when he won a special prize for outstanding potential at the First International Sibelius Conductors’ Competition, in Helsinki.

A minute’s silence was ordered across Sri Lanka on Saturday as the visionary British science-fiction writer Arthur C. Clarke was buried in a plot in the General Cemetery in the capital, Colombo, Agence France-Presse reported. Tamara Ekanayake, daughter of his business partner, Hector Ekanayake, said, “He wanted us to write on his tombstone: ‘Here lies Arthur Clarke. He never grew up but didn’t stop growing.’ ” Clarke was 90 when he died on Wednesday. Family, friends, schoolchildren and space buffs walked behind his coffin as the police and security personnel led the way to the cemetery. Clarke had asked for a funeral without political pomp or religious rites, but politicians, a dozen Buddhist monks and a Catholic priest joined the mourners and watched as his body was buried. The government asked people to observe a minute of silence at midafternoon, when the burial took place, and a newspaper headline mourned the “final voyage of a titan.”.

“Dr. Seuss’ Horton Hears a Who” held on to first place at North American box offices over the weekend, while three new releases broke into the Top Five. “Horton,” a 20th Century Fox release, grossed an estimated $25.1 million in its second week, beating “Tyler Perry’s Meet the Browns” (Lionsgate). In its debut that film, a comedy and morality tale starring Angela Bassett, took in $20 million, according to the box-office tracking company Media by Numbers. Another newcomer, the horror tale “Shutter” (Fox), finished third, with $10.7 million, followed by “Drillbit Taylor” (Paramount), a comedy starring Owen Wilson, which rang up $10.2 million in its first weekend. Fifth place went to another holdover, “10,000 B.C.” (Warner Brothers), which grossed $8.6 million in its third week.

Competing films about the reggae star Bob Marley, above, are sparring over his music and the timing of their release dates, Reuters reported. The adversaries are the makers of a Weinstein Company drama and a Martin Scorsese documentary. Marley’s family, including his son Ziggy Marley, executive producer of the Scorsese film, has refused to license any of his music for the Weinstein film, even though Marley’s widow, Rita Marley, is its executive producer. The Scorsese documentary is being produced by Tuff Gong Pictures, owned by the Marley family, and Steven Bing’s Shangri-La, which has licensed Marley songs. The family members say they believe the Weinstein drama’s release date, expected to be late 2009, would conflict with the planned opening of their documentary, February 2010. (Marley was born on Feb. 6, 1945; he died in 1981.) Chris Blackwell, president of Blue Mountain Music, publisher of Marley’s music, said he expected an agreement soon under which Weinstein would take a stake in the documentary and agree to postpone its drama.

Lawyers for the Beatles are suing to thwart distribution of previously unreleased recordings supposedly made during Ringo Starr’s first performance with the band, at the Star Club in Hamburg, West Germany, in 1962, The Associated Press reported. Under the title “Jammin’ With the Beatles and Friends, Star Club, Hamburg, 1962,” the eight tracks are said to include Paul McCartney singing Hank Williams’s “Lovesick Blues” and Mr. McCartney and John Lennon singing “Ask Me Why.” Apple Corps, the London company formed by the Beatles, maintains that the songs were taped without their consent, and that Fuego Entertainment of Miami Lakes, Fla., and two sister companies have no right to distribute them. Apple’s lawsuit contends that the recordings are of poor quality and that circulating them “dilutes and tarnishes the extraordinarily valuable image associated with the Beatles.” Paul LiCalsi, a lawyer for Apple Corps, said, “This appears to us to be a garden-variety bootleg recording.” Hugo Cancio, the president of Fuego, said: “Don’t claim that these were just bootlegged. It’s not like today, that you just go in with a phone or BlackBerry and you record.” He added: “The world deserves to hear these tracks. The fact is that we have it, they don’t, and that is what’s bothering them.”.

About 1,000 ancient artifacts found in the country home of a wealthy engineer outside Rome have been traced by archaeologists to one of Emperor Trajan’s first-century villas, CBC News reported. The archaeologists said the pieces, used as decorations in the engineer’s weekend residence, came from the walls of what is believed to have been Trajan’s hunting retreat in Arcinazzo Romano. The suspect in the case has not been identified because the matter remains under investigation, and he is not in police custody. The police did not provide a date for their raid on the home but indicated that it took place more than a year ago.

The $25 million London production of “The Lord of the Rings,” above, will close at the Theater Royal Drury Lane on July 19 after 492 performances, Broadway.com reported from London. The Guardian of London reported that the show would enter the record books as one of the West End’s costliest failures, and it noted that the show had also flopped in Toronto, where its budget was a reported $23 million. Nevertheless, Broadway.com said, the producers are discussing a German-language version, to open in Germany next year, as well as tours of New Zealand, Australia and Asia.
The Wall Street Journal’s transition to more breaking news and shorter articles will include a makeover of its Marketplace section, editors and reporters there said.
Chris Wallace took some of his Fox colleagues to task, claiming that they took Senator Barack Obama’s comments about race out of context.
The ministry has set a deadline of April 24 for companies to submit bids to help develop the Akkas gas field in the former Sunni insurgent stronghold of Anbar province.
The rethinking of Beijing’s earlier promise to broadcasters comes as the government has poured troops into Tibetan areas wracked by antigovernment protests this month.
Daniel Clifton begins his “Marked Territory” on a decidedly melancholy note.
In its two-week season at the London Coliseum, which ended on Sunday, New York City Ballet closed its all-Balanchine program with “Symphony in C.”
There may be panic on Wall Street, but Doubledown Media, publisher of magazines for the wealthy, says its business and readers are largely immune to the problems.
Mark Lamos’s stark staging of "Tosca" for the New York City Opera updates the story to Fascist Rome.
Directors and senior managers at HBOS, Britain’s biggest mortgage lender, bought some 1.4 million shares at 446 pence, $8.87, a share using their bonus entitlements.
Iraq coverage by major American news sources has dropped to about one-fifth of what it was last summer, according to a survey.
Michelle DeYoung shared a concert on Thursday at the Morgan Library & Museum with Bryan Hymel, a young tenor who won the George London Foundation's award last year.

Barely a shot is fired in the two-and-a-half-hour opening installment of “Bush’s War,” a two-part “Frontline” report beginning Monday on PBS. But there are hostilities aplenty.

Geraldine Cardiel’s “On/Off,” seen on Friday night at Joyce SoHo, was frustrating.

Sun Microsystems has received a $44 million contract from the Pentagon to explore the high-risk idea of replacing wires between computer chips with laser beams.

COMPANY REPORTS It is a light week for earnings, with reports coming from Tiffany and Walgreen (Monday); SAIC (Tuesday); Oracle (Wednesday); the Apollo Group, ConAgra Foods, Lennar and Red Hat (Thursday); and KB Home (Friday).

BROWNSTEIN--Edward J., M.D., Chairman Emeritus of the Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences and former Dean of Admissions at New York Medical College, died on Sunday, March 23, 2008 at his home in Larchmont, New York at the age of 82. Dr. Brownstein was a graduate of UT Southwestern Medical School and did his psychoanalytical training at Columbia University, Center for Psychoanalytic Training and Research at the College of Physicians and Surgeons. He was a leader in the field of psychiatric education and training, and took great pleasure in helping new doctors embark on their medical careers. He served as a sergeant in the Army Air Corps in World War II, and was an avid tennis player and singing enthusiast. He is predeceased by wife Vivian, and survived by son Glenn, daughters Nancy, Alison and Katherine, and grandchildren Nina, Samuel, William, Abigail, Alexander, Jackson and Emily. Funeral services will be held on Tuesday, March 25, 2008 at 11:30am at John J. Fox Funeral Home in Larchmont, New York. Memorial donations may be made to the Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research.

RUSSO--Salvatore Esq., devoted husband of Eileen (nee McCormack) beloved father of Alana and Salvatore (Sam Russo Jr. Esq.) Chapel service 9am Tuesday. In repose Raccuglia & Son 321-323 Court St., Bklyn 718-855-7737.

O'MALLEY--Charles R., 93, died peacefully in NYC of natural causes on March 19, 2008. Deeply mourned and sadly missed by his family including fourteen nieces and nephews and his many friends in NYC and elsewhere. A wake will be held at Gannon Dimiceli Funeral Home, 152 East 28th St in Manhattan on March 24 from 5-9pm. Funeral mass will be celebrated on Tuesday March 25 at 10am at the Church of our Saviour, 59 Park Ave at 38th St. Burial will be at Violet Hill Cemetery in Perry, IA on Friday, March 28 following visitation at Murdoch Funeral Home in Perry from 1-8pm on March 27. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that contributions be sent to Charles' favorite charity, St. Patrick's School, 1312 3rd St., Perry, IA 50220.

WILKINS--Iris. We are profoundly saddened by the loss of Iris Wilkins. She was a very special and wonderful person. We extend our deepest sympathy to the Wilkins and Kwiat families and to Zeke Cooper. Alice, Jacques and Shelley, Rita and Sheldon, Michele and Steve, Allie and Steven WILKINS--Iris. We are profoundly saddened by the loss of our ''Aunt'' Iris. Her intellect and sense of humor touched all of us who were fortunate enough to know her. Her grace and courage through this devastating illness will be an inspiration to all who loved her. Our deepest condolences to the Wilkins and Kwiat families and Zeke Cooper. Marc and Ellen, Eric and Lisa, Beth and Peter, Adam, Jill, Max, Jake, Luke, Jonathan, Alexander and Zachary WILKINS--Iris. Our family is mourning the loss of our beloved mother and grandmother, Iris Wilkins. She was our matriarch who shared her extraordinary zest for life with all of us. Through her example, Iris taught us the importance of family and the true meaning of generosity. Her elegance and style were unmatched and her love for her family was unparalleled. A true survivor, Iris fought to end with the same grace that defined her life. Her legacy will live on with each and every one of us. With all our love, Fern and Lowell Kwiat, Laurie and Stuart Wilkins and all the grandchildren WILKINS--Iris. The treasure of true friendship is forever. For all the years we shared laughter and joy and all the times we leaned on each other through life's challenges the one constant was the love and commitment of our friendship. PLATT--Ann (Ania Bienstock), of New Rochelle, New York, passed away on February 9, 2008 after a brief illness. Her husband of 63 years, Harold Platt, died following their 63rd wedding anniversary two years earlier. Born in Lvov, Poland in 1920, Ann was brought to safety in New York by her Aunt Charlotte on the eve of World War II. Her entire family perished in the Holocaust. As a youth, she was a skilled athlete. Once in the USA, Ann began to work in the garment industry. She learned English in night school and after marrying, she started her American family. With Harold, Yiddishkeit and family became and remained the center of their lives. Moving to New Rochelle in 1956 she achieved success as a mother and recognition in the community in the Sisterhood of Temple Beth El and the Workmen's Circle. She became president of her chapter of Woman's American Ort. Ann was an avid reader and compassionate advocate for the disenfranchised. She was manager of the Balalaika Russian Night Club in NYC. With Harold, she also became a follower of the Arts and enjoyed both the great Yiddish cultural life in New York as well as theater, music and all of the Arts. She was a strong supporter of Russian Jewry and the State of Israel. She became a skilled artist and had a one woman show of her needlepoint. With Harold, Ann shared in building and maintaining many organizations (the Workmen's Circle (Arbiter Ring), Beth El Synagogue in New Rochelle, the Folksbienne Yiddish Theater). A woman born into poverty and subjected to the terrible loss of her family, she felt fortunate to be an American. She was the loving mother of Laura, Marc and Leslie and mother-in-law of Richard, Susan and Marcia. She was the blessed grandmother of Rachel, Sydney, Emily, Alex, Josh and Bill and friend to many.

An article in some editions on March 13 about New Jersey legislators' criticism of Gov. Jon S. Corzine's $33 billion budget referred incorrectly to Mr. Corzine's planned cutback of $168 million in municipal aid. That amount would apply to all municipalities statewide -- not just the 323 smallest, which stand to lose $57 million. (The error appeared on March 7 in an article about how the proposed cuts would affect small towns.) The March 13 article also referred imprecisely to a vow by several senators to restore the $168 million. The money would go to all municipalities, not just the smallest towns, although the senators expressed particular concern about those towns.

Video game sales totaled $669 million in February, up 47% from February 2007, and game players spent some $480 million on game hardware. The best-selling platform was Nintendo DS, followed by the Wii and PlayStation 2. The industry sees plenty of off-screen action. In the last week, Gibson Guitar filed separate patent infringement suits against both Activision, which makes Guitar Hero, and Electronic Arts, which makes Rock Band, as well as several retailers. Guitar Hero, which was originally released in 2005, has since had more than $1 billion in sales of all versions. SHELLY FREIERMAN

FRANK--Ilse Katharina, nee Haensel, known as Kit. Born in Berlin on July 3, 1911, passed away at her home on March 21, surrounded by family and friends. SMITH--Joe D. Jr., Services for Joe Dorsey Smith, Jr. will be at 3:00pm Monday, March 24th, 2008, in St. James Episcopal Church with the Rev. Fred H. Tinsley, Jr. officiating. Interment will be in Greenwood Memorial Park, Pineville under the direction of John Kramer & Son. Joe Dorsey Smith, Jr., 85, of Alexandria, died Thursday, March 20th, 2008, in his residence. Mr. Smith was preceded in death by his first wife, Jane Wilson Smith. Mr. Smith was a graduate of Louisiana College and was the retired general manager, president, publisher and chairman of The Town Talk. During World War II, Mr. Smith served his country in the Army Air Corps. He was a member of the Louisiana Board of Regents and received an honorary doctorate from LSU for his service to the university. Mr. Smith was a past chairman and past president of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, the Southern Newspaper Publishers Association and was on the board of The Associated Press for a number of years. Mr. Smith was involved in banking, having been on the board of the Guaranty Bank & Trust Company and later the board of the Hibernia Bank in New Orleans. Additionally, Mr. Smith was a past president of the Public Affairs Research Council and the board of Tulane Health Sciences Center. Joe D. Smith, Jr. is survived by: wife, Bertie Murphy Smith of Alexandria, LA; son, Larry D. Smith and his wife, Brenda Smith, of Austin, TX; two nephews, Andrew ''Andy'' Smith of Pineville, LA; Burton Smith of Alexandria, LA; two nieces, Nancy Smith Morris of Jupiter, FL; Lindsay Smith Bailey of Alexandria, LA; two stepsons, John W. Deming, Jr. of Palo Alto, CA; Claiborne P. Deming of El Dorado, AR; two stepdaughters, Bertie Deming Heiner of Charlottesville, VA; Cathy Deming Pierson of New Orleans, LA; 11 grandchildren. Friends are asked to call from 1:30pm until 3:00pm Monday at St. James Episcopal Church Parish Hall. The pallbearers will be Mike Day, Claiborne Deming, Rod Noles, Hunter Pierson, Ted Silver, and Andy Smith. The honorary pallbearers will be Richard B. Crowell, Tom Hardin, Brenner Sadler, and Harry Silver. The family has requested memorials be sent to St. James Episcopal Church, 1620 Murray Street, Alexandria, LA 71301. Notes of condolence may be sent to the family online at kramerfunerals@aol.com

Detective Michael Oliver’s grand jury testimony, given a year ago, was read aloud on Monday during his manslaughter trial by members of the Queens district attorney’s office. It was the closest to a firsthand account of his actions that the public has yet heard. The prosecution has now introduced the grand jury testimony of all three detectives on trial, but the detectives may testify later. When a prosecutor asked if it would have been wiser to seek cover, Detective Oliver replied, “Yes, it would have been the wiser course, but I put myself in harm’s way to protect members of my team.”

The folks who study fingerprints at crime scenes do not want their palms scanned to verify their time clocks.
