A federal appellate court has rejected New York State’s right to penalize airlines for not providing adequate services to passengers trapped on planes at airports for more than three hours.

A total of 34 school districts outside of New York City have failed to meet annual benchmarks for standardized test scores and high school graduation rates under the federal No Child Left Behind law, or six more than the previous year, according to a list released Tuesday by the State Education Department.

A friend of Sean Bell’s testified on Tuesday that not only did Mr. Bell argue with a stranger outside the Club Kalua the night Mr. Bell was killed, but also that the stranger told Mr. Bell, “I’ll shoot you.”The testimony followed hours of witnesses over the last 17 days of trial who have turned the exchange in front of Club Kalua into something out of “Rashomon,” with everyone seeming to see and hear something different. Accounts have ranged from a heated exchange between Mr. Bell and his friends and the stranger, Fabio Coicou, to a pleasant conversation about their neighborhood, Far Rockaway.

I think that I shall never see a zoning text amendment lovely as a tree. But the new Section 26-41 of the Zoning Resolution, which was approved on Monday by the City Planning Commission, no doubt comes close for fans of a green city. It requires the planting of street trees for new developments, as well as major enlargements and certain conversions of existing buildings. One tree is required for every 25 feet of street frontage.

Sludge from the city sewer system is burned there and made into fertilizer pellets.

If it is true that cleanliness is next to godliness, then riders of the L train may have a closer relationship with the divine than therest of us. At least, that’s a conclusion that could be drawn from the latest survey by an advocacy group that tried to measure subway cleanliness. The survey released today by Straphangers Campaign, which is financed by New York Public Interest Research Group, found that the L train had the cleanest cars in a recent series of visits to the various lines. The dirtiest cars run on the E and the Q lines, the group concluded.

Pia Sundhage is the sixth coach in the history of the United States women's national team, but the first from outside the country. Sundhage, 48, was hired by U.S. Soccer last November to replace Greg Ryan, who was fired after the American team finished third in the Women's World Cup in China. She is charged with qualifying the United States for this summer's Olympics in Beijing and defending the gold medal won by the American women four years ago in Greece. Sundhage was interviewed by phone last week from Stockholm, where she was preparing to travel to Los Angeles where the United States team is now training for next week's qualifying games in Ciudad Juarez, Mexico.

The latest report of the Social Security Trustees is out. I think the key message is what has happened to the estimate of actuarial balance -- the difference between projected outlays and projected revenues over the next 75 years. This is the thing that's supposed to get steadily worse as time goes by, as the 75-year window contains ever fewer years in which the baby boomers are in the work force, paying payroll taxes, and ever more years when the boomers are out of the work force and collecting benefits.

BRIEFS A federal court today rejected New York State's attempt to require airlines to provide water, fresh air, power and working restrooms during lengthy delays, precisely the situation encountered today on a "flight" of the London Eye, the British capital's Ferris wheel attraction. Whether or not it was legally required to do so, the Eye rushed a raft of comforts for stranded passengers: water, blankets, glucose tablets and commodes.

Just like Joyce, I couldn't get enough of "The Bonfire of the Vanities" when it came out, both because it was a great read and because Wolfe was chronicling my world - except it was a different world from hers. I was working on Wall Street and Sherman McCoy's education and upbringing exactly corresponded with mine. Having read and re-read Wolfe constantly since I was twelve, I could not help but be engrossed when he dissected Sherman's and my tiny node of America. More broadly, though, as a native New Yorker living in Manhattan at the time, I was fascinated by his portrayal of the city as a whole, and simply as a novel-reader, I loved the book. Reading it twenty years later, I again found it completely absorbing; it still crackled with wit, insight and drama. Maybe most amazingly, I didn't find it at all dated, even though, as Joyce says, the New York of today differs so much from the New York of 1987. "Bonfire" transcends its era, a remarkable achievement for a book so dependent on period details.

Did you know that the number of buildings over eight stories in Shanghai went from 121 in 1980 to 10,045 in 2005? That 56 percent of all London residents in 2001 were foreign born? And that 65 percent of New Yorkers belong to an ethnic minority? You will after flipping through "The Endless City" (Phaidon), a chronicle of the unprecedented shift towards urban living that the world has been experiencing since the early 20th century. In 1910, 10 percent of the world's population lived in cities; we are currently at 50 percent and the projection for 2050 is 75 percent.

The Villanova backup center Casiem Drummond broke his right ankle in the Wildcats’ second-round victory against Siena and will miss the rest of the tournament. Drummond was set to have a screw inserted into the ankle Tuesday. Villanova said the injury was unrelated to the stress fracture in the same ankle that sidelined him earlier this season.

The San Francisco 49ers lost twice with linebacker Lance Briggs, failing to sign him in free agency and forfeiting their fifth-round draft pick in next month’s draft after N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell determined Monday that the Niners had tampered with Briggs, a violation of league rules. The 49ers and the Bears will also exchange their picks in the third round, giving the Bears San Francisco’s seventh pick, while the Niners will get the Bears’ pick at No. 12. Briggs was with the Bears last season when reports surfaced that the 49ers had had contact with Briggs’s agent, Drew Rosenhaus. The Bears had made Briggs their franchise player in 2007, and Briggs, who was angered by the move, stated he would not return to the Bears after he played out his one-year contract. But Briggs re-signed with the Bears this month. In the meantime, the Bears filed a tampering charge with the league.

Floyd Landis’s hearing in front of the Court of Arbitration for Sport ended Monday after 35 hours of testimony spanning five days that included 14 witnesses and written testimony from 10 others. A C.A.S. news release said a decision on the “voluminous” case is not expected before June. The hearing is Landis’s last chance to have his 2006 Tour de France title restored. It was stripped last September after an arbitration panel ruled Landis used performance-enhancing substances during his victory.

PREMIUM AIR TRAVEL SAGS Premium traffic, which had been increasing robustly around the world in recent years, “is now slowing sharply,” said the International Air Transport Association, noting that the number of passengers traveling globally in first- and business-class seats “barely grew” in January compared with January 2007. Premium traffic on the lucrative trans-Atlantic routes grew 5.6 percent in 2007, and was 2.6 percent higher in January compared with January 2007. But that represented slowing compared with December, when trans-Atlantic premium traffic rose 5.7 percent over December 2006. Premium traffic to and from the Middle East continued to grow unabated, with a 20.6 percent increase last year, the international airline trade group said. Continental Airlines has announced a sharp reduction in 60-day advance-purchase business-class fares to Europe for the summer. Here’s a sample round-trip fare: Newark-London Heathrow, $1,798 plus taxes and fees.

ABC edged past CBS in attracting viewers on Easter Sunday as “Extreme Makeover: Home Edition” and “Oprah’s Big Give” drew the night’s top ratings among adults 18 to 49. According to Nielsen’s estimates, the two shows drew 11.1 million viewers and 9.9 million total viewers at 8 and 9, respectively. CBS nearly eclipsed ABC, however, thanks to an overrun of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament coverage in the 7 o’clock hour. CBS’s “60 Minutes” followed, netting more than 10 million viewers. CBS’s ratings faltered later as “Big Brother,” “Cold Case” and “Dexter” averaged fewer than seven million viewers. NBC ranked third over all, winning the 10 o’clock hour in total viewers with a “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit” rerun (eight million), even as ABC’s “Here Come the Newlyweds” (6.9 million) led the time slot in the 18-to-49 set. Fox finished fourth for the night.

It looks as if the Metropolitan Opera’s “Tristan und Isolde” will have a happy ending. The Canadian tenor Ben Heppner, right, who missed the first four of six scheduled performances because of illness, will appear as Tristan in the final performances, on Tuesday and Friday, the company confirmed on Monday. Mr. Heppner, the reigning Wagnerian tenor, was initially said to be suffering from a virus, but The Vancouver Sun reported that he had said that his illness had been misdiagnosed in New York. Mr. Heppner told The Sun that after consulting his doctor in Toronto, he had decided to go home, and at North York General Hospital, “the doctors discovered that I had a blood-borne infection that had abscessed in the pelvic region. I was immediately put on heavy-duty antibiotics to attack the infection, and the abscess was drained through a surgical procedure. I felt so much better immediately and began the road to recovery.”.

Missing for 160 years, a painting by the French master Jean-Antoine Watteau has been found in a private home in England and will be sold at a Christie’s auction in London on July 8, when it is expected to fetch $3 million to $5 million, Reuters reported. The painting, “La Surprise” (about 1718), depicts a seated actor playing a guitar and glancing to his right at a couple amorously embracing. It was last noted in a probate valuation in 1848, when it was bequeathed to the family of the current owners, who had no idea what they had. A spokesman for Christie’s said, “It was found during a routine valuation in the corner of a small sitting room in an English country house.” The only other known version of the painting is a copy in the Royal Collection at Buckingham Palace. The current record price for a Watteau is $4.75 million.

After 19 years with the Maryinsky Ballet Company of St. Petersburg, Russia, Monika the donkey, above, has retired, Reuters reported. At a farewell party given by the Maryinsky, Monika, 21, waltzed with one of the company’s ballerinas and was given a carrot cake, a pinafore and a kerchief. Monika’s principal role was in “Don Quixote,” carrying Quixote’s overweight servant, Sancho Panza. “She loves to perform, and she loves applause,” said Tatyana Solomatina, a spokeswoman for the St. Petersburg zoo, which is home to Monika between performances. “She knew the exact time to appear in the ballet, even without someone accompanying her.” Monika will be succeeded by Alina.

The record label that is home to Amy Winehouse and Eminem is now home as well to a group of Gregorian chanting monks. The monks from the Abbey of the Holy Cross, who number Pope Benedict XVI among their fans, have been signed by Universal Records, Reuters reported. Though they are based at the world’s second-oldest Cistercian monastery, established in 1133 and 10 miles west of Vienna, the monks were discovered in a very modern way, by responding via YouTube to advertisements seeking medieval chanters. They beat more than 100 other entries from around the world. The monks’ spokesman, Father Karl Wallner, said they answered the ad for fun. “But now it has become a very serious and positive thing for us, because Gregorian chant is an expression of our spirituality; it’s how we pray,” he said. “We’re not Robbie Williams or Michael Jackson; we’re just a group of monks who sing every day because it’s our prayer and it’s our life.” The first album is scheduled for release by summer.

Opponents of a plan to move the Barnes Foundation and its world-renowned art collection from a Philadelphia suburb to a downtown site asked a Pennsylvania judge on Monday to reconsider his 2004 decision allowing the relocation. Lawyers for the Friends of the Barnes Foundation, a community group, and for the government of Montgomery County, where the Barnes has been since its founding in the late 1920s, appeared before the judge, Stanley R. Ott of the Montgomery County Orphans’ Court in Norristown, to request that he reopen the case. Judge Ott’s ruling in 2004 permitted the foundation, which has struggled financially, to bypass the charter and bylaws of its founder, Albert C. Barnes, who stipulated that no picture in his collection could be lent, sold or moved from the walls of the galleries that he built in Merion. The judge said he considered the move “the only viable alternative” to save the Barnes from bankruptcy. But the opponents contend that the collection’s financial troubles have been overstated and that new ways to raise the money to prevent a move have emerged. The county has offered, for example, to buy the foundation’s buildings and land for $50 million or more to keep the collection in place. But lawyers for the foundation and for the Pennsylvania attorney general’s office argued before Judge Ott that the county’s plan had come too late and that it could expose the foundation to “extraordinary financial risk.”.

The Grammy Award-winning Tejano singer Emilio Navaira was in critical condition on Monday after he and seven other passengers aboard his band’s bus were injured in a crash on a highway in Houston, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Navaira, 45, underwent surgery at Memorial Hermann Hospital to remove a blood clot in his head, said Joe Casias, his agent. “The next 24 hours are very critical,” Mr. Casias added. The bus, carrying Mr. Navaira and his band, Rio, after a performance in a Houston nightclub on Saturday night, was the only vehicle involved in the crash, above, about 5 a.m. on Sunday. Mr. Navaira won the 2003 Grammy for best Tejano album for “Acuérdate.”.

WILKINS--Iris. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Iris Wilkins, who expressed an unwavering commitment to strengthening the New York Jewish community. Iris's philanthropic spirit will continue to touch the lives of many for years to come. We extend our condolences to the Wilkins and Kwiat families, and to Zeke Cooper. John M. Shapiro, President Jerry W. Levin, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO WILKINS--Iris. Our family is mourning the loss of our beloved mother and grandmother, Iris Wilkins. She was our matriarch who shared her extraordinary zest for life with all of us. Through her example, Iris taught us the importance of family and the true meaning of generosity. Her elegance and style were unmatched and her love for her family was unparalleled. A true survivor, Iris fought to end with the same grace that defined her life. Her legacy will live on with each and every one of us. With all our love, Fern and Lowell Kwiat, Laurie and Stuart Wilkins and all the grandchildren WILKINS--Iris, ''We make a living by what we get, we make a life by what we give.'' Iris gave so much, and your families will have her gifts forever. With all our love, Lisa, Jeffrey, Alix and Brittany Jurick WILKINS--Iris. We are profoundly saddened by the loss of our ''Aunt'' Iris. Her intellect and sense of humor touched all of us who were fortunate enough to know her. Her grace and courage through this devastating illness will be an inspiration to all who loved her. Our deepest condolences to the Wilkins and Kwiat families and Zeke Cooper. Marc and Ellen, Eric and Lisa, Beth and Peter, Adam, Jill, Max, Jake, Luke, Jonathan, Alexander and Zachary

BAUM--Eileen, 63. Allure magazine mourns the loss of our esteemed research director, who died on March 23, after a valiant battle with breast cancer. Born in Brooklyn, Eileen studied at the School of American Ballet and graduated from New York University. Before joining Allure in 1990, she worked at Vogue, Vanity Fair, and in the film industry in Munich. In addition to her dedication to accuracy, we will remember her for her love of the sciences, classical music, and East Hampton; her fierce debating skills; and devotion to needy animals. Linda Wells Editor in Chief, Allure

WIESEN--Tobie A., passed away on March 23, 2008, a few days before her 97th birthday, six years after the passing of her husband Irving of 60 years. To the end she was gracious, engaging and considerate; sophisticated, insightful and articulate, whether it be in English, French, Spanish or Russian --all of which she spoke with fluency. She held herself to the highest level of integrity and respect for others --if you sent her a card she thanked you by letter; regardless of your age, Tobie addressed you by your last name and title until you permitted her to call you by your first name. Holding a masters degree in education and having studied piano at the Julliard School of Music, Tobie - Antoinette Wiesen, daughter of Julie and Aaron Mnuchin, daughter-in-law of Rose and Max Wiesen, was a teacher of children and also a founder of the Junior Committee of The National Council of Jewish Women. She loved her son Jeremy, her grandson Gavin, her cousin Simone Rosen, her stepdaughter Barbara Prager; Barbara's daughters Karen and Emily, Karen's husband Will Balliett and their daughters Adelaide and Charlotte; and her many friends including Belinda Brackenridge, Bill Prager and Cynthia Witter. Her long devoted care-givers, Princessa Manuel, Dorothy Robinson and Irena Ivanov served lovingly like daughters for many years; and, Dr. Leonard Raifman was on-call as if he were treating his own mother. Tobie Wiesen cherished her brother; her brothers-and sisters-in-law; and nephews, nieces and their children --hardly forgetting a birthday. Relatives; neighbors; friends of Jeremy and Gavin; employees and colleagues; all learned from the hundreds of proverbs, Shakespearean soliloquies, poems and sonnets that Tobie would teach us; and her short-cuts for conjugating the subjunctive for pluperfect verbs in French and Spanish. Today, it is comforting to remember especially, ''en casa de tia, pero no cada dia''; ''petit a petit, loiseau fait son nit''; and a maxim of Pushkin by which she lived: ''If you have a thousand friends it is not too many; but one enemy is too much.'' Even in her later years, she firmly believed one's spirits should never falter so long as they have the beauty of poetry to lift them, often reciting from one of her favorites, William Wordsworths ''Daffodils'': ''For oft, when on my couch I lie In vacant or in pensive mood They flash upon that inward eye Which is the bliss of solitude; And then my heart with pleasure fills, And dances with the daffodils.''

SCHOENFELD--Erika, 81 years young died unexpectedly on Sunday, March 23. Survived by sons, Mark and Peter, daughter Andrea Fishberger, Mark and Andrea's spouses, Cindy and Steve, grandchildren Amy, Elyse, Jill, Mallory, Rebecca, Gregory and Haley, sister Trudy Owett, plus nephews, nieces, Sylvia Raynor, extended family, and friends. Predeceased by beloved husband, Jerry, it is hard to describe the impact Erika's larger than life personality, generosity and love had on her children, grandchildren and other survivors, who loved her deeply and greatly. Their loss and grief is huge. The Funeral Service will be at 1pm on Wednesday, March 26, at Temple Judea, 333 Searingtown Rd. Manhasset (exit 36 on the LIE, and turn North). Those wishing to visit the family can do so Wednesday and Thursday from 6 to 9pm, call 212-673-6282 after 1pm for details. Donations in Erika's memory may be made to: The Jewish Foundation for the Righteous. www.jfr.org

BAILEY--Walter Ronald, of New York City died of prostate cancer on March 23, 2008 at the age of 65. Born September 3, 1942 in Brooklyn, New York, he was the only son of the late Dorothy and Walter Bruce Bailey. He was raised in Syosset, NY and was a graduate of St. Dominic High School, Villanova University and Cornell University Law School. He also had an LLM degree in taxation from New York University. He was with the F.B.I. before becoming a trusts and estates attorney in Manhattan. He was a member of the University Club and Winged Foot Golf Club. Walter was an avid oenophile and golfer. He is survived by his beloved wife of twenty years, Jane Watson Bailey, sister Carol Ann Weston and brother-in-law Paul of Colchester, Connecticut and a niece Beth Meekins and nephew, David Weston. The funeral service will be held on Thursday, March 27, at 12 noon at Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home, 352 East 87 St. after which a reception will be held at the University Club. After cremation, interment will take place at a later date, at Greenwood Cemetery, Rye, New York in the Bayles family plot of his wife.

Senator Barack Obama escaped the campaign trail for a short vacation in the Virgin Islands, but he couldn't escape cable news. Walking on a beach in St. Thomas on Sunday, Mr. Obama was spotted by a family of American tourists, including a 6-year-old girl who asked him to pose for a photo with her. He obliged, and the girl's family promptly sent the photo to Fox News, where it was shown Monday throughout the day.

(CW) BEAUTY AND THE GEEK In the first episode the geeks were sad to learn that they would be working against, not with, the beauties this season. Instead of being paired up and rooming with a good-looking member of the opposite sex, they are right where they started: hanging with other geeks. Perhaps the personal growth the show promises will be stunted this time around? In tonight's episode the teams go head to head in a football game, and it's hard to tell who has the advantage, the skinny nerds or the ditsy women.

A protracted nominating campaign and unreliable Senate schedules have made it difficult for the presidential candidates to make it back to Washington to vote. So difficult, in fact, that Senator John McCain of Arizona has missed more than half of the roll-call votes since January 2007, more than any other senator except Senator Tim Johnson of South Dakota, who spent most of 2007 recuperating from a brain hemorrhage. When Mr. McCain ran for president in 1999-2000, he missed just 30 percent of the Senate votes. Still, Mr. McCain has a long way to go to match the number of votes Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts missed when he ran for president in 2003-4: 72 percent. He led the entire Senate, followed by Senator John Edwards of North Carolina, who missed nearly half the votes.

BERNIKER--Deborah. With deep and heartfelt sorrow Horace Mann School mourns the passing of Deborah Berniker, beloved wife of HM Coach and faculty member Neil Berniker, loving mother of J. Scott Berniker '87 and Eric Berniker '90, daughtersin-law Michelle L. Berniker and Jennifer Berniker, and adoring grandmother. Deborah (Debby) Berniker was a treasured member of the HM community. Her children's academic and athletic activities and her husband's 44year coaching career were felt by all the members of our community. She continued to share her warmth and support throughout the Horace Mann School community even as she began her heroic battle with ALS over seven years ago. Deborah Berniker inspired hundreds in our community and beyond as she faced her illness with courage and without complaint, and as she lived as fully as possible for the joys of being with her family and friends, and watching her grandchildren grow. The courage she inspired in her family, as well, and the respect, love, and care with which the Bernikers faced the challenge of ALS will always resonate in our community. May our memories of Deborah be a source of consolation to us all. Our sincere condolences, thoughts and love are with Deborah's family and friends in this time of profound sadness. Funeral services, March 25, 2008, noon, Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 1652 Central Park Avenue, Yonkers, NY 10710, 914-793-3800. Dr. Thomas M. Kelly, Head of School Steven M. Friedman '72 Chair, Board of Trustees

LAMPTON--Elizabeth Whitcomb. Born November 27, 1933 died March 22, 2008 after a carriage accident at Elmendorf Farm. She and her husband Dinwiddie Lampton Jr. lived at Elmendorf and enjoyed driving horses on their farm. They competed together in many events. They met in Saratoga Springs when Elizabeth was driving her beloved horse Saint and Dinwiddie a Four in Hand. She asked him to hold her horse, and he was at her command thereafter. She graduated from the University of Vermont. Elizabeth was crowned Miss Vermont which lead her to competing in the Miss Universe Pageant. Her love for horses came from her father who was a lifelong Stander bred Horseman in New England. Among her most recent and proud accomplishments at the age of 72 was the winning of a Ladies' Phaeton Carriage Class at the Indiana State Fair. This was obtained with a pair of Hackney Horses that she personally trained. She was a director of the American Hackney Horse Foundation and the past Director of the Carriage and Coaching Museum of America. During her career while living in New York City, Elizabeth was the first woman to sell Mercedes Benz. She was voted top salesperson in the country several times for her Park Avenue Location. She served as the President of the Condominium Association of the Dorchester on 57th and Park at which in time she lived. Elizabeth also took great pride in the restoration of the Whipton Place Farm in Lexington, KY. She is survived by her devoted husband Dinwiddie Lampton Jr., brother Robert Whitcomb of Vermont and niece May Armstrong of Vermont. A memorial service will be held at Elmendorf Farm by the Columns at Two o'clock Tuesday, March 25th, 2008: The family will gather for a private burial at Cave Hill Cemetery in Louisville, Wednesday, March 26th 2008 at 1pm. Services under the direction of Pearson's. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Kentucky Horse Park Foundation for the Carriage Museum.

Democratic registration in Pennsylvania hit a record of more than four million voters on Monday, the last day to register before the primary on April 22. ''It's kind of incredible,'' said Harry A. VanSickle, the state's elections commissioner. ''It's the first time we know of that a party in Pennsylvania has gone over four million.''

The San Francisco 49ers lost twice with linebacker Lance Briggs, failing to sign him in free agency and forfeiting their fifth-round draft pick in next month's draft after N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell determined Monday that the Niners had tampered with Briggs, a violation of league rules. The 49ers and the Bears will also exchange their picks in the third round, giving the Bears San Francisco's seventh pick, while the Niners will get the Bears' pick at No. 12. Briggs was with the Bears last season when reports surfaced that the 49ers had had contact with Briggs's agent, Drew Rosenhaus. The Bears had made Briggs their franchise player in 2007, and Briggs, who was angered by the move, stated he would not return to the Bears after he played out his one-year contract. But Briggs re-signed with the Bears this month. In the meantime, the Bears filed a tampering charge with the league.

PICKER--Harvey. A physicist, inventor, businessman, educator, philosopher and friend died on March 22 at age 92. Mr. Picker ran Picker X-ray Company for 25 years. He was a well-known inventor of x-ray technology and groundbreaking developments including cobalt therapy for cancer, nuclear imaging diagnostics and the use of ultrasound for oceanography, which was adapted for medical imaging. Along with his wife Jean, an ambassador to the U.N. in the 1960s, now deceased, he then founded the Picker Institute, a nonprofit dedicated to advancing the principles of patient-centered care and pioneered the systematic collection of data from hospital patients to help improve the delivery of medical services in the U.S. and Europe. Mr. Picker also taught at his alma mater, Colgate University, and served as the dean of the School of International and Public Affairs at Columbia University. He also helped found the Picker Engineering Program at Smith College, his wife's alma mater. He is survived by two daughters, Bobbi Hamill of Boston, MA and Gale Jean Picker of Seattle, WA, as well as three grandchildren, Jean Picker Larsen, Evelyn Picker Larsen and Matthew James Mrachek. A memorial service will be held in Camden, ME in early June.

VANCE--Grace Sloane. The staff and advisory board of the Cyrus R. Vance Center for International Justice mourn the passing of Grace Sloane Vance, a strong supporter of the Center's work to advance access to justice globally. Her commitment to promoting a just and equitable society will be greatly missed. Our hearts go out to her children and grandchildren at this sad time. VANCE--Grace Sloane, (known as ''Gay''), beloved wife of the late Cyrus R.Vance, passed away on Saturday March 22, 2008. A native New Yorker, Gay's family founded the W&J Sloane furniture company. Gay was a full partner in her husband's very public life. During their time in Washington, DC, she was a true ''first lady'' of the State Department, looking after the welfare of state department families. In her own right, Gay was a civic leader dedicated to promoting human equality and opportunity as Vice-Chairman of the Board and then President of the New York Urban League, and to expanding arts and education through public television in New York City as a board member and later Vice-Chairman of the Board of WNET Channel 13. Numerous non-profit organizations and corporate boards, including W. R. Grace & Company, Colgate University and the National Urban League sought out Gay for her common sense, strong intellect and integrity. Gay was devoted to her family. She is survived by her two sisters, Nancy Coates of Ardmore, Pennsylvania and Evelyn Pyne of Far Hills, New Jersey. Gay lost her cherished daughter, Amy Sloane Vance, just two weeks ago to cancer. Gay will be missed by her three daughters, Elsie Nicoll Vance, Camilla Vance Holmes and Grace Roberts Vance, her son, Cyrus R. Vance, Jr., her grandchildren Simon and Clare Vance, step-grandson Kemal Askar, daughter-inlaw Peggy Vance, and sonsin-law Attila Askar and William Holmes, as well as by a large community of loving and diverse friends from around the world and across many generations whom she inspired. Services will be held this Saturday, March 29, 2008 at 4pm at the Church of the Heavenly Rest at 90th Street and Fifth Avenue. In lieu of flowers, Gay asked that any donations be sent to the Vance Center for International Justice Initiatives, which provides support to lawyers around the globe to expand access to justice, and to ensure a fair and equitable judicial system, c/o New York City Bar, 42 West 44th Street, New York, NY 10036-6689.

James Carville, a political adviser to the Clintons, said Monday that he stood by his comment on Good Friday in which he compared Gov. Bill Richardson of New Mexico to Judas for his endorsement of Senator Barack Obama. Though a Clinton campaign aide said that if he were Mr. Carville he would apologize, Mr. Carville himself, right, declared: ''I was quoted accurately and in context, and I was glad to give the quote, and I was glad I gave it. I'm not apologizing, I'm not resigning, I'm not doing anything.''

Brier, President and CEO Maimonides Medical Center GROB--David, M.D. The Medical Staff of Maimonides Medical Center is deeply saddened by the death of Dr. David Grob. Dr. Grob was a physician at Maimonides for over 50 years. He served as Chairman of the Department of Medicine from 1958-1989. He was Medical Director of the Maimonides Research and Development Foundation from 1982-present. He also served as Director of Research and Education and Medical Education at Maimonides. He was one of the noted experts in Myasthenia Gravis. He was one of the original physicians with the U.S. Army during World War II to liberate the Concentration Camps. He will be sorely missed by all his colleagues, patients and friends. Sincere condolences are extended to his entire family. W. Wexelman, M.D., Pres S. Farber M.D., Pres-Elect H. Wasserman, M.D., Secy E. Fitzpatrick, M.D., Treas GROB--David, M.D. The members of the Maimonides Medical Center, Department of Medicine, record with sadness the death of David Grob, M.D. Dr. Grob was Chairman of our Department and led it to a position of academic and educational prominence from 1958 to 1989. From 1989 until his retirement in 2006, he served as Medical Director of the Maimonides Research and Development Foundation. He was an internationally recognized expert in neuromuscular diseases and myasthenia gravis. We extend our condolences to his children, Charles, Susan, Emily and Philip and his grandchildren. About 173,500 adult New Yorkers became obese and more than 73,000 received new diagnoses of diabetes from 2002 to 2004, according to a new study by the New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene. Put another way, “the citywide weight gain totaled more than 10 million pounds in just two years,” the city noted in a news release summarizing the study, which is being published in the April issue of Preventing Chronic Disease, a medical journal published by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

My Thursday column is about the duel for the Democratic nomination. I argue that Senator Clinton has only a minimal chance of winning the nomination -- but a fair chance of creating such discord in the Democratic Party that John McCain can claim the White House. You see that in the exit polls, in which Obama and Clinton supporters said back in January that they would be perfectly happy if the other person ended up as the nominee -- while now they are much less happy with the other person and in some cases they say they would vote for McCain.

As the regulars at Shifting Careers know, we've been doing a lot of talking about health insurance for the self-employed since my initial post, Health Insurance for the Self-Employed, and a follow-up post, The Minefield of Health Insurance, a few weeks later. While it is shameful that adequate and affordable health insurance is so difficult to find that it affects people's career choices, I did find one bright light in researching this subject. People are willing to share information in a way that genuinely helps others, that is until the government or private industry steps up with some better solutions.

Over in the Book Review's Reading Room, we're talking about Tom Wolfe's "Bonfire of the Vanities." One of the big questions: How does the book hold up today, as rooted as it is in close observations of late 1980s New York? Is it a period piece best read as a work of urban history? Or did Wolfe capture the timeless spirit of the city (or, for that matter, the fundamental nature of man)?

"Crapulence" - that word appeared this month in our review of Scott Spencer's book "Willing," and when I came across it during an edit, its first four letters sent me straight to the dictionary. The Times's bearers of standards wrinkle their noses at words excremental, and I was pretty certain I'd have to make a note to the author ("Sorry, bud, no 'crapu-etc.' in The Times"). But to my delight, the word turned out not to be unsavory at all, and was instead an unusual way of referring to "excessive drinking" (or, in the context of the review - in which it appeared as "sexual crapulence" - excessive anything). Excellent! I wrote a very different note: "This is my new favorite word."

Is recombinant bovine somatotropin (rBST, more commonly called bovine growth hormone, or BGH) on its way out? Once considered inevitable, it has met with so much consumer resistance that its use is in decline. And as this story demonstrates, that resistance is as middle-of-the-road as Hot Pockets. I'm not sure this is a "victory" for sustainable agriculture or anything else -- and I think the beginning of this story is hyperbole of the first order -- but it's a sign of the power American consumers have. What's next? Grass-fed beef at McDonald's?
NBC may borrow a fourth show from the stable of its cable network USA.
The Associated Press reports:

Unlike James and Joyce (nice phrase, that), I have little experience of New York itself. I left Harlem when I was six, and have rarely spent two days in the city since. I cannot join the debate on whether "The Bonfire of the Vanities" was - or is - in some sense the quintessential New York novel. So I will, with apologies, slip off on a tangent.

Would Hillary Clinton gain politically by distancing herself from pro-choice activists? "Clinton does have one group of political activists to whom she is especially indebted," writes Michael Sean Winters at In All Things, the editorial blog of America, the national Jesuit weekly. "Pro-choice groups like NARAL, NOW and Emily's List have been the base of her fundraising and organizational support. They have sent e-mails and placed phone calls to voters in key primary states questioning Obama's commitment to Roe v. Wade."

It's a full day of internationals Wednesday -- friendlies and not-so-friendlies. In the latter category, North Korea and South Korea were forced to play their World Cup qualifying match at a neutral venue after FIFA ruled Pyongyang too inhospitable for sport. The Democratic People's Republic of Korea refused to play the Republic of Korea's national anthem or allow the South Korean flag to be flown on their turf. So, the teams played in Shanghai where they drew 0-0.

Aired Tuesday night on "The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson" on CBS: Hillary Clinton has been caught telling a lie about a trip she took to Bosnia, and the whistle-blower was Sinbad, the comedian. Nothing says great journalism like the co-star of "Jingle All The Way."

In a speech setting out his worldview, Senator John McCain reiterated his opposition to withdrawing troops from Iraq at this time, and drew a stark line between his presidential candidacy and the Democrats' ideas.
In anticipation of its upfront presentation on Wednesday, USA has revealed four of the projects on its development slate. But viewers will not see any of the shows for years, if ever.
Is there a shortage of air marshals, or is that a myth? It depends on whom you believe.

YouTube opens its tent to all kinds of folks -- from offbeat, off key and off kilter to the Old Gray Lady herself. So why not the I.R.S.? A USA Today article today on the tax agency's online video efforts quotes one of them -- the YouTube generation -- drawing the line:
CNBC reports on American Airlines's cancellation of more than 200 flights in order to check plane wiring.

Louisiana State defensive tackle Glenn Dorsey is working out in front of more than 100 N.F.L. coaches and scouts today at the school's pro day. But nothing he does in the 40-yard dash, vertical jump or bench press will eliminate the nagging questions about whether he can stay healthy through a professional season.
Detroit struck first.

Dear Readers, you may post nasty comments at times, but deep down you're wonderfully benevolent, joyful souls -- well, at least many of you who responded to last week's invitation to fill out a survey.

Every indicator you can think of is pointing to a real crisis in food in the coming years, as you can see from this lovely series of charts from the BBC (hat tip to Suzanne Lenzer). Food prices are up; ethanol production is up, which will put further pressure on grain prices; population growth continues apace, as has been well publicized.
CNBC coverage of Treasury Secretary Henry Paulson's speech in which he discusses the possibility of new federal oversight for Wall Street investment houses.
The following is the text as prepared for delivery of Senator John McCain’s speech on foreign policy to the Los Angeles World Affairs Council, as provided by his presidential campaign.
Al Qaeda's latest tape has just dropped, so what's the verdict of the hipster music site Pitchfork? From 236.com:

The first summer that I ever spent in Hong Kong, I lived in a pricey serviced apartment that charged $100 extra a month for linen service. I figured I could buy my own linen for less than the cost of the rental, so I set out one day in search of inexpensive bedsheets, towels and comforters. But where to go?
The Jam column presents fashion's latest soundtracks.
In The High Low column, T's fashion team roll up their Balenciaga sleeves to rummage for the cheap and the chic.

Today's Minimalist column (and don't forget the video) is about fermented black beans, which, needless to say, I messed around with quite a bit in the course of putting together that piece. I love them with clams; to make them, just follow the shrimp recipe, cooking the clams -- hard shells only, please -- until they pop, at which point they'll release a bunch of liquid. They're also great with cut-up pork, cubes of tofu, especially pre-cooked, scallops, and so on.

Adding his own twist to the Latin American strongman railing against American policies, President Manuel Zelaya of Honduras began talking to journalists on Tuesday. "Here I have the box of melons," he said, according to CNN. "Permit me to make a demonstration."

It wasn't that long ago--10 years at most--that consumers would blanch at spending $800 for a large-screen traditional picture tube TV. But today, with CRT TVs nearing extinction (even Costco doesn't stock them any longer), many customers seem perfectly happy with plunking down even $2,000 for a wide-screen HDTV.
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
The increasingly ferocious standoff between Senators Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama could take a toll in November, says a new survey from Gallup:

Aired Tuesday night on CBS: Here's news from Hollywood. You know Pamela Anderson? Well, she recently had her marriage annulled. The marriage lasted two months. I mean, she goes through husbands like New York goes through governors.

On Wednesday, the Ford Motor Company agreed to sell its Jaguar and Land Rover brands to Tata Motors in India. Tata will pay Ford $2.3 billion -- or $200 million less than what Ford paid for Jaguar alone in 1989 -- while Ford will contribute $600 million for the Jaguar-Land Rover pension fund.
The fighting threatened to destabilize a long-term truce that had helped reduce violence in the five-year-old Iraq war.

Britain's financial services regulator admitted Wednesday that it had done a poor job of supervising Northern Rock, the mortgage lender which became Britain's most prominent victim of the subprime mortgage crisis.
.. And pretty much the forecast every day in Haiti:

Pedro Martinez was showing off a photograph this morning of him and a boy, maybe 13 at the time, that was taken 15 or 16 years ago. Pedro was skinnier then, about 155 pounds, and he wore a blue satin Dodgers jacket and a Dodgers cap. The boy wore a gold Florida State hat and a Northampton baseball T-shirt.

Citigroup has agreed to pay Enron creditors $1.66 billion as the final part of a settlement of a lawsuit over banks' responsibility in the energy trading firm's downfall, a group representing creditors said on Wednesday.

Sometimes extreme books can be more clarifying than careful ones. A few years ago Michael Scheuer had a surprise best-seller with a fierce, angry polemic about United States foreign policy, "Imperial Hubris," which he published anonymously because he was a high-level C.I.A. agent at the time. Now, as a professor at Georgetown, he writes under his own name, and he seems just as angry, maybe more so.

Aired Tuesday night on NBC: The White House has announced that during President Bush's last year in office, he's going to visit more countries than in any other year of his Presidency. Bush says he's going to accomplish all of this in one weekend by going to Epcot Center.
Aired Tuesday night on NBC: I'm a little upset. You know, Hillary Clinton was supposed to be our first guest tonight, but she got pinned down by sniper fire and was not able to come in.
Lots of us have bought a car that turned out to be a lemon and then been forced to sell it at a loss. For Ford Motor Company, though, the loss had nine zeroes after it.
The United States men's national team will be outfitted with new black away jerseys (and shorts and socks) for its friendly match in Poland on Wednesday. And you have to wonder: What's going on here?
While Michael Beasley toils over whether to become filthy rich now or next year, feel lucky that you don't have such difficult decisions hanging over your head.

See, this is what happens when you don't have a primary for a few weeks: the traveling press is getting bored. "[W]e're in the phase of the campaign I don't find especially interesting," The New Republic's Noam Scheiber writes at The Stump, his magazine's campaign blog. He continues:
Reuters reports:
Fed up with being excluded from the debates and otherwise marginalized, former Senator Mike Gravel of Alaska announced today that he will seek the Libertarian Party nomination for president.

An action movie hero turned governor fires a Hollywood icon turned parks commissioner over a project that pits his constituents' hopelessly irreconcilable passions for cars and beaches against one another. And as an added bonus, the news arrives with a perfect sound bite. That's California politics, sweetheart:

Back from vacation in the Virgin Islands, Senator Barack Obama hits the road right away -- today in North Carolina -- and just as quickly he has several issues confronting him. In a brief chat with reporters before leaving the islands, he said the economy would be uppermost on his mind. And his new schedule boasts a "major speech" on the economy set for Thursday in New York.
Eric Ripert, a four-star seafood chef, takes on a 99-cent frozen salmon fillet.
India's Tata Motors says it will acquire British automakers Jaguar and Land Rover from the Ford Motor Company for $2.3 billion, sealing a long-expected deal for the luxury car lines.
Motorola said Wednesday that it would split itself into two publicly traded companies as it struggles to boost its stock price and faces pressure from activist investor Carl C. Icahn.

Deutsche Bank's shares fell Wednesday in Europe after the German banking group warned that a business slowdown and possible write-downs could make it hard to achieve its profit goal for the year. The shaky outlook suggested that Deutsche Bank, which managed to avoid taking any write-downs related to subprime mortgages in the fourth quarter, is not out of the woods yet.
One of Citigroup's most persistent critics hasn't changed her negative view on the stumbling financial giant.
[UPDATE, 4/16: Libby Rosenthal has gone into the field to explore soot in the kitchen and greenhouse.]
A used T-shirt bearing the Bear Stearns logo has sold for $151.76 online, worth about 14 or 15 shares in the once venerable Wall Street investment bank, Reuters reported.

In a move that has apparently left peHUB's Dan Primack "confused", Chicago-based private equity firm Willis Stein & Partners is pre-marketing its fourth fund, just weeks after its largest-ever investment, Ziff Davis, filed for bankruptcy protection.

The London Stock Exchange's share price has hit nearly a four-year low, sparking fresh takeover rumors for the exchange that has been coveted by everyone from the Deutsche Borse to the Nasdaq Stock Market, Financial News reported.
Brazil's Vale, the world's largest iron ore miner, said that talks to buy Swiss rival Xstrata had failed and that Vale would look at other potential takeover targets.

Fortress Investment Group, the alternative asset manager that Tuesday reported a $29 million loss for the fourth quarter, aims to raise $15 to $20 billion in new capital this year to help the hedge fund and private-equity firm pounce on opportunities created by the global credit crunch, Chief Executive Wes Edens said on Tuesday.

The embattled financial sector took another hit on Tuesday as JPMorgan Chase and UBS cut their earnings forecasts for Merrill Lynch and said they expect the Wall Street firm to disclose more write-downs.
The $19.5 billion sale of the radio broadcaster Clear Channel Communications to two private equity firms is in jeopardy.

Drawing a sharp distinction between himself and the two Democratic presidential candidates, Senator John McCain of Arizona warned Tuesday against vigorous government action to solve the deepening mortgage crisis and the market turmoil it has caused, saying that "it is not the duty of government to bail out and reward those who act irresponsibly, whether they are big banks or small borrowers."

Liffe, the London-based futures and options exchange, has turned up the heat on rivals including Rainbow, the planned European derivatives exchange backed by investment banks and brokers, by confirming it plans to launch a clearinghouse, a move that will hit its existing supplier LCH.Clearnet.
JPMorgan Chase agreed the acquisition of carbon offset provider ClimateCare for an undisclosed sum, the two businesses said in a joint statement.
Shares of Thornburg Mortgage, a provider of jumbo mortgages that is trying to stave off a bankruptcy filing, rose 36 percent on Tuesday after the company disclosed plans to raise $1.35 billion.

In most families artifacts such as childhood videos are merely heirlooms, their value measured in memories. For the Hollywood talent agency Creative Artists Agency and the hedge fund Pequot Capital, however, these are assets to be exploited.

Pequot Capital Management is in launch mode as the $6.5 billion hedge fund firm prepares to debut its second hedge fund of the year. The Connecticut multi-strategy shop is launching the Pequot New Vision Fund on April 1 with $18.1 million in assets, according to FINalternatives.
Malaysia's biggest lender, Malayan Banking, is set to buy a controlling stake in Bank Internasional Indonesia, or BII, for $1.5 billion, gaining a foothold in Southeast Asia's biggest economy.
Caterpillar, the world's largest maker of earthmoving machinery, will take control of a 44-year-old Japanese venture with Mitsubishi Heavy Industries to help expand in Asia.
Bio-Imaging Technologies said it bought Phoenix Data Systems, a privately held provider of clinical data services, for $24 million in cash and stock.
AES, a worldwide power-plant developer, announced Tuesday that it will partner with private-equity firm Riverstone Holdings to invest up to $1 billion in solar energy projects around the world.
Merrill Lynch and Morgan Stanley were sued on Tuesday by clients accusing them of deceptively marketing auction rate securities.
Value Partners Group, Asia's second-largest hedge fund manager, said 2007 profit surged 66 percent on growing assets.

South Korea said on Wednesday it has started the sale of Daewoo Shipbuilding and Marine Engineering, the world's No. 3 shipbuilder, by putting up a 50.4 percent stake worth $3.6 billion at current market prices.

The Bank of China and the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China posted higher fourth-quarter profits Tuesday, buoyed by the country's surging economy but dragged down by holdings in American subprime-related securities.
A former major leaguer looks back at the joys and hardships of baseball's spring training.

Economists these days are raving about the continued growth of "cross border transactions," the movement of investment money from country to country. Even with the much-discussed property slowdown, the amount of money flowing around the world is at unprecedented levels, they say, bolstering markets and creating quick run ups.
Properties on the market in Florida, California and Texas.
Images from exhibitions in Berlin about the work of the artist Heinrich Zille.
Many daily newspapers have chosen not to dispatch reporters to cover the leading Democratic candidates on a regular basis.
“Shotgun Stories” defines the classic western phrase “doing what a man’s got to do” as both a moral imperative and a biological compulsion.
Alexander Sokurov’s “Alexandra” feels like a communiqué from another time, another place, anywhere but here.
Little guidance is offered to parents on teaching teenagers about the pleasures of wine with a meal without endorsing reckless behavior.
Regulators are investigating Visa Europe to determine whether the fees it charges on cross-border transactions within the European Union break laws against price fixing.
“Improper” practices by New Century Financial were condoned and enabled by KPMG, according to an independent investigation.
For many businesses and workers who are paid in dollars or dollar-linked currencies, the depreciating currency is a sure sign of tougher economic times ahead in Asia and globally.
Seeking to put its legal problems behind it as it confronts larger financial ones, Citigroup became the last of 11 financial institutions to resolve Enron claims going back to 2003.
The shuttle landed at 8:39 p.m., roughly an hour after Capt. Dominic L. Gorie fired twin braking rockets that brought the spacecraft out of orbit.
Senator John McCain made his case for continuing the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan in a major foreign policy speech.
Under pressure to raise its stock price, the company plans to split itself in two, spinning off its unprofitable mobile phone unit.
Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. defended the takeover even as he called for more transparency on the part of Wall Street.
Oil prices jumped $4 a barrel after a government report showed larger-than-expected drops in U.S. fuel stocks. Gold futures rose to $947.50 an ounce in late-morning trading.
Excavations in a cave in the mountains of northern Spain have uncovered the oldest known remains of human ancestors in Western Europe, scientists reported.
New data suggested Europe was fairing better than many analysts had expected, but officials warned that a slowdown was probably inevitable.
A small business expert advises people who want to take the leap and become entrepreneurs to follow the ancient Greek maxim: know thyself.
Richard Widmark created a villain in his first movie role who was so repellent and frightening that the actor became a star overnight.
The $2.3 billion purchase price is more than the market expected but still about half what Ford originally paid for the luxury brands several years ago.
Xcor Aerospace’s co-founder said the first version would be flying by 2010 and reach an altitude of 38 miles.
Citigroup is the last of 11 banks to settle with Enron creditors in litigation known as “MegaClaims,” stemming from the downfall of the energy trading company.
The drug company has agreed to pay $15 million to the state of Alaska to settle a lawsuit claiming that its schizophrenia drug Zyprexa caused patients to develop diabetes.
India’s Tata Motors will acquire Jaguar and Land Rover in a deal that will net the struggling American automaker about $1.7 billion — roughly a third of the price it paid for the two luxury brands.
A pair of pessimistic reports on home sales and business spending reminded investors about the precarious state of the economy.
Orders to factories for big-ticket manufactured goods fell for a second consecutive month in February, providing more evidence of an economic slowdown.
The fighting threatened to destabilize a long-term truce that had helped reduce violence in the five-year-old Iraq war.

Denver Broncos receiver Brandon Marshall could miss up to four months of off-season preparations after slicing his right forearm in a freak accident. After initially playing down the injury that required surgery, Marshall has acknowledged it was the result of horseplay with family members and a misplaced fast-food bag. He said he slipped on the bag Saturday while wrestling with family members at a Florida resort and put his right arm through a home entertainment center.

Pacman Jones went on Michael Irvin’s radio show and spoke about the Tennessee Titans in the past tense. Equal parts contrite and defiant in discussing his six arrests since being drafted three years ago, he said he wanted to be a Cowboy and expressed confidence that Commissioner Roger Goodell would reinstate him.

A former chemist for the Bay Area Laboratory Co-Operative testified in a San Francisco courtroom that he had provided the former cyclist Tammy Thomas with designer steroids, directly contradicting her grand jury testimony.
Two men were killed in Brooklyn in separate encounters, the police said on Tuesday.
The Devils, who have put in only three goals in their last four games, were held scoreless by the Penguins on Tuesday.

The starting guard Rich Seubert signed a three-year extension with the Giants on Tuesday, keeping him under contract through 2012. Seubert’s career nearly ended in 2003 when his right leg was broken in three places in a game against Philadelphia. He had an operation and missed the 2004 season, then played in four games in 2005.
A woman was arrested Tuesday afternoon and accused of running a large prostitution ring on the East Side, the police said.
In stark contrast to the free-for-all the Rangers and the Flyers played in Philadelphia on Friday, the Flyers won a defensive battle in overtime on a goal by Mike Richards.
The mining giant Companhia Vale do Rio Doce said it had stopped negotiations to acquire the British-Swiss mining company Xstrata.
President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner refused to ease tax increases on agricultural exports, facing down angry farmers embroiled in a nationwide strike.
BP’s regulatory troubles in Russia deepened this week as authorities idled 148 expatriate engineers and geologists in a dispute over the legality of their work permits.

Japan’s trade surplus rose 0.9 percent in February from a year earlier, to 970 billion yen ($9.69 billion), in the first increase in four months, the Finance Ministry said. The trade surplus with the United States fell 13.3 percent, to 696.9 billion yen ($6.96 billion). The surplus with Asian nations including China jumped 104.8 percent, to 922.2 billion yen ($9.22 billion).
Retail sales posted a third straight month of big gains in January thanks to a cut in the federal sales tax and an appetite for new passenger cars.
Denmark, France and Italy began recalling stores of the blood-thinning drug heparin and any ingredients used in it that had originated in China.
Peru’s former president, Alberto K. Fujimori, had to be awakened by the judge at his murder and kidnapping trial.

About 70 cars and trucks slammed into each other in a heavy snowfall on a highway in northwestern Austria, killing a woman and injuring at least 37 other people, six seriously, the police said. The accident happened on the Seelwachen-to-St. Georgen stretch of the Vienna-Salzburg A1 Autobahn. The speed limit is 80 miles an hour.
Josh Howard scored 32 points and Jason Kidd neared a triple-double Tuesday as the host Dallas Mavericks beat the Los Angeles Clippers, 103-90.

Four hundred people were trapped on the London Eye for more than an hour while engineers fixed a mechanical fault, a spokeswoman for the tourist attraction said. The sightseers were suspended up to 450 feet above the ground on Monday night as workmen repaired one of the four huge tires that turn the observation wheel. Staff members spoke to the visitors over an intercom system, and they received offered water and blankets. They were also offered a refund.
A Finnish tourist was detained after the police said he broke off a piece of rock from the earlobe of one of the mysterious ancient giant statues on Easter Island.

Hundreds of soldiers from the African Union and Comoros seized rebel-held Anjouan, one of the three islands that make up the archipelago nation, and the government said its renegade leader, Col. Mohamed Bacar, had fled dressed as a woman.
With its speed, superior rebounding and 60 percent shooting from the floor (39 of 65), Connecticut routed Texas, 89-55, on Tuesday.
Marc-André Fleury made 31 saves Tuesday night for his fourth shutout of the season and the Pittsburgh Penguins clinched a playoff berth with a 2-0 victory over the Devils.
The seven crew members are scheduled to land at 7:05 p.m., Wednesday.
Sanctions against a pharmacist who refused to dispense birth control pills to a woman and would not transfer her prescription elsewhere where upheld.
Mayor Kwame M. Kilpatrick of Detroit was arraigned on eight felony charges, including perjury and official misconduct.
A motion filed in Sacramento County Superior Court says state corrections officials had no authority to re-arrest her after she was paroled last week.
A chunk of Antarctic ice about seven times the size of Manhattan suddenly collapsed, putting an even greater portion of glacial ice at risk.
Seven percent of their results from the March 4 primary so must be recounted so that a judge can find and fix problems in preparation for the general election.
Most of those pardoned had been convicted of drug offenses or white-collar crimes including embezzlement, mail fraud and falsifying a loan application.
The Houston Texans released center Steve McKinney, one of the franchise’s original players, and re-signed punter Matt Turk.

Tim Jitloff withstood a charge by the junior competitor Tommy Ford to win the giant slalom title at the United States Alpine Championships in Carrabassett Valley, Me. Jitloff led after the first run down the sun-splashed Narrow Gauge trail at Sugarloaf, then held off the 19-year-old Ford in the second run.

Dale Petroskey resigned as president of the baseball Hall of Fame on Tuesday after its board’s executive committee found he “failed to exercise proper fiduciary responsibility.” The Hall’s executive committee said it found there were “other business judgments that were not in the best interest of the National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum.”.
John McCain drew a sharp distinction with the Democratic presidential candidates, placing some of the blame on homeowners.
As newspapers slash costs, the presence of relatively few print reporters on candidates’ buses and planes this year is striking.

A picture caption with the Our Towns column on Sunday, about the intersection of March Madness for college basketball with the anxiety felt by high school seniors in April, when they find out which colleges have accepted them, misidentified the fan at center watching a game at the Black Bear Saloon in White Plains. He is Justin Marinucci, not Jason Zulauf.

Because of an editing error, a report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Thursday about plans by George Clooney to hold a screening of his new movie, “Leatherheads,” in Maysville, Ky., misstated the location of Maysville in relation to Augusta, Ky., where Mr. Clooney grew up. It is about 16 miles east of Augusta, not west.

A jazz entry in the Listings page on Friday, about the Randy Johnston quartet at the Kitano Hotel, misspelled the given name of the bass player and included an extraneous punctuation for the initial that follows it. He is Harvie S, not “Harvey S.”.

An article on Monday about Anita M. Busch, a former reporter who received a threat that began the series of events leading to the trial of a Hollywood private investigator, Anthony Pellicano, misidentified those who doubted her account and called her the “Tawana Brawley of the newsroom.” They were people at The Los Angeles Times when she was a contract writer there, according to a 2002 article in The Washington Post, which did not identify them. It was not The Washington Post that referred to her that way.

An article on Tuesday about the Justice Department’s approval of a merger of XM Satellite Radio and Sirius Radio referred incorrectly to a competing radio technology. It is called HD Radio, not high-definition radio. The “HD” is simply part of a brand name.

An article on Saturday about the increased number of women holding top managerial jobs in foundations misstated the position of Susan E. Manske, of the MacArthur Foundation. Ms. Manske is vice president and chief investment officer; she does not “head” the foundation. (Jonathan F. Fanton is its president and Robert E. Denham is chairman of the board.).
BUSINESS DAY.

An article on Friday about the near-autonomy that Army and Marine captains have in the Iraq war described the rank of captain incorrectly and misidentified the type of bonus that captains may receive if they continue beyond their initial commitment. Captains are officers who are commissioned, not enlisted, and therefore they receive retention bonuses, not re-enlistment bonuses.
A day of testimony in the wiretapping trial of the Hollywood private eye Anthony Pellicano included industry names in the most embarrassing of contexts.
The top federal official responsible for AIDS research agreed that more fundamental knowledge is needed about H.I.V. before a vaccine can be developed.

NORWALK, Conn. — Four days after a Norwalk police officer on patrol was found fatally shot in a church parking lot, officials said Tuesday that he had probably committed suicide, and that an AK-47 rifle was found at the scene along with his service pistol.
The baseball season got under way in a stadium in Toyko, while many Red Sox fans woke up at 6 a.m. to tune in from New England.
A report from the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform presents the pitcher’s testimony as “a far more complicated picture than some may want to believe.”

Gov. David A. Paterson has been asked by the Albany County district attorney to allow the district attorney to make public the findings in his latest investigation of former Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s administration.
Samples of buffalo mozzarella tainted with elevated levels of dioxin may force officials to address the large-scale illegal trash-dumping in Naples.

Massachusetts rallied to defeat Syracuse, 81-77, on Tuesday night in the quarterfinals of the National Invitation Tournament.

Daniel L. Doctoroff, who left City Hall for a private position, may remain involved in city projects that were begun while he was deputy mayor for economic development.
Barack and Michelle Obama increased their giving as Mr. Obama began to run for president and book sales helped buoy their income.
The E and the Q trains are rated the dirtiest lines in the New York City subway system in the latest survey by a rider advocacy group. The L line is rated the cleanest.
In her first comments on the controversy, Hillary Rodham Clinton criticized Barack Obama for not leaving his Chicago church.
The Department of Homeland Security’s new 10-finger screening process brought mixed reactions at Kennedy International Airport.
The Dodgers are celebrating 50 years in Los Angeles by crashing for a night at the Ping-Pong parlor that put them up for their first four seasons.
Branded entertainment, in which a brand is integrated into the plot of a movie or TV series, is intended to prevent consumers from avoiding advertising.
A private survey found that Americans feel worse about the economy’s prospects than at any time since 1973, when Americans struggled with soaring oil prices and inflation.
The Hall of Fame goalie Patrick Roy and his son were suspended a total of 12 games for their parts in a brawl during a Quebec Major Junior Hockey League playoff game.
Creative Artists Agency is expected to launch WePlay.com, a social networking site for youth sports — something like Facebook for young athletes — in April.
Brook and Robin Lopez, the brothers who have led Stanford’s basketball team to the Round of 16, are free-spirited, athletic and 7 feet tall.
The ruling is likely to discourage other states, including California, that had been considering following New York’s lead in enacting an Airline Passenger Bill of Rights.
Andy Pettittee, who has been slowed by tightness in his lower back, will likely pitch a minor league game as a tuneup for his first start of the season.
Despite the floods that ravaged parts of Missouri last week, the release of hundreds of thousands of gallons of water from a dam into the Missouri River will go ahead as planned.
Yahoo announced it would join an alliance that will try to make it easier for programmers to write software that can run on many social networking Web sites.
The United States women’s national team is back sitting on top of the world, No. 1 in the latest FIFA rankings, after winning the Algarve Cup earlier this month in Portugal.
A Boston sports bar opened at 5:30 a.m. for the game, but Red Sox fans had mixed feelings about the fact that the season opener was being played in Japan.

Since receiving free tickets to a game in 1999, Glenys and Bob Manfre have spent their springs traveling the country to cheer on the Scarlet Knights.
Attorney General Michael B. Mukasey argued to reinstate an explosives-related charge against Ahmed Ressam, who tried to cross the border from Canada in a car full of explosives.
Clear Channel and its two private equity buyers may go to court to try and force the banks that had agreed to finance the deal to complete the buyout.
As Taylor Phinney trains to become an Olympic cyclist, he is watching his father, a former professional athlete, being ravaged by Parkinson’s disease.

The United States, by far the biggest donor, is responsible for half of the shortfall, according to a new report.

ALBANY (AP) — The state’s top court ruled on Tuesday that the police can strip-search someone they had arrested and look inside his or her body cavities without a warrant if they have reason to suspect that concealed evidence is inside. But they cannot physically search a cavity without getting a court warrant, the court ruled.

A Buddhist temple in suburban Tokyo revealed itself on Tuesday as the buyer that paid $14.3 million for an 800-year-old cypress wood sculpture of Buddha at a Christie’s auction in New York last week, Agence France-Presse reported. The Shinnyo-en temple said it bought the sculpture of the Dainichi Nyorai, or supreme Buddha, above, with donations from the faithful because it did not want the icon to fall into foreign hands. The sale set a record for a piece of Japanese art and exceeded the sculpture’s presale estimates of $1.5 million to $2.5 million.
Truth remained stranger than even Wagnerian fiction for the Metropolitan Opera’s six-performance revival of “Tristan und Isolde” in its fifth outing, on Tuesday.

A guest appearance from Britney Spears helped CBS’s “How I Met Your Mother” attract its largest audience of the season on Monday, as 10.6 million viewers tuned in to the sitcom at 8:30 p.m., Nielsen reported. The series, in its third season, also earned its highest ratings on record among adults 18 to 49, lifting CBS into first place on the night in that demographic. Although ABC drew more total viewers, thanks to “Dancing With the Stars” from 8 to 10 (20.3 million), CBS’s “Two and a Half Men” at 9 (14.3 million) eked out a victory as the top-rated show with the 18-to-49 set. CBS also led during the 10 p.m. hour with “CSI: Miami” (15.8 million), which easily outpaced both NBC’s “Medium” (8.8 million) and ABC’s “Bachelor” (8 million). ABC ranked second for the night in the 18-to-49 age bracket, followed by NBC and Fox in a tie for third. NBC garnered solid ratings at 9 for “Deal or No Deal” (10 million) but lagged behind at 8 with “My Dad Is Better Than Your Dad” (4.3 million). Fox broadcast a “House” repeat at 8 (7.6 million) and “New Amsterdam” at 9 (6.3 million).

A $3.9 million Guarneri violin, made in 1741, was played in public for the first time in more than 70 years when Pinchas Zukerman, above, performed in Moscow on Saturday at a private concert before 160 guests of the instrument’s new owner, Maxim Viktorov, a lawyer who bought it at a Sotheby’s auction last month, The Guardian of London reported. Mr. Viktorov, 35, a violin collector who likes to play to the piano accompaniment of his wife, Anastasia, said: “I tried out the instrument a little in London before I bought it. But since then, I haven’t been able to touch it. The instrument cannot bear any agitation. I want the maestro, who lives by his art, to be the first to play it so the violin is receiving the respect it deserves. Then I might find the strength to play it myself because it’s a great source of energy.”.
A Colorado appeals court has ruled that stage performances are not exempt from the state’s two-year-old ban on indoor smoking.

The Smashing Pumpkins filed a breach of contract lawsuit against Virgin Records, accusing the company of using the band’s name and music in promotional deals that injured its credibility with fans, The Associated Press reported. In Los Angeles County Superior Court on Monday, the members contended that Virgin’s use of the band in a promotion with Amazon.com and PepsiCo threatens their “artistic integrity.” The Pumpkins lawsuit argues that Virgin, which released the band’s music for 17 years, had no contractual right to use it in campaigns to sell other products. The band asked to be compensated with Virgin’s profits from the promotion, and also requested an injunction to bar use of its name and music. Virgin did not immediately respond to a call for comment.

Fred Thompson, eliminated from the long-running reality show that is the campaign for United States presidency, is returning to the make-believe of acting, Reuters reported. Mr. Thompson, 65, a former United States senator from Tennessee and recently the fictional New York district attorney Arthur Branch on the television crime drama “Law & Order,” has signed an agreement to be represented as an actor by the William Morris Agency. Mr. Thompson has appeared in numerous television shows and films, including “Die Hard 2” and “In the Line of Fire.” His quest for the Republican presidential nomination attracted little support and he abandoned the race in January.

George Michael, below, is planning his first tour of North America in 17 years, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Michael, 44, who sang with the 1980s pop group Wham! before starting a successful solo career, will begin his 22-date “25 Live” tour in San Diego on June 17 and finish in Sunrise, Fla., on Aug. 3, after stops that include New York, Atlanta, Las Vegas, Los Angeles, Seattle and Chicago. ... Illness has forced the pianist Murray Perahia to withdraw from a concert with the Academy of St. Martin in the Fields at Avery Fisher Hall on April 8. An announcement said he would be replaced by Marc-André Hamelin in the program of Mozart and Haydn works conducted by Neville Marriner. ... Woody Allen and his New Orleans Jazz Band will make their first appearance at the Montreal International Jazz festival on June 30.

Mitchell J. Landrieu (above, right), the lieutenant governor of Louisiana, has emphasized the importance of culture to his state’s recovery from Hurricane Katrina and Hurricane Rita. At a news conference on Monday at Jazz at Lincoln Center in New York, he said: “Culture in fact means business. It is an end in and of itself.” Mr. Landrieu said that the second World Cultural Economic Forum, a three-day conference on arts-related issues, would take place in Louisiana in October. The first forum was held in August 2007. In addition, the Louisiana Cultural Economy Foundation, established after the hurricanes, announced a $750,000 economic opportunity fund to help people in creative fields. Its first recovery fund of $1 million was distributed in 300 grants. Of the 144,000 culture-related jobs in the state, about 80 percent have returned since the hurricanes, Scott Hutcheson, the foundation’s executive director, said in an interview. At the news conference the actress Patricia Clarkson, a New Orleans native (above, with the pianist Jonathan Baptiste), said, “I think my state made me the actress I am today,” adding that she was about to travel to Cairo to make a film and “I’m going to bring beignets.”.

HAUM--Barbara Rose, artist, age 45, my refreshingly brilliant, sincere and real friend will be deeply missed by me and my whole family. She has touched and enriched my life in so many ways. My heart goes out also to her devoted mother and sister. Caryl Englander

PECK--William H., formerly of Oyster Bay NY, passed away on March 24th, 2008 at the age of 92 in Southbury CT. He is survived by Polly (nee Weeks), his wife of almost 65 years, sons Bill and Charlie and daughters Heidi Sullivan and Ellen Nicoll. He was grandfather to nine and great-grandfather to three. He was Yale '36 and Harvard Law '39, where he was a member of the law review. He was a decorated WWII veteran, having served in the Navy. Upon his return he practiced law in New York City and then Oyster Bay. He was very active at Planting Fields Arboretum, Theodore Roosevelt Sanctuary and Christ Church Oyster Bay before moving to Southbury, CT where he remained until his passing. A memorial service will be held at Christ Church, Oyster Bay, NY on April 26th at 11:30am.

GROB--David, M.D. Dr. Joseph Cunningham and the Department of Surgery at Maimonides Medical Center, Brooklyn, New York, mourn the passing of our respected colleague and admired educator. Dr. Grob guided and taught generations of faculty, residents and students in the art and science of medicine. Dr. Grob was Chairman of Medicine at Maimonides Medical Center, Professor of Medicine at SUNY Health Science Center Brooklyn, Clinical Associate Dean at Downstate Medical Center and Director of the Maimonides Research and Development Foundation. His numerous contributions to the medical literature and his acclaim to research in myasthenia gravis serve as many of the hallmarks of medicine. His contributions to Maimonides for over 45 years will long be remembered. He was a source of wisdom and inspiration to all.
