GELLHORN--Alfred. The New York Academy of Medicine acknowledges with profound sorrow the death of Alfred Gellhorn, Fellow of the Academy since 1992. Dr. Gellhorn's long and distinguished career included serving as first Director of the Medical Center and Dean of the School of Medicine at the University of Pennsylvania, as Director of Medical Affairs for the New York State Department of Health and as Vice President for Health Affairs at City College. We join many in remembering his outstanding contributions to the fields of medicine and medical education, and we are especially grateful for his support of the Academy. The Academy Board, Fellows and staff extend deepest condolences to his family. Jo Ivey Boufford, M.D., President Thomas Q. Morris, M.D., Chairman, Board of Trustees GELLHORN--Alfred, M.D., 94. Physician, Farmer, Reformer, Practical Visionary, Mentor and Humanist died peacefully at home on March 24, after an active career in medicine and healthcare policy spanning 72 years. Pioneer in oncology at Columbia University 1943--1968; Dean, U of PA School of Medicine; Founding Director, Sophie Davis School of Biomedical Education of City U, and the Gateway Institute in NYC's public high schools; Director of Medical Affairs at the NYS Department of Health; Board Member and advisor for the Aaron and Irene Diamond Foundations. He was a physician-scientist, beloved teacher and mentor who wrought far-reaching reforms in graduate medical education, primary care and minority access to education. Predeceased by his wife Olga and daughter Maria, he leaves loving daughters Martha, Anne, Tina and Edna, five grandchildren and one greatgrandchild. Burial will be private, with a memorial celebration in NYC planned for later in the spring. The family suggests donations to Gateway Institute, City College, Harris Hall H06, 106 Convent Avenue, NY, NY 10031.
MORGANTE--Linda. Linda... One year later, we all still think of you with love, admiration, and hope. Joe

Health officials in Denmark, France and Italy began recalling stores of the blood-thinning drug heparin and any ingredients used in it that had originated in China, as a precautionary measure. In the United States, certain batches of the drug have been linked to 19 deaths and hundreds of allergic reactions. The lots were manufactured by Baxter International and used ingredients from China; investigators discovered that the faulty batches contained a contaminant. Baxter has recalled virtually all its heparin products. In Germany, heparin made by Rotexmedica from Chinese raw materials is believed to be the cause of more than 80 cases of allergic reactions. There have been no reactions reported in Denmark, France or Italy, according to the European Medicines Agency.

STACKLOW--Thomas, 95 years young, loved by family and friends. The Stacklow family is saddened by the passing of our patriarch, Papa Tommy, born May 5, 1912 in Brooklyn, NY. He raised his family in Brooklyn and Valley Stream, NY, retired to Winston Towers, Miami, FL and then Huntington Pointe, Delray Beach, FL. He was a role model to his children, Elaine (the late Abraham Siev), Martin (Judi), William (Lynn), Arthur (Marion). His spirit will live on through his 20 grandchildren and 21 great-grandchildren and generations to come. His family was large in numbers, but his love was shared personally to all. We will always remember how lucky we were to have had him with us. Rest well Pop and give love to Nanny.

THEY might sit there, unnoticed and undisturbed, in your fridge or cabinet, for weeks or months or even longer. But they're waiting -- or at least they should be -- until your stir-fries need a jolt of distinctive, impossible-to-mistake flavor that nothing else can give you. They are fermented black beans, and in an Asian market a dollar or two buys a pound, a supply that will last you a long time because you use only a tablespoon or two at a time.

SCHOTT--Michael B., Beverage Industry Exec, dies at 59. Michael Bennett Schott, age 59, died on March 24, 2008 after a valiant battle with brain cancer. Born in Cincinnati, OH, in 1948, to the late Cincinnati Police Chief Jacob Schott and his wife Dollie, Michael leaves behind his wife Evonne Stevenson Schott; his children, Kyle Louise, Chicago, John Chapin, Boston, Margaret Condon, San Francisco, Leslie Kathleen, Los Angeles, and Mark Edmund, Santa Cruz, CA; siblings Barbara Boyd (Jack Boyd, late), Jacksonville, FL, Jacob Schott (Donna), Cleveland, OH, and; step-children Samuel Joseph Stevenson and Thomas Scott Stevenson, Grosse Pointe Woods, MI. Mike graduated from Western Hills High School and was named All-American for his football prowess. Mike attended Ohio University on a full football scholarship and excelled not only on the field but in the classroom as well. After leading his team to an undefeated season and the 1968 Tangerine Bowl, he was inducted into the Ohio University Hall of Fame. Dr. Vernon Alden, then president of Ohio University and former Associate Dean of Harvard Business School, became Mike's mentor, guiding his decision to pursue a Masters in Business Administration at Harvard Business School rather than a professional football career. After graduation from Harvard in 1972, Mike began his career and eventual rise as the industry king in the beverage world. He returned to Cincinnati, with NuMaid Margerine where he met and married Roberta Louise Condon. As newlyweds they moved to the New York metro area and Mike began working for Pepsi Bottling Co. He eventually became president of Poland Spring Water, holding the position until the company's purchase by Perrier. Upon the sale of Poland, Mike moved back to Cincinnati, to be a partner in the Hudepohl Schoenling Brewing Co. In Cincinnati, Mike's family grew to five beautiful children. Not long after the birth of their youngest child, the family moved to Detroit where Mike turned his efforts to Don Lee Distributor. Within a year, the talented entrepreneur was tapped to launch AriZona Iced Tea. At AriZona, Mike further demonstrated his ability to improve operations and manage rapid sales growth in the beverage industry. He was quickly promoted into senior management at Nantucket Nectars, Snapple, SoBe, Everfresh, and others, eventually becoming the lynchpin in building Monster Energy, the backbone of the unprecedented growth of Hansen Beverage Company. During Mike's five years with Hansen, the company was named by Forbes Magazine as the number one small company in the U.S. in 2005 and 2006. In 2005, Mike Schott married Evonne Stevenson. Too soon thereafter, in October 2006, Mike was diagnosed with a Stage Four GBM brain tumor. Mike's work ethic and determination to succeed now faced an even greater challenge. He used this tragic turn of events as an opportunity to move medical science forward. Mike was a man who put his time, effort, and financial resources into supporting projects he felt would benefit the greater good. While his battle with cancer was eventually lost, the medical progress he forged with Genentech Inc. will continue to fight for those suffering from similar ailments for years to come. Mike was known for his work ethic based on his favorite sayings including attitude is everything, persistence and determination alone are omnipotent and from those to whom much is given, much is expected. His legacy will continue to grow through the Michael B. Schott Fund at the Hermelin Brain Tumor Center at the Henry Ford Health System, Detroit, MI.

8 P.M. (13) PETER AND THE WOLF It's a ''Great Performances'' double bill. First this PBS series presents Suzie Templeton and Hugh Welchman's animated adaptation, above, of this children's story from Prokofiev (using his music but not his narration). It won this year's Oscar for best animated short. At 9, the fairy tale theme continues as the season premiere of ''Great Performances at the Met'' offers the Metropolitan Opera's production of ''Hansel and Gretel,'' with Alice Coote, Christine Schäfer and Philip Langridge. 8 P.M. (ABC) WIFE SWAP A carefree mom who runs a traveling carnival switches lives with an upper-class wife who puts more emphasis on rules and structure.

WESTERMANN--Barbara, 71, a resident of New York City formerly of Dobbs Ferry, NY. Wife of the late Coenraad Dirk Westermann. She is survived by nieces and nephews and many close friends. Funeral Service 11am Friday, Gustavus Adolphus Lutheran Church, 155 East 22nd St, New York, NY 10010. Memorials to Calvary Hospital, 1740 Eastchester Ave, Bronx, NY 10451

GELLHORN--Alfred. The New York Academy of Medicine acknowledges with profound sorrow the death of Alfred Gellhorn, Fellow of the Academy since 1992. Dr. Gellhorn's long and distinguished career included serving as first Director of the Medical Center and Dean of the School of Medicine at the University of Pennsylvania, as Director of Medical Affairs for the New York State Department of Health and as Vice President for Health Affairs at City College. We join many in remembering his outstanding contributions to the fields of medicine and medical education, and we are especially grateful for his support of the Academy. The Academy Board, Fellows and staff extend deepest condolences to his family. Jo Ivey Boufford, M.D., President Thomas Q. Morris, M.D., Chairman, Board of Trustees GELLHORN--Alfred, M.D., 94. Physician, Farmer, Reformer, Practical Visionary, Mentor and Humanist died peacefully at home on March 24, after an active career in medicine and healthcare policy spanning 72 years. Pioneer in oncology at Columbia University 1943--1968; Dean, U of PA School of Medicine; Founding Director, Sophie Davis School of Biomedical Education of City U, and the Gateway Institute in NYC's public high schools; Director of Medical Affairs at the NYS Department of Health; Board Member and advisor for the Aaron and Irene Diamond Foundations. He was a physician-scientist, beloved teacher and mentor who wrought far-reaching reforms in graduate medical education, primary care and minority access to education. Predeceased by his wife Olga and daughter Maria, he leaves loving daughters Martha, Anne, Tina and Edna, five grandchildren and one greatgrandchild. Burial will be private, with a memorial celebration in NYC planned for later in the spring. The family suggests donations to Gateway Institute, City College, Harris Hall H06, 106 Convent Avenue, NY, NY 10031.

JACOBS--Shirley R., March 23rd, of Palm Beach, FL. Loving wife of the late Herbert. Devoted mother of Alan L. Jacobs (Barbara), Betty Malech (Kenneth) and Lilith Jacobs. Beloved sister of Florence Weiss (Irving) and Arlene Stieglitz. Cherished grandmother of Emily Florin (Doug), Daniel Malech and Edward and Charles Jacobs. Services Wednesday 10:15 AM at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam. Donations to the charity of your choice would be appreciated.

CLUB In England, Chelsea extended its unbeaten streak at home to 79 matches in league play Sunday, rallying from a 1-0 deficit to defeat Arsenal, 2-1. Coincidentally, Arsenal was the last team to beat Chelsea at home, in February 2004. The goal, his second of the match and his 19th in all competitions this season, helped erase a 3-1 deficit. Third-place Heerenveen (54 points) plays host to second-place Ajax (57) on Saturday.

FINELL--Julian, age 83, died on March 20, 2008 from complications of Myelodysplastic Syndrome and heart disease. He leaves behind his beloved wife Janet, devoted sisters Edith Hiller and Lenore Liff. Julie was a poet, classical music lover and amateur artist. His toy poodle Lucy was always at his side.

BAILEY--Walter Ronald, of New York City died of prostate cancer on March 23, 2008 at the age of 65. Born September 3, 1942 in Brooklyn, New York, he was the only son of the late Dorothy and Walter Bruce Bailey. He was raised in Syosset, NY and was a graduate of St. Dominic High School, Villanova University and Cornell University Law School. He also had an LLM degree in taxation from New York University. He was with the F.B.I. before becoming a trusts and estates attorney in Manhattan. He was a member of the University Club and Winged Foot Golf Club. Walter was an avid oenophile and golfer. He is survived by his beloved wife of twenty years, Jane Watson Bailey, sister Carol Ann Weston and brother-in-law Paul of Colchester, Connecticut and a niece Beth Meekins and nephew, David Weston. The funeral service will be held on Thursday, March 27, at 12 noon at Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home, 352 East 87 St. after which a reception will be held at the University Club. After cremation, interment will take place at a later date, at Greenwood Cemetery, Rye, New York in the Bayles family plot of his wife.

PECK--William H., formerly of Oyster Bay NY, passed away on March 24th, 2008 at the age of 92 in Southbury CT. He is survived by Polly (nee Weeks), his wife of almost 65 years, sons Bill and Charlie and daughters Heidi Sullivan and Ellen Nicoll. He was grandfather to nine and great-grandfather to three. He was Yale '36 and Harvard Law '39, where he was a member of the law review. He was a decorated WWII veteran, having served in the Navy. Upon his return he practiced law in New York City and then Oyster Bay. He was very active at Planting Fields Arboretum, Theodore Roosevelt Sanctuary and Christ Church Oyster Bay before moving to Southbury, CT where he remained until his passing. A memorial service will be held at Christ Church, Oyster Bay, NY on April 26th at 11:30am.

JONES--Suzanne Y., of Greenport, NY, 73, on March 19. Founding Executive Director of the Single Parent Resource Center. A compassionate and devoted champion for single parents and their families, including those homeless, formerly incarcerated, and in recovery. Most beloved mother of Laura F. Jones, Paul M. Jones, Jr., and Martha S. Jones. An avid gardener, yard saler, craft maker, and beach comber. Memorial celebration Saturday, March 29, 2008 at 3 pm, Jones residence, 410 Fifth St., Greenport, NY. Donations to Single Parent Resource Center, NY, NY.

CICARELLI--Vincent Patrick, born on August 26, 1976, died suddenly at the age of 31 on Sunday, March 23, 2008. Vinny, who lived in Sunnyside, Queens, was a generous and loving spirit who touched many lives as a nursing home care provider and later as a Patient Services Assistant at Columbia University Student Health Services. He graduated from Webutuck High School and was taking courses toward a degree in Nursing at Borough of Manhattan Community College. In his free time, Vinny loved to cook, enjoy music, and express his unique energy in New York dance clubs. He is survived by his partner of eight years, Andrew Horgan, his parents, Patrick Cicarelli and Evelyn Carroll, and his siblings Rachel Carroll, Jennifer Carroll, Heather Barney, and Nicholas Cicarelli. Visiting Thursday, March 27, 2:005:00pm and 7:00-9:00pm at John J. Barrett & Son Funeral Home, 424 West 51st Street, New York, NY. A burial service will be held at Ferncliff Cemetery, Hartsdale, NY, Friday, March 28, 11:00am.

Marc and Ellen, Eric and Lisa, Beth and Peter, Adam, Jill, Max, Jake, Luke, Jonathan, Alexander and Zachary

PICKER--Harvey. A physicist, inventor, businessman, educator, philosopher and friend died on March 22 at age 92. Mr. Picker ran Picker X-ray Company for 25 years. He was a well-known inventor of x-ray technology and groundbreaking developments including cobalt therapy for cancer, nuclear imaging diagnostics and the use of ultrasound for oceanography, which was adapted for medical imaging. Along with his wife Jean, an ambassador to the U.N. in the 1960s, now deceased, he then founded the Picker Institute, a nonprofit dedicated to advancing the principles of patient-centered care and pioneered the systematic collection of data from hospital patients to help improve the delivery of medical services in the U.S. and Europe. Mr. Picker also taught at his alma mater, Colgate University, and served as the dean of the School of International and Public Affairs at Columbia University. He also helped found the Picker Engineering Program at Smith College, his wife's alma mater. He is survived by two daughters, Bobbi Hamill of Boston, MA and Gale Jean Picker of Seattle, WA, as well as three grandchildren, Jean Picker Larsen, Evelyn Picker Larsen and Matthew James Mrachek. A memorial service will be held in Camden, ME in early June.

MULLIN--Edith. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) mourn the loss of Edith Mullin of Boca Raton, FL. Mrs. Mullin was a visionary who along with her late husband, Chuck, supported the Technion for nearly 50 years. Her energy and leadership in the South Palm Beach Chapter will be sorely missed. She was a member of the national Board of Directors and, until last year, president of the South Palm Beach Chapter. The Eugene Mullin Memorial Scholarship Fund, the Edith Mullin Endowed Undergraduate Scholarship Fund, and the Graduate Student Village are among the numerous projects she supported. WOFSEY--Earl Jack, a resident of Long Boat Key, FL and Stamford, CT, passed away peacefully on the morning of March 21, 2008 after a lengthy illness. Born in Stamford, CT, in 1916, to Emma Bluming Wofsey and Judge Abraham Wofsey, he graduated Phillips Academy, Andover, Cum Laude. He graduated Yale University, Phi Beta Kappa, and Yale Law School, where he was a member of the Yale Law Journal. Mr. Wofsey served as a Judge Advocate in the United States Army during World War II. Later, Mr. Wofsey practiced law for five years at the highly regarded Reorganization Division of the Securities and Exchange Commission, and several years at Crisona Brothers Law Firm. In 1960, he established the firm which became known as Wofsey, Certilman, Haft, Snow and Becker, where he led the corporate law practice as Senior and Managing Partner. There, he was responsible for many initial public offerings. Among his major clients was the MetPro Corporation, where he became an active Member of the Board. He was instrumental in guiding the firm toward world leadership in water purification and pollution control. Mr. Wofsey was also very active in the Stamford, CT Jewish community. He served as the President of Temple Beth El (1965-1967) and then, in 1973, he successfully led their ''New Building Fund'' which created a new, larger Temple and adjacent cemetery. From 1978-1995, he dedicated himself to the Fairfield Country Home for the Jewish Elderly as Board Member and then Chairman, from 1989-1991. During that period, the Home greatly expanded its facilities and service, achieving national recognition for excellence. Mr. Wofsey is survived by his son, Dr. Alan R. Wofsey and Alan's wife Susan of Bryn Mawr, PA, their two daughters, Lilana D. and Michelle R. Wofsey, and his brother Robert A. Wofsey and Robert's wife Marcia of Mamaroneck, NY. He is also survived by his wife Violetta Lashauri-Wofsey and his three stepchildren, Revaz, Maria and Natalie Mekvabishvili from Toronto, Canada and Long Boat Key, FL. His first wife, Beatrice Sosnowitz Wofsey is deceased. Funeral services were held at Temple Beth El, Sunday, March 23, 2008. Shiva is being observed at 7:00pm, Wednesday, March 26, 2008, at the Wofsey home, 929 Riverbank Road, Stamford, CT 06903. Donations may be given in Mr. Wofsey's honor to the Yale Law School.

CORSER--John B., M.D., was a colleague and friend of exceptional warmth, insight, openness, caring and bioethical acumen--a person of great sympathy, possessing no arrogance, who was always present in the moment. We, the faculty and participants of the Certificate Program in Bioethics and Medical Humanities, the Clinical Ethics Credentialing Project, the HHC Bioethics Council and the HHC Palliative Care Initiative mourn his passing, will miss his leadership and feel the deep loss that he leaves in our lives and the lives of his wife, children and loved ones. Colleagues & friends of John
DIAMONDSTONE-Lawrence. Happy Birthday! Your memory endures. Mr. and Mrs. Milton Feldman and family

Peering up the winding iron staircase in the water tower at Highbridge Park in Washington Heights. The tower was built in 1872 as part of the Croton Aqueduct system, which had started bringing a dependable supply of fresh water into New York City in 1842, and it remained in use as a pumping station until 1949.

STACKLOW--Thomas, 95 years young, loved by family and friends. The Stacklow family is saddened by the passing of our patriarch, Papa Tommy, born May 5, 1912 in Brooklyn, NY. He raised his family in Brooklyn and Valley Stream, NY, retired to Winston Towers, Miami, FL and then Huntington Pointe, Delray Beach, FL. He was a role model to his children, Elaine (the late Abraham Siev), Martin (Judi), William (Lynn), Arthur (Marion). His spirit will live on through his 20 grandchildren and 21 great-grandchildren and generations to come. His family was large in numbers, but his love was shared personally to all. We will always remember how lucky we were to have had him with us. Rest well Pop and give love to Nanny.

VANCE--Grace Sloane. The Trustees, staff, and volunteers of Educational Broadcasting Corporation, licensee of Thirteen/WNET and WLIW New York, deeply mourn the passing of Grace Sloane Vance, Vice Chairman Emeritus. A true friend and passionate advocate for the mission of public television, Gay Vance served on the EBC Board of Trustees from 1974 through 1993 additionally serving as Vice Chairman for many of those years. Among her numerous, enduring contributions to Thirteen/WNET, she helped found the Patron Circle program of core station supporters, serving as its chairman until 1994. Her extraordinary leadership and enthusiasm for Thirteen/ WNET's work played a vital role in strengthening the institution, promoting its goals, and enhancing the power and reach of public television in our community and nationwide. We offer our heartfelt sympathies to her children Elsie Vance Askar, Camilla Vance Holmes, Grace Roberts Vance, Cyrus R. Vance, Jr., and to the members of her extended family. Like them, we are comforted by the knowledge that Gay's wonderful contributions to Thirteen/WNET over the years continue to flourish, touching countless lives here in New York City and all across America. Sincerely, James S. Tisch Chairman Neal Shapiro President and CEO VANCE--Grace Sloane, (known as ''Gay''), beloved wife of the late Cyrus R. Vance, passed away on Saturday March 22, 2008. A native New Yorker, Gay's family founded the W&J Sloane furniture company. Gay was a full partner in her husband's very public life. During their time in Washington, DC, she was a true ''first lady'' of the State Department, looking after the welfare of state department families. In her own right, Gay was a civic leader dedicated to promoting human equality and opportunity as Vice-Chairman of the Board and then President of the New York Urban League, and to expanding arts and education through public television in New York City as a board member and later Vice-Chairman of the Board of WNET Channel 13. Numerous non-profit organizations and corporate boards, including W. R. Grace & Company, Colgate University and the National Urban League sought out Gay for her common sense, strong intellect and integrity. Gay was devoted to her family. She is survived by her two sisters, Nancy Coates of Ardmore, Pennsylvania and Evelyn Pyne of Far Hills, New Jersey. Gay lost her cherished daughter, Amy Sloane Vance, just two weeks ago to cancer. Gay will be missed by her three daughters, Elsie Nicoll Vance, Camilla Vance Holmes and Grace Roberts Vance, her son, Cyrus R. Vance, Jr., her grandchildren Simon and Clare Vance, step-grandson Kemal Askar, daughter-inlaw Peggy Vance, and sonsin-law Attila Askar and William Holmes, as well as by a large community of loving and diverse friends from around the world and across many generations whom she inspired. Services will be held this Saturday, March 29, 2008 at 4pm at the Church of the Heavenly Rest at 90th Street and Fifth Avenue. In lieu of flowers, Gay asked that any donations be sent to the Vance Center for International Justice Initiatives, which provides support to lawyers around the globe to expand access to justice, and to ensure a fair and equitable judicial system, c/o New York City Bar, 42 West 44th Street, New York, NY 10036-6689.

SCHOTT--Michael B., Beverage Industry Exec, dies at 59. Michael Bennett Schott, age 59, died on March 24, 2008 after a valiant battle with brain cancer. Born in Cincinnati, OH, in 1948, to the late Cincinnati Police Chief Jacob Schott and his wife Dollie, Michael leaves behind his wife Evonne Stevenson Schott; his children, Kyle Louise, Chicago, John Chapin, Boston, Margaret Condon, San Francisco, Leslie Kathleen, Los Angeles, and Mark Edmund, Santa Cruz, CA; siblings Barbara Boyd (Jack Boyd, late), Jacksonville, FL, Jacob Schott (Donna), Cleveland, OH, and; step-children Samuel Joseph Stevenson and Thomas Scott Stevenson, Grosse Pointe Woods, MI. Mike graduated from Western Hills High School and was named All-American for his football prowess. Mike attended Ohio University on a full football scholarship and excelled not only on the field but in the classroom as well. After leading his team to an undefeated season and the 1968 Tangerine Bowl, he was inducted into the Ohio University Hall of Fame. Dr. Vernon Alden, then president of Ohio University and former Associate Dean of Harvard Business School, became Mike's mentor, guiding his decision to pursue a Masters in Business Administration at Harvard Business School rather than a professional football career. After graduation from Harvard in 1972, Mike began his career and eventual rise as the industry king in the beverage world. He returned to Cincinnati, with NuMaid Margerine where he met and married Roberta Louise Condon. As newlyweds they moved to the New York metro area and Mike began working for Pepsi Bottling Co. He eventually became president of Poland Spring Water, holding the position until the company's purchase by Perrier. Upon the sale of Poland, Mike moved back to Cincinnati, to be a partner in the Hudepohl Schoenling Brewing Co. In Cincinnati, Mike's family grew to five beautiful children. Not long after the birth of their youngest child, the family moved to Detroit where Mike turned his efforts to Don Lee Distributor. Within a year, the talented entrepreneur was tapped to launch AriZona Iced Tea. At AriZona, Mike further demonstrated his ability to improve operations and manage rapid sales growth in the beverage industry. He was quickly promoted into senior management at Nantucket Nectars, Snapple, SoBe, Everfresh, and others, eventually becoming the lynchpin in building Monster Energy, the backbone of the unprecedented growth of Hansen Beverage Company. During Mike's five years with Hansen, the company was named by Forbes Magazine as the number one small company in the U.S. in 2005 and 2006. In 2005, Mike Schott married Evonne Stevenson. Too soon thereafter, in October 2006, Mike was diagnosed with a Stage Four GBM brain tumor. Mike's work ethic and determination to succeed now faced an even greater challenge. He used this tragic turn of events as an opportunity to move medical science forward. Mike was a man who put his time, effort, and financial resources into supporting projects he felt would benefit the greater good. While his battle with cancer was eventually lost, the medical progress he forged with Genentech Inc. will continue to fight for those suffering from similar ailments for years to come. Mike was known for his work ethic based on his favorite sayings including attitude is everything, persistence and determination alone are omnipotent and from those to whom much is given, much is expected. His legacy will continue to grow through the Michael B. Schott Fund at the Hermelin Brain Tumor Center at the Henry Ford Health System, Detroit, MI.

MULLIN--Edith. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) mourn the loss of Edith Mullin of Boca Raton, FL. Mrs. Mullin was a visionary who along with her late husband, Chuck, supported the Technion for nearly 50 years. Her energy and leadership in the South Palm Beach Chapter will be sorely missed. She was a member of the national Board of Directors and, until last year, president of the South Palm Beach Chapter. She inspired her three children to continue their parents' legacy of generosity, and others to become ATS leaders. The Eugene Mullin Memorial Scholarship Fund, the Edith Mullin Endowed Undergraduate Scholarship Fund, and the Graduate Student Village are among the numerous projects she supported. To her sons David and Howard, daughter Ellen Greenfield and the entire Mullin family, we extend our heartfelt condolences. American Technion Society Joan Seidel, President Dr. Stephen A. YOU have one. Everybody does. The dish that stands out above all others: the most delicious food ever cooked by a beloved person who is no longer here to cook it. Mine is fried meat kreplach. BAILEY--Walter Ronald, of New York City died of prostate cancer on March 23, 2008 at the age of 65. Born September 3, 1942 in Brooklyn, New York, he was the only son of the late Dorothy and Walter Bruce Bailey. He was raised in Syosset, NY and was a graduate of St. Dominic High School, Villanova University and Cornell University Law School. He also had an LLM degree in taxation from New York University. He was with the F.B.I. before becoming a trusts and estates attorney in Manhattan. He was a member of the University Club and Winged Foot Golf Club. Walter was an avid oenophile and golfer. He is survived by his beloved wife of twenty years, Jane Watson Bailey, sister Carol Ann Weston and brother-in-law Paul of Colchester, Connecticut and a niece Beth Meekins and nephew, David Weston. The funeral service will be held on Thursday, March 27, at 12 noon at Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home, 352 East 87 St. after which a reception will be held at the University Club. After cremation, interment will take place at a later date, at Greenwood Cemetery, Rye, New York in the Bayles family plot of his wife.

CICARELLI--Vincent Patrick, born on August 26, 1976, died suddenly at the age of 31 on Sunday, March 23, 2008. Vinny, who lived in Sunnyside, Queens, was a generous and loving spirit who touched many lives as a nursing home care provider and later as a Patient Services Assistant at Columbia University Student Health Services. He graduated from Webutuck High School and was taking courses toward a degree in Nursing at Borough of Manhattan Community College. In his free time, Vinny loved to cook, enjoy music, and express his unique energy in New York dance clubs. The number of jobs in New York State dipped in February, signaling that the state may be following the nation into a recession. According to the state Department of Labor, employment in New York, adjusted for seasonal fluctuations, declined by 0.1 percent last month to 7.27 million jobs. That was the first decline from one month to the next since last summer and it came as economists watched for signs that turmoil in the financial markets may have halted a four-and-a-half-year expansion fueled by a boom in New York City.

John Dewey High School in Brooklyn was under a lockdown for several hours today after a substitute teacher saw a student holding a handgun in a classroom. The student was apparently showing the gun to another student when the gun suddenly fell on the floor. The student then picked up the gun and ran from the classroom, the police said. Within minutes, police had surrounded the school and kept students inside the building, but several students had already left before the police arrived. After searching the school for more than two hours, the police were unable to find the student with the gun.

A $103.9 million concrete contract, the largest single construction contract for the National September 11 Memorial and Museum at the World Trade Center, was awarded Thursday to a company in Long Island City, Queens, that has not yet performed work at ground zero.The Queens company, Navillus Contracting, together with Bovis Lend Lease, which is heavily involved at the trade center site, won the contract from the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. It sounded like an explosion just outside the bedroom windows, eight floors up, and suddenly the air-conditioner was wrenched out of its sockets. I pulled up the blackout shades — rarely opened, but curtains raised now on an extraordinary urban drama — and saw the aluminum scaffold that workmen had been using for weeks to point the facade. The scaffold had collapsed on one side, and was tilted crazily at a 45-degree angle, the left (lower) end just outside our windows, resting on the shattered air-conditioner, and the right end somewhere out of sight, up on the ninth or tenth floor. At either end of the platform, workmen dangled perilously, both of them cradled in yellow safety harnesses, but helpless and hanging on ropes anchored to the parapet on the 17th floor.

Diesel puts great stock in weirdness - a calculated, carefully-designed meticulously-crafted weirdness. Its new fragrance, Fuel for Life Pour Femme, smells like canned fruit compote. The smell is "canned" because it's vaguely metallic. "Fruit" because it's fruity in the way that Juicyfruit gum is "fruity." I use the word "compote" because there is absolutely no recognizable fruit species here; not even the hybridized tangelo comes close. But remember, the actual smell is incidental in a perfume like this; its purpose is not to be beautiful, but to be a scent marker, identifying its wearer as part of a tribe, a sort of olfactory cattle brand.

Why do some political missteps haunt their candidates forever, while others are easily put to rest? John Kerry saying he voted for the war funding before he voted against it, or Howard Dean screeching on a stage in Iowa, instantly becomes the stuff of political history, but when George W. Bush admits that he was once arrested for driving under the influence, it immediately fades into obscurity. Some politicians, as they used to say of Ronald Reagan, seem coated in Teflon, while others seem covered in Krazy Glue, unable to shake the stickiness of what seem like minor embarrassments.Here's a political postulate for you: whether or not a bad moment sticks to the candidate depends on how closely related it is to the core rationale of that candidate or his opponent. In other words, if your gaffe goes directly to the main argument you are trying to make about yourself with the electorate, or if it substantiates the most relevant thing that your rival would have us believe about you, then it has the potential to become a serious problem. If, on the other hand, you do something completely idiotic that is tangential to what voters most hope or fear about you, then you tend to get a pass. So Mr. Kerry's choice of wording hurt because it played into the main theme that the Republicans had chosen to discredit him-the notion that he wanted to have everything both ways. By contrast, Mr. Bush's brush with the law had nothing to do with the story he was telling about himself as a competent manager, nor did it underscore the central argument that Democrats were advancing about him (because, really, there wasn't one).

Entertainment One is expected to announce Thursday that it is buying the Canadian assets of Toronto-based rival ThinkFilm, The Globe and Mail reported. The move would put the fast-rising company into the upper echelons of the film industry from bit player in less than a year.
Breathe Technologies, a respiratory treatment company, raised $15 million in its second round of venture funding.
Temasek, the Singapore investment company, has sold its holding in Bank Internasional Indonesia for $1.1 billion to Maybank, Malaysia's biggest financial services group, Finance Asia reported.

BSG Alliance has secured more than $50 million in Series B funding that likely will extend a string of acquisitions. The company has already made five acquisitions in less than a year, according to The Austin Business Journal.
In its second round of venture funding, Bubble Motion, which sells voice messaging service, raised $14 million.
Air France-KLM Group said it is willing to push back deadlines for an agreement to purchase Alitalia, in order to allow talks with unions to continue.

Take-Two Interactive, fresh from rejecting Electronic Arts' $2 billion takeover offer as too low, on Wednesday opened the door to possible suitors interested in presenting a sweeter bid sooner rather than later, The New York Post reported.
Barely Political has some fun with Hillary Clinton's now-retracted claim that she dodged sniper fire in Bosnia:
It's a flesh den without meat but, as today's Times reports, not everyone's game:

You know the economy's taken a turn for the wurst, as in hot dogs, when the Times dining section starts exploring the gourmet possibilities at 99-cent stores. Then again, with the chef Eric Ripert of Le Bernardin guiding the way, how bad can a recession be? Show us the bread line!

Tears mingled with the fast-food grease on our chubby fingers today as we requested extra napkins to mourn both the founder of Popeyes and the creator of the Egg McMuffin. But the clouds lifted as we revisited this post on an innovation of the Korean-based chain BBQ Chicken: the "Col-Pop," an all-in-one nuggets and soda cup. Honor the past, but snack to the future! A video demo:
More of your "late night" jokes (send via the comment link below):
From the halls of Montezuma to the stores of Berkeley:
Four buzzworthy urban architects are collaborating on Tribeca, which is billed as the largest residential scheme in Liverpool's history.
The democratization of taste continues with “Myles of Style,” a decorating show that began this month on HGTV.
The following is an edited transcript of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s interview with Kevin Sack of The New York Times about health care.

Rather than depending on fading European stars, Major League Soccer teams are finding affordable talent in Latin America. Of the 24 new players in the league, 19 are from South or Central America, where coaches and general managers can find players with more flair and better skills than most homegrown players offer.
We invite you to leave your responses to the Thursday, Mar. 27 column.

Few folks in the U.S. Airways Arena on Wednesday could come up with first-hand recollections of the former Western Kentucky coach E.A. Diddle. But the CBS announcer Bill Raftery spun a few yarns about the Diddle, who is still among the top 20 in career victories (759) for men's coaches.
A national anti-gossip campaign at Jewish high schools tries to use religious teachings to raise awareness about the power of speech, for good and for ill.
The business software company reported a 30 percent rise in quarterly profit, but a lower-than-expected increase in new software licenses caused shares to fall in after-hours trading.
The former governor of Alabama, Don Siegelman, was released on appeal in a case cited by Democrats as an example of politics influencing the Justice Department.
The chairman of Bear Stearns, James E. Cayne, sold $61.3 million of Bear shares, according to a regulatory filing.
The British Defense Ministry formalized a $26 billion contract with a consortium led by European Aeronautic Defense & Space to supply the Royal Air Force with combat refueling tankers.
President Bush said the fighting in Iraq demonstrated the willingness of Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki to impose order.
By placing an order for regional jets made by Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, All Nippon becomes the first customer for what could be the first new Japanese aircraft in a generation.
American International Group has filed a complaint in New York Supreme Court accusing its former chief executive Maurice R. Greenberg and six others of breaching their fiduciary duty.
Jane Mendillo has been appointed president of the Harvard Management Company, which oversees the university’s $34.9 billion endowment.
Anibal Acevedo Vila has been charged with 19 crimes including conspiracy to violate federal campaign laws and making false statements to federal investigators.
David Neeleman said the new airline will begin operating next year with three jets and eventually grow to a fleet of 76 planes flying nationwide.
Jane Mendillo, who has been chief investment officer at Wellesley College for the last six years, will oversee Harvard’s nearly $35 billion endowment.
David Neeleman, now chairman of JetBlue, said the new airline will begin operating next year with three jets and eventually grow to a fleet of 76 planes flying nationwide.

Nothing makes my father angrier than when one of our beloved Illinois Fighting Illini players misses a free throw. It just drives him nuts. This was a particularly prevalent offense for the Illini in this diasppointing season, and point guard Chester Frazier was my father’s most frequent target. “The guy is getting a free ride to college, to play basketball, and he can’t make a free throw! And he’s not even tall!”.

The Boston Red Sox and Oakland A’s kicked off the baseball season in Japan on Tuesday, nearly a week before other Major League teams played their first games. Has that game taken something away from the splendor of Opening Day?.

One moment, not exactly shining: It’s 1986, and in a bar in East Lansing, Mich., a woman approaches a struggling folk musician named David Barrett. "A waitress," Barrett recalled last year, "too beautiful for words. What do I say to this woman?" He panics, glances at the TV, sees Larry Bird "using someone like soap." So he starts talking about Larry Bird, “how amazing he is, blah blah blah." The woman is unimpressed. Barrett slinks out of the bar, thinking that he might write a song about basketball, and a phrase pops into his head, out of nowhere, and the next morning he sits down for lunch and scribbles on a napkin the great cornball anthem that, two decades later, still makes grown men cry.

“Every athlete has heard of it, most seem to believe in it and many say they have experienced it,” Gina Kolata writes in The Times today about the so-called runner’s high. “But for year scientists have reserved judgment because no rigorous test confirmed its existence.” Now, she writes, medical technology has caught up with exercise lore, and German researchers have reported that running does elicit a flood of endorphins in the brain. “The endorphins are associated with mood changes,” she writes, “and the more endorphins a runner’s body pumps out, the greater the effect.”.

Western Kentucky and Washington State are both underdogs in their games today, but the similarities between the two programs basically end there. Washington State, behind a tough defense, is making its first appearance in the Sweet 16. Western Kentucky, as The Times reports today, is one of the more storied programs in college basketball, “but memories of Western Kentucky’s run of dominance in the 1960s seem to have faded with the set shot and canvas sneakers. In part, the run came about because of Western kentucky’s willingness to integrate its team at a time when such a policy was still taboo in the South. Those involved with Western Kentucky still take great pride in the university’s breaking of racial barriers.”.
GE Money and Commercial Finance agreed to exchange several European banking assets with Banco Santander of Spain. In exchange, GE Money will receive Interbanca, an Italian commercial bank.
ConAgra said that it would sell the commodities trading group to the Ospraie Special Opportunities fund as it focuses on its core consumer foods business.
The radio station operator said a Texas judge had issued an order barring banks from taking steps that would “interfere or thwart” the closing of the proposed buyout of the company.
The economy nearly sputtered out in the final quarter of last year and is probably faring even worse now amid the housing, credit and financial crises.

Jeremy Crouch had 27 points, including a 3-pointer that sparked a decisive run, to lead Bradley (20-15) to a 96-85 victory against Virginia (17-16) in the semifinals of the College Basketball Invitational in Charlottesville, Va. Bradley will face Tulsa (23-13), a 73-69 winner against visiting Houston (24-10), on Monday in the first game of a best-of-three championship.

Chris Warren scored 5 of his 22 points in a 9-0 second-half run to lead Mississippi (24-10) to a 81-72 victory against Virginia Tech (21-14) in the National Invitation Tournament quarterfinals in Blacksburg, Va. Mississippi will face Ohio State (22-13) on Tuesday at Madison Square Garden. Kosta Koufos’s 21 points led the host Buckeyes to a 74-63 victory against Dayton (23-11).
The Nets win was tamped down by the Hawks, who managed to stay a half-game in front for the final playoff spot in the N.B.A.’s Eastern Conference.
Wednesday’s win aside, Isiah Thomas seems to be preparing a welcoming gift for Donnie Walsh: a high position in the draft lottery for the Knicks.

A picture on Tuesday with a report in the World Business Briefing column about plans for Turkey’s first nuclear power plant was published in error. The man shown is Turkey’s president, Abdullah Gul — not its prime minister, Recep Tayyip Erdogan.

An article on Monday about a popular Internet video prank known as rickrolling referred incorrectly to its use during a March 8 women’s basketball game at Eastern Washington University, based on information provided by Pawl Fisher, a student; Davin Perry, who shoots game videos for the university; and Dave Cook, its sports information director. The stunt, which involves a person lip-synching the 1980s hit song “Never Gonna Give You Up” while dressed as the British singer Rick Astley, was performed before the start of four separate basketball games, and the pranksters distilled the performances into a YouTube video. The March 8 game, between Eastern Washington and Montana State, was not interrupted by a performance.

Because of an editing error, the chess column on Sunday, about Hou Yifan, a 14-year-old rising star in the chess world, referred incorrectly in some editions to her ranking at the Corus tournament in January, in which she finished in the middle of the field. She was the second-lowest-ranked player in just the B section of the tournament — not in the tournament over all.

A headline on Saturday with an article about the increasing number of women who serve as chief investment officers for university endowments and foundations used a “glass ceiling” metaphor in a way that conveyed the opposite point made by the article. The headline should have said something to the effect that “The Glass Ceiling Is Lifting,” not “The Glass Ceiling Is Edging Lower.”.
BUSINESS DAY.

An obituary on June 7, 2006, about the rock keyboardist Billy Preston misstated his date of birth. His Web site recently announced that he was born on Sept. 2, 1946 — not Sept. 9, as was widely reported.

A listing of credits on Wednesday with a theater review of “The Four of Us,” presented by the Manhattan Theater Club at City Center, misspelled the given name of the company’s artistic director. She is Lynne Meadow, not Lynn.

Because of an editing error, a picture caption with the Advertising column on Tuesday misidentified, in some editions, the television network that is promoting the return of its scripted comedy shows with a campaign featuring the theme song from “Welcome Back, Kotter.” It is NBC, not CBS.
Lou Williams scored 23 points and Andre Miller had a season-high 18 assists Wednesday night to help the Philadelphia 76ers rout the visiting Chicago Bulls, 121-99.
Two nights after losing in Edmonton, the Minnesota Wild was the aggressor from the start in a 3-1 victory over the visiting Oilers on Wednesday.

Larry A. Silverstein, who has won nearly $4.6 billion in insurance payments to cover his losses and help him rebuild at the World Trade Center site, is seeking $12.3 billion in damages from airlines and airport security companies for the 9/11 attack.
The federal government’s decision to deny death benefits to the families of two auxiliary police officers killed a year ago by a gunman in Greenwich Village provoked a fresh round of appeals.

No charges will be filed in a fire that damaged the facade of the Monte Carlo hotel-casino in Las Vegas. Chief Steve Smith of the Clark County Fire Department says the Jan. 25 fire was started by welders working on the roof without proper permits, but it was not intentional. The fire forced the evacuation of 6,000 guests and employees and cost some $100 million in damage and lost business.

A speaker maker and two bus companies have agreed to tentative settlements stemming from a fire at a Rhode Island nightclub that killed 100 people. Court papers show the companies agreed to pay a combined $1.3 million to fire survivors and families of victims of the 2003 fire at the Station in West Warwick. A pyrotechnics display for the band Great White started the fire. The band used speakers from JBL Inc. that a lawsuit alleged had flammable foam inside. JBL says it will pay $815,000. ABC Bus Leasing Inc. and Superstar Services, which leased buses for band members and the fireworks, have agreed to pay a combined $500,000. None of the companies admit wrongdoing.
The family of Carol A. Gotbaum, the Manhattan woman whose death in police custody in the Phoenix airport last year drew national attention, has filed a notice of claim against the city of Phoenix.

The Air Force lawyer who quit as chief prosecutor for the war court at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, five months ago because of what he called political interference has asked to leave the military, he said Tuesday. The lawyer, Col. Morris D. Davis, said he submitted retirement papers last week, partly over fallout from his public criticism of the Guantánamo court and partly because of family concerns. Colonel Davis was a fierce advocate for the court created by the Bush administration to try terror suspects, but he resigned in October, alleging Pentagon officials had exerted political influence in an effort to rush through high-profile charges and approved the use of torture-tainted evidence.

A federal agency said it would consider Endangered Species Act protections for ribbon seals, above, in the Bering Sea, and three other seal species that rely on sea ice for survival. The agency, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, accepted a petition from an environmental group, the Center for Biological Diversity, seeking threatened or endangered status for ribbon seals, above, because their habitat is melting from global warming brought on by humans. NOAA Fisheries also expanded the status review to include ringed, spotted and bearded seals.
If all politics really are local, here’s a shout out to a guy who reminds us that the rules of the game at the bottom aren’t all that different from the rules at the top.
There is a worthy chance for Gov. David Paterson to show business as usual will not always trump justice and economic sense in a supposedly chastened Albany.
John McCain’s talk therapy will not ease, let alone end, the worst foreclosure crisis since the Depression or the financial crisis that has erupted in its wake.
Although the elections on Saturday raise hopes that President Robert Mugabe’s destructive rule can be brought to an end, his defeat would not be enough.
A recording found in Paris is believed to predate Thomas Edison’s invention of the phonograph by nearly 20 years.

A prosecutor accused a Manhattan woman on Wednesday of controlling a ring of several dozen high-priced prostitutes and said that she tried to dismantle the operation when she sensed the authorities closing in.
Lulled by good times, millions of Americans borrowed against the roofs over their heads. Now the bill is coming due.
Rambus, the developer of memory chip technology, said it won an important ruling in a long-running patent lawsuit, sending its shares 39 percent higher.
Prosecutors drew a link between Michael S. Ovitz, a founder of Creative Artists Agency, and illegal database checks by private investigator Anthony Pellicano.
FGIC said its exposure to mortgage losses exceeded legal risk limits and that it might raise loss reserves because of litigation related to the stricken German bank IKB.
A misdirected e-mail message has set the stage for a suit accusing six banks that agreed to finance Clear Channel’s $19.5 billion buyout of reneging on their commitments.
The video game company famous for its “Grand Theft Auto” games told its shareholders to reject a $2 billion buyout bid from Electronic Arts, calling it insufficient.

California fired Coach Ben Braun after another disappointing season in which the Golden Bears missed the N.C.A.A. tournament. Braun spent 12 years at Cal and made the tournament five times. But the Bears went to the N.C.A.A. tournament only once in his final five seasons. Cal finished ninth in the Pacific-10 this season, going 17-16 over all and 6-12 in the conference.

Carlos Bocanegra and Oguchi Onyewu headed in first-half goals, the substitute Eddie Lewis scored in the second half, and the United States beat host Poland, 3-0, in an exhibition game Wednesday night in Krakow. The three-goal margin of victory was the largest for the Americans in Europe since a 3-0 victory against Austria in 1998. The United States opens World Cup qualifying June 15 against Barbados at Carson, Calif.

The Bloomberg administration is proposing that the Police Department, not the Port Authority, assume the main responsibility for securing the streets that will run through the new World Trade Center site and to control access to the complex once it is complete, city and state officials said.

David Beckham made his 100th appearance for England, starting an exhibition match against France and becoming one of five English players to reach the mark. He was shown a yellow card in the 38th minute for pulling Frank Ribery’s shirt and was replaced in the 63rd minute.

Lauren Ross rallied in her second run to beat Laurenne Ross (not related) in the women’s giant slalom as the United States Alpine Championships ended in a steady snowfall at Sugarloaf in Carrabassett Valley, Me. Lauren Ross had been fifth after the first run but charged through the second to finish in 2 minutes 15.22 seconds for both runs. Laurenne Ross was second with a combined time of 2:15.31.

The Finnish ski jumper Janne Ahonen retired after 15 seasons at the international level. Ahonen, 30, finished third over all this season in the World Cup, in which he has 37 career wins among 121 top-three finishes.

The women’s coach Patrick Riml has resigned from the United States Ski Team after five seasons that included Lindsey Vonn’s World Cup title and Julia Mancuso’s Olympic gold medal. Riml, a native of Austria who took over the American women’s program in 2003, said he had no immediate plans other than spending time with his wife and young daughter.
Western Kentucky broke racial barriers in the 1960s with its willingness to integrate the team when it was still taboo.

PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — There are 41 players left in the Mets’ major league camp, meaning that General Manager Omar Minaya must bid adieu to 16 by Sunday to complete the opening day roster. Most of the decisions will not be fulfilled until Friday, when the team leaves Florida, but the lucky 25 who will be introduced Monday at Dolphin Stadium are slowly but surely taking shape.
The space shuttle Endeavour’s mission was the longest flight to the International Space Station since construction of the station began.
A closed military court sentenced in absentia Rakhat Aliyev, who was married to President Nursultan Nazarbayev’s oldest daughter, to 20 years in prison.
A huge explosion at a fireworks warehouse set off a raging fire that raced through an industrial zone in Dubai on Wednesday morning, killing at least two people.
A car bomb exploded at a crowded farmers’ market in southern Afghanistan, killing eight civilians and wounding 17, Afghan officials said.
The principal of Serero Architects said his firm submitted unsolicited designs and put them on the Web, where they were later seen by news organizations.
Iran said the United States, Britain, France and Germany should apologize to the country’s leaders for damaging their reputations through sanctions resolutions against the country’s nuclear program.
As South Korea’s new president prepares to meet with Japan’s prime minister, memories of Japan’s colonial rule continue to sour South Korea on its neighbor’s art forms.
Islamist fighters overpowered government troops and briefly seized a strategic town, the latest in a string of recent victories.
A private New York club is seeking macaroons that are as sweet and chewy as those from a bakery that has closed.
American Airlines and Delta Air Lines said that more than 200 of their planes might not comply with F.A.A. rules for securing wire bundles.
Testimony in the perjury trial of the former cyclist Tammy Thomas implicated Victor Conte Jr. as a distributor of steroids to Barry Bonds and other athletes.
Lenny’s son Cutter Dykstra is one of the nation’s finest high school baseball prospects and a possible first-round pick in the June draft.
The Justice Department did not claim any wrongdoing by the three lawmakers, whose five-day trip to Iraq occurred five months before the American invasion.
Senators are demanding information about how the Federal Reserve arranged the $30 billion shotgun marriage of JPMorgan Chase and Bear Stearns.

The City Council voted on Wednesday to establish one of the nation’s toughest recycling programs for electronic gear, employing an approach that lawmakers said would allow them to move forward with most of the plan while continuing to work through the most controversial elements.
In an effort to market the N.B.A. overseas the Nets, the Heat, the Hornets and the Wizards will be opening their preseasons in Europe.
It may be years before anything gets built over the 26-acre railyards on the Far West Side of Manhattan.
Developments in the state budget suggest that Gov. David A. Paterson of New York and lawmakers are taking steps to get the government back on track in the wake of Eliot Spitzer’s resignation.
The Florida Legislature formally apologized for the state’s “shameful” history of slavery, joining five other states that have expressed public regret.
José Canseco now says he believes Roger Clemens never used steroids and testified truthfully about it before Congress.
Rather than courting fading European stars, U.S. soccer teams are now finding much affordable talent with more flair and better skills from south of the border.
The undercurrent of much of next week’s annual N.F.L. owners meeting will be about protecting the integrity of the game.
The Los Angeles Times is reviewing its recent report linking Sean Combs to the shooting of Tupac Shakur.
The prospect of a pending Supreme Court case that could sweep away many lawsuits against drug companies loomed over Alaska’s $15 million settlement with Eli Lilly.
S. Alan Stern, an experienced planetary scientist who came to NASA less than a year ago to lead the agency’s science division, did not publicly give a reason for his resignation.
Leave it to the Bush administration to throw thousands of law-abiding American workers and companies off a cliff in perilous economic times.
Taylor Phinney, the son of Olympic medal-winning cyclists, will have his own chance to bring one home from Beijing.
A 60-foot-tall tree of the same species as the one made famous by the novel “A Tree Grows in Brooklyn” was chopped down at the Noguchi Museum in Queens.
Southern California Edison plans to install solar panels on more than two square miles of rooftop, enough to power about 160,000 homes when the sun is shining.
Dr. Penland studied how Louisiana’s coastal marshes and barrier islands form, evolve and vanish, and became in the process a forceful advocate for their preservation.
Gov. Jon S. Corzine embraced the recommendations of a task force to improve safety for teenage drivers in New Jersey.
Fewer people flocked to the nation’s fastest-growing metropolitan regions last year compared with the year before, the Census Bureau is reporting.
Many sound bites mischaracterize and distort what John McCain said when he uttered the phrase “maybe a hundred” years in Iraq.
The basic ingredients for life — warmth, water and organic chemicals — are in place on Saturn’s small moon Enceladus, scientists said.
Excavations in a cave in the mountains of northern Spain have uncovered the oldest known remains of human ancestors in Western Europe, scientists said.
The strike by farmers who are protesting a tax increase on the export of grains, has led to shortages of meat and dairy products in the country.
India’s Tata Motors is buying the high-end brands for $2.3 billion — about half what Ford paid for the brands when it bought them.
Mr. Widmark’s debut as a giggling killer made him an overnight star, giving rise to an enduring Hollywood career playing a gallery of chilling hoodlums and flawed heroes.
Dr. Lesch’s name is attached to a hereditary disorder characterized by self-mutilation that he helped identify as a medical student.
Since the March 15 accident, about $90,000 in jewelry, cash and other items has been reported stolen from three apartments in two buildings near the accident site.
Wall Street pulled back on Wednesday after a drop in durable goods orders for February injected more pessimism about the economy into the stock market.
Jay Lauf will leave Condé Nast Publications to become vice president and publisher of The Atlantic.
The company hopes the new feature will turn YouTube from an online video site into a place where marketers can test their messages.
The Frito-Lay division of PepsiCo is trying to transform its SunChips snacks into a “green” brand by powering one of its California production plants with solar power.

A federal appeals court’s ruling appears to have cleared the way for thousands of lawsuits filed against New York City and its contractors by ground zero workers to move closer to trial or settlement.
A fierce debate has erupted over a plan by Utah to allow oil drilling on the Great Salt Lake, and the focus is a work of art that juts into the lake.
Israeli soldiers on Wednesday arrested a Hamas militant suspected by Israel of directing the bloodiest suicide bombing of the Palestinian uprising.
The United States Navy said on Wednesday that an Egyptian citizen was killed when a Navy-contracted ship fired warning shots at approaching motorboats in the Suez Canal.
If you find that mouse pointer on screen distracting while you’re typing on your Windows machine, you might be able to hide it.
What is this thing called XPS Document Writer in the printer settings on my Vista computer?
Is there a way to get the “beats per minute” information for a song automatically filled in for iTunes tracks?
The Mets have only till opening day, Monday, to trim their roster from 25 to 16 players.
State Department workers viewed passport applications containing personal information about high-profile Americans, including Anna Nicole Smith, at least 20 times since January 2007.
Citigroup said it would pay $1.66 billion to the Enron Bankruptcy Estate, which represented Enron creditors caught up in one of the biggest corporate scandals.
Manufacturers, wary of making large investments during the economic slowdown, sent new orders for durable manufactured goods down 1.7 percent in February.
The Supreme Court heard arguments in a case that questions if the mere competence to stand trial also is sufficient to allow self-representation at trial.
A worn parachute found in rural southwestern Washington may be the one used in what authorities call the only unsolved hijacking in United States history.
José Canseco’s book portrayed Alex Rodriguez as curious about steroids and infatuated with Canseco’s former wife.
William E. Kovacic will succeed Deborah Platt Majoras as the chairman of the Federal Trade Commission when she resigns at the end of the month.
The meeting is likely to be the last between the two leaders before the Russian president is replaced by his protégé, Dmitri A. Medvedev.
North Carolina Coach Roy Williams has openly mocked the defensive-minded basketball that has quietly brought Washington State to challenge him in the Round of 16.
The City Council overrode the mayor’s veto of a bill to prohibit landlords from discriminating against tenants who intend to pay their rent with federal rent-subsidy vouchers.
Super Smash Bros. Brawl allows players to choose from a wide selection of Nintendo characters and fight it out, battling one another for the most part by pressing a few buttons on the controller.
The popularity of universal remotes points to a problem — and marketing opportunity — as people create their own home theaters and home automation systems: remote control proliferation.
Just because NATO cannot be an alliance of equals does not mean that it won’t play a significant role in our grand strategy.
Adobe’s new Photoshop Express site lets users group images into Web albums and then post them to popular social networking sites.
The Monster’s iSoniCast Wireless Audio Bridge lets you beam music from the iPod itself to a distant stereo.
Given current economic realities, the selection on Wednesday of a team led by Tishman Speyer to develop the West Side railyards seems like a wishful fantasy.
The business software company reported a 30 percent rise in quarterly profit, but a lower-than-expected increase in new software licenses caused shares to fall in after-hours trading.
The Logitech ClearChat wireless headset broadcasts over the 2.4-gigahertz band, just like many portable phones.
The Nyko 83009 Zero Wireless gamepad buzzes in the player’s hand and replaces the standard-issue PS3 joysticks.
Three young women stagger through a fateful night on the town in Adam Bock’s flimsy but sweet comedy “The Drunken City.”
“Rent,” scheduled to close on June 1, has extended its run through Sept. 7.
“Glory Days,” a show about four high school friends that had its premiere this year at the Signature Theater in Arlington, Va., is moving to the Circle in the Square Theater.

A Czech judge dismissed charges on Tuesday against seven artists accused of scaremongering by Czech Television after they hacked into a live broadcast in June and superimposed images of a nuclear explosion on a picture of mountains being used as the backdrop for a weather forecast, above, Agence France-Presse reported. At the end of a six-hour hearing in the Trutnov regional court, the judge, Stanislava Suchankova, said: “The images of the explosion could not have created public unrest. People were rather amused at how easy it was to disrupt the signal.” Cheers and applause welcomed the decision, but the state prosecutor, Zdena Hourova, said the state would consider an appeal. The artists of the Ztohoven collective had faced a maximum sentence of three years in jail. The stunt, which was posted on the Internet, attracted international notice and won them a national prize for young artists.

The MTV-bred girl group Danity Kane, above, scored its second No. 1 on the Billboard album chart this week. Its new release, “Welcome to the Dollhouse” (Bad Boy/Atlantic), moved 236,000 copies in the United States, Nielsen SoundScan reported. The only other debut in the Top 10 had surprisingly low sales: Flo Rida, the Miami rapper whose song “Low” is the biggest-selling digital track ever, sold only 86,000 copies of his album “Mail on Sunday” (Atlantic) to reach No. 4. The pop compilation “Now That’s What I Call Music!” Vol. 27 is No. 2 with 170,000; Rick Ross’s “Trilla” (Slip-N-Slide/Def Jam), last week’s No. 1, fell two spots with 90,000 sales; and Jack Johnson’s “Sleep Through the Static” (Brushfire/Universal) is No. 5 with 67,000. Also this week, Miley Cyrus became the first female artist since LeAnn Rimes 11 years ago to have two albums in the Billboard Top 10, with “Hannah Montana 2 /Meet Miley Cyrus” (at No. 6) and “Hannah Montana/Miley Cyrus: The Best of Both Worlds Concert” (No. 10), both released by Disney.

No Oscar for Bob Yari. That was the decision by the Second District Court of Appeal in California, which decided that Mr. Yari, below, was not entitled to a statuette even though he was one of the six credited producers of the 2005 film “Crash,” winner of the Academy Award for best film, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Yari sued after the Producers Guild of America and the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences named only two people as producers for purposes of Oscar credit. He contended that the snub damaged his reputation, but the appeals court ruled that private organizations can make their own decisions about their awards. Mr. Yari called the decision “unfortunate.” Bruce Davis, executive director of the academy, said it was “nice to be assured that the courts don’t want to be in the business of deciding who wins an Academy Award.”.

Bob Dylan, below, will join Amy Winehouse, the Police and other performers at the Rock in Rio festival in Madrid in July, Agence France-Presse reported. ... “On Departure,” the first play in nearly two decades by the former Czech president Vaclav Havel, will have its premiere on May 22 at the Archa Theater in Prague, Agence France-Presse reported. ... Justin Timberlake will serve as the host of the annual ESPY Awards at the Nokia Theater in Los Angeles on July 20, The Associated Press reported. “I’ll do my best to deliver a great show, as I do not want to be roughed up backstage by these athletes who are bigger, faster and stronger than me,” he said.

CBS’s sci-fi show “Jericho” limped across the finish line on Tuesday, attracting just under six million viewers for its series finale, Nielsen reported. “Jericho,” first canceled last spring but revived over the summer after an outcry from devoted fans, only to be canceled once again, finished third in its 10 p.m. slot, behind ABC’s “Primetime” (10.4 million) and a repeat of NBC’s “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit” (8.5 million). CBS ranked fourth for the night, despite drawing higher ratings with an “NCIS” rerun at 8 (9.4 million), followed at 9 by “Big Brother,” which also attracted 6 million viewers but fared better than “Jericho” among adults 18 to 49. Fox easily led over all, thanks to a 90-minute edition of “American Idol” from 8 to 9:30 (24.4 million). ABC was second with “Dancing With the Stars” at 9 (17.2 million). NBC finished third.

A Russian billionaire is bankrolling an exhibition that will send about 100 paintings by J. M. W. Turner to the Pushkin Museum of Fine Arts in Moscow from Tate Britain in London in November, Reuters reported. The show will be the first Turner exhibition in Russia since 1975. “The generations have changed since Turner was last in Moscow, and it’s important that the young see him,” said Zinaida Bonami, deputy director of the Pushkin. The man behind the deal is the Russian metals magnate Alisher Usmanov, ranked 142nd last year on the Forbes list of the world’s wealthiest people.

HOUSTON -- Prior to his Thursday news conference, Texas Coach Rick Barnes was talking to several members of the news media when Memphis Coach John Calipari happened to walk by. Calipari said he wanted to ask a question, but Barnes asked him one first. ''I'm going to do a clinic in Austin and I need a free-throw shooting coach,'' Barnes said. ''Can you help me?'' The question elicited laughter. It was a none-too-subtle reminder that Calipari's top-seeded Tigers are shooting 59.2 percent at the free-throw line this season, ranking them 326th out of 328 Division I teams. Calipari, hardly fazed, responded with his own zinger. ''I think your point guard shot that airball,'' Calipari said. His quip was a reference to the final seconds of Texas's victory against Miami on Sunday when the sophomore D.J. Augustin's airballed a free throw. Barnes responded: ''Hey, that's what I'm talking about. I can't coach it. I need you.''

A memorial reception will be held on Thursday, April3, 2008 from 5:00 pm to 7:00 pm at the University of Rhode Island's University Club, 95 Upper College Road, Kingston. Standish, President East Side House Board of Managers John A. Sanchez, Executive director East Side House Settlement

BOORSCH--Jean, 102, Street Professor Emeritus of French, Yale University, died peacefully at home, March 23, 2008. Born in Anzin, France, graduated from Lycee Condorcet and Ecole Normale Superieure, Paris. Taught French language and literature at Middlebury College, 1929-34, at Yale 1934-74. Taught at Middlebury summer language school in 1940s and 1950s; directed French school 1963-71. Created ''methode orale,'' which developed into ''French in Action.'' Chevalier of the Legion d'Honneur. Predeceased by his wife of 63 years, Louise Totten Boorsch, in 1997, and son John Peter Boorsch, in 1999. Survived by son James Totten Boorsch, daughters Suzanne Boorsch and Mary Louise Vogler, son-in-law Allan Appel, daughter-in-law Dorothea Dietrich, grandchildren Sophie Appel, Nathaniel Appel, Elizabeth Vogler. Private burial; memorial service later in the spring.

STECKLOW--Thomas, 95 years young, loved by family and friends. The Stecklow family is saddened by the passing of our patriarch, Papa Tommy, born May 5, 1912 in Brooklyn, NY. He raised his family in Brooklyn and Valley Stream, NY, retired to Winston Towers, Miami, FL and then Huntington Pointe, Delray Beach, FL. He was a role model to his children, Elaine (the late Abraham Siev), Martin (Judi), William (Lynn), Arthur (Marion). His spirit will live on through his 20 grandchildren and 21 great-grandchildren and generations to come. His family was large in numbers, but his love was shared personally to all. We will always remember how lucky we were to have had him with us. Rest well Pop and give love to Nanny.

NATURAL Landscapes, a wholesale nursery, supplies the Delaware Nature Society's native plant sale, held at Coverdale Farm, 543 Way Road, in Greenville, Del., on May 3 and 4 (www.delawarenaturesociety.org/nps.html). The New England Wild Flower Society's Nasami Farm, in Whately, Mass., has a large variety of blueberry plants, including Burgundy, named for its fall color, and Friendship, a half-high type good for small gardens. The farm is open to the public eight weekends in the spring, Thursday through Sunday, from April 17 through June 8; it reopens for the same long weekends Sept. 4 and closes after the first weekend in October. The farm's plants are also sold at Garden in the Woods, the society's public garden in Framingham, Mass. (508-877-7630; www.newfs.org).

BRALOVE--Olga M.D., of 140 East 81st St. Apt 9D, NY, NY 10028, died peacefully on March 23, 2008 with her children at her side. Having completed her medical training in her home town Buenos Aires, Argentina, she moved to New York to complete her residency at Harlem Hospital. Specializing in Psychiatry, she met her husband, Richard Bralove, M.D. (1921-1982) at Bellevue Hospital. They moved to Scarsdale, NY where they raised their three children, collected art, antiques, bred and showed champion Borzois. A pioneer in the treatment of Alcoholism she founded and directed a nationally recognized outpatient program in Grasslands, Valhalla, NY. In 1987, she stopped her practice, moved to Manhattan and dedicated her life to her art, travel, and the cultural resources of New York City. A devoted student of oils and water color at the Art Students League, she was known for her passion, perseverance, insight and vitality. In addition to her children David of Chevy Chase, MD, Bob of San Francisco and Alicia of New York, she is survived by grandchildren Benjamin, Nicholas and Gabriella Bralove of Chevy Chase, and Richard and Alistair Ramirez of Manhattan. Thank you for showing us how to live life to the very last moment.

ROSEN--Ann Claire (Shenker). Beloved wife, mother, grandmother, and greatgrandmother. Died in Boca Raton, FL Tuesday. For 45 years she was a treasured teacher and colleague in the Westchester School System, starting in Special Education, then as a substitute teacher in many of the school districts in the county. She graduated from N.Y.U. age 18. After raising her children, she earned her Masters from Manhattanville College in Purchase, NY. She lived in Harrison, NY for 50 years and moved to Hunters Run in Boynton Beach, FL 5 years ago. She clearly missed New York. She is survived by her devoted husband Bob, her children, Lynda Rosen Obst, Richard, Michael, her grandchildren Oliver Obst, Jonathan, Sally, Molly, Caroline, Nicky, and great-granddaugther Sunny Natasha Obst. A memorial service will be held at Hunters Run in Boynton Beach, FL, 11am Thursday. A graveside funeral will be held at 11am Friday at the Independent Standford Lodge, Exit 39, E. side of Hoyt St, N. of Camp Ave. Darien, CT. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be sent to: Autism Speaks.

An ''Ad Campaign'' analysis on Wednesday about a new television advertisement for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton misstated her action on a recent trade agreement with Peru. Although she publicly supported the deal, she did not vote for the pact because she was not present when the vote was taken.

ZWEIG--Estelle. Beloved wife, mother, grandmother and great-grandmother. Estelle Zweig, died March 19, 2008 at age 83. Friends and family are welcome to join in a memorial service at her home in Boca Raton, FL on March 30, 2008 at 10am. The family will also welcome guests that day 1-4pm and on March 31, 2008 10am-1pm. Born in Astoria, NY January 14, 1925 as Estelle Mildred Mishler to Julius and Shirley Mishler, she had two brothers, Arthur and Lenny, and a sister, Phyllis (deceased). Estelle graduated Brooklyn College 1945, and became a NYC teacher. She later obtained a Masters to become a guidance counselor and teacher for the emotionally challenged. She married the love of her life, Robert Zweig on August 23, 1947, and they shared 50 blissful years in Brooklyn, then Altoona, then back to New York in Woodside and later on 185th St. in Fresh Meadows, until retiring in 1993 to Boca Raton. Robert (Bob) died February 12, 1997. Estelle was known by her family for her strong and articulate opinions, as well as her culinary delights. From her matzo ball soup at Passover to her bread stuffing at Thanksgiving, she delivered family favorites with ease and modesty. Estelle was best known by her friends as an avid tennis player, swimmer, cook, and always an eclectic, sharp conversationalist. Estelle is survived by her two sons, Paul of Columbia, MD, and Michael of Malibu, CA, by six adored grandchildren, Rachel, Aaron and Ben (of Paul and Sandy), and Megan, Casey and Sarah (of Michael and Marie), and a great-grandson, Robert William (of Noel and Rachel Collins). Estelle will be dearly missed. Donations, if requested, may be made on her behalf to UJA.

KLEIN--Belle (Bessie Goldfarb). Beloved wife of the late Leon Klein. Devoted mother of Geri Sedler and Irene Klein and loving mother-in-law of Herbert Sedler. Daughter of the late Isaac and Eva.
