LERNER--Philip. We mourn Philip Lerner, who died March 23 after battling COPD. Loving father of Barbara, David, Karen, grandfather of Aron, Maddy, Lizzy, father-in-law of Paul, Anne. Devoted brother to Janet, brother-in-law to Marty, uncle to Fred, Carol, uncle-inlaw to Vicki, Tom, greatuncle to Daniel, Becky, Zach. Former husband of Phyllis Freberge; together they maintained our family. Born on Ellis Island, 1923, to Rebecca and Israel Lerner, whose first daughter died in transit from Russia. Brownsville, Brooklyn native; Stuyvesant H.S., N.Y.U. graduate. WWII veteran; mechanical engineer; math and science teacher at Clara Barton. Expert in Laplace Transform; toy inventor. Lindy hop and 1939 Duncan Yo Yo champion; big band aficionado; guitar player; Times crossword expert; lifelong Democrat; Brooklyn Dodgers and Mets fan. He loved his family, and he was loved in return. We'll miss him greatly. Service at Wellwood, March 27, 1:00pm.

CHERINGTON--Dorothea, a beloved leader of the New York theatrical community, passed away on March 22, 2008 after a long illness. She was the Development Director of the Theatre Development Fund, The Acting Company, and WNYC. A graduate of Radcliffe College, she was the widow of Paul W. Cherington, Professor of the Harvard Business School. She leaves her beloved daughter, Anne tenCate Cherington, and a large extended family. The funeral will take place on Friday, March 28th at 11:00 at the Marble Collegiate Church on Fifth Avenue and 29th Street.

PICKER--Harvey. A physicist, inventor, businessman, educator, philosopher and friend died on March 22 at age 92. Mr. Picker ran Picker X-ray Company for 25 years. He was a well-known inventor of x-ray technology and groundbreaking developments including cobalt therapy for cancer, nuclear imaging diagnostics and the use of ultrasound for oceanography, which was adapted for medical imaging. Along with his wife Jean, an ambassador to the U.N. in the 1960s, now deceased, he then founded the Picker Institute, a nonprofit dedicated to advancing the principles of patient-centered care and pioneered the systematic collection of data from hospital patients to help improve the delivery of medical services in the U.S. and Europe. Mr. Picker also taught at his alma mater, Colgate University, and served as the dean of the School of International and Public Affairs at Columbia University. He also helped found the Picker Engineering Program at Smith College, his wife's alma mater. He is survived by two daughters, Bobbi Hamill of Boston, MA and Gale Jean Picker of Seattle, WA, as well as three grandchildren, Jean Picker Larsen, Evelyn Picker Larsen and Matthew James Mrachek. A memorial service will be held in Camden, ME in early June.

The increasingly nasty standoff between Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama could take a toll in November, according to a new survey from Gallup. ''A sizable proportion of Democrats would vote for John McCain next November if he is matched against the candidate they do not support for the Democratic nomination,'' the pollsters said. ''This is particularly true for Hillary Clinton supporters, more than a quarter of whom currently say they would vote for McCain if Barack Obama is the Democratic nominee.''

HAUM--Barbara Rose. After a long battle with illness Barbara Rose Haum passed away peacefully on March 25, 2008. Barbara was born in 1962 in Frankfurt, Germany. She had been living in New York City since the 1980s, a city she loved dearly, and knew as well as any native New Yorker. She will be dearly missed by husband Henri and daughter Talia. She also leaves behind mother Marianna, father Herbert, sister Annette as well as many nieces, nephews and in-laws. Barbara completed her under graduate work at the School for Visual Arts and received a doctorate in Studio Art from New York University. She was an assistant Professor of Culture and Communications at New York University. A respected artist, teacher, researcher and valued colleague. Over the span of her artistic career in New York the emphasis of her work gradually shifted from photography to creating multimedia installations to digital imagery and internet based performances, particularly her pioneering work in internet2 based theater performances. Barbara was the recipient of many prestigious awards and honors. Amongst many other venues, her works have been exhibited nationally and internationally at the National Museum of Women in the Arts in Washington, DC, The Bronx Museum of the Arts, The Jewish Museum in Frankfurt, Germany, The Museum of Contemporary Art in Paris, France, The Photography Forum in Frankfurt, Germany. Barbara was a wonderful and loyal friend to all who knew her. Her wisdom, insight, wit and humor touched everyone she met. Barbara will be remembered as the gentle bearer of a moving and original soul. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, March 27 at 1:30pm at The Plaza Jewish Memorial Funeral Home at the corner of 91st and Amsterdam in Manhattan. HAUM--Barbara Rose. The Department of Media, Culture, and Communication at the Steinhardt School, New York University, mourns the loss of Barbara Rose Haum, gifted artist, scholar and teacher. She will be remembered always for her creativity, vibrancy and spirit, and as a truly remarkable friend and colleague. Our deepest sympathies to her husband Henri Lustiger - Thaler and her daughter Talia.

For the next week, the New Directors/New Films series -- or ''Serious Directors/Small Films,'' as A. O. Scott prefers to think of it -- offers ''friendly, sincere absurdism'' (think Miranda July's ''Me and You and Everyone We Know'') and ''unadorned realism'' in more than 30 movies at Lincoln Center and MoMA. Mr. Scott enjoyed ''The Toe Tactic,'' from the animator Emily Hubley (you know her work from ''Hedwig and the Angry Inch''); ''Jellyfish,'' from an Israeli husband and wife; and ''Munyurangabo,'' set in Rwanda (the latter two are showing tonight). For even more miniature offerings, head to the IFC Center, where tonight only they'll screen the best short films from the upcoming, and final, 15th installment of the New York Underground Film Festival. ''Big Ideas in Deceptively Small Packages,'' by A. O. Scott

GILLIS--Freda. 1914-2008, died peacefully at the Hebrew Home for the Aged in the Riverdale section of the Bronx after a long struggle with Parkinson's Disease, which she self-diagnosed in 1997. Born in Riga, Latvia in 1914 to Rosa and David Neiburgs, Freda received her medical degree from the University of Bologna in 1939. She was able to leave for Portugal four days before all travel for Jews in Italy was prohibited. She waited in Lisbon for the arrival of her medical diploma. Beneath her name on the parchment document was an inscription indicating that she was ''of the Jewish race.'' She then continued her journey to the United States, escaping the tyranny of Nazism that claimed her mother and other members of her family. Once in New York, Dr. Gillis completed her medical residency at Brooklyn Jewish Hospital and was a primary care physician and later a psychiatrist in both private practice and on the staffs of Grasslands Hospital in Valhalla, NY and the Veterans' Administration Hospital in the Bronx. She was married for 28 years to Ivan Gillis, who died in 1968. The two met when Freda, a newly arrived immigrant, was a student in Ivan's class that prepared foreign doctors for the Medical Board exam. Freda was also predeceased by her brother, Dr. Felix Neiburgs, who lived in Russia from 1939 to 1991, and died in New York in 2003. Conversant in seven languages, Freda never lost her accent. She will be remembered for her warmth, empathy, generosity, sense of humor and lust for life. A woman whose independent spirit and professional accomplishments were in many ways ahead of their time, she was open to the great variety of human experiences, and served as a powerful role model for many who knew her. Freda is survived by her children, Verna, David and Renee; grandchildren, Ivan, Sarah and Aram; and great-grandchildren, Max and Ezri.

MAY--John A. (Jack), 79, of Berwyn, Pennsylvania, a prominent lawyer and businessman, died suddenly Easter morning of heart failure at his second home in Hobe Sound, Florida. Mr. May, the son of A. John May and Sara Brothers McLaughlin, was born in Petoskey, Michigan on November 2, 1928. He grew up in Selinsgrove, Pennsylvania, graduated from Mercersburg Academy in 1946 and then attended Princeton University on an ROTC scholarship. A member of the Cloister Club, he graduated from Princeton with a degree in Economics in 1950. Following his first year at Harvard Law School, Mr. May was commissioned as a second lieutenant in the U.S. Army, serving as a forward artillery observer with the 18th Airborne Corps and 45th Infantry Division in Korea from 1951 to 1952, ending his active service as a Captain. He continued to serve as a reserve officer in the 108th Field Artillery, 28th Infantry Division of the Pennsylvania National Guard until 1957. Mr. May married Gwendolyn Abrahamsen in 1952. Mr. May received his law degree from Harvard Law School in 1954. Mr. May joined the law firm of Duane, Morris and Heckscher (now Duane Morris LLP), headquartered in Philadelphia, in 1954. He was made a partner in the firm in 1962, served as Vice-Chairman from 1985 to 1990, Chairman and CEO from 1990 until 1995 and Counsel to the firm from his retirement in 1999 until his death. He loved the legal profession and convinced his son and three daughters to attend law school as the best form of education possible. In addition to the practice of law, Mr. May was active in many business ventures involving property and casualty companies and various publicly and privately owned manufacturing companies. He was a Director and then Chairman of the PMA Capital Corporation, a director of the PMA Foundation, and a director of the Pennsylvania Manufacturers' Association. Mr. May was also very involved in his community. In 1988, Mr. May was honored by the Easttown Township Board of Supervisors for his nearly thirty years of continuous township service. He served on the township Zoning Board of Adjustment from 1959-1984 as both a member of the committee and its Chairman, as well as serving as a member and Chairman of the township's Planning Commission from 1970 to 1983. He was a board member and later President of the School Board and a member of the township Board of Supervisors. He was instrumental in developing Trinity House in Berwyn, a living facility for low and middle income elderly residents. Perhaps as important as the practice of law, Mr. May loved the game of golf. A member of several golf clubs, including Pine Valley and Loblolly, Mr. May was one of the founders and early President of Waynesborough Country Club in Paoli, Pennsylvania and the founder and Chairman of Stonewall in Elverson, Pennsylvania. With the active support of his wife, he traveled to England, Scotland and Ireland every summer for 25 years to play golf at the birthplace of the game and owned a house in the Dominican Republic where he could indulge his passion during the winter. He is survived by his wife of fifty-five years, Gwendolyn, his son, A. John May III and his wife, Jeanne of Paoli, PA, his daughters, Ann Moore of Milford, CT, Susan Eckman and her husband, Rick of Chadds Ford, PA and Elizabeth Gieske and her husband, Edward of Paoli, PA and 14 grandchildren. He will be remembered by his family as a man who shaped their lives with the force of his intellect and his personality and for his generosity; and who was always there when needed. The funeral will be private with a celebration of life held at Stonewall Golf Club on Saturday, March 29th at 4:00pm. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests contributions in his memory to the J. Wood Platt Caddy Scholarship Fund.

HYLAND--William G. The Council on Foreign Relations mourns the passing of former Foreign Affairs magazine editor William G. Hyland, whose keen intelligence and dry wit guided the Council's flagship publication from 1984 to 1992. Mr. Hyland was a dedicated public servant with a long and distinguished career in the field of intelligence and foreign policy, serving with distinction at senior levels in the Nixon and Ford administrations. To those fortunate to work with him at the Council, he will be remembered as a generous colleague, mentor, and friend. We offer heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Evelyn Hyland, his children, William Jr. and James, and their families. Richard Haass, President, Council on Foreign Relations James F. Hoge, Jr., Editor, Foreign Affairs

DRURY--Leila, died March 16 in Charleston, SC, of lung cancer. Born on June 16, 1925 in Washington, DC to Leila Florence Batty and John Dryden. Her great-grandfather, Senator John Fairfield Dryden, founded Prudential Insurance Co. During his Senate term, he worked with President Theodore Roosevelt to authorize the Panama Canal. Attended Miss Gill's School in Bernardsville, NJ, home of his grandparents Mr. and Ms. Forrest F. Dryden. Leila grew up in Bernardsville, NJ. As a secondary school student and personal friend of Miss Gill, in 1938 she persuaded her parents to donate to the Gill School Stronghold, the home of her grandparents, Grace Marion Carleton and Forrest Fairchild Dryden. Stronghold was converted in 1940 to house the girls academy, which later merged to form the coeducational Gill-Saint Bernard's School. Leila graduated from Westover School in 1943. She then married Frederic N. Millen, a pilot in the Army Air Corps. He retired as Colonel USAF, and now lives in Austin, TX. The marriage ended in divorce in 1972. In 1979, she married Peter A. Drury of Charleston, SC and lived with him there until his death in 2003. She is survived by her daughter and son-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. Lester Lovin of Austin and her son, the Rev. John Frederic Millen of San Francisco, CA; and five grandchildren. She studied voice at Mannes College, and sang with the Charleston Symphony Chorus. Memorial services will be held on Friday, April 4, 2pm Bishop Gadsden Chapel. Donations to Bishop Gadsden home or the Westover School.

There are times when the gestures available to the average New Yorker are just not sufficient. Wouldn’t it be great if there were a discreet sign you could make when you see a celebrity on the street and want to express admiration for his or her work, without interrupting any conversations or causing any discomfort? Wouldn’t a universally understood gesture be handy to express, while driving — “yikes, sorry, didn’t mean to cut you off, my mistake” — to pre-empt more common gestures that fly during such encounters? How about a polite one for “please put your knees together, mister, as you’re taking up three subway seats?”While certain gestures have become notorious lately, like that push-the-thumbtack into-my-teleprompter to-prove-a-point move that says “I want to be presidential,” or the facial expression through which a governor says, in effect, “I am swallowing my lips because I am so busted sorry,” there is a need for an expansion of the number of widely understood gestures.

Like Joyce, I found Stephen's comments about how "Bonfire" was received in the academic world - as an attack on Reaganism - to be very interesting, because for many years before the book came out Wolfe had been making his conservative beliefs well-known. Many people, myself included as a college student in the seventies, were shocked that Wolfe, the liberating stylist and journalist, turned out to be very antipathetic to liberals and leftish intellectualism in all its forms, political, literary, artistic and architectural. Yes, in about 1970 he had written "Radical Chic and Mau-Mauing the Flak Catchers," but they were brilliant pieces that didn't necessarily demonstrate a systematic conservatism. By the late 1980s, though, Wolfe had written and lectured often about his conservative views, he had been a guest of Reagan's and Christopher Hitchens had called him the "moth-eaten court jester" for the White House. Wolfe would probably be amused that the academy was so insulated and so steeped in its own conventional wisdom that its members simply assumed that he agreed with them.

Big Wall Street investment companies have jumped all over the Federal Reserve's unusual offer to obtain emergency loans, as borrowing more than doubled in the program's second week, The Associated Press reported.
Will Lehman Brothers bounce back?

As rumors swirled in recent weeks that the banks backing the $25 billion buyout of Clear Channel Communications would scotch the deal unless the private equity buyers agreed to rewrite the credit terms, many observers -- including The Deal Professor -- suspected the sponsors, too, would be secretly delighted to see the deal die.

Clearly, work/life balance has captured the world's attention when part of the recruiting strategy of Israel's domestic intelligence agency is allowing four of its agents to blog anonymously about their workaday lifestyles. Check out this item, "Israeli secret agents blog on work-life balance," from the Daily Telegraph.

Microsoft's hostile takeover attempt against Yahoo may encounter an unexpected hurdle in August after a Chinese antimonopoly law takes effect that will extend the nation's economic influence far beyond its borders.

Senator Barack Obama called Thursday for tighter regulation of mortgage lenders, banks and financial houses, even as he spoke of pumping $30 billion into the economy to shield homeowners and local governments from the worst effects of the collapse of the housing bubble.
European aircraft manufacturer Airbus on Thursday ended talks to sell three German production sites to financial investors, blaming instability in the financial markets and a record euro.

Despite all the headlines in recent months about high-profile hedge-fund collapses and near-collapses, data from the industry publication Absolute Return suggests that 2008 is actually on pace for the smallest number of fund shutdowns in several years.

David Neeleman, who as founder of JetBlue Airways helped to redefine start-up carriers in the United States by using new jets and offering above-bargain-basement service, said Thursday that he would start a domestic airline in Brazil.
Citigroup was sued on Thursday by two clients accusing the financial institution of failing to properly disclose the risks of investing in auction rate securities.
JPMorgan Chase, the world's second-biggest custodian of assets, agreed to buy 200 billion euros, or $315.6 billion, of investments from Nordea Bank, the Nordic region's biggest bank by value.

Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the government-chartered mortgage companies, may raise as much as $20 billion in capital as part of an agreement that allows them to buy more debt securities, their regulator told Bloomberg News .

SolarWinds, a provider of network management software, filed to go public last week, becoming the first enterprise technology company to do so in three months. The 451 Group looks at its prospects and concludes it could shine on Wall Street.

The Harvard Management Company, which oversees the university's $34.9 billion endowment, appointed Jane Mendillo, the chief investment officer at Wellesley College, as its president and chief executive on Thursday.

The woes of United States banks could mount, Boston Fed President Eric Rosengren said Friday, adding that the Federal Reserve, with its access to their confidential information, can use those data to make sound policy.
From The Onion:
Man Group, the world's largest publicly traded hedge fund manager, said Thursday that annual earnings would surpass analysts' estimates as its flagship fund gained even as competitors faltered.
Gripes from the complaint blog whitewhine.com:
The first hedge fund to float in Amsterdam plans to add a London listing in a boost for the London Stock Exchange's efforts to attract so-called alternative fund listings.

3i Group, the publicly-listed London private equity firm, on Thursday reported a 72 percent increase in its investments for the first 11 months of its financial year, but said there was a decline in its realization proceeds for the same period.
MonoSol Rx, a drug delivery company, has canceled its planned initial public offering of 4 million shares, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing on Thursday.
India is known around the world for many things: the Taj Mahal, curry, call centers, arranged marriage, Rajasthan and the caste system, to name a few. But it ought to be known for bespoke.

Air France-KLM agreed to take on about 900 more employees of Alitalia's ground services unit than planned under a new proposal to secure its takeover of the struggling Italian carrier, according to Reuters.
More of your "late night" jokes(send via the comment link below):
Athletic shoe retailer retailer Finish Line, fresh from fleeing a merger with rival Genesco, said the escape cost it $81.5 million and led to a fourth-quarter loss of nearly $40 million.
Illinois Tool Works said Thursday it would buy Quipp, a publicly traded maker of newspaper production equipment, in a deal valuing Quipp at less than $10 million.
China National Offshore Oil Corporation, the parent of CNOOC, said it is in talks to acquire several independent refineries in eastern China's Shandong province.

Mitchells & Butlers will discover on Friday which private equity groups, if any, are willing to take up its offer of partial stakes in the British pubs group, having concluded that market conditions have all but killed off the prospect of an outright cash offer.
Credit Suisse Group will allocate at least $300 million to Hudson Capital Management's Hudson Clean Energy Partners fund, the companies announced Thursday.

American International Group has filed a complaint in New York State Supreme Court against its former chief executive, Maurice R. Greenberg, and six other former directors and officers, accusing them of breaching their fiduciary duty.
The Xerox Corporation said Thursday it would pay $670 million to settle a securities lawsuit from 2000, without admitting wrongdoing.

Pentagon Capital Management, a 1 billion pound ($2 billion) hedge fund run by the investor Lewis Chester, said Thursday that it would close its funds and return investors' money because of a mutual fund trading investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Additional images from the exhibitions,

Anyone with an unfulfilled desire to sing might be interested in an upcoming festival at London's Southbank Centre. "Chorus", devoted to choral singing and the human voice, runs from May 11th - 18th and offers opportunities for both participation and listening.
Evidence continues to mount that Spain's property market is heading for a "crash," not a "slowdown."
No matter how much sex “The Tudors” has given us, it is a show that never gets quite dirty enough.
“Tracey Ullman’s State of the Union,” a new series that arrives Sunday on Showtime, is a one-woman travelogue of American fame, folly and misfortune.
The flailing, protagonists of “Backseat,” while not exactly 40-year-old virgins, can have avoided that fate only by the tender mercies of women with low expectations.
“Hats Off” is a documentary tribute to the 93-year-old actress Mimi Weddell, one of those people for whom the word “individual” seems especially apt.
Greed is good and comes without a hint of conscience in “21,” a feature-length bore about some smarty-pants who take Vegas for a ride.
A major access road to Jerusalem has taken on special significance in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.
When Catholic churches close, their  precious artifacts find new homes.
The following is a transcript of Senator Bob Casey of Pennsylvania endorsing Senator Barack Obama’s presidential campaign, as provided by CQ Transcriptions via The Associated Press.
Thursday night's action in the N.C.A.A. tournament.
A look at Silver Star Mountain, in British Columbia.

PHOENIX -- Give credit to the members of the U.C.L.A. band, who showed that their basketball I.Q.'s matched their lofty S.A.T. scores. As the seconds drained down in No. 1 U.C.L.A.'s 88-78 victory over No. 12 Western Kentucky, the Bruins band chanted one name: James Keefe.
The Rangers' seventh straight victory over the Devils this season came with so many subplots, it was hard to keep them all straight Thursday night:

O.K., full disclosure. I haven't stopped questioning my A.L. picks since the moment I posted them. I'm not second-guessing my pick of the Yankees to miss the playoffs; I still can't believe I couldn't squeeze the Tigers in there. I guess I've just seen teams (the late 1990s Mariners) with awesome lineups become undone by a bad bullpen. And that Angels pick looks shakier with each passing injury out there, but oh well. In the words of Brian McNamee, it is what it is.

Comedy Central has successfully satirized evening newscasts on "The Daily Show with Jon Stewart" and news talk shows on "The Colbert Report" with Stephen Colbert. Last month it introduced a court show satire by Lewis Black called "Root of All Evil." Up next: spoofs of reality shows and news magazines.
In some ways, there is a grim, accidental timeliness in the release of “Stop-Loss,” which focuses on the ordeal of American soldiers in and out of combat.
A confused young artist is torn between his family and his future in “Shelter,” a sensitive romantic drama from the writer and director Jonah Markowitz.
Forget reality shows exalting American gluttony and savor the more refined amenities on the coasts of southern France in the cynical Gallic comedy “Priceless.”
“A Four Letter Word” is a surprisingly endearing romantic comedy that explores gay relationships with low-budget verve.
“Flawless” is a mildly diverting period heist movie in which an odd couple conspire to loot an evil London diamond company, for which they both work.
“Run, Fat Boy, Run” is an inspirational fantasy with guy’s-guy banter and gross-out humor. Yet it’s effective and affecting.
“The Cool School,” a breezy, lively documentary about a thin slice of the Los Angeles fine art scene in the 1950s, is easy on the eyes, and the ears too.
Any film that dares attempt a nonjudgmental portrait of John Lennon’s assassin would most likely be accused of tastelessness, but in the case of “Chapter 27” the charges are justified.
“My Brother Is an Only Child” is a lively minor addendum to the grand tradition of Italian fraternal cinema.
A Delaware court ruled in favor of Barry Diller in his dispute with Liberty Media’s chairman John Malone, paving the way for IAC to proceed with its planned spin-off of four units.
Membership in the United Auto Workers union fell below 500,000 for the first time since World War II, reflecting the restructuring undertaken by Detroit’s automakers.
Membership in the United Auto Workers union has fallen below 500,000 for the first time since World War II, reflecting the reorganization undertaken by Detroit’s automakers.
Informal merger talks resumed between the airlines with Northwest inquiring whether Delta would be interested in pursuing a combination even without prior pilot approval.
The retailer slashed its earnings forecast for the first three months of the year by 33 percent, blaming an outright drop in consumer spending that bodes poorly for competitors.
A string of planned protests centered around the Olympic torch relay is troubling news for sponsors of the event, including Coca-Cola, Lenovo and Samsung Electronics.
UBS, Merrill Lynch and the Bank of America were subpoenaed as the state looks into whether investors were properly informed of the risks of auction-rate securities.
The move by Northwest follows similar steps taken by other carriers to bolster revenue amid high fuel prices.
Boeing agreed to acquire a 50 percent stake in a South Carolina fuselage subassembly facility in a move that could improve efficiency in the construction of the new 787.
The mortgage lender said that banking regulators had declared its banking unit undercapitalized and had required the company to raise money or find a buyer in two months.
Consumer spending grew at the slowest pace in more than a year in February, as the housing slump and a weak job market continued to put pressure on pocketbooks.

Consumers, jolted by a credit crisis, job cuts and soaring energy costs, turned in the weakest spending performance in 17 months in February, more evidence that the risks of a recession are increasing.
The department store operator slashed its first-quarter earnings forecast, citing lower-than-expected sales through the Easter holiday and low consumer confidence.
U.C.L.A. survived scary second-half moments Thursday night to advance to the regional final with an 88-78 victory over Western Kentucky.
Mr. Mann brought incisive characterization and a searing sense of justice to “Judgment at Nuremberg,” for which he won an Academy Award for screenwriting.
Louisville went ahead early, and while Tennessee kept the game within range into the second half it could never close the gap in a 79-60 loss.
Two people were killed and a third was injured by gunfire outside a bar in Newark on Thursday night, the police said.
Gov. David A. Paterson and New York State legislative leaders announced an agreement on a rough spending ceiling of $124 billion for the fiscal year that begins April 1.

TBS announced yesterday that Ron Darling and Buck Martinez would be the analysts for its first season of Sunday afternoon broadcasts that are to begin on April 6 with Boston playing Toronto. Each will work separately with Chip Caray, the play-by-play announcer, and Darling’s appearances will not conflict with his schedule as a Mets game and studio analyst for SportsNet New York.

A defendant in a lawsuit stemming from the exhumation of the Notre Dame great George Gipp’s body in Houghton, Mich., said a judge had dismissed the case. Two men claiming to be Gipp’s cousins sued in November, contending that the remains of the player’s sister, Bertha Isabelle Gipp Martin, were disturbed because workers initially dug in the wrong spot. She was buried next to her brother. The remains of Gipp, who died in 1920 of pneumonia, were dug up Oct. 4 for DNA testing to determine whether he fathered his girlfriend’s child. The results were negative.

Brian McNamee gave a brief motivational speech to a small group of workout buffs but refused to comment on the steroid scandal that landed him and Roger Clemens, his former client, in front of Congress. In his first public comments since testifying that he injected Clemens with steroids and human growth hormone, McNamee spoke to about 25 high-school athletes, coaches and parents.

Angela Stanford shot a career-best 10-under 62 to break the Prospector Course record and take a three-stroke lead over the defending champion Lorena Ochoa in the Safeway International in Superstition Mountain, Ariz.

Ron Polk, the Southeastern Conference’s career leader in coaching wins and an outspoken critic of the N.C.A.A. during his tenure at Mississippi State, has resigned. The university said his resignation would take effect at the end of the season. Polk is in his 29th season as head coach at Mississippi State and in his 35th over all. He has clashed with the N.C.A.A. over recent rules changes.

Dean Wilson birdied three of the last four holes in windy conditions for a six-under 66 and a one-stroke lead after the first round of the Zurich Classic in Avondale, La. Wilson had played eight straight tournaments before taking two weeks off.
The Musketeers outlasted West Virginia in a 79-75 overtime victory on Thursday to move on to the Round of 8.
Jarkko Ruutu had a goal and two assists Thursday night as the Pittsburgh Penguins beat the visiting New York Islanders, 3-1.
Officials are denouncing a Food and Drug Administration decision asking American grocers to stop selling cantaloupe imported from a Honduran company because of links to a salmonella outbreak
Washington State was able to play to their strengths against North Carolina, yet still ended up getting trounced, 68-47.
An Egyptian security official said border guards killed two African migrants who were trying to cross illegally into Israel at the northern Sinai Peninsula.
After weeks of advance hoopla trumpeting the opening of London’s Heathrow Airport new, high-tech Terminal 5, the facility opened in something less than glory.
President Robert Mugabe gave out 450 cars to senior and midlevel doctors at government hospitals in what opponents say is a vote-buying campaign.
Security forces raided the apartments of journalists from independent and foreign news media, days after the police broke up an opposition rally in the capital, Minsk.
The Rangers scored their wildest goal of the season with three minutes left, capping a come-from-behind victory Thursday at the Garden.
A New York cabbie was honored for capturing a man suspected of sexual abuse by trapping him inside of his cab until police arrived.

Canadian communications regulators approved the 51.7 billion Canadian dollar ($50.9 billion) buyout of BCE, the country’s biggest phone provider, and set conditions that require the carrier to remain Canadian controlled. One of the six criteria requires Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan to appoint six directors, instead of the five proposed. The pension plan and its United States partners agreed to modify the original deal to appease the Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission, which had expressed concerns that BCE might end up being controlled by United States investors. That proposal did not go far enough, the agency said in its decision. Deborah Allan, a spokeswoman for the pension plan, said the pension fund was reviewing the conditions and had no further comment.

The Barrick Gold Corporation said that Greg Wilkins, its president and chief executive since 2003, had taken a leave of absence for medical reasons and that the chairman, Peter Munk, would act as interim chief executive. Barrick, the gold-mining company, said that Mr. Wilkins had “a serious medical condition that will require his absence as he undergoes further tests, examinations and treatment.” Barrick did not elaborate.

EADS, the parent of Airbus, landed its second big government order in two months when Britain signed a $26.36 billion contract to replace the Royal Air Force’s aging fleet of midair refueling tankers. Airbus will provide the Royal Air Force with 14 A330-200 passenger aircraft converted for military use under a 27-year contract. EADS, whose full name is European Aeronautic Defense and Space, was the junior partner in a consortium headed by Northrop Grumman that was chosen over Boeing to supply the United States Air Force with 179 refueling aircraft for $35 billion.
President Evo Morales, left, has set an April 30 deadline for Bolivian subsidiaries of British Petroleum, Repsol and Ashmore Energy International to return to state control.

An obituary on Monday about Israel López, the Cuban bassist and composer known as Cachao, who was a pioneer of the mambo, misidentified the documentary about him that is to be released next month. It is “Cachao: Uno Más,” not “Cachao, Ahora Sí.” (“Ahora Sí” was a documentary released in 2004 with the CD of that name.).

An article last Friday about the difference between the Dalai Lama’s stance on Tibet and the more aggressive position of some of the younger exiles misstated his followers’ beliefs about his reincarnation. They regard the Dalai Lama as the reincarnation of Avalokitesvara, the Buddha of Compassion — not the Buddha himself. The article also referred incorrectly to Samdhong Rinpoche, prime minister of the Tibetan government in exile. Rinpoche is an honorary title given to a monk; the prime minister is not known as Mr. Rinpoche.

An article on March 12 about financial problems in Jefferson County, Ala., stemming from a series of exotic bond deals, misidentified the business of the Birmingham firm of Porter White, which is advising the county on its finances. It is an investment banking firm, not a law firm. The article also misidentified the elective office of Larry P. Langford, a local official who signed off on the bond deals. He was elected a county commissioner in 2002 and was appointed president by his fellow commissioners; he was not elected county president. The article also misstated the degree to which sewer bills have increased in the last decade, partly as a result of the ill-fated deals. With an increase of more than 300 percent, they have quadrupled — not tripled.

The “Really?” column on Tuesday, about the debate over the risk of breast cancer from eating grapefruit, misstated the relationship between the enzyme CYP 3A4 and grapefruit. Grapefruit contains several compounds that inhibit the 3A4 enzyme, thus increasing the level of substances that are normally metabolized by 3A4, including estrogen. Grapefruit does not contain the enzyme itself.

The headline on the baseball roundup in some copies on Thursday misspelled the surname of the Oakland Athletics pitcher who won Wednesday’s game against the Boston Red Sox in Tokyo. He is Rich Harden, not Hardin.

An article on March 18 about suicides by teenagers in Nantucket, Mass., referred incorrectly to a population area of 130,000 in Wales where 17 young people are thought to have killed themselves in the course of last year and early this year. It is the county borough of Bridgend — not the town of Bridgend, population 39,000, located in the borough.
The Food and Drug Administration said that recent data show patients taking H.I.V. drugs from GlaxoSmithKline and Bristol-Myers Squibb may have increased risk of heart attack.
The presidential candidates’ ideological clashes are less about whether the government should step in and more about whom it should try to rescue.
Tishman Speyer’s plan for developing Hudson Yards, if done right, would produce tax revenues for the city and add another great community to New York.
In life, the five young women who burned to death in a Chinese clothing store during rioting in Tibet were not the types who would make headlines.
The government is fighting off challenges in several major terrorism cases and a raft of prisoners’ legal claims that it may have destroyed evidence.
The chairman of Bear Stearns, James E. Cayne, sold $61.3 million of the company’s shares, according to a regulatory filing.

The San Diego Padres right-hander Mark Prior said he felt strong after facing live hitters for the first time in a year. Prior, who had shoulder surgery in April while with the Chicago Cubs, threw 25 pitches during an eight-minute session. “It was good,” Prior said. “It was nice to see their reaction to how I’m throwing even though they’re way ahead of me as far as being prepared. It was good to get in there and see where you’re at.” Prior signed a $1 million deal with his hometown Padres in December, with the chance to make more in incentives. He will start the season on the 60-day disabled list and is expected to be ready to pitch in the big leagues around June 1.

The struggling Marat Safin hit another low when he lost to the American qualifier Bobby Reynolds, 7-6 (3), 4-6, 7-6 (5), in the first round of the Sony Ericsson Open in Key Biscayne, Fla. Safin, a two-time Grand Slam champion, fell to 1-5 in 2008. He has not won a title since the 2005 Australian Open, and his ranking has fallen from 56th to 90th since the start of the year. Reynolds, ranked 104th, snapped a four-match losing streak.

Outfielder Elijah Dukes missed the Washington Nationals’ final Florida exhibition game because he had to deal with some matters unrelated to baseball that the team did not specify. Dukes, who had sat out recent games because of a hamstring injury, was to travel to Washington separately from the team later Thursday. The Nationals said that Dukes’s obligations existed before the team acquired him from Tampa Bay in the off-season for a minor league pitcher. He had various arrests and suspensions during his time with the Rays.

Five finalists for the Golf Digest United States Open Challenge were named Thursday, selected from 56,374 entries. The winning finalist will play Torrey Pines Golf Course in San Diego, the site of the 2008 United States Open, on the Friday before the first round of the championship. An hourlong show documenting the round will be broadcast June 15, as a lead-in to NBC’s live coverage of the final round. The winner will be determined by online ballots cast March 28 to April 30 by voters 18 or older at gdopencontest.com.

A New York judge scheduled a hearing April 2 to settle the date for the America’s Cup showdown between the defending champion Alinghi of Switzerland and the American challenger BMW Oracle Racing. Alinghi wants to race after May 1, 2009, and BMW Oracle Racing is sticking to this October for the head-to-head duel.

The United States national team completed plans to play Argentina in an exhibition game June 8 at Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J. The American team will play games at England on May 28 and at Spain on June 4. It will begin World Cup qualifying against Barbados on June 15 at Carson, Calif.
It may be too late to stop the warming decay at the boundaries of Antarctic ice, yet there is everything to be done.
The underlying themes of the presidential race seemed to infiltrate the battle over the filling of a vacancy on the Bethlehem board.

Less than a week after being told he would probably need surgery on his ailing pitching elbow, Milwaukee Brewers pitcher Chris Capuano has decided to try rehabilitation that would allow him to play this season. The Brewers placed the left-handed Capuano on the 15-day disabled list, retroactive to March 21.
Manischewitz, which manufactures the bite-size matzos, installed a new production oven, but it wasn’t ready in time for Passover.
In August, a Chinese antimonopoly law takes effect that will extend the nation’s economic influence far beyond its borders.
Pessimism is often this city’s default position, but people have had ample reason of late to be skeptical.
Third-seeded Wisconsin has amassed a 31-4 record with 11 players from the state of Wisconsin, not particularly known as a hotbed of basketball talent.
Senator Barack Obama may or may not make it to the White House, but OBAMA 08 already has.
A Ford Field in Detroit, N.C.A.A. Tournament games are played on a court that is raised 27 inches above the football field, almost like a boxing ring.
The same day $2 billion in transportation funds were proposed to save the project, Madison Square Garden made its announcement, putting the project on the skids once again.
Prosecutors at the trial of the cyclist Tammy Thomas, directed I.R.S. Special Agent Jeff Novitzky to describe his investigative work without identifying any of the athletes implicated for doping.
The talk among leaders of Pakistan’s new coalition government about reviewing Pakistan’s role in the Washington-led war on terrorism is very worrying.
Anibal Acevedo Vila has been charged with 19 crimes, including conspiracy to violate federal campaign laws and making false statements to federal investigators.
Davidson’s roster includes players from England, Congo, Nigeria, Canada and Turkey — and only two players from in-state.
As of Thursday evening, Major League Baseball’s commissioner’s office and the players association had not reached an agreement on recommendations on performance-enhancing drugs.
Coach Jim Calhoun is making plans for his 23rd season at Connecticut, and they do not include some of his current Huskies.
The upscale home goods retailer posted a higher quarterly profit, but its shares fell 5 percent after it forecast disappointing earnings for the current fiscal year.
The latest report by Medicare trustees, all top officials of the Bush administration, contained the same bad news as last year’s report.
The Xerox Corporation said Thursday it would pay $670 million to settle a securities lawsuit from 2000, without admitting wrongdoing.
Investigators found that ammunition sent to Afghan security forces, certified by a major supplier as Hungarian, was actually made in China, according to a memorandum.
Eager to be a role model, an African-American teacher plans to travel to Antarctica, where almost all is white.
Even as the national economy slips toward recession, job numbers in New York City have moved counter to that trend.
The home of whiskey-slugging contralto blues singer Ma Rainey has been restored in a historic black neighborhood of Columbus, Ga.
Dave Marash, the channel’s most prominent American anchor, has quit, citing an increased amount of editorial control.
Religious artifacts are on the move, following the Roman Catholic population to new geographic areas, and new houses of worship.
Donnie Walsh will probably be running the Knicks soon. And N.B.A. Commissioner David Stern is optimistic about the Knicks. But Stern insists the two things are not necessarily related.
Television figure Greg Mathis denied he supports Detroit Mayor Kwame M. Kilpatrick, who was charged Monday with obstruction of justice, perjury and other felonies.
The Los Angeles Times acknowledged on Thursday that it had relied on apparently forged documents for its investigation into an assault on the rapper Tupac Shakur.
Opera director Chen Shi-Zheng’s has created an intentionally dark and violent film.
An Israeli court’s acceptance of separate roads for Palestinians has brought accusations that it is the beginning of legal apartheid in the West Bank.
Despite moving after Katrina, D. J. Augustin, Texas’s star point guard, lifts New Orleans.
A campaign that is scheduled to begin on Monday presents the Intel Corporation as the problem-solver for the people who solve the computer network problems for others.
Newark experienced it’s seventh homicide of the year, compared with 22 homicides by the same time last year.
The first official estimate of the total number of convicts eligible for deportation indicates it would cost at least $2 billion a year to find and deport all of them.
David Neeleman, founder of JetBlue Airways, said he has already agreed to buy 36 Brazilian-made jets with a total list price of $1.4 billion.
Barack Obama is embarking on a six-day tour across the complex political landscape of a state that some thought he might duck.
Mr. Hassler authored a series of novels that affectionately mocked the foibles of small-town teachers, gossips, troublemakers and assorted other eccentrics.
The company has filed a complaint in New York State Supreme Court against its former chief executive and six other former directors and officers.
Hillary Rodham Clinton said she would like to limit the cost of health insurance to no more than 10 percent of Americans’ income, a significant reduction for some families.
Rapper Remy Smith kept her composure as she heard the verdict read, but broke down wailing after being led to a holding cell.
George Steinbrenner, the Yankees’ principal owner, made a rare visit to the team’s spring training home on the day that it was renamed after him.
Gov. Jon S. Corzine said he wanted to do away with the state’s 13-year-old multibillion-dollar formula for municipal subsidies and come up with a new system by the end of the year.
The Giants are expected to begin the defense of their Super Bowl championship at Giants Stadium against the Washington Redskins on Thursday, Sept. 4.
The Federal Reserve announced Thursday that it would hold public meetings next month on the offer by Bank of America to acquire Countrywide Financial.
Mark Yudof, the University of Texas chancellor, has been named the next president of the 10-campus University of California system.
The economy nearly sputtered out in the final quarter of last year and is probably faring even worse now amid the housing, credit and financial crises.
The Harvard Management Company appointed Jane Mendillo, the chief investment officer at Wellesley College, as its president and chief executive on Thursday.
To quell the fears of flooded Missourians The Army Corps of Engineers has halted the annual release of millions of gallons of water into the Missouri River from Gavins Point Dam.
A judge’s ruling that pares back the federal case against Frederick S. Schiff, former chief financial officer at Bristol-Myers Squibb, has delayed his trial.
The Lennar Corporation reported a first-quarter loss of $88.2 million as it absorbed charges to write down asset values and costs, while new home sales and prices sank.
Medical testimony showing that Sean Bell’s vision was greatly impaired raised doubts about whether he was able to see detectives shields on the night of the shooting.
The Food and Drug Administration said Thursday that it was investigating a possible link between Merck’s best-selling drug Singulair and suicide.
The shooting occurred on a stretch of Interstate 64 two hours’ drive of the area near Washington that was terrorized by the sniper attacks in 2002.
All Nippon Airways has ordered 15 of the aircrafts, which will be the first regional jet to use composite material for its wings and vertical stabilizer.
The distributor of open-source software said higher expenses related to sales and marketing offset a jump in revenue.
In June, one of the five finalists, whose essays were chosen from 56,374 entrees, will play the site of the 2008 United States Open, on the Friday before the first round.
Cybersyn, a project that included a clunky mainframe computer and a network of telex machines, was in the early 1970s a part of an experiment to help manage Chile’s economy.
A rare and previously undetectable genetic variation has been linked to a significant increase in the risk of developing schizophrenia.
The deputy secretary of state bore the brunt of a range of complaints that Pakistanis now feel freer to air with the end of military rule by President Pervez Musharraf.
A corrections officer, a maintenance worker and four inmates have been indicted on charges of running a contraband ring at the Union County Jail, where two inmates escaped three months ago.
The Department of Agriculture released a list of all districts nationwide that received beef included in a recall of meat from a California slaughterhouse.
Mr. Peterson invented the Egg McMuffin as a way to introduce breakfast to McDonald’s restaurants.
Tom Glavine, who returned to the Atlanta Braves so he could be closer to his family, is scheduled to pitch against the Mets on April 5.
In volatile trading, the Dow Jones industrial average fell by more than 100 points.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,993 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Wednesday:.
Mr. Aragon, the lightweight and welterweight boxing contender of the 1950s, was known as Golden Boy for his flamboyant ring presence and love for the Hollywood life.

ConAgra, the owner of brands like Healthy Choice, Chef Boyardee and Peter Pan, also increased its earnings outlook for the full year on Thursday.
A memorial for the author Norman Mailer will be held at 4 p.m. April 9 at Carnegie Hall.
The acquisition is American Express’s latest effort to bulk up its corporate payments business, seen as a relatively stable earnings generator.
Experts said the study, while not identifying the cause of the disorder, provided a striking demonstration of new gene-scanning technology.

An air of orderly professionalism pervades the Armory Show on Pier 94.
Juilliard honored Martha Graham, Antony Tudor and José Limón with “Dance Masterworks of the 20th Century,” an eloquently danced program of three pieces on Wednesday.

'JUNIE B. JONES' Here's a young heroine who inspires immediate sympathy. Entering a new grade, Junie B. Jones discovers that her closest pal, Lucille, has become the ''new best friend'' of snooty twins. Things on the school bus aren't better: Junie's former seat mate would rather ride with someone else. The day improves only when Herb, a new boy, sits next to Junie and begins to discuss going bowling together. These events may bring back vivid memories of middle school. Except that this isn't eighth grade; it's first. But the ability of ''Junie B. Jones'' to tap into the psyches of older children is one of its strengths. Even though some 6-year-olds may not identify with the precocious Junie, they will recognize her anxieties. And no 9- or 10-year-old taken to this musical, now being revived by Theatreworks/USA, can complain that the material is babyish. Smartly directed by Peter Flynn, it offers enough humor to tickle even adults.

TABAIMO An animation by the Japanese artist Tabaimo, 32, is always a spectacle worth seeing, what with the enormous screens, the eerie digitalization of the Ukiyo-e, or Japanese ''floating world'' woodblock style, and the Surrealistic erosion of innocence into violence, sex or self-abuse. In her ''dolefullhouse,'' a hit at last summer's Venice Biennale, giant hands arranging furniture in a dollhouse start scratching at the structure to reveal bleeding human flesh. Tabaimo's second solo show in New York centers on ''public conVENience,'' above, a three-screen work from 2006 set in a spacious restroom reminiscent of a train station (''ven'' is Japanese for public). Forgoing innocence, this piece progresses from weird to very weird, as the facilities are used in all sorts of symbolic ways. One woman dives into a toilet, another washes obsessively, a third gives birth to a baby through a nostril. Large moths fly about, their cameralike eyes snapping pictures for a voyeur lurking outside a small window. The roving viewpoints make voyeurs of the audience, revealing a particularly female world of isolation, vulnerability and obliviousness.

EDWARDS--Junius, 78, died peacefully at home in New York City on March 22, 2008. He is survived by his beloved wife of 50 years, Inger Marie, his two sons, Eric and Tony, his daughter Ellen, four grandchildren, and one greatgrandchild. Born in 1929 in Alexandria, Louisiana, Junius Edwards joined the Army at 18, served for nine years in Korea and Japan, and worked in the Judge Advocate General Corps and the Army Counter Intelligence Corps. After his honorable discharge he went to study at the University of Oslo, Norway using his GI Bill, where he continued to pursue his passion for writing. In 1958 he won first prize in the Writer's Digest Short Story Contest for ''Liars Don't Qualify'' and in 1959, he received a Eugene F. Saxton Fellowship for creative writing. His published work also includes short stories ''Duel with the Clock,'' ''Mother Dear and Daddy,'' and the novel ''If We Must Die''. His writing primarily focused on racial and personal problems faced by the African-American soldier and African-Americans living in the South. During the 1960s in New York, Junius Edwards worked as a copywriter for various advertising agencies such as Ogilvy & Mather, Ted Bates Inc., and Norman, Craig, & Kummel. He went on to establish Junius Edwards Inc., one of the first blackowned advertising agencies in New York City with clients that included Carver Federal Savings Bank, Faberge, Liggett & Myers, and The Greater New York Savings Bank. He later worked as a consultant and Special Fellow for United Nations Unitar, while also expanding into several entrepreneurial endeavors in the health, travel, publishing, and airline industries. We, your adoring family, thank you for being a wonderful and inspiring man, a great father, and loving husband.We love you Papa. Messages of condolence can be sent to JJEdwards@aol.com

She will live in our hearts always.

''In the late '70s and early '80s, I took the subway to school and back each day. Just this morning I was marveling at the clean, efficient silver cars moving through the station. In my mind's eye, I juxtaposed them with my memories of the foul, dank, vandalized, broken-down, stifling trains of my childhood -- which we had all grown inured to and had abandoned hope that they'd ever improve. They have. It's nice.'' -- Ben Munisteri ''New York City is the richest city in the country, yet our subway system is filthy and smelly and crowded and loud and none of the loudspeakers ever work correctly and only about half of the conductors ever take their jobs seriously enough to actually give the riders decent announcements of service changes. ... If I were a tourist, I would be positively repulsed.''-- E. A. Durden

For decades, this 20-story apartment building, which was built in 1966, was one of the only residential buildings overlooking the Allegheny River in downtown Pittsburgh. Now it is attracting a new generation of baby boomers and retirees who want to live in a walkable downtown area close to the river. This 3,800-square-foot unit (originally three apartments that were merged into one large living space) is on the 10th floor. It has walls of windows with unobstructed views of the river, Point State Park and the stadiums at PNC Park and Heinz Field. The apartment, which is being offered fully furnished, has stone and cork flooring and wall-to-wall carpeting in the bedrooms. Countertops are marble, glass and poured concrete. At the unit's center is a glass bar with a built-in icemaker and wine cooler from which there are views in three directions. The apartment has commercial-grade appliances, including a washer and dryer. There are two and a half bathrooms. Building amenities include a fitness room, a billiards room, a library and a party room. Condo fees: $1,800 a month. Agent: Linda DiBucci, Coldwell Banker -- Hampton, (412) 487-0500; www.pittsburghmoves.com.

NY UKEFEST 2008 When Stephen DiLauro decided to pick up the ukulele again several years ago, he should have seen it coming. After all, this was the instrument that in the early 1900s, fresh from Hawaii, had managed to win over millions of American devotees who bought recordings by Tin Pan Alley musicians like Ukulele Ike. This is the instrument that a generation later was resurrected by Arthur Godfrey, who peddled a plastic version on television. So when Mr. DiLauro, a guitarist, created a ukulele-playing persona called Uke Jackson in 2000, it should have been no surprise that the ukulele was on the cusp of a comeback driven by fringe musicians and that he would surrender his name to the instrument.

APRIL AT THE STONE Ever since the Stone, a nonprofit experimental-music space in the East Village, opened its doors three years ago, it has heeded a scrupulous guest-booking policy: Each month a different artist programs the calendar, according to his or her own designs. John Zorn, the artistic director of the Stone, calls these artists curators, and each month can be seen as an autonomous collection of works. This has been truer of some months than others, but as a general principle it works remarkably well. The Stone's April calendar is the work of Chris Speed, a clarinetist and tenor saxophonist in his early 40s, and one of the principal figures in a dynamic left-of-center jazz/improv scene around the city. Like most Stone curators, Mr. Speed put a lot of himself on the program: he has seven scheduled appearances. But with only one exception, he will be working as a sideman, in stellar groups led by the trumpeter Cuong Vu, the percussionist John Hollenbeck and the alto saxophonist Tim Berne, among others. Beyond those, the lineup draws from a pool of artists based in Brooklyn and parts more remote (including Germany, Iceland and Italy). Just about every night looks solid.
CLASSICAL Full reviews of recent music performances: nytimes.com/music.

Situated on the banks of the Allegheny River in downtown Warren, Breeze Point Circle is part of the first phase of residential construction downtown along the river. These units were completed late in 2007. Until now, riverfront properties in Warren have tended to be commercial. Residential housing is located mostly three to five blocks away in the town's historic district. (Such homes usually list for $200,000 to $300,000.) This three-story condominium is one of 24 units in two buildings and has 2,080 square feet of living space. All of the rooms at the front have unobstructed views of the Allegheny River. The condominium has basic finishes, but buyers can pay for upgrades. The unit has two and a half bathrooms. It has a balcony overlooking the river with views of a lighted walkway that runs along the water. Shops, restaurants and a new arts center are all within walking distance. The building has geothermal heat and central air conditioning. One outdoor parking space is included. Condo fee: $160 a month. Agent: Melina King, Coleen Christy GMAC Realty, (814) 723-3910; www.coleenchristygmac.com.

STEPHEN PETRONIO COMPANY If Stephen Petronio ever calls it quits with dance, he might consider a career as a matchmaker or trend-spotter. Since founding his company in 1984 he has had a singular knack for pairing his sexually charged, elegantly virtuosic movement language (interpreted by dancers like Davalois Fearon, above) with some of the hottest musicians and fashion designers of the moment; more impressively, he has done it for artistic imperatives, not marketing ones. For his coming Joyce Theater stint Mr. Petronio snagged classical music's It Boy, Nico Muhly, whose composition ''Keep in Touch,'' along with works by Antony and Lou Reed, form the soundtrack for ''This Is the Story of a Girl in a World.'' The dance, a premiere, consists of five pieces exploring the increasingly blurred concept of gender.

Davidson's Stephen Curry has caught the imagination of college basketball fans with his performance through the first two rounds of the N.C.A.A. tournament. With 70 points through the first two games, Curry is the most prolific star in March heading into Friday's matchup with Wisconsin. He still has a ways to go before he approaches the single-tournament scoring record, 184 points, set in six games by Michigan's Glen Rice in 1989. But his stellar play led two former tournament stars to reflect about their college days.

FOR CHILDREN 'AESOP'S FOIBLES' (Saturday and Sunday) As the title indicates, this new musical by Aaron Michael Zook takes a somewhat irreverent approach to Aesop's fables. 'T J & DAVE' AND 'TWO MEN TALKING' A latecomer could sit through an entire performance by this duo without realizing that there is no script. Without hearing their regular opening line, ''This is all made up,'' you might not gather that these Chicagoans are masters of long-form improvisation, creating an original, full-length play on the fly at every performance. They have won awards both at home and in New York for their efforts. T. J. Jagodowski, above right, and Dave Pasquesi, left, make periodic visits here with the show they have presented weekly for the last several years at the iO Theater. At each performance one of them starts by blurting out a sentence -- anything at all that he feels like saying at that moment -- and they build a story from there, playing multiple characters and somehow bringing it easily to a close about an hour later. Their onstage chemistry, comic instincts and never-miss-a-beat improvisation abilities, rather than audience suggestions, keep the evening flowing.

Two Columbia journalism graduate students have put together an interactive Web site looking at the history of chess in New York City. It has interviews with a number of prominent city players, including Hikaru Nakamura, Maurice Ashley (the only African-American grandmaster) and Joshua Waitzkin, on whose life the book and movie "Searching for Bobby Fischer" is based. There are also interviews with children and chess teachers, and a timeline of events with some archival photographs. A good deal of the historical material is about Bobby Fischer, the American champion who grew up in Brooklyn and who died two months ago. The students, Radha Vij and Jennie Cohen, are not chess players but became immersed in the culture as they worked on the project.

Re "Playing Favorites? Don't Be So Sure" (March 9):I've noticed some other, more subtle forms of bias - both in The New York Times and in other news sources - that I don't quite understand.For example, when Senator Barack Obama wins a state he is expected to, like Wyoming, the victory seems to be played down. But when Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton wins a state she was expected to, like Ohio, it is heralded as a major alteration of the nomination's dynamic.I can see this story line being developed for Pennsylvania, which is being framed as the crucial contest, but one that Mrs. Clinton begins with great strength.If the rules as set up by the Democratic National Committee are to choose a candidate by the total delegate count, and Mr. Obama has essentially a total that cannot be surpassed through regular state primaries and caucuses, I wonder why news coverage continues to treat the race as essentially even, and worse, that Senator Clinton somehow is gaining the upper hand.There are not always two equal sides to a story. In the case of the Democratic contest, it seems that the media are willing to engage in this subtle bias to continue the competitive narrative.Marc SchlossbergEugene, Ore., March 10, 2008

For the second successive day, British Airways canceled dozens of flights at Heathrow Airport’s glittery new Terminal 5 as its staff struggled with state-of-the-art technology supposed to hasten check-in and baggage-handling procedures. The hitches since the terminal opened on Thursday were “definitely not British Airways’ finest hour,” the airline’s chief executive, Willie Walsh, told reporters. Some passengers slept overnight inside the steel-and-glass terminal, reviving precisely those images of delay and decline in British aviation that British Airways said Terminal 5 would banish.

Some 25 brands of buffalo mozzarella with elevated levels of the carcinogen dioxin were pulled from stores as the nation worked to reassure foreign buyers that none of the contaminated cheese had left the country. The government announced that it would permit the general public to buy cellphones, which until now were set aside mainly for the Communist Party elite. The move was seen as a sign of liberalization by the new president, Raúl Castro. But most Cubans, who earn only about $20 monthly in state salaries, will find it hard to afford the phones without help from relatives off the island.

A “criminal network” was behind the assassination of the former Lebanese prime minister Rafik Hariri and is “linked to” some of the 20 additional killings of anti-Syrian officials in Lebanon, the head of the United Nations inquiry into the deaths, David Bellemare of Canada, said in his first report since taking the post in November.

The government offered cash and reduced jail terms to leftist guerrillas in exchange for releasing the politician Ingrid Betancourt after years of captivity in jungle camps. Ms. Betancourt, left, 46, was kidnapped during her 2002 presidential campaign by the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC, and is suffering from malnutrition and hepatitis B, according to Colombia’s human rights ombudsman. President Álvaro Uribe said his government would maintain a $100 million fund to pay rewards to guerrillas who free any of the hundreds of kidnapping victims held by the FARC. On Thursday he signed a decree allowing for a mass release of guerrillas from jail if Ms. Betancourt was freed.

Novak Djokovic often bounces the ball more than a dozen times before serving, and the tedious ritual may have cost him a match Friday. Djokovic, the defending champion at the Sony Ericsson Open in Key Biscayne, Fla., went into a funk after being warned for taking too much time between points, then blew a third-set lead to lose his opening match. The qualifier Kevin Anderson, a 6-foot-7 former N.C.A.A. doubles champion at Illinois, beat the third-ranked Djokovic, 7-6 (1), 3-6, 6-4. Djokovic won his first Grand Slam title at this year’s Australian Open and was coming off a title at Indian Wells last week.

Jeff Gordon turned a lap at 96.228 miles an hour on the 0.526-mile Martinsville Speedway oval, the oldest, shortest and trickiest in Nascar’s Spring Cup Series, to beat Denny Hamlin (95.757) easily for his seventh career Martinsville pole and the 65th of his career over all, the fourth-best total in Nascar history. Only Richard Petty (126), David Pearson (112) and Cale Yarborough (70) have won more Nascar poles.

Angela Stanford was clinging to the lead halfway through Safeway International in Superstition Mountain, Ariz. Stanford had a one-shot lead through 36 holes of the L.P.G.A. Tour tournament. She followed her course record and career-best 10-under 62 on Thursday with a three-under 69 on Friday for a 13-under 131 total. Lorena Ochoa, the defending champion and world’s top-ranked female golfer, was one back at 12 under. She began the day three strokes back and shot a 67.

Giants middle linebacker Antonio Pierce pleaded guilty Thursday in Monroe Township, N.J., municipal court to neglecting his pet pit bulls and agreed to pay a $1,300 fine. Authorities said one of the dogs was severely underweight and had a respiratory illness. They also said Pierce and his girlfriend let the dogs run loose and failed to get them rabies shots. Pierce’s girlfriend, Jocelyn Maldanado, also pleaded guilty and was fined $1,300. A lawyer for the couple said the dogs were given away as part of the plea agreement. The dogs were discovered running around a neighbor’s yard in late January, the week before the Giants upset the Patriots in the Super Bowl.

Briny Baird shot a three-under-par 69 to take a one-stroke lead over Peter Lonard and Jay Williamson in the Zurich Classic in Avondale, La. Baird, winless on the PGA Tour, birdied the final two holes to finish at eight under at the T.P.C. Louisiana. Lonard shot a 70, and Williamson had a 69. The defending champion Nick Watney (67) was two strokes back.

Lisa Fernandez, a three-time Olympic champion and perhaps softball’s biggest star for more than a decade, did not make the United States team’s final 15-player roster for the Beijing Games. “It’s like Michael Jordan getting cut from the basketball team,” catcher Stacey Nuveman said. Fernandez, 37, was named as a replacement player on the team, which will try to win its fourth straight gold medal this summer.

An article last Saturday about financing for private equity deals provided by small European banks misidentified the supermarket chain purchased by BC Partners, a private equity firm based in London. It is Migros Turk, based in Turkey — not Migros, which is a supermarket chain in Switzerland.

An article on Page 52 of The Times Magazine this weekend about this summer’s Olympics in Beijing and the effects of political activists on them and their sponsors omits a sentence in a statement from Microsoft, a sponsor of the games, about the need for international organizations to intervene in Sudan, which buys weapons from China. The passage containing the statement should read: The company further “commend[ed] Dream for Darfur and other organizations for their leadership in casting a spotlight on this atrocity and the need for immediate international resolution. Governments and international organizations — the United Nations chief among them, as well as humanitarian relief organizations — will need to continue to work together locally and globally to address the problems in the Sudan. Microsoft will continue to support these organizations in their mission through technology assistance and other resources.”.

An article on Wednesday about José Canseco’s new book on the use of performance-enhancing drugs in baseball referred incorrectly to a report in The New York Times in January involving his proposal to keep Magglio Ordóñez of the Chicago White Sox out of the book. The Times reported that Canseco had asked Ordóñez to invest in a $5 million movie project he was promoting — not that Canseco had asked for $5 million to help finance a film.

A picture caption on Wednesday with an article about the election of political moderates in Pakistan’s North-West Frontier Province, and the possible effect that could have on the government’s relations with the Islamic militants based there, misstated the date that the photograph of a street scene in Peshawar, the provincial capital, was taken. It was Monday, March 3 — not this past Monday.

The cover article in The Times Magazine this weekend, about the recent struggles of the Republican Party, misspells the surname of the Democratic congressman who helped devise the strategy for the Democratic gains in the 2006 Congressional elections. He is Rahm Emanuel, not Emmanuel.

The Leopold Museum Private Foundation of Vienna has been accused of knowingly purchasing works that could have been stolen by the Nazis, The San Francisco Chronicle reported. A law professor commissioned by Austrian Jews found that at least 11 of the foundation’s works, including some by Egon Schiele (whose “Liegende Frau” is above), Anton Romako and Albin Egger-Lienz, belonged to people persecuted by the Nazis and that the collector Rudolf Leopold certainly knew that they might have been looted. “He knew, or he must have known, that these paintings belonged to people who were persecuted by the Nazis,” said Georg Graf, the professor. “Because of that knowledge, he must have been aware of the possibility that these were stolen goods.” Mr. Leopold, in an interview with Die Presse, disputed the allegation. “In my eyes, the pictures were acquired lawfully,” he said. The Austrian culture minister, Claudia Schmied, said at a news conference this week that she expected the foundation to approve an independent examination of its collection. ... The National Gallery in London said its painting “Cupid Complaining to Venus,” by the German artist Lucas Cranach the Elder, was once part of Hitler’s private collection and may have been looted during World War II, The Washington Post reported. A researcher, Birgit Schwartz, spotted the painting — showing Cupid complaining to Venus that he has been stung by bees after stealing honey — in a photograph of Hitler’s private gallery contained in an album at the Library of Congress in Washington and brought it to the attention of the National Gallery. The museum has been unable to account for the painting’s ownership or whereabouts from 1909, when it was sold at auction in Berlin, to 1945, when an American war correspondent took it from a warehouse of art guarded by American troops in southern Germany, a National Gallery spokesman said.

The Village Voice has dismissed its dance critic, Deborah Jowitt, leaving the weekly with no full-time staff dance writers. Ms. Jowitt, right, began at the newspaper in November 1967 and was one of its senior arts writers. She said in a telephone interview that she learned on Tuesday that her position was being eliminated “for economic reasons,” along with that of the film critic Nathan Lee. Julie Lichtenstein, a spokeswoman for the paper, said in an e-mail message: “Financial constraints force us to convert two full-time positions to freelance jobs. Both Deborah Jowitt and Nathan Lee have been asked to continue writing for The Voice.” Ms. Jowitt said, “I was told that the dance page would continue to exist,” adding that her dismissal “came as a complete shock to me.”.

Nine classical artifacts that until recently belonged to the New York philanthropist Shelby White will go on view Saturday at the Palazzo Poli in Rome as part of an exhibition of illicitly excavated antiquities returned to Italy by American museums, dealers and collectors. Among the pieces Ms. White handed over this year after long negotiations are two from the fifth century B.C., a bronze statuette of a nude youth and a calyx-krater attributed to the so-called Eucharides Painter. A 2,500-year-old krater attributed to the Greek master Euphronios will go back to Italy in two years under the agreement Ms. White reached with the Italian Culture Ministry. In a statement issued on Friday by both sides, Ms. White said that her collection had been purchased at public auction from dealers whom she and her husband, Leon Levy, who died in 2003, had “believed to be reputable.” She said she had nonetheless concluded, based on Italian government evidence, that “their export from Italy was questionable.” The Italian government has never accused Ms. White or Mr. Levy of any wrongdoing, and the joint statement said that Ms. White had “shown great sensitivity and taken the initiative voluntarily to offer to return 10 items.” The exhibition at the Palazzo Poli is an expanded version of “Nostoi: Recovered Masterpieces,” a show of some 70 pieces recovered mostly from four American museums, which opened in December at the Quirinale, or presidential palace, in Rome.

NBC’s “Apprentice” finale earned Thursday’s highest ratings. Nielsen estimated that 12.1 million viewers tuned in from 9 to 11 p.m., the largest audience since the finale of “The Apprentice 4” in December 2005. Ratings for the series had fallen since its inaugural 2004 season, which averaged almost 21 million viewers an episode, reaching its lowest level a year ago, with an average of just over seven million viewers. For the night over all, NBC ranked first, just ahead of CBS, which broadcast N.C.A.A. basketball. Fox was third and ABC fourth.

The city, which reportedly enjoyed its brush with celebrity, decided to hold its own gala premiere on April 4 at the local Camelot Cinemas, the same night that the two stars attend the opening in Hollywood.

Martin Scorsese's crime drama ''The Departed'' may be a paean to the city of Boston, but a number of scenes featuring Leonardo DiCaprio were shot at the county courthouse and library here. It was a surprisingly apt title, since 2007, the year ''The Departed'' won the Academy Award for Best Picture, was also the year that many film and television shoots departed -- for Connecticut. With a proud film history dating back almost a century, to D. W. Griffith's creation of a 28-acre production lot in Mamaroneck, Westchester County is increasingly watching production companies be lured across the border to Connecticut, which now offers them a 30 percent tax credit, compared with New York State's 10 percent.

Is the pope Catholic? That used to be a sarcastic way of saying, could anything be more obvious? Is fire hot? Is water wet? Now, however, that nothing in the world is obvious, when Pope Benedict XVI arrives in the United States on April 15 there will surely be voices in the media apparently disconcerted to discover that, yes, the pope is Catholic.

FEHER--Julianna, passed away March 26, 2008 at age 69. Born November 16, 1938 in Budapest, Hungary to Frederick and Regina Endler. Julianna worked as a lab technician for Montefiore Hospital. She is survived by her cherished daughter, Lisa, and predeceased by her sister Suzanna Zibrinyi.
