LARSCHAN--Adele Fath, age 96. Beloved wife of the late Walter. Loving mother of Edward (deceased) and Richard. Devoted grandmother of Erica, Alexandra, and Sara. Cherished companion of Doris and Julissa Diaz. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to PBS Channel 13 or The Williams Residence.

DREHER--Meyer (Mike), died on March 28, 2008. Beloved father of Barbara Blacksberg and Fran Hirschel, and son-in-law David Hirschel, and proud grandfather of Michael and Robert and Megumi Hirschel. Brother of Syb Leipow and Jack and Deb Dreher. Widower of the late Josephine (Phenie) Dreher. Services Sunday at 1pm at the Astoria Center of Israel, 27-35 Crescent St., Astoria, NY.

The Treasury Department will propose on Monday that Congress give the Federal Reserve broad new authority to oversee financial market stability, in effect allowing it to send SWAT teams into any corner of the industry or any institution that might pose a risk to the overall system. The proposal is part of a sweeping blueprint to overhaul the nation's hodgepodge of financial regulatory agencies, which many experts say failed to recognize rampant excesses in mortgage lending until after they set off what is now the worst financial calamity in decades.

WOLMAN--Tobias ''Ted''. August 10, 1920-September 29, 2007. Loving husband of Bernice Spector Wolman, father of Paul and Stephen (1951-2000), grandfather of Rachel (Dean) Pody, and great-grandfather of Maia and Noah Pody. A Brooklyn College graduate and World War II U.S. Army veteran, Ted taught English and journalism at Boys and Bayside High Schools. In 1969, he became English Department chair at New Utrecht High. He also taught at Queensborough and LaGuardia Community Colleges. An avid baseball player and Giants fan, ardent teacher unionist, literary guide, and writer of letters to the editor, he lived in retirement in Copake, New York, and Boynton Beach, Florida. His last residence was Seattle, Washington. Interment was at Tahoma National Veterans Cemetery, Kent, Washington.

WEINREICH--Beatrice Silverman, of New York and Cranberry Isles. Mother, motherin-law, grandmother, folklorist. Survived by Stephanie, Don, Barbara, Nienke, Alex, Kate, Max, family and many friends. Wife of the late Uriel Weinreich. Deeply loved, deeply loving. Memorial Service April 27, 2008.

THEOBALD--Richard Farrar, passed away on March 25, 2008. Owner of (MAVS) Kearny, NJ. Survived by wife Teresa Theobald and two children, Christopher and Sara. He will be missed by so many. Viewing 2-9pm on Saturday March 29, 2008 at Bongarzone Funeral Home Tinton Falls, NJ, 2400 Shafto Road.

FELDMAN--Jerome Oscar, died March 27. Col. Jerry Feldman was the beloved husband of Joan; father of Victoria, Robert and Marla, grandfather of Lauren, Carli, Jillian, Emily, and Kasey. Born May 6th, 1924, he proudly served in WWII and the Korean War. He had a long career in the aerospace industry. He will be sorely missed. Funeral at Gutterman's in Rockville Centre Sunday March 30th at 11am.

STEWART--Leslie D., Jr. Died peacefully at home in Vero Beach, Florida on March 27th, 2008 at age 76. Beloved husband of Gillian Holland Stewart. Loving father to Laura Stewart Bauman and husband John, Susan Stewart Johnson and husband Brendan, and adoring grandfather to Elizabeth, Katherine, Charles, and William.

BUTLER--Michael Dome nick. My beloved son, my spiritual twin, separated from me by the passing of his corporeal body on March 29, 2006. One day to be reunited, for now, at peace at last. In my heart forever and always. Love, Marie Katerina

VAN DER KEMP--Florence. Florence Russell Bennett Harris. The Officers and Staff of The Versailles Foundation, Inc., mourn the passing of Florence Van der Kemp, Founder and President, Chevalier de la Legion d'Honneur, Chevalier des Arts et Lettres, Foreign Correspondent Member of the Institut de France, Academie des Beaux-Arts, who died in New York City on February 11, 2008. She dedicated her extraordinary energy with her late husband and Academicien, Gerald Van der Kemp to the restoration of The Chateau de Versailles, Trianons & Parc, along with the resuscitation of the Home and Gardens of the painter Claude Monet at Giverny. Her Memorial Mass was held in the Basilique Sainte Clothilde of her Paris neighborhood. She is buried next to her beloved husband in the Church cemetery of Giverny, where she resided until her death. A true ''grande dame'' who will be affectionately missed by all who knew her. Barbara de Portago Daughter and President The Versailles Foundation, Inc. New York City

BONJEAN--Emile. Beloved Emile, native of France, and resident of Long Island, NY, was a tender and treasured part of our family for 50 years. His dedication and brilliance transformed Greentree from a personal home into a ''House of Peace,'' where he welcomed visitors from all over the world for Greentree Foundation as they came to negotiate agreements and discuss global issues. His influence will continue to be felt through the extraordinary atmosphere he helped create by all who continue to meet at Greentree to pursue issues of social justice and international harmony. Our family will miss him terribly, and remember him always with love. Kate Whitney and Franklin Thomas and their family Sara and Ronald Wilford and their family

A week ago Thursday, just days after the big Bear Stearns crisis, Representative Barney Frank gave a speech to the Greater Boston Chamber of Commerce. Most people know Mr. Frank, a Democrat from Massachusetts, as one of the most liberal members of Congress. He is also known for his quick wit and his sharp tongue. But ever since the Democrats regained control of Congress two years ago, Mr. Frank has taken on another identity: he's the chairman of the powerful House Financial Services Committee, which oversees financial institutions and their regulators.

The Texas sophomore D. J. Augustin's favorite musician is the rapper Lil Wayne. As it happens, Lil Wayne is a fan of Augustin, a fellow New Orleans native and now the Longhorns' starting point guard. But Lil Wayne said he took notice of more than Augustin's basketball skills.

WINTHROP--Eleanor B. Beloved wife of the late Nathaniel Thayer Winthrop, passed away peacefully Tuesday, March 25 at her Park Ave. home of 58 years. She was 89. Daughter of Ruth and Arthur Beane of Cambridge, MA, she survived brothers Arthur and Richards and sister Louisa Browne. Eleanor graduated Wellesley College in 1940, and she was a personnel manager in Chicago and New York before marrying Mr. Winthrop, a tax and estate lawyer at Shearman & Sterling, in 1950. She was highly active in community and charitable activities in Manhattan, including long service on several non-profit boards. She summered in Brooklin, ME. Memorial Service followed by reception April 13, 2:00 at the Cosmopolitan Club, 122 E. 66th St., NYC. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Arthur & Ruth Beane Scholarship Fund, Northfield Mount Herman School, 1 Lamplighter Way, Mount Herman, MA 01354. Eleanor is survived by children Nathaniel (and wife Martha, of Montpelier, VT), Kate (of Bernardsville, NJ), Nina (of New York, NY), Stephen (and Jane Williamson, of Wayland, MA) and stepchildren John (and Libby, of Charleston, SC), Matthew (of Boston, MA), Beekman (and Phoebe Jane, of Washington, DC), and Serita (and Tom McCance, of Hamden, CT), all Winthrops, as well as by numerous grandchildren and great-grandchildren, nieces and nephews. She will live in our hearts always.

GRANT--Edgar, born Vienna 1921, cherished husband of Eva for more than 60 years, went quietly on Wednesday to be with Eva; devoted and beloved father and father-inlaw, adored grandfather, loving uncle and great-uncle, caring cousin, and respected friend and colleague. Services to be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th and Amsterdam, on Sunday, March 30th at 11:15am. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to The Eva and Edgar Grant Memorial Fund, Calvary Hospital Fund, 1740 Eastchester Road, Bronx, NY 10461.

He is given a shot at redemption -- and a chance to pay off his debt from his last saloon brawl -- when he's hired to transport three women off the plains and back to civilization. Of course there's a menacing gunman (Lance Henriksen) in the way. The film also stars Jamie Anne Allman, Jillian Armenante, Dominique Swain and Felicia Day. 7 P.M. I think I'm going to write my next column about China, in the wake of the Tibetan protests, and I'd love to hear from some Chinese readers. For those of you in China, has the Times website been restored so that you can access this site? I gather that it was cut off after the Tibetan upheavals, but maybe the links have been restored. In any case, my sense is that many Chinese -- whether in China or outside the country -- are deeply indignant at U.S. media coverage of Tibet in particular and China-U.S. relations in general. I get waves of angry emails whenever I write about China and Darfur. So here's your chance: What do we get wrong, and why?

Dith Pran has been a legendary figure in The New York Times family for decades, and so we are in mourning today after his death from pancreatic cancer. He's best known of course for "The Killing Fields," the movie of his odyssey in Cambodia under Pol Pot. The movie is the true story of how, as the interpreter/fixer for The New York Times in Cambodia, he relentlessly gathered news and saved the life of our correspondent, Sydney Schanberg. When the Khmer Rouge arrived Schanberg tried to get Dith Pran out but couldn't.

Christian Gomez scored on a penalty kick and the Colorado Rapids beat David Beckham and the Los Angeles Galaxy, 4-0, in Commerce, Colo., on a day when Major League Soccer opened its season. Beckham flew back from Europe after playing for England against France on Wednesday.

Libby Trickett broke the world record in the women’s 50-meter freestyle, finishing in 23.97 seconds at the Australian championships and Olympic trials Saturday in Sydney. Trickett, formerly Libby Lenton, topped Marleen Veldhuis’s record by 12-hundredths of a second. Trickett also set a world record in the 100 freestyle Thursday. Eight world records have been set at the Australian titles at the Sydney Olympic Park Aquatic Centre.

New American open-wheel era or not, it was business as usual in the IndyCar Series race at Homestead-Miami Speedway in Florida. A Target Chip Ganassi Racing entry, this one driven by the former series champion Scott Dixon, won the season opener for the third straight year. None of the newcomers making the transition from the Champ Car World Series to the newly unified IndyCar series were able to compete with the leaders.

Bernhard Langer birdied his first two holes, then avoided the mistakes that plagued his closest rivals in the Champions Tour’s Ginn Championship in Palm Coast, Fla. Langer, a two-time Masters champion, was one of only two players who did not have a bogey on the windy Oceanside course. He shot a six-under-par 66 to reach 11-under 133 after two rounds, moving two strokes ahead of Lonnie Nielsen (69).

The Tour de France winner Alberto Contador, whose Astana team has been barred from entering this year’s race, said he would not change teams to defend his title. The Tour’s organizer, Amaury Sport Organization, said Astana could not take part in this year’s race because it had been implicated in doping scandals.

The torch relay for the Beijing Olympics reached the Acropolis in Athens amid heavy police security and brief demonstrations by small groups of protesters. The police briefly scuffled with antiglobalization demonstrators shortly after the relay entered the city. At the foot of the Acropolis, another group unfurled a banner reading Free Tibet. Neither protest disrupted the relay, and no arrests were reported.

Lindsay Davenport says she tried to talk Venus and Serena Williams into taking part in the next round of the Fed Cup, but failed. Davenport will lead the United States team when it faces Russia late next month in Moscow. She said she lobbied Venus Williams last month at a tournament in Memphis. “It didn’t work,” Davenport said, laughing. “She said that she wasn’t going.” Davenport said she received a similar response from Serena Williams this week. Ashley Harkleroad is expected to play singles with Davenport.

INTERNATIONAL.

An article on Page 52 of The Times Magazine this weekend about this summer’s Olympics in Beijing and the effects of political activists on them and their sponsors omits a sentence from a statement from Microsoft, a sponsor of the games, about the need for international organizations to intervene in Sudan, which buys weapons from China. The passage containing the statement should read: The company further “commend[ed] Dream for Darfur and other organizations for their leadership in casting a spotlight on this atrocity and the need for immediate international resolution. Governments and international organizations — the United Nations chief among them, as well as humanitarian relief organizations — will need to continue to work together locally and globally to address the problems in the Sudan. Microsoft will continue to support these organizations in their mission through technology assistance and other resources.”.

An article last Sunday about Sharla Musabih and her efforts to protect battered wives and victims of human trafficking in Dubai paraphrased incorrectly from her comment about the need to take strong action to protect women. She said she was fighting any attitudes that made domestic abuse possible; she did not say that she was fighting patriarchal Arab traditions.

A photograph with the “Living In” article last Sunday about Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, was published in error. It shows properties on Lafayette Avenue in Fort Greene, not in Clinton Hill. A map with the “Living In” article on March 16 about Woodside, Queens, referred incorrectly to a subway line in the neighborhood. The G, R and V line does not carry E and F trains. (Within Woodside, E and F trains run on a separate line, not shown on the map, but that line eventually merges with the line carrying the G, R and V trains.).

A caption last Sunday with the “In the Region” article about developments in downtown New Brunswick, N.J., misidentified the project shown in the architectural rendering. Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about preparations for a flu pandemic included outdated rankings on emergency-preparedness given to states last year by Trust for America’s Health, a Washington-based nonprofit health watchdog group. Thirty-seven states scored 8 or higher on a scale of 1 to 10, and the lowest score given to any state was 6. More than half the states did not receive a score of 5 or lower last year. They are 767s, not 757s.

For a few years now, Type A travelers have been racing off to polo matches in Mongolia and Norwegian salmon-fishing expeditions with waiting lists that can last a lifetime. But lately the idea of the trophy trip has reached a peak, as the travel industry keeps offering rarer and more meaningful ways to connect to the world.

Now that bureaux de change are doing brisk business in rubles and yuan, it’s clear there’s a new world order in travel. “People from everywhere are going everywhere,” says Ian Bremmer, the president of the consulting firm Eurasia Group. And with new wealth come fresh stereotypes — remember the Ugly American? Bremmer ascribes clichés to “pure economics. It’s who’s spending the most money and annoying the locals.” Here, a pop-anthropological look at the travel universe now. ANNA LOUIE SUSSMAN.

Calling Diego Della Valle a frequent flyer is certainly an understatement. Most mornings the chairman and C.E.O. of Tod’s Group shuttles by helicopter or private jet from his main home in Casette d’Ete, Italy, to the company headquarters in Milan. Beyond this regular commute, there are frequent jaunts to London and Paris, business trips to Asia and occasional getaways to New York and places like Parrot Cay in Turks and Caicos. So it’s no surprise that Della Valle is obsessed with globes. “I have been a collector for about 50 years,” he says. “All my friends give them to me as presents.” He found this one at Florian Papp, a small antiques shop on Manhattan’s Upper East Side; it’s become a favorite and now has pride of place in his office. “I think I like them so much because I miss traveling for my soul rather than business,” he says. “I’d love to stay for a long time in a small place where the food is fantastic and there are no phones.” Della Valle hopes to hit the road soon, renting a motor home with his son and driving across America, making stops at places like Yellowstone National Park; Jackson Hole, Wyo.; and Palm Springs, Calif. After that, he might head off the beaten path. “Maybe I’ll just spin the globe, put my finger on it and go wherever it lands. That’s the dream.” ARMAND LIMNANDER.

magnet / (mag& nit) / n. / a place that has attracted a following among a particular group, e.g., “Berlin’s become a total magnet for artsy expats — it’s to today what Paris was to the ’20s.” For travelers, connotes how an influx of fresh blood can create newly interesting destinations, as in, “Eco-geeks have made Boulder a magnet city of the green movement. They even have an official bicycle ambassador!”.
In Taipei, the collision of history and reinvention is changing the face of the Taiwanese capital. Click through to see additional photos by Michael Wolf not in the magazine.

You may not be able to live without your oversize Fendi clutch, but is it packable? These zip-and-go travel bags fold up to become chic wallet-size cases that fit snugly in your suitcase. Devi Kroell’s shoulder candy comes in dyed alligator and contrasting nylon ($2,690; devikroell.com). Hermèss compact shopper is done in its iconic scarf prints ($960; hermes.com). And Lanvin has even done a convertible suede lambskin duffel for men ($652; lanvin.com). ALEX HAWGOOD.

Despite a sensational farmers’ market, Santa Monica, Calif., has long been something of a culinary void. But lately things have been looking up. Rustic Canyon Wine Bar and Seasonal Kitchen (1119 Wilshire Boulevard; 310-393-7050; entrees $16 to $34) began the turnaround with Samir Mohajer’s seasonal dishes like lamb shanks with polenta and roasted baby artichokes. Michael Reardon’s Catch (above; 1910 Ocean Way; 310-581-7714; entrees $26 to $42) serves inventive seafood plates in the Casa del Mar hotel, and in the Huntely hotel, the Penthouse (1111 Second Street; 310-393-8080; entrees $22 to $48) features farmers’ market fare prepared by Seth Greenburg.

Between snowcapped mountains and the ocean shore, Vancouver has always been Canada’s beauty queen. But the city isn’t relying on its looks alone. With trailblazing chefs, designers and artists — not to mention a thriving film scene — it’s become the hottest spot north of the border.
No matter what you get up to after dark, Vancouver’s got you covered.
Three leaders of the strikingly original (and influential) Vancouver indie-rock scene — and where to hear them.
The city has a hotel to suit every taste. T’s favorites, in five categories.

Ever since Hollywood came to town — thanks to generous tax incentives and a diverse landscape — Vancouver has been a favorite filming location for big-budget productions and struggling indies alike. Here’s where to catch some of the town’s best moviemaking and watch visiting stars spending their per diems.

Hiking the Grouse Grind is a rite of passage for any Vancouverite and a favorite cardio jolt for fitness fanatics (and there are more than a few of those here). The intense 1.8-mile stair-climb straight up Grouse Mountain has its rewards, particularly the phenomenal panoramic views of the city, Vancouver Island and northern Washington State — not to mention a cozy mountaintop pub serving local brews and perfectly credible nachos. Or you can take the easy way up: the tram. 6400 Nancy Greene Way; (604) 984-0661; grousemountain.com.
In Vancouver’s most dynamic neighborhood, boutiques and restaurants sprout so rapidly it can be hard to keep pace. What’s hot right now?.

Vancouver’s sense of style has evolved past yoga pants, but the fashion establishment hasn’t completely renounced its crunchiness. These top labels take cues from Mother Nature: silhouettes drape and flow, embellishments are subtle, and form follows function.
Wabi-sabi — beauty in imperfection — is the city’s reigning ethos, and these designers get it just right.
The “100-Mile Diet,” by the Vancouverites J. B. MacKinnon and Alisa Smith, spawned a craze for farm-to-table eating here. Sample the best of the local bounty from these award-winning kitchens.

The Vancouver School — the 1980s movement led by the conceptual photographers Jeff Wall and Ian Wallace — put the city squarely on the art-world map. Now the scene has graduated beyond photography to include painting, sculpture and video.

Machu Picchu, Bhutan, the Sultanate of Oman, Kazakhstan, Mongolia: there’s no place too far or too exotic for the fashion critic Hilary Alexander. “I travel all over the place,” she says. “The key to traveling is to never be surprised by anything.” Alexander, the fashion director of The Daily Telegraph and twice the recipient of a British Fashion Award for journalist of the year, likes to keep things as simple as a fashionista can while trotting the globe. She never goes anywhere without an electric toothbrush charger, a pair of flats,.

Against the deadpan sameness of downtown Anchorage, a marquee featuring an Eiffel Tower and the words “Club Paris” in cursive neon juts out from a nondescript storefront. Anchorage is an oil boomtown that was built on the remnants of a gold and fur boomtown that was largely wiped out by an earthquake in 1964. Club Paris is that rare elderly building that survived. (Large portions of a J. C. Penney landed around it, but failed to destroy it.).

To the Editor: I read with interest “Need a Doctor in the Air? Fly With One” (Practical Traveler, March 16), on medical emergencies on airplanes. It had particular pertinence for me. I was returning from Portland, Ore., to New York on JetBlue when I was overcome by severe stomach pains and bloating; I was in agony. My wife talked to a flight attendant who asked if there was a doctor on board.

BY MIDDLE ROCK LAKE IN MOUNT HOOD NATIONAL FOREST, SEPT. 26, 2007 Steve Herppich, 43, a newspaper photo editor in Olympia, Wash. ''I try to get out in the woods on a backpacking trip at least once a year. What I do for a living is totally immersed in humanity: there's something I really love about covering assignments and meeting all different kinds of people every day. But to get out where, for all you know, there's nobody within miles is priceless. The whole little mountain lake was surrounded by foothills, and our campsite was right alongside. After dinner, you've got a full belly, and scenery all around you. You watch the final rays of the sun cut across the top of the mountain, not a breeze in the air, the water still, like glass. The only ripples in the lake were these little red salamanders. Once in a while they would bump into each other and thrash around. But that was the only disturbance. It was really, really sweet.'' As told to Seth Kugel
To the Editor: Re ''Perfect Tone, in a Key That's Mostly Minor,'' by Mickey Rapkin (Sunday Styles, March 23):

PALUMBO--Anthony , painter, renowned drawing instructor at the Art Students League of New York died February 29, 2008 age 85. He was an innovative art teacher who will be dearly missed by all who were graced by this gentle giant, talented soul. He is survived by his wife, painter Phyllis Tracy Malinow.

More than three hours after Reggie Jackson's three homers in Game 6 won the 1977 World Series for the Yankees, he was still in his pinstriped uniform at his locker when he suddenly had a quiet question for the half-dozen reporters who had been questioning him. ''How far did that last homer go?'' he said.

TAYLOR--Mary Wisner , 89, personnel director for UNICEF for many years, died on March 16, in Philadelphia. Services pending at Watermark Retirement Home. Born on May 19, 1918 in Youngstown, Ohio to Dr. William. H. and Ellen Belden Taylor, she graduated from Smith College in 1940; served in Germany with UNRRA after World War II; was personnel officer for UNICEF until retirement in 1978; then volunteered with Save the Children Federation. She visited 80 countries; moved from New York City to Philadelphia in 1998. Survived by nephews Edward W. Merkel, New York City and William T. Merkel, Oregon. Contact: ted.merkel@earthlink.net
SCHARY--Ola . 1914-2007. Survivor of the Warsaw Ghetto. Gentle of soul, noble of heart. Forever our beloved.

MAISEL--Edward , 90, internationally known writer on music and Tai Chi, died March 21, 2008 after a long illness. A resident of NYC, he was born in Buffalo, NY. He graduated Magna Cum Laude from Harvard University where he was also inducted into Phi Beta Kappa. Mr. Maisel's inimitable character was reflected in his career that broadened the audience for many ''hidden gems.'' He wrote Charles T. Griffes: the Life of an American Composer, the first and still influential biography of this major early American composer. Mr. Maisel also produced a CD, The Songs of Charles T. Griffes. In 1986, he produced Griffes' final but unfinished work, Salut au Monde for the Kennedy Center's Terrace Theater. Mr. Maisel was instrumental in shaping thinking about physical fitness. He wrote Tai Chi for Health, the first Western manual of the classic (Yang) form of the Chinese system of meditative exercise. A world traveler, he visited China during the eras of Mao and Deng refining his understanding of Tai Chi. In The Alexander Technique, Mr. Maisel wrote the introduction and edited the writings of F. Mattias Alexander. This book on Alexander's method of body-mind training became widely used as a textbook for actors and dancers. His other books related to fitness include Have Your Baby, Keep Your Figure and Fit to Drive. His article, Should Veterans Have Legs?, about the poor quality of artificial limbs available to WWII veterans helped prompt the government's investigation of prosthesis. He served as director of research at the International Center of the Disabled, director of the American Physical Fitness Research Institute and in Hawaii, where he lived for many years, director of Ka Lima O Maui, a sheltered workshop for the disabled. He was predeceased by his wife, Betty Cage, general manager of the NYC Ballet and by five sisters. He is survived by a brother-in-law Robert O. Swados of Buffalo and many nieces and nephews. Donations may be made in his name to the Artemis Center, 310 West Monument Ave., Dayton, Ohio 45402.

WEINREICH--Beatrice (Bina) . The YIVO Institute for Jewish Research mourns the passing of our dear friend and colleague, Bina Weinreich, widow of Uriel. An author and ethnographer, Bina was affiliated with YIVO for over 50 years, first as assistant to Max Weinreich, then as a researcher, teacher and editor. Her publications include ''Yiddish Folktales'' (1998), a classic collection of Eastern European Jewish folklore. She will be sorely missed. We send our deepest sympathy to her children, Stephanie and Don. May her memory be a blessing. Bruce Slovin, Chair Carl J. Rheins, Exec. Director WEINREICH--Beatrice Silverman, of New York and Cranberry Isles. Mother, motherin-law, grandmother, folklorist. Survived by Stephanie, Don, Barbara, Nienke, Alex, Kate, Max, family and many friends. Wife of the late Uriel Weinreich. Deeply loved, deeply loving. Memorial Service April 27, 2008.

CONE--Arthur L., Jr. , age 87, of Williamsburg, VA, died March 15, six weeks after the loss of his beloved wife Joan. Survived by brothers Ross and Eric, four children and three grandchildren. A fine writer, hunter and fisherman, he will be deeply missed.

ZWEIG--Estelle . Beloved wife, mother, grandmother and great-grandmother. Estelle Zweig, died March 19, 2008 at age 83. Friends and family are welcome to join in a memorial service at her home in Boca Raton, FL on March 30, 2008 at 10am. The family will also welcome guests that day 1-4pm and on March 31, 2008 10am-1pm. Born in Astoria, NY January 14, 1925 as Estelle Mildred Mishler to Julius and Shirley Mishler, she had two brothers, Arthur and Lenny, and a sister, Phyllis (deceased). Estelle graduated Brooklyn College 1945, and became a NYC teacher. She later obtained a Masters to become a guidance counselor and teacher for the emotionally challenged. She married the love of her life, Robert Zweig on August 23, 1947, and they shared 50 blissful years in Brooklyn, then Altoona, then back to New York in Woodside and later on 185th St. in Fresh Meadows, until retiring in 1993 to Boca Raton. Robert (Bob) died February 12, 1997. Estelle was known by her family for her strong and articulate opinions, as well as her culinary delights. From her matzo ball soup at Passover to her bread stuffing at Thanksgiving, she delivered family favorites with ease and modesty. Estelle was best known by her friends as an avid tennis player, swimmer, cook, and always an eclectic, sharp conversationalist. Estelle is survived by her two sons, Paul of Columbia, MD, and Michael of Malibu, CA, by six adored grandchildren, Rachel, Aaron and Ben (of Paul and Sandy), and Megan, Casey and Sarah (of Michael and Marie), and a great-grandson, Robert William (of Noel and Rachel Collins). Estelle will be dearly missed. Donations, if requested, may be made on her behalf to UJA.

ARTHUR--Paul . The film studies faculty at Montclair State University mourn the sudden, tragic loss of our beloved friend, Paul Arthur: brilliant scholar, dynamic teacher and generous colleague. We will miss his intellect, integrity, and wit every day. Janet Cutler and Art Simon ARTHUR--Paul. Exuberantly loving father; brilliant, passionate film scholar, critic and teacher; of a mind, body and spirit too capacious to describe in these few column inches, Paul Arthur died March 25 at home, five weeks after he was diagnosed with melanoma. He was 60 years old. With him when he died were his daughters, Jarrett Rachel (25) and Devin Valerie (22); his former wife, Dr. Karen Arthur; his mother, Pearl Fried; and his dog, Monk. He also leaves a sister, Roseanne. Only a year ago, he suffered the loss of his partner, Susan Deul, to breast cancer. Since 1989, Paul had been a professor of English and Film Studies at Montclair State University; he was named the Distinguished Scholar of the University for 2007-2008. He received a B.A. (1969) in English from Tufts University, where he also was on the football team and in SDS, and a Ph.D. (1985) in Cinema Studies from NYU. Coming of age in the 1960s, he was drawn to the political activism of the New Left and the radical modernism of avant-garde film. Both were for him, as he later wrote, ''expressions of resistance and transformation'', and he remained committed to them for life. His writings weave aesthetics and politics in the context of American history and culture. Paul was a contributing editor of Film Comment, associate editor of Cineaste and co-editor of Millennium Film Journal. His book A Line of Sight: American Avant-Garde Film Since 1965 was published by Minnesota Press; at the time of his death, he had nearly completed a collection of his writings on documentary and a book on Nick Broomfield. He embodied contradictions as bold and fascinating as those of the art works he loved. He was both spontaneous and ritualistic in his personal relationships and in his work. He made a journal entry for every film he saw, freely noting his immediate responses and ideas; and he commemorated the death of John Coltrane every July 17 for 40 years. As mentally and physically tough as he was, he took pure pleasure in a good laugh, a great meal, a well-played hockey game, a compelling argument over a movie. The refinement of his senses of sight and sound notwithstanding, he was a thoroughly tactile and physically demonstrative person. His talismanic animal was the bear. The family members, colleagues, students and friends who mourn him echo one another in describing him as larger than life. The hole he leaves in our hearts and the world is too big to be filled.

A picture last Sunday with an essay about a crack house in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, was published in error. The three houses in the picture are on the same street as the crack house, but none of the three figured in the essay.

TESLA MOTORS, the nascent dot-car manufacturer that promised the world an electric sports car, has announced that series production of the Tesla Roadster had begun at the Lotus plant in Hethel, England. The Roadster is powered by a 185 kilowatt (248 horsepower) electric motor and promises to be the only mass-production electric car offered in America. If Tesla overcomes the many hurdles of bringing a high-tech, alt-energy, niche-market car to profitable production, it'll certainly be remembered as one of the signature cars of the decade.

VAN DER KEMP--Florence . Florence Russell Bennett Harris. The Officers and Staff of The Versailles Foundation, Inc., mourn the passing of Florence Van der Kemp, Founder and President, Chevalier de la Legion d'Honneur, Chevalier des Arts et Lettres, Foreign Correspondent Member of the Institut de France, Academie des Beaux-Arts, who died in New York City on February 11, 2008. She dedicated her extraordinary energy with her late husband and Academicien, Gerald Van der Kemp to the restoration of The Chateau de Versailles, Trianons & Parc, along with the resuscitation of the Home and Gardens of the painter Claude Monet at Giverny. Her Memorial Mass was held in the Basilique Sainte Clothilde of her Paris neighborhood. She is buried next to her beloved husband in the Church cemetery of Giverny, where she resided until her death. A true ''grande dame'' who will be affectionately missed by all who knew her. Barbara de Portago Daughter and President The Versailles Foundation, Inc. New York City

FISCHER--Michael D. , age 69, of Miami Beach, passed away on Thursday, March 27, 2008. Beloved husband of Maxine. Devoted father of Lisa (Bernard) Noble, Adam (Jeanie) Fischer, Rachel (Arthur) Heller, Jonathan (Jamie) Fischer. Cherished son of Irving and the late Sylvia Fischer. Dear brother of Harriet Sanders and Richard Fischer. Adored grandfather of Benjamin and Elizabeth Noble, Andrew, Michael and Katie Heller, and Zachary Fischer. Born and raised in New York, Michael graduated from Queens College where he met his wife, Maxine, of 49 years. His love for Israel and the Jewish people led him to pursue a long and fruitful career as a fundraiser for Jewish causes, ultimately serving as a senior executive for the Greater Miami Jewish Federation and the United Jewish Communities in New York. Over the years, Michael led numerous missions to Israel, raised hundreds of millions of dollars, and was recognized for his significant fundraising successes by various world leaders. Michael was an incredibly kind and special man and was a gift to all who knew him. Michael was most proud of his family who he loved and cherished, and who loved and adored him in return. Services held today in Miami Beach, FL. Special thank you to Edward Goldstein and family of Parkside Memorial Chapels, Queens, NY. Donations to United Jewish Communities.

WINFIELD--Lillian , passed away on March 20 after a long and uncomplaining struggle with Parkinson's. Born June 14, 1921 to Yetty Stern and Isidor Yudien, she grew up in the Bronx, graduated in 1942 from Hunter College, and then refused a graduate biology fellowship to help support her parents. In 1943 she married the late Sidney L. Winfield, her husband of 48 years, with whom she raised her only child, Richard, first in Fresh Meadows, Queens, and later in Roslyn, Long Island. Returning to Hofstra for a M.Ed. degree, Lillian taught science at Weber Jr. High in Port Washington, before joining her husband's shoe importing firm in Manhattan, where she worked as VP for several decades. She moved to Athens, GA in 1996 to be near her son's family. Beloved wife, mother, mother - in - law, grandmother, sister and aunt, Lillian is survived by her son, Richard Dien Winfield, his wife Sujata Gupta, their children, Kalindi, Manas, and Rasik, and her sister Muriel Friedman, niece Lois Kopolow and nephew Joel Friedman. Lillian's brilliance, beauty, love, and generosity will not be forgotten. In her memory, donations may be made to the Hunter College Foundation.
Art Randy Kennedy

ENGELHARDT--Dean Lee, Ph.D. , 68, died on March 25 of pancreatic cancer. In his final year, he forged deeper relationships with his loved ones: his wife and best friend, Sara, daughters, Barbara Martin and Margaret Engelhardt, son-in-law and grandson, Lance and Wolf Martin, and nephews, Alec and Chris Cumming. Dean's friends sought his company because of his creative and open mind and his engaged style. His productive career as a research scientist and biotech executive led not only to over 20 patents and several significant clinical trials, but to writing science ''faction'' novels and learning to speak both Japanese and German. To honor his passion for the outdoors, including camping, skiing, hiking, and everyday jogs, donations can be made to the Mohonk Preserve at mohonkpreserve.org.

MCKENZIE--Kermit E. , 83, died on March 18, 2008. Raised in Richmond, VA, he was educated at the University of Richmond and Columbia University, where he earned a Ph.D. and Certificate from the Russian Institute. He was a Sergeant in WWII and was awarded two Purple Hearts. After teaching at Columbia, Yale and the University of Wisconsin, in 1960 he began a 35-year career at Emory University as professor of Russian history. He authored the book ''Comintern and World Revolution, 1928 -1943, The Shaping of Doctrine'' and numerous articles during his career, notably a fierce stance in ''Emory Today'' in 1966 arguing against US involvement in Vietnam from an historical perspective. He was a longtime member of the American Association for the Advancement of Slavic Studies. Kermit was an avid chess player, world traveler, and lover of cats. He will be remembered by family and friends for his gentle and kind nature as well as his intellect and erudition. He is mourned by his wife of 40 years, Mary Burton McKenzie, children Joan Baker, Charles Finlayson (Donna), and Leigh Finlayson (Trixie), all of Atlanta; daughters Victoria Carriger (Jerry) of Tulare, CA and Valerie McKenzie (Carl Delo) of New York City from his prior marriage of 16 years to Vivian Borton Sherman of Tulare, CA; six grandchildren and one great-grandchild. Memorial contributions can be made to the liberal cause of your choice or your local animal shelter.

ROSENFELD--Ruth C. , born Ruth C. Frey in Rochester, New York on November 28, 1926 died at home in Concord, Massachusetts on Marth 27th after a long struggle with pancreatic cancer. A caring, wise woman of infinite heart, Ruth will be remembered by all who knew her for her quick mind, her ready smile, her extraordinary kindness and graciousness and adventuresome spirit. She saw good in everyone and will be forever in the hearts of her family and those who loved her. Her spirit and memory is kept alive by her devoted husband of more than 60 years, Lawrence Rosenfeld, her loving children, daughters Faith, Jan and Amy and son Eric; their spouses and partners, Fran Rosenfeld, Lissa Walsh, and Michael Cantania; grandchildren, Jamie and Alison Rosenfeld and Taran and Leif Catania and her brothers and their families; Harvey Frey of London, England and Irwin Frey of Ruskin, Florida. A memorial service will be held at the Chapel at Concord Academy on Main Street in Concord, Massachusetts on Sunday April 6th at 11am. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to Emerson Health Care Foundation to benefit Bethke Cancer Center, 133 Old Road to Nine Acre Corner, Concord, Massachusetts 07142. She fought a valiant battle but passed in peace surrounded by love. She will be sorely missed by all. Visit: www.concordfuneral.com

RUSS--Marion . Teacher, poet. July 26, 1912-March 4, 2008. Marion died in Mountain View, California on March 4. Widow of Ben Russ, a CBS technical director who worked with Sinatra and other stars in the golden age of live television, from 1957-1974 Marion pioneered teaching science fiction and mass media in New York City schools. She then moved to California, was a writing consultant to Palo Alto schools and led widows bereavement groups. A gifted poet, she eulogized many who predeceased her. She's survived by her son Dr. Jonathan Russ and his wife Louise of Los Altos, California, and their daughters, Melanie and Elisabeth. Also surviving are grandchildren Jennifer and Benjamin Russ, children of the late Dr. Kenneth Russ and his late wife Linda of University City, Missouri. A memorial service was held Friday, March 14, at Congregation Etz Chayim in Palo Alto. Donations in Marion's name may be made to Kara grief counseling center at 457 Kingsley Ave, Palo Alto, CA 94301.

KRAUSE--Paul Rockwell , 81, died February 19 at home in Brooklyn, survived by his brother Robert, sister-in-law Gloria, nephew Robert and niece Joan, all of Columbus. He saw action in the Battle of the Bulge. A graduate of Tufts, he was a caseworker and writer. Paul biked and walked through much of the world. PICKER--Harvey . A physicist, inventor, businessman, educator, philosopher and friend died on March 22 at age 92. Mr. Picker ran Picker X-ray Company for 25 years. He was a well-known inventor of x-ray technology and groundbreaking developments including cobalt therapy for cancer, nuclear imaging diagnostics and the use of ultrasound for oceanography, which was adapted for medical imaging. Along with his wife Jean, an ambassador to the U.N. in the 1960s, now deceased, he then founded the Picker Institute, a nonprofit dedicated to advancing the principles of patient-centered care and pioneered the systematic collection of data from hospital patients to help improve the delivery of medical services in the U.S. and Europe. Mr. Picker also taught at his alma mater, Colgate University, and served as the dean of the School of International and Public Affairs at Columbia University. He also helped found the Picker Engineering Program at Smith College, his wife's alma mater. He is survived by two daughters, Bobbi Hamill of Boston, MA and Gale Jean Picker of Seattle, WA, as well as three grandchildren, Jean Picker Larsen, Evelyn Picker Larsen and Matthew James Mrachek. A memorial service will be held on May 24th at 11am at the Camden Library in Camden, ME.

THE federal economic stimulus package signed last month has started to take effect for mortgages, and the results for borrowers in the New York area are not encouraging. While more homeowners are eligible for bigger loans than were initially expected, they are not yet getting a meaningful break on interest rates, dampening hopes that the plan would give the housing market an immediate boost. The stimulus plan lifted the size limits for loans eligible for purchase by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, two government-sponsored companies that resell packages of loans to investors. Previously, only mortgages below $417,000 qualified as so-called conforming loans.

ROSENTHAL--Richard J. , born on June 29, 1943, passed away on March 13, 2008. He is survived by his only sister, Ronnie Haran Mellen, and brother-in-law Chase Mellen. Beloved son of his deceased parents, Harry and Gertrude Rosenthal. Those who knew and loved him know that he is at peace at last.

For many restaurantgoers on the East End, the annual Hamptons Restaurant Week is the first sign of spring. The eight-day promotion, which this year runs from March 30 through April 6, marks ''the end of cabin fever,'' according to Walter Struble, the general manager of Della Femina in East Hampton. ''It gets people out of the house to come and try the restaurants,'' he said. Now in its sixth year, Restaurant Week includes more than 60 participating restaurants on the North and South Forks, each of which will offer a three-course prix fixe dinner for $21.95 all evening long (except Saturday, when it will be available until 7 p.m.). Tax, beverage and gratuity are extra.

GELLHORN--Alfred, M.D. , 94. Physician, Farmer, Reformer, Practical Visionary, Mentor and Humanist died peacefully at home on March 24, after an active career in medicine and healthcare policy spanning 72 years. Pioneer in oncology at Columbia University 1943--1968; Dean, U of PA School of Medicine; Founding Director, Sophie Davis School of Biomedical Education of City U, and the Gateway Institute in NYC's public high schools; Director of Medical Affairs at the NYS Department of Health; Board Member and advisor for the Aaron and Irene Diamond Foundations. He was a physician-scientist, beloved teacher and mentor who wrought far-reaching reforms in graduate medical education, primary care and minority access to education. Predeceased by his wife Olga and daughter Maria, he leaves loving daughters Martha, Anne, Tina and Edna, five grandchildren and one greatgrandchild. Burial will be private, with a memorial celebration in NYC planned for later in the spring. The family suggests donations to Gateway Institute, City College, Harris Hall H06, 106 Convent Avenue, NY, NY 10031.

GROB--David , M.D. Dr. Joseph Cunningham and the Department of Surgery at Maimonides Medical Center, Brooklyn, New York, mourn the passing of our respected colleague and admired educator. Dr. Grob guided and taught generations of faculty, residents and students in the art and science of medicine. Dr. Grob was Chairman of Medicine at Maimonides Medical Center, Professor of Medicine at SUNY Health Science Center Brooklyn, Clinical Associate Dean at Downstate Medical Center and Director of the Maimonides Research and Development Foundation. His numerous contributions to the medical literature and his acclaim to research in myasthenia gravis serve as many of the hallmarks of medicine. His contributions to Maimonides for over 45 years will long be remembered. He was a source of wisdom and inspiration to all.

TAN--Charlotte M.D. The Department of Pediatrics at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center mourns the passing of Charlotte Tan, M.D. Dr. Tan was Vice Chairman for Developmental Therapeutics from 1974-1996 and Member Emeritus of Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center. She received her degree in medicine at Hsiang-Ya Medical College in Hunan, China, and immigrated to the United States in 1948. After completing an internship at St. Barnabas Hospital, residency training in pediatrics at Children's Hospital of Philadelphia and specialty training in oncology at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, she joined our faculty in 1954. Dr. Tan was a pioneer in the field of developmental therapeutics who was the first to explore several cancer drugs in the treatment of malignancies of childhood. Her seminal studies of dactinomycin, and the anthracyclines daunomycin, and adriamycin, and the enzyme l-asparaginase demonstrated their therapeutic potential and led to their introduction into the multidrug regimens which now provide curative treatments for a high proportion of children afflicted with leukemia and cancers of developing bone, muscle and nerve cells. Thereafter, she shepherded initial Phase I trials that identified the safety and activity of several other cancer drugs that are now in standard use in the treatment of childhood malignancies. In addition to her landmark studies in developmental therapeutics, Dr. Tan was also widely recognized for her important contributions in the treatment of children with Hodgkin's disease. Dr. Tan's accomplishments were many and substantive. She authored over 126 papers in her field, worked tirelessly to ensure that the most promising new drugs would be available to children with cancer early in their development and successfully treated hundreds of young patients who are now cured, healthy adults leading productive lives throughout the world. Dr. Tan was a strong, energetic and careful physician and clinical investigator, passionately committed to the development of more consistently curative treatments for children with cancer. Her indomitable spirit sustains us today and will live on in the hearts of her cherished family and her many patients, colleagues and friends.

BEHLKE--Jean . It is with great sadness that The Society of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center notes the death of Past President Jean Behlke. An Associate Professor of Anatomy and Cell Biology, she taught at SUNY Downstate for over 40 years (1967-2008) as a member of both the Gross Anatomy and Neuroscience teaching faculty. A revered teacher, generations of students benefited from her vast knowledge of anatomy and her enthusiastic teaching style. She is survived by her half sisters, Laura, Monica and Antonia Sinks. A memorial service will be held on Thursday May 1st, 3pm at SUNY Downstate. Donations may be made in her memory in support of Anatomy Education by calling 718270-6794. John C. GRUNTAL--Carol Bach , Volunteer and Accomplished Tennis Player, dies at 87. Carol Bach Gruntal of Armonk, New York died on Wednesday, March 26th, 2008 at the age of 87 at The Sarah Neuman Nursing Home in Mamaroneck, New York from complications from Alzheimer's. Mrs. Bach Gruntal was born on March 12, 1921 in Manhattan. She was the daughter of Frederick F. and Ethel Bach and the sister of the late Judy Bach Angelo Cowen. She was educated at the Harcum Junior College in Pennsylvania and was later married to the late Louis Henry Goldman. Mr. Goldman was the great grandson of Marcus Goldman the founder of the renowned Wall Street financial firm, Goldman Sachs. Carol and Louis had two children, the late William L. Goldman and Dianne Goldman Pederson. Mrs. Bach Gruntal married Peter Gruntal in 1966 and spent their time between homes in Armonk, New York and Manhattan. Mr. and Mrs. Gruntal enjoyed spending their time at the Whippoorwill Country Club in Armonk. Mrs. Bach Gruntal was an avid and accomplished tennis and golf player. She volunteered her time in many ways. During World War II she volunteered as a candy striper at The New York Flower Hospital. Her favorite volunteer position was in New York City teaching English as a second language. She enjoyed the vibrancy of Manhattan as well as the serenity and beauty of her home in Armonk where she maintained beautiful gardens. Prior to her illness she enjoyed spending time with her husband, children and grandchildren. She enjoyed traveling and entertaining and had a passion for all things beautiful. Mrs. Bach Gruntal is survived by her husband, Peter Gruntal, her daughter, Dianne Goldman Pederson, her grandchildren and their respective spouses, Gunnar G. Pederson, Silvia Verderame Pederson, Kimberly Pederson Barta and Damon Barta and her greatgrandchildren, Jake Zajkowski, Claire Zajkowski, and Nicholas DeMetro, her nephew John M. Angelo and her lifetime friend Elizabeth Benjamin.

JUST as fans of the NBC sitcom ''The Office'' were celebrating the transformation of the fictional colleagues Jim Halpert and Pam Beesly from unrequited lovers to an honest-to-goodness couple, the writers' strike cruelly stalled their romance and halted production on the show for several months. But for John Krasinski, the actor who plays Jim, the affable everydude of ''The Office,'' the news wasn't all bad. He used the hiatus to resume postproduction work on his directorial debut, an adaptation of David Foster Wallace's ''Brief Interviews With Hideous Men,'' a collection of short stories and monologues that he has been trying to make into a film for more than five years. ''It was just something that I wanted to do, and it seemed like the only way to get it done was to do it myself,'' said Mr. Krasinski, who studied at Brown University and the O'Neill National Theater Institute in Waterford, Conn. ''We'll see if that was a good or bad decision.''

COOPER--John Lewis , Westwood, MA , formerly of Dover, MA, on Monday, March 24, 2008. Born in Pittsburgh, PA, on June 26, 1913, he was the son of the late Maurice D. and Marion (Lewis) Cooper. Holyoke College, and Trustee of Phillips Academy. A Memorial Service will be held at 11:00am on Tuesday, April 1st, at the Dover Church, 17 Springdale Ave, Dover, MA. Burial will be held privately at the Highland Cemetery, Dover. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent in his memory to the National Braille Press, 88 St. Stephen St., Boston, MA 02115.

He leaves behind his two children, Matthew Karl Gale of Sausalito, California and Elizabeth Millett Gale of Dublin, Ireland, and his wife, Anna Gale. He also leaves behind a sister, Kathleen Wist Gale, and her husband, David Bernard, of Palmyra, Virginia. A true Renaissance man, Kirby enjoyed reading, traveling, and learning new languages; he also had a love of the land, sea, and air. He is remembered for his unique use of language, his dry and endearing sense of humor, and his compassion. A hobbyist sailor for the last forty years, Kirby was sailing in a charity race outside of the San Francisco Bay with his good friend Anthony Harrow when the ship disappeared in turbulent seas. Kirby was blessed to have a large community of friends who fondly recall his curiosity, intellect, humanity, and humility. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation in his name to Doctors without Borders or the Jewish Community Free Clinic in Rohnert Park, California (www.jewishfreeclinic.com).

The Yankees' second baseman is named for the Brooklyn Dodgers' second baseman, the man who stole home at Yankee Stadium in the first game of the 1955 World Series. Where Jackie Robinson once slid, Robinson Canó now hits. It is not only Canó, of course. Almost every star of the last 85 years has dug his spikes into the clay at 161 Street and River Avenue in the Bronx, staring down Lefty Grove or Bob Feller, Whitey Ford or Mariano Rivera, staring into history.

BEFORE we were married my husband and I had a counseling session with our officiant, an Episcopal priest as humorless as driftwood. He asked us questions like, ''Are you on the same page about how to spend money?'' (''Sure,'' I answered. ''Whoever has a working credit card at the moment pays.'') ''Have you discussed how many children you want?'' (''Que sera, sera,'' we answered.) ''Have you discussed religion?'' (''Whatever. Just marry us.'') ''Do you like the same food?''

THEY may seem like strange academic bedfellows, but the names of Tom Cruise, Herman Melville and Toussaint L'Ouverture, the 18th-century Haitian independence fighter, are likely to pop up -- along with performances by the tenor saxophonist Joe Lovano, the pianist Vijay Iyer and the trombonist Ray Anderson -- at the three-day jazz conference and festival that starts Thursday at Stony Brook University. All events are open to the public, some at no charge. Concerts by Mr. Lovano, Mr. Iyer and Mr. Anderson are clearly apt fare for a jazz event. So, too, it turns out, are discussions of writers, fighters and actors (at least in their film roles), given the interdisciplinary scope of the conference, ''Brilliant Corners: Jazz and Its Cultures.''

STACK--J. William, Jr . The Council and members of The Yale Club of New York City wish to express our deepest sympathy and condolences to the entire Stack family. Bill was a long time member and Council member of our club, and he will be deeply missed. STACK--William. Joseph William (Bill) Stack, Jr. died peacefully at the Health Care Center at Meadow Ridge in Redding, Connecticut on March 25, 2008, at the age of 89. Born and raised in East Lansing, Michigan, where his father was a Professor at Michigan State University, he graduated from Yale University in 1940. There he was Captain of both the freshman and varsity football teams. He served in the Navy during WWII, seeing action at Midway and Guadalcanal before transferring to the European theatre where he took part in D-Day. He rose to the rank of Lieutenant Commander and was the first U.S. Naval Officer to enter liberated Paris. After the war, his business career began at General Motors, and culminated in 1970 when he founded his own executive search firm in New York City, William Stack Associates. He ran the firm until his retirement in 1995. Throughout his life he was active in Yale alumni affairs. He served on the Boards of the Yale Alumni Association, the Football Y Association and was a founding member of Lux et Veritas. He was also always active in the Episcopal Church serving on several different Vestries. After his retirement he became a Mentor in the Norwalk, CT school system. He is survived by his beloved wife of 60 years, Wolcott Rorick (Mimi) Stack, and their children and families, Chris, Martha, Nathan, Courtney, Charlotte, David, Sarah, Hadley, Isabel, Will, Peter, Sonya, Joey, Patrick, Mickey and Jamie. He was predeceased by his son Joseph William III, and his sister, Elizabeth Leslie. A memorial service will be held later this Spring. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be sent to Mid-Fairfield Hospice, P.O. Box 489, Wilton, Connecticut 06897.

ON Wednesday, the Ford Motor Company agreed to sell Jaguar and Land Rover to Tata Motors of India. Tata will pay Ford $2.3 billion -- or $200 million less than Ford paid for Jaguar alone in 1989 -- while Ford will contribute $600 million for the Jaguar-Land Rover pension fund. While it may seem a bit late for hand-wringing over the end of the British Empire, the sale of Jaguar to an Indian company must be even more jarring to lovers of classic English brands than the sale of Bentley and Rolls-Royce to the Germans. But any change for Jaguar must be seen as a positive one.

THIRTEEN days ago, United States Customs authorities refused to admit the infamously debauched writer Sebastian Horsley into the country for a book tour. After a lengthy interrogation at Newark airport, he was put on a plane back to England. One might read the statement by a Customs spokeswoman, citing concerns of ''moral turpitude'' relating to his past arrests in England for drug possession and prostitution -- which in his book, ''Dandy in the Underworld'' (Harper Perennial), Mr. Horsley asserts that he has both solicited and proffered -- and think that the United States was protecting itself.

LESCH--Michael , M.D. The entire St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center family joins with the leadership of its parent company, Continuum Health Partners, and with the leadership and faculty of the Columbia University Medical Center in acknowledging with profound sadness the sudden passing of our dear friend and colleague, Michael Lesch, M.D., Chairman of the Department of Medicine at St. Luke's-Roosevelt since 1998 and the John H. Keating, Sr., Professor of Medicine at Columbia University College of Physicians & Surgeons. Dr. Lesch made enormous contributions to St. Luke's-Roosevelt during his tenure as Chairman of Medicine, greatly expanding and enhancing the hospital's scope of clinical services. In addition, he was a revered member of the Columbia medical faculty, working tirelessly to advance the education and training of the next generation of physicians. And he will forever be remembered both nationally and internationally as a pioneer and recognized leader in the field of cardiology. He will be greatly missed by all who knew him and worked with him. To his beloved wife, Bella, his family and all of his loved ones, we extend our heartfelt condolences during this very difficult time. Lawrence S. Huntington Chairman, Board of Trustees Continuum Health Partners Stanley Brezenoff President and CEO Continuum Health Partners Frank J. Cracolici President and CEO St. Luke's-Roosevelt Donna Mendes, M.D. President, Medical Board St. Luke's-Roosevelt Lee Goldman, M.D. Executive Vice President For Health and Biomedical Sciences Dean of the Faculties of Health Sciences and Medicine Columbia University Medical Center Steven Shea, M.D. Senior Vice Dean Columbia University College of Physicians & Surgeons LESCH--Michael, M.D. -The physicians, residents and staff in the Department of Medicine at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center are deeply saddened at the untimely passing of our revered and beloved Chairman, Michael Lesch, M.D. Words cannot adequately describe how much this very special man meant to all of us. Without question, his death is a great loss to the world of medicine, particularly the field of cardiology. But, on a deeply, personal note, his absence from our everyday lives at St. Luke's-Roosevelt will be profound. We extend our sympathies to his dear and devoted wife, Bella, and the entire Lesch family. We join with them in grieving this incredible loss. Bruce Polsky, M.D. Interim Chairman Julie Clegg Administrator

BY 2002, Lisa Sette and Peter Shikany were in an advanced state of dating, but they were not looking to buy a house together, let alone an unfinished one with a fabric roof that had been the cause of head- and heartaches for its original owners. No matter. Ms. Sette's best friend, Gretchen Freeman, suggested that they check out the structure just behind her own in Phoenix. It is known as the House of Earth and Light, and Ms. Freeman thought it perfectly fit their sensibilities. ''And I guess we were moving their relationship along,'' she said recently.

Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about preparations for a flu pandemic included outdated rankings on emergency-preparedness given to states last year by Trust for America's Health, a Washington-based nonprofit health watchdog group. Thirty-seven states scored 8 or higher on a scale of 1 to 10, and the lowest score given to any state was 6. More than half the states did not receive a score of 5 or lower last year. (Those rankings were from a 2005 report.)

THE trees travel at night. They wait, strapped to 48-foot-long trailers in a muddy lot in a New Jersey nursery, until about 11 p.m., when the roads are clear. THE NEWS Federal regulators ordered inspections of thousands of older model Boeing 737s after reports of fuel leaks caused by a potentially faulty bolt. BEHIND THE NEWS Last August, a fire destroyed a China Airlines 737 when a bolt from a wing slat punctured the jet's fuel tank. All 165 people aboard were evacuated unharmed before the plane exploded on a runway in Japan. The Federal Aviation Administration ordered inspections of newer model 737s similar to the China Airlines jetliner, then expanded the order to include older models after Boeing reported fuel leaks on some of those. The new order affects 652 jetliners in the United States and a total of about 3,500 worldwide.

In a city known for crowded subway platforms and standing-room-only buses, many residents, even those with robust public transit options, remain fiercely loyal to their cars, Diane Cardwell writes. Despite the threat of traffic jams, honking horns and the urban version of road rage, these New Yorkers choose to drive, whether to shave time off their commutes, run their errands with less hassle or have a few moments to themselves inside mobile oases. Many of these drivers would be affected by the mayor’s congestion pricing proposal, whose future is still in doubt as the plan heads toward votes in the State Legislature and City Council.

Trent Benefield, a passenger wounded in the police shooting that killed Sean Bell, testified on Monday morning in the trial of three detectives charged in the case that he was shot first in Mr. Bell’s back seat and again as he ran away.The testimony from Mr. Benefield, 24, appeared to contradict the grand jury testimony of the detectives, none of whom have said they shot at him as he ran away. Mr. Benefield said he was first shot in both calves in the back seat.

The most volatile clash of sports and fashion since Flo Jo's one-legged unitard? It may be the April 2008 cover of Vogue, featuring Gisele Bundchen and the NBA superstar LeBron James (the magazine's first African-American male cover subject). For several days, the photo, taken by Annie Leibovitz, has fueled blogosphere debate and dinner-party chatter on the topic of racist imagery. James is shown baring his teeth, dribbling a ball, with his arm around a smiling Gisele - a pose that bloggers have likened to representations of King Kong. (A commenter on Feministe wrote, "I see a scary animalistic black man, a primal scream, and a beautiful white woman.") Did Leibovitz intend the questionable reference? As a Rare, Rare Find points out, the basketball player's nickname is King James. For what it's worth, Style.com's behind-the-scenes video of the shoot shows the pair dancing, jumping and skipping together. Furthermore, James, Vogue and the NAACP have all weighed in on the matter. Now it's your turn. ...

WASHINGTON -- Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, Democrat of New Jersey, announced on Monday that he is running for re-election. If he wins, Mr. Lautenberg, 84, would serve his fifth term in the Senate -- and his second consecutive term since coming out of retirement to replace Senator Robert Torricelli, who dropped his 2002 re-election bid because of corruption allegations. Mr. Lautenberg, who served in the Senate from 1983 until he retired in early 2001, was named to replace Mr. Torricelli on the ballot.

I do like coincidences. On Saturday afternoon as I was reading Dave Kehr's appraisal of the late Richard Widmark, my wife was watching a movie, "Conspiracy Theory,'' on television. Just as I was reading about Widmark's breakout performance as Tommy Udo in "Kiss of Death,'' where he famously ties an old lady to her wheelchair and throws her down a flight of stairs, there on the small screen was Mel Gibson, bound to a wheelchair - don't ask -- and actually throwing himself down a flight of stairs. A fitting tribute to an underrated actor - Widmark, not Gibson.

My colleague Jeff DelViscio-who among other admirable qualities loves to see animated objects roll, topple and tip-once sent me to this great Dutch site that I still visit from time to time. It still brings on a childlike glee, and, like the work of John Pavlus, it suggests what can be done when all the visual clichés that crowd our computer screens are upset.

It seems everywhere you turn lately you run into ads for HBO's epic miniseries, "John Adams." The iconic "Join or Die" banner featuring a fragmented snake seems to be everywhere, from buses to newspapers to the sides of buildings. People are talking about the show too. "Amazing," say some. "Boring," say others. "Did you know Ben Franklin would play chess with women while in the bath? Isn't that wonderful?" says someone else. Yikes. Wasn't this supposed to be the country where "historical" was right at home in front of "amnesia"? Now history's sweeping the land. I hate it.

The Yankees are eager to play the final Opening Day at Yankee Stadium but, two and a half hours before it is scheduled to start, the weather is not cooperating. The Bush administration is proposing the broadest overhaul of Wall Street regulation since the Great Depression, in effect allowing it to send SWAT teams into any corner of the industry or any institution that might pose a risk to the overall system. The plan is to be unveiled on Monday morning, although key elements were provided to the media in advance. In a news analysis over the weekend, The New York Times said the overhaul has its genesis in a yearlong effort to limit Washington's role in the market.

Stocks fell overseas amid expectations of more losses in the banking sector, as investors prepared to close out a dismal quarter.
A woman in a Brooklyn playground was shot to death on Sunday night, the police said.

Michael Schumacher finished fourth in his first official motorcycle event, a minor KTM series race in Misano, Italy. Schumacher, the retired seven-time Formula One champion, started on the front row but had a slow start. He eventually registered the second-fastest lap of the race and reached 127 miles an hour at one point, the fastest speed of the day. Schumacher finished 5.169 seconds behind the winner, Andrea Padovani. Schumacher.
Housing Secretary Alphonso R. Jackson is expected to resign Monday, The Wall Street Journal reported Sunday night.

Lorena Ochoa left her pursuers in the desert dust to successfully defend her title at the Safeway International with a seven-stroke victory in Superstition Mountain, Ariz. With three big flags from her native Mexico waving in the crowd, she shot a six-under 66 to finish at 22-under 266. It was her second win in three attempts this season and her 19th career victory.

An art review on Friday about “In the Forest of Fontainebleau: Painters and Photographers From Corot to Monet,” at the National Gallery of Art, misidentified the man depicted in Frédéric Bazille’s painting “The Improvised Field Hospital,” which is in the exhibition. He is Claude Monet, not Alfred Sisley.

A report in the Empire Zone column in some editions on March 10 about a bid to legalize so-called mixed martial arts fighting in New York State referred incorrectly to the rules of the Ultimate Fighting Championship, a league devoted to the sport. Choke holds are in fact allowed, not banned.

An article in some editions on Wednesday about the Rangers’ 2-1 loss in overtime to the Philadelphia Flyers misstated the sequence of action leading to the winning goal, by Mike Richards. Sean Avery of the Rangers turned over the puck to Flyers defenseman Jason Smith, who passed it to Richards. Avery did not send the puck directly to Richards.
INTERNATIONAL.

The Santiago Journal article on Friday, about an experiment by the government in Chile with an early computer system that helped the government survive a devastating strike by truckers and other groups in 1972, misstated the duration of the strike. It lasted from Oct. 9 to Nov. 5. It did not end within a week.

An article on Thursday about an internal investigation at The Los Angeles Times into whether sources provided fabricated documents for an article on an 1994 assault on the rapper Tupac Shakur misspelled the name of the reporter who wrote the article. He is Chuck Philips, not Phillips.

A film column on Thursday about a tribute to United Artists at Film Forum referred imprecisely to the ownership of the company. While Sony is a co-owner of MGM, United Artists is owned jointly by MGM, Tom Cruise and Paula Wagner. Sony has no direct ownership interest in United Artists.

A picture caption on Friday with an article about a West Bank road at the center of a dispute over whether Palestinians can be required to use separate roads referred incorrectly to a truck shown. Concrete barriers — not the truck — were blocking the entrance to the road.

An article on Friday about a Los Angeles Times article on a 1994 assault on the rapper Tupac Shakur, which turned out to have been based on forged documents, misstated the location of the article in that paper. It appeared on the cover of the entertainment section, not on the front page. (The newspaper’s explanation and apology appeared on the front page.).

A picture on Tuesday with an article about guidelines that New York State health officials use to determine who should receive breathing machines called ventilators during an epidemic was published in error. It showed a mask for anesthesia, not a ventilator.

A front-page article on March 22 about State Department workers improperly looking at the passport files of the three presidential candidates misstated the middle initial for the department spokesman. He is Sean I. McCormack, not Sean D. McCormack.
A theater review on Friday about “The Fifth Column,” at the Mint Theater, misstated the director’s surname. He is Jonathan Bank, not Banks.

An article on Wednesday about the growing number of Muslims in the United States who have chosen to home-school their children referred incorrectly to Pakistan’s location. It is in South Asia, not Southeast Asia.

Because of an editing error, an article in some editions on Tuesday about a last-minute bidding contest over development rights for the West Side railyards in Manhattan gave an outdated name for an investment bank that was to have been the anchor tenant for office towers planned by one bidder, Tishman Speyer Properties. The bank, which has since dropped out of the project, is now Morgan Stanley, not Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. (The error appeared in an article in some editions on Oct. 6 about Morgan Stanley’s initial plans to join the project.).

An article on Thursday about Minoru Mori, Japan’s most prolific developer, attributed an erroneous distinction to one of his buildings. The Taipei 101 in Taiwan is currently the world’s tallest building, not Mr. Mori’s 101-story Shanghai World Financial Center. (His building does have the tallest roof height at 492 meters, but a spire on the building in Taipei makes it taller, at 508 meters.).

An article on Tuesday about the candidacy of Andrew Unanue, a political novice who moderate Republicans in New Jersey say has the best chance to defeat Frank Lautenberg, a Democrat and the state’s senior United States senator, gave the wrong year in some editions for a bid by Murray Sabrin, a conservative Republican candidate for the Senate seat, for governor as a Libertarian. It was 1997, not 2000.

The N.F.L.’s meetings begin Monday in Palm Beach, Fla., and among the items under discussion is a possible ban on hair hanging from the back of helmets. The idea of banning long hair — players would be allowed to tuck it under their helmets — was proposed by the Kansas City Chiefs.

Lorena Ochoa left her pursuers in the desert dust to successfully defend her title at the Safeway International with a seven-stroke victory in Superstition Mountain, Ariz. With three big flags from her native Mexico waving in the crowd, she shot a six-under 66 to finish at 22-under 266. It was her second win in three attempts this season and her 19th career victory.
Andrés Romero of Argentina won the Zurich Classic in his 12th career start on the PGA Tour, closing with a four-under 68 on Sunday for a one-stroke victory over Peter Lonard of Australia.

Michael Schumacher finished fourth in his first official motorcycle event, a minor KTM series race in Misano, Italy. Schumacher, the retired seven-time Formula One champion, started on the front row but had a slow start. He eventually registered the second-fastest lap of the race and reached 127 miles an hour at one point, the fastest speed of the day. Schumacher finished 5.169 seconds behind the winner, Andrea Padovani. Schumacher.

Bernhard Langer won the Ginn Championship in Palm Coast, Fla., for his second Champions Tour victory in three starts, shooting a one-under 71 in windy conditions for an eight-stroke victory over Lonnie Nielsen and Tim Simpson. Langer finished at 12 under and earned $375,000 for his third victory in 11 career starts on the 50-and-over tour.

Liverpool took control of the fight for fourth place in England’s Premier League with a 1-0 win over city rival Everton on Sunday. Liverpool moved 5 points ahead of Everton after Fernando Torres’s 28th goal of the season.

Canada won the women’s world curling championships, beating the surprise finalist China, 7-4, in the final at Vernon, Canada. It was Canada’s 15th world title since 1979. China, which was first after qualifying, became the first Asian nation to get on to the podium.

A sudden split between two actors unions over the weekend added an unhappy twist to Hollywood's troubled contract cycle. On Saturday, the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists suspended its bargaining alliance with the Screen Actors Guild, just before a board meeting where they had hoped to approve a joint negotiating strategy. The actors' contract with the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers expires on June 30, and talks about a new contract were to have begun within two weeks.

A picture caption on March 19 with information about online material on the director Anthony Minghella, who died on March 18, referred incompletely to the writing of the movie ''Cold Mountain,'' which he directed. While Mr. Minghella is in fact credited as writer of the screenplay, it was based on the novel by Charles Frazier, who is also included in the film credits.

ROBERTS--Patricia Hennecart , died in New York, New York on March 29, 2008. She was the daughter of Baron and Baroness Charles Hennecart. She attended Shelbourne School for girls in England. She married John A. Roberts of Utica, New York. Pat was a member of the Junior League of New York, The Cosmopolitan Club, Roackaway Hunt Club. She served on the boards of The Visiting Nurse Service of New York, The Maternity Center Association and The Children's Blood Foundation. Pat was the Owner and CEO of Frederics Helton Travel Service. She is survived by a daughter and stepson. Her sharp mind and humor will be sorely missed by family and friends. A memorial service will be announced at a later date.

A picture caption on March 21 with an art review of ''Birth of the Cool: California Art, Design and Culture at Midcentury,'' at the Addison Gallery of American Art in Andover, Mass., misidentified the person shown sitting in a 1950s chair designed by Charles and Ray Eames, a selection of whose chairs are in the exhibition. He is a model, not Charles Eames. (Mr. Eames died in 1978.)
