GEORGE STRAIT ''Troubadour'' (MCA Nashville) Year in and year out since 1981 George Strait has rarely left the country charts. Mr. Strait, 55, is the genial, pious, faithful, casually virile Texan whose music leans toward old-fashioned honky-tonk but doesn't rule out other possibilities. With a voice full of classic country slides and breaks, he often sings about loyalty and attachment: to a woman he loves or to a woman who left him that he can't forget. Stability counts both in the songs he chooses and in his career.

WARDEN--Herbert W. III , of Yeamans Hall Club in Charleston, SC, a former advertising executive and author, died March 28, 2008 in Charleston, SC, after a brief illness. He was 83. Born in Philadelphia, PA, he was the son of H.W. Warden, Jr. and Dorothy Ely Warden of Philadelphia and Santa Barbara, CA. He attended Le Rosey School in Switzerland and graduated from St. Georges School in Newport, RI, and from Princeton University, Class of 1946, where he was a member of Cap and Gown. He was a First Lieutenant in the US Marine Corps, serving five and a half years during WWII and the Korean War. Soon after leaving the service, he took a job in New York City as a copy writer, eventually moving into the advertisement industry. He led campaigns for products such as Sudafed, Actifed, Neosporin, Dove and Tic Tac. He retired as a Senior Vice President and executive at Bates USA in New York City. In his retirement, he pursued his passion for research and writing, and published several books, including In Praise of Sailors, and most recently, American Courage. Mr. Warden lived much of his life in New York City, but also in Princeton, NJ and New Canaan, CT. He was on the Board of Governors at Yeamans Hall Club in Charleston, SC, and belonged to the Princeton Club and the Union Club, both of New York City. He is survived by his children, Nancy A. Warden of Gloucester, MA; Herbert W. Warden IV, of Bedford, MA; Polly Taylor and husband, Herb, of Pennington, NJ; Anne W. Sinkinson and husband, Mark, of Gloucester, MA; and five grandchildren, Heather B. Taylor, H. Hudson Taylor, Charlotte H. Taylor, Elizabeth S. Sinkinson, and M. Crawford Sinkinson, Jr. Private services are scheduled at Yeamans Hall Club. Services by J. Henry Stuhr, Inc., Northwoods Chapel of North Charleston, SC.

Did Bill Gates Really Say That? Fred Shapiro, the editor of ''The Yale Book of Quotations,'' published in 2006, prides himself on his high success rate in chasing down the origins of popular quotations. Yet he continues to seek the original source of several well-known computer-related sayings and statements.

THE BLACK KEYS ''Attack & Release'' (Nonesuch) In practice and in principal the Black Keys consist of just two people, the guitarist-singer Dan Auerbach and the drummer Patrick Carney. But on ''Attack & Release,'' their fifth album, they welcome an interloper: Brian Burton, the producer better known as Danger Mouse (or in some circles, as the nonsinging half of Gnarls Barkley). Happily, the results are not just evident but potent. While the sound of this blues-rock duo has been fleshed out, none of its grit has been glossed.

'MY BLUEBERRY NIGHTS' Music From the Motion Picture (Blue Note) ''I don't know how to begin,'' Norah Jones sings softly in ''The Story,'' her contribution to the soundtrack of Wong Kar-wai's first English-language film, the forthcoming ''My Blueberry Nights.'' She sounds credibly unsure, though the song's musical setting -- cowpoke bass line, pianistic rustle, brushwork on a snare -- so clearly reflects her natural mode. ''The Story'' could have fit on one of Ms. Jones's Blue Note albums if it didn't have a purpose to serve on this one.

OSSMAN--Marilyn . The membership and the Board of Governors of the Boca Rio Golf Club, Boca Raton, FL announce with deep regret and sorrow the passing of our dear friend and esteemed member, Marilyn Ossman, and extend our sincerest condolences to her husband Ben and their family. Robert Merson, President Boca Rio Golf Club, Inc.

FISCHER--Michael D. , age 69, of Miami Beach, passed away on Thursday, March 27, 2008. Beloved husband of Maxine. Devoted father of Lisa (Bernard) Noble, Adam (Jeanie) Fischer, Rachel (Arthur) Heller, Jonathan (Jamie) Fischer. Cherished son of Irving and the late Sylvia Fischer. Dear brother of Harriet Sanders and Richard Fischer. Adored grandfather of Benjamin and Elizabeth Noble, Andrew, Michael and Katie Heller, and Zachary Fischer. Born and raised in New York, Michael graduated from Queens College where he met his wife, Maxine, of 49 years. His love for Israel and the Jewish people led him to pursue a long and fruitful career as a fundraiser for Jewish causes, ultimately serving as a senior executive for the Greater Miami Jewish Federation and the United Jewish Communities in New York. Over the years, Michael led numerous missions to Israel, raised hundreds of millions of dollars, and was recognized for his significant fundraising successes by various world leaders. Michael was an incredibly kind and special man and was a gift to all who knew him. Michael was most proud of his family who he loved and cherished, and who loved and adored him in return. Services held today in Miami Beach, FL. Special thank you to Edward Goldstein and family of Parkside Memorial Chapels, Queens, NY. Donations to United Jewish Communities.

''Armageddon in Retrospect,'' a collection of unpublished stories and nonfiction by Kurt Vonnegut Jr., will be released on Tuesday. Mr. Vonnegut (above) used elements of science fiction and humor to question authority and criticize war, consumerism and religion. His unconventional novels, still popular after many decades, achieved cult status in the '60s and '70s. ''Armageddon'' opens with a letter he wrote to his father during World War II, when the writer survived the firebombing of Dresden as an Army prisoner of war. It also includes short fiction and a speech. SHELLY FREIERMAN

JUSTIN TOWNES EARLE ''The Good Life'' (Bloodshot) Sometimes Justin Townes Earle, Steve Earle's 25-year-old son, sounds as if he was born in the wrong era. An article on Thursday about a census report that compared population figures in metropolitans areas for 2005-06 and 2006-07 described shifts in New York and Chicago incorrectly. Both showed a decline in the number of residents lost to domestic migration -- not in the overall number of residents. (The overall population increased for both areas.)

She is survived by her husband, Alan W. Dunton, M.D., her children, Sarah and Warren Dunton, her siblings Jeanne, William and James and brother-in-law, John Donlan. The Art of Video On Search Pages Google and Yahoo have both started including video advertising on search results pages. Depending on how consumers react, this could open a vast new source of ad revenue or could deter users from clicking on the already incredibly lucrative text ads.

SCHECHTER--Stanley , of Palm Beach Gardens, Florida and North Shore Towers, Queens, New York, died peacefully surrounded by loved ones two weeks after his 87th birthday. He was the beloved husband of Sylvia Masnikoff Schechter, his wife of 62 years; treasured father of Neil and Kenneth Schechter and Tina Adler; loving grandfather of Benjamin, Anna, Sophie, Nicole, and Elizabeth; cherished father-in-law of Carlota, Edith, and Clifford; brother of Martin; and brother-in-law of Mannie, Della and Arlene. His kindness, sense of humor and generosity blessed the lives of all who knew him. Funeral will be held at Sunset Chapels, 1285 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, New York. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Hospice of Palm Beach County.

Two widely prescribed cholesterol-lowering drugs, Vytorin and Zetia, may not work and should be used only as a last resort, a panel of four cardiologists told an audience of more than 5,000 people at a major cardiology conference on Sunday. Instead, doctors and patients should rely more heavily on older cholesterol-lowering drugs called statins, which have proven benefits and can be cheaper, the panel said.

It was a night when children were given the floor to bestow accolades on Hollywood. At the 21st annual Kids' Choice Awards on Saturday, Miley Cyrus, below, the star of the Disney Channel series ''Hannah Montana,'' was chosen favorite television actress and female singer, while ''Drake and Josh,'' a Nickelodeon series, was honored as favorite television show with one of its stars, Drake Bell, as favorite television actor. The awards were the result of more than 80 million votes that Nickelodeon said were cast through its Web site, nick.com. Also honored at the ceremony, which was held in Los Angeles and shown on Nickelodeon, were ''Alvin and the Chipmunks'' (favorite movie); Johnny Depp (movie actor, for ''Pirates of the Caribbean: At World's End''); Jessica Alba (movie actress, ''Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer''); ''American Idol'' (reality show);Chris Brown (male singer); and the Jonas Brothers (music group).

BONJEAN--Emile . Beloved Emile, native of France, and resident of Long Island, NY, was a tender and treasured part of our family for 50 years. His dedication and brilliance transformed Greentree from a personal home into a ''House of Peace,'' where he welcomed visitors from all over the world for Greentree Foundation as they came to negotiate agreements and discuss global issues. His influence will continue to be felt through the extraordinary atmosphere he helped create by all who continue to meet at Greentree to pursue issues of social justice and international harmony. Our family will miss him terribly, and remember him always with love. Kate Whitney and Franklin Thomas and their family Sara and Ronald Wilford and their family

McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 2-4 and 7-9pm Tuesday. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, on Wednesday April 2 at 10am.

CHAMBERLAIN--Narcisse , a highly respected cookbook editor and writer, died on Saturday, March 22, 2008, in New York City following a long illness. She was 83. In her more than 20 years as a senior editor at William Morrow and Company, Ms. Chamberlain edited many of the culinary lights of the last 40 years, including Michael Field, Anne Seranne, Michel Guerard, Jean Anderson, Fredy Girardet, Anne Willan, and Paul Prudhomme. Having been trained as a painter, she also edited a number of esteemed design books, including Needlepoint Design by Louis J. Gartner, Jr., and The Art of the Painted Finish by Isabel ONeill. Ms Chamberlain was the daughter of the wellknown author, photographer and etcher, Samuel Chamberlain, and Narcissa G. Chamberlain, an accomplished cookbook writer. With her parents, Narcisse co-authored many books including The Flavor of France (1959), The Flavor of Italy (1965), and French Menus for Parties (1968). She was also a contributor to the 1988 and 2001 editions of Clementine in the Kitchen, a book originally authored by her father. Narcisse Chamberlain was born June 17, 1924, in Paris. When war threatened in 1939, the family settled permanently in Marblehead, Massachusetts. She attended St. Marys-inthe - Mountains, now the White Mountain School, in Littleton, New Hampshire, and received a B.A. from Bennington College in 1946. She began her career as a researcher for Time in New York City (1950-1952), and for Newsweek in Paris (1952-1953). Later she became an editor for Gourmet (1954-1956), then moved to book publishing, serving as an editor with Hasting House and M. Barrows & Co., Inc. In 1968, she was appointed senior editor at William Morrow where she remained until her retirement. In addition to her parents, she was predeceased by a sister, Stephanie. A private burial will be held in Marblehead, Massachusetts.

LICHTENBERG--Ann Greenspan , 96 of Millbrook, NY and a former Westchester Co. resident on March 25, 2008. Beloved wife of Daniel Lichtenberg; devoted mother of Stephen Lichtenberg and his wife Patricia; dear grandmother of Sarah and husband Adam Bass, Adam Lichtenberg, and Emily Lichtenberg; and great-grandmother of Lena Jordan Bass. Microsoft, seeking to expand offerings on its Xbox 360 console, has reached an agreement with a company headed by Peter Safran, the veteran Hollywood producer and talent manager, to produce original shows for distribution on the system. Through his Safran Company, Mr. Safran represents clients like the actor and producer Sean Combs (''Monster's Ball''), the actor and writer Nia Vardalos (''My Big Fat Greek Wedding'') and the filmmakers Jason Friedberg and Aaron Seltzer (''Epic Movie''). Mr. Safran founded the company in 2006 after leaving Brillstein-Grey Management.

STACK--William. Joseph William (Bill) Stack, Jr. died peacefully at the Health Care Center at Meadow Ridge in Redding, Connecticut on March 25, 2008, at the age of 89. Born and raised in East Lansing, Michigan, where his fatherwas a Professor at Michigan State University, he graduated from Yale University in 1940. There he was Captain of both the freshman and varsity football teams. He served in the Navy during WWII, seeing action at Midway and Guadalcanal before transferring to the European theatre where he took part in D-Day. He rose to the rank of Lieutenant Commander and was the first U.S. Naval Officer to enter liberated Paris. After the war, his business career began at General Motors, and culminated in 1970 when he founded his own executive search firm in New York City, William Stack Associates. He ran the firm until his retirement in 1995. Throughout his life he was active in Yale alumni affairs. He served on the Boards of the Yale Alumni Association, the Football Y Association and was a founding member of Lux et Veritas. He was also always active in the Episcopal Church serving on several different Vestries. After his retirement he became a Mentor in the Norwalk, CT school system. He is survived by his beloved wife of 60 years, Wolcott Rorick (Mimi) Stack, and their children and families, Chris, Martha, Nathan, Courtney, Charlotte, David, Sarah, Hadley, Isabel, Will, Peter, Sonya, Joey, Patrick, Mickey and Jamie. He was predeceased by his son Joseph William III, and his sister, Elizabeth Leslie. A memorial service will be held later this Spring. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be sent to Mid-Fairfield Hospice, P.O. Box 489, Wilton, Connecticut 06897.

Updated, 11:06 a.m. | Even as supporters of congestion pricing prepared to gather at City Hall at 11 a.m. today to cheer the City Council’s vote approving the plan and to urge the State Legislature to approve the $8-a-day traffic fees, opponents of congestion pricing have mobilized as well — at least in their talking points.

Bloomberg and his ally, the Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, a major victory. As Diane Cardwell notes, the fight now moves to Albany, where the biggest obstacle for the plan may well by Sheldon Silver, the State Assembly speaker. (See related blog post.)

Like smoking and trans fats, plastic bags are becoming the target of a continued campaign of public disdain. The anti-plastic bag movement — which has drawn the most momentum abroad in countries like Ireland and Bangladesh — is becoming more and more local.New York’s City Council has discussed mandatory recycling and there have even been faint rumblings of a plastic bag tax. An outright ban, however, like the one in San Francisco, hasn’t gathered much momentum in New York.

Councilwoman Inez E. Dickens said at a City Council hearing this afternoon that she does not support a rezoning plan that would transform 125th Street into a major commercial and business district. An internal review by the inspector general of the federal Department of Justice is sharply critical of how the department has administered federal death benefits for police and firefighters. The review focuses on the work of the department’s Bureau of Justice Assistance, the agency that has denied claims by the families of two auxiliary police officers who were killed a year ago by a gunman in Greenwich Village, provoking protests from city and federal officials.It was not immediately clear what influence the review would have on the cases of the New York auxiliary officers, Nicolas T. Pekearo and Yevgeniy Marshalik, who were killed on March 14, 2004.

The Unlawful Internet Gambling Enforcement Act of 2006 made it illegal for banks and other financial institutions to process online wagers. The goal was to find an indirect way to regulate offshore casinos, which are outside the jurisdiction of American law enforcement. In short: the casinos are out of reach, but not the banks in the United States that process their transactions.

The recent trend in pop-up books has been watchwork complexity and conspicuous feats of engineering. (See "Star Wars: A Pop-Up Guide to the Galaxy," which dominated the children's best-seller list this holiday season.) There have been no shortage of pop-ups marketed to an older audience, either. (I'm thinking here of Sam Ita's "Moby Dick," which topped my gift list.) But here's one perfect for the tyke that you can display with pride on your Noguchi coffee table too: Marion Bataille's "ABC3D," a deceptively-simple race through through the alphabet that's full of sly visual winks and typographical fun. The video readthrough above is pure pleasure. So much so, it seems, that the book is selling swiftly - it hit #55 in Amazon sales rank last week - even though it won't be released until October. (Found via Gizmodo.com)

For decades, the Chicago Blackhawks were ridiculed both in the Windy City and around the sports world for refusing to televise their home games. Former owner Bill Wirtz reasoned that TV would keep fans away from Chicago Stadium and then the United Center, which would not only erode ticket sales, but also the parking and concession businesses, which Wirtz controlled. Critics pointed out that Wirtz's obstinance cost him a chance to get potential fans to sample the games, which would lead to better home attendance, but he never budged.

I hear that Gianfranco Ferre will announce later today the appointment of Tommaso Aquilano and Roberto Rimondi as its new designers. Rimondi and Aquilano, of the label 6267, have been at the center of Ferre speculation for the past month. They're a good choice, considering their background in tailoring, and of course their own designs for 6267 and Malo have been generating buzz for a couple of seasons. Living in Italy, working for many years at Max Mara, looking closely at couture--it's fair to say that Rimondi and Aquilano already know a lot about Ferre and, possibly, what the label needs to be contemporary.

The E.P.A. is investigating I.B.M. over an $80 million bid to modernize the agency’s financial systems and has been suspended from seeking new contracts with all federal agencies.

Colorado Springs approved a $53 million deal aimed at enticing the United States Olympic Committee to keep its headquarters and training center in the city for at least 25 years. The U.S.O.C. has been a fixture in Colorado Springs for nearly 30 years and has been considering relocating because of aging facilities. The proposal must be agreed to by the U.S.O.C. The proposal will give the U.S.O.C. a new headquarters, renovations to an existing building and 158 new housing units for athletes at the Olympic Training Center.
The British insurance group Friends Provident rejected a $6.9 billion takeover bid from J. C. Flowers.
Peak Gold, owner of the Amapari mine in Brazil, agreed to a $1.6 billion all-stock combination with Metallica Resources and New Gold to diversify and increase production.
The China Telecom Corporation, the nation’s largest operator of fixed-line telephone services, said 2007 profit fell 13 percent as more customers switched to mobile phones.

Hugo Sánchez was fired as coach of Mexico’s national team, two weeks after it was eliminated from Olympic qualifying. The Mexican soccer federation fired Sánchez 16 months after he took the job amid promises of regional titles and an Olympic medal. The failure to qualify for Beijing was particularly stinging for Mexican players of this generation, who won the Under-17 World Cup in Peru in 2005 and reached the quarterfinals at the Under-20 World Cup in Canada last year. Mexico also lost last year to the United States in the Concacaf Gold Cup final.
Alitalia’s main unions agreed to extend talks with the Air France-KLM Group beyond a midnight deadline in an effort to reach an agreement on its takeover bid for the Italian carrier.

Georgie Boy is off the Kentucky Derby trail after pulling a muscle in his back. The trainer Kathy Walsh said the colt would not require surgery. He was scheduled to run in Saturday’s $750,000 Santa Anita Derby, the West Coast’s major prep for the Kentucky Derby on May 3. Georgie Boy is 2-0 as a 3-year-old, winning the San Vicente Stakes on Feb. 10 and the San Felipe Stakes on March 16, both at Santa Anita.
Japanese industrial production fell in February for the second month in a row, underscoring the bleak economic outlook.

Serena and Venus Williams advanced to the quarterfinals of the Sony Ericsson Open in Key Biscayne, Fla. Serena Williams, who has won the tournament four times, beat Kaia Kanepi, 6-3, 6-3, and will next play the top-ranked Justine Henin. Venus Williams beat 17-year-old Caroline Wozniacki, 6-3, 6-3, but Lindsay Davenport hit a bump in her comeback, losing to Dinara Safina, 6-3, 6-4. Roger Federer reached the fourth round on the men’s side.

Less than two months after their Super Bowl victory, the Giants were back at work Monday as players returned to Giants Stadium for the beginning of the team’s off-season conditioning program, the team said. The news media were not allowed to attend the workouts, and the Giants refused to say how many players took part.
Louisiana State Coach Van Chancellor can thank Sylvia Fowles for his first trip to a Final Four.
Jermaine O’Neal scored 9 points after sitting out more than two months with a knee injury, and the Indiana Pacers beat the visiting Miami Heat, 105-85, on Monday night.

NATIONAL.

An article on March 17 about internal disagreements and accusations of favoritism at Wikipedia misstated the name of the Canadian network that once employed Sue Gardner, executive director at the Wikimedia Foundation, which runs the various Wikipedia projects. It is the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, not the Canadian Broadcasting Company.

An article on Friday about vehicles that were struck by gunfire on I-64 in Virginia misspelled the surname of a gunman involved in highway shootings in the Washington area in 2002. He is John A. Muhammad, not Mohammed. Because of an editing error, the article also referred incorrectly to the distance between the recent shootings and the area that was terrorized six years ago. It is about two hours’ drive, not about an hour’s drive. (The error was repeated in an article on Saturday about the arrest of two teenagers in the Virginia shootings.).

An article on Thursday about an apology by the Florida Legislature for the state’s history of slavery included an incorrect attribution from Gov. Charlie Crist for the quotation “All that is necessary for evil to prevail is for good people to do nothing.” Although often attributed to the philosopher Edmund Burke, the quotation does not appear in his writings, and its author is unknown.

The caption for a photograph in some editions on March 23 with an article about a new pipe organ at Christ and St. Stephen’s Episcopal Church in Manhattan referred incorrectly to the pipes being examined by Paul Jacobs, the artist-in-residence at the church. They were decorative pipes that do not produce sound when the organ is played; they line the outer wall of a specially built chamber at the front of the church that houses the 1,042 pipes mentioned in the article.

A picture caption with an article on Saturday about a legal victory for the heirs of Jerry Siegel, a creator of the Superman action character, misstated the given name of his co-creator. He was Joe Shuster, not Max. The article also misspelled Mr. Siegel’s family name as Seigel in one reference.
A picture caption on Sunday with an obituary of G. David Low, a space shuttle astronaut, carried an incorrect date in some editions. The photograph of Mr. Low was taken in 1990, not 1989.
The bill would give the state some of the toughest rules in the nation restricting toxic materials used in children’s products.

A listing of information in the New Jersey section on Sunday with an article about the Garden State Film Festival in and around Asbury Park misstated the date of one screening and gave an incorrect price and admission details for another. “Legends Behind the Comic Books” will be shown at 1 p.m. on Saturday, not Sunday. “Greetings From the Shore,” on Saturday at 8:15 p.m., costs $10, not $20, and is not accompanied by a cocktail party and reception.
Selling high-priced tickets and pieces of two ballparks.
The I.R.S. special agent Jeff Novitzky was cross-examined for the first time in open court Monday in connection with the Balco case.
From start to finish, Joe Torre’s debut as Dodgers manager was as picture perfect as the weather on a sun-kissed Monday afternoon, his new team welcoming him with a win over the Giants.

President Raúl Castro’s new government will begin allowing Cubans to stay at hotels that were previously set aside for foreign tourists, the latest in a string of moves liberalizing internal restrictions on Cubans. In other changes, Cubans will be able to rent cars and buy cellphones, computers, microwaves and DVD players. However, with state salaries of about $20 a month, most Cubans will not be able to afford them.

Ecuador filed a lawsuit against Colombia in an international court, seeking to end Colombia’s fumigation of coca crops along the border. Ecuador says that the aerial herbicide spraying also kills legal crops in Ecuador and that it sickens Ecuadoreans living near the border. Faced with previous complaints, Colombia had recently increased manual eradication of coca plants as part of an antinarcotics program financed by the United States. The lawsuit, filed in the International Court of Justice in The Hague, followed a raid by Colombian forces on March 1 on Colombian guerrillas in Ecuador.

A member of the Navy Seals who threw himself on a grenade in Iraq to save his comrades will be posthumously awarded the nation’s highest military tribute, the Medal of Honor, the White House announced. Petty Officer Second Class Michael A. Monsoor, 25, of Garden Grove, Calif., was part of a sniper team in Ramadi in 2006 when an insurgent threw a grenade at him, the Navy said. He was the fifth person to receive the honor since the beginning of the Iraq and Afghanistan wars.
Michael McGee Jr. has spent 10 months behind bars on federal charges of extortion and soliciting bribes from area business owners, but many see race as an issue.

Six French aid workers who had been sentenced to eight years of hard labor for the attempted kidnapping of 103 children were pardoned and released. The workers had chartered a plane to fly to Europe children they claimed were orphans of the conflict in the Darfur region of Sudan. Most of the children were neither orphans nor from Sudan. The workers were serving their time in France, but after France pledged to help defend Chad’s president, Idriss Déby, from rebel attacks in February, he agreed to consider pardoning them.

At least 60 people remain jailed in China over the June 1989 protests by pro-democracy demonstrators centered at Tiananmen Square in Beijing, a human rights activist says. John Kamm, executive director of the Dui Hua Foundation, an advocacy group for political prisoners, urged China to release the protesters, who may number as many as 100, before the Summer Olympics in Beijing in August. The protests led to a military crackdown that killed hundreds of people.

A homemade bomb destroyed the entrance of a branch of Citigroup’s Mexican subsidiary, Banamex, in southern Mexico City, causing no injuries. No one claimed responsibility, but small guerrilla groups have previously attacked foreign-owned banks.

Tony Peña Jr. hit a two-out, tie-breaking single in the 11th inning Monday and the frugal Kansas City Royals held on to beat the big-spending Tigers, 5-4, on opening day in Detroit to give Trey Hillman a victory in his major league debut as a manager.

An editorial on Sunday about Macedonia’s bid to join NATO misspelled the name of the United Nations mediator trying to resolve a dispute with Greece over Macedonia’s name. It is Matthew Nimetz, not Nimitz.

A nude watercolor painted by Picasso when he was about 20 and struggling for recognition has been found stacked against a wall in the bedroom of a house in southwest England, Agence France-Presse reported. The painting, “Entreinte” (“Embrace”), from 1901 or 1902, depicts a nude Picasso entwined with his girlfriend Louise Lenoir, known as Odette. He authenticated it in 1969. The watercolor was found with two other paintings, by George Stubbs and Alfred Munnings, both specialists in portraying horses. “To find one of these works would have been incredible, but to find three was quite exceptional,” said Guy Schwinge of Duke’s, the auctioneers that will sell the paintings on April 10. Each is expected to fetch as much as $199,000.

The political season continues to be very good to CNN, which will officially announce on Tuesday that for the first time since 2001, it managed to beat the Fox News Channel in prime time for one quarter of the year in the category of news viewers most desirable to advertisers, according to Nielsen. Thanks to its debate coverage and heavy focus on the presidential primaries, CNN’s ratings in prime time for viewers 25 to 54 were up 90 percent, to an average of 453,000 for the first quarter of 2008. That was enough to edge past the perennial leader, Fox, which had 438,000 viewers, up 12 percent from last year. MSNBC also had a strong quarter in prime time, growing 68 percent to 329,000 viewers. CNN has done especially well on the nights of contested primaries, winning every night in those ratings except one, the Florida primary on Jan. 29. That was the only night when the Republican race was of higher interest than the Democratic one, and Fox won that night. Among total viewers in prime time, Fox maintained its leadership position in the first quarter with an average of 1.8 million viewers, up 14 percent from last year. CNN grew 67 percent to 1.3 million viewers. MSNBC was up 59 percent to 791,000 viewers.

Philip Roth, right, the Pulitzer Prize-winning novelist and recent chronicler of the vagaries of old age, will return to the anxieties of youth with his 29th book, “Indignation,” to be published in September by Houghton Mifflin. Mr. Roth, whose last novel was “Exit Ghost” (2007), the ninth and final book about the author’s literary alter ego, Nathan Zuckerman, has set the new book during the Korean War. The story follows Marcus Messner, a young man from Newark who is obsessively worried about being drafted into the war. He ends up at a conservative college in Winesburg, Ohio, to escape his overbearing father. “The novel tracks him trying to find his place and fit in and having the tough time of it that he does,” said Becky Saletan, publisher of Houghton Mifflin Harcourt.

Kathie Lee Gifford, right, the former longtime co-host of “Live With Regis and Kathie Lee,” is returning to morning television as the host of the fourth hour of NBC’s “Today” program, the network confirmed Monday. The feature-heavy fourth hour of “Today,” introduced in September, competes directly against “Live” in some markets, so Ms. Gifford will go up against her former colleague, Regis Philbin, and the woman to whom she ceded her chair in 2000, Kelly Ripa. The assignment, beginning April 7, will be Ms. Gifford’s third morning show stint: she reported for “Good Morning America” before becoming Mr. Philbin’s co-host on “Live” for 15 years. Ms. Gifford was introduced on “Today” by Matt Lauer and Meredith Vieira, the hosts of the first two hours. “I’m 8 years older, 10 pounds heavier and a half-inch shorter, just in time for HD television,” Ms. Gifford joked. With seven hosts sitting on the set, the cameras could barely show the entire ensemble. But the addition of Ms. Gifford will reduce the workload for some of the others. Ms. Gifford will join Hoda Kotb, her co-anchor for the fourth hour. Ann Curry and Al Roker, two members of the 7 to 9 a.m. team, will continue as co-hosts of the third hour but will no longer contribute to the fourth. Natalie Morales, who was named a co-anchor of the fourth hour last September, will become a host of the third hour.

With a boost from its afternoon coverage of the N.C.A.A. college basketball tournament, CBS eked out a slight ratings victory on Sunday, edging past ABC as the night’s most watched network. According to Nielsen’s overnight estimates, the 23-minute college basketball overrun into the 7 p.m. time slot meant that more than 17 million viewers were tuned in to CBS during the first half-hour of prime time. Directly after the live coverage ended, CBS drew about 12.3 million viewers for “60 Minutes,” followed by an above-average audience of 8 million viewers for CBS’s “Big Brother.” Despite its second place finish, ABC outpaced CBS among adults 18 to 49 thanks to “Extreme Makeover: Home Edition” at 8 (12.8 million) and “Oprah’s Big Give” at 9 (11.3 million). Fox was third for the night in that demographic, trailing both ABC and CBS with its animated comedy lineup. NBC, which drew slightly more total viewers than Fox, finished a distant fourth in the 18-to-49 set. NBC broadcast repeats from 9 to 11, following a special showing of MSNBC’s “Countdown With Keith Olbermann” at 7 (3.4 million) and “Dateline” at 8 (6.7 million).
“Cirque Dreams Jungle Fantasy,” described as a “theatrical, acrobatic and musical adventure,” will play a 10-week engagement this summer at the Broadway Theater.

Karen Kain, artistic director of the National Ballet of Canada, resigned on Monday from her post as chairwoman of the Canada Council for the Arts, CBC News reported. In a letter to Josée Verner, minister of Canadian Heritage, Ms. Kain said she wanted to devote more time to the ballet company. The council, charged with promoting the arts in Canada, is that nation’s largest arts-granting organization. Ms. Kain has been its chairwoman since September 2004 and, since July 2005, artistic director of the National Ballet, where she danced from 1969 to 1997.

Brace yourself for a season of nostalgia. Everything that happens at Yankee Stadium, or Shea Stadium, for that matter, will be the last of this or the last of that.

When the Rolling Stones performed on May 9, 1965, in Chicago, a high school senior named Hillary Rodham was part of the screaming crowd. Nowadays, Hillary Rodham Clinton may be on a first-name basis with Mick Jagger and Keith Richards, but at heart, she confessed early Sunday to reporters traveling with her on the campaign trail, she is still very much a fan. ''If you go to a Stones concert today, and I have, it is still amazing,'' she said.

Kathie Lee Gifford, right, the former longtime co-host of ''Live With Regis and Kathie Lee,'' is returning to morning television as the host of the fourth hour of NBC's ''Today'' program, the network confirmed Monday. The feature-heavy fourth hour of ''Today,'' introduced in September, competes directly against ''Live'' in some markets, so Ms. Gifford will go up against her former colleague, Regis Philbin, and the woman to whom she ceded her chair in 2000, Kelly Ripa. The assignment, beginning April 7, will be Ms. Gifford's third morning show stint: she reported for ''Good Morning America'' before becoming Mr. Philbin's co-host on ''Live'' for 15 years. Ms. Gifford was introduced on ''Today'' by Matt Lauer and Meredith Vieira, the hosts of the first two hours. ''I'm 8 years older, 10 pounds heavier and a half-inch shorter, just in time for HD television,'' Ms. Gifford joked. With seven hosts sitting on the set, the cameras could barely show the entire ensemble. But the addition of Ms. Gifford will reduce the workload for some of the others. Ms. Gifford will join Hoda Kotb, her co-anchor for the fourth hour. Ann Curry and Al Roker, two members of the 7 to 9 a.m. team, will continue as co-hosts of the third hour but will no longer contribute to the fourth. Natalie Morales, who was named a co-anchor of the fourth hour last September, will become a host of the third hour.

LISS--Seymour. The Paper Bag Players express deepest sympathy to our Executive Director Judith Liss and her family on the loss of her husband. Seymour was a devoted friend and supporter who will be deeply missed. Kathy Mele, Board President Judith Martin, Artistic Director.

ROSS--Daniel M., was born May 20, 1918 and died on Sunday March 30, 2008. Surviving are his wife, Norma (Mandelbaum), his children, Joan and Paul Ross, and his grandchildren, Benjamin and Hannah Hoffman, with whom he shared his unswerving love for life. Daniel was known throughout his career in life insurance and financialplanning as a legend in his own time. A self-made success, he approached every task with tremendous optimism and enthusiasm, a keen mind, and the willingness to work hard. By his example and teaching, he helped others make their lives successful and fulfilling. Daniel gave generously to many charitable organizations, including United Jewish Foundation and his Alma mater, Michigan State University. He was a Mason, and he served in the U.S. Army during WWII. In his youth, Daniel was a track star. He ran in the Pennsylvania Relay, and was proud to recount that he ran against Jesse Owens. Daniel added happiness and hope to the lives of those who knew him. He will be remembered at a funeral service on Wednesday, April 2nd at 2:30PM at Temple Sinai in Stamford, CT. (203)322-1649

OSSMAN--Marilyn Judith, of Boca Raton, FL passed away March 30, 2008. Beloved wife of Ben for 61 years, loving mother of Eileen Siner and Denise (Michael) Litsky, cherished grandmother of Jason, Alexis, Sage and Morgan and Great-grandmother of Casey, Samantha and Jack. Services today April 1st 2008 in Boca Raton, FL. For further Info: ''Gutterman's'' 800-992-9262.

VANNERSON--Frank L. (1938-2008). With great sorrow we note the untimely loss our of Chairman and dear friend. Frank was instrumental in the birth of the alternative investment industry, beginning with the co-founding of Commodities Corporation in 1969, and remained at the forefront of the money management business throughout his career. He was among the first to apply strictly quantitative models to futures markets and, with his partners at Mount Lucas Management, was a pioneer in developing institutional interest in those markets. Frank was a masterful trader with particular focus in the grain markets extending back to his Ph.D. dissertation work at Princeton University. He will be sorely missed by all of us at Mount Lucas. Our deepest sympathy to his family. Mount Lucas Management Corp

Do not look for clarity in the Texas Democratic delegate scramble any time soon. With Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton leading Senator Barack Obama, 65 to 61, in delegates chosen proportionately in the March 4 primary, 67 pledged delegates were up for grabs in 284 party conventions last Saturday. But pledged to whom?

The nation's tuberculosis rate dropped last year to its lowest level since national reporting of the rate began in 1953. But the decline is slowing, and that troubles Dr. Heather Menzies, an officer of the Epidemic Intelligence Service of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. ''It means we have to have a sustained effort to continue our progress,'' she said. ''There's a perception that TB is a disease of the past, but it continues to exact a severe toll on many U.S. communities.'' More than half the cases are among the foreign-born, which, Dr. Menzies said, ''speaks to the fact that this is a global epidemic.'' She added that the C.D.C. has begun a study of diagnosis, prevention and treatment among African-Americans, whose rates are eight times as high as those of whites. There was a slight decline in drug-resistant tuberculosis cases in 2007, but Dr. Menzies regards it as insignificant. ''In recent years,'' she said, ''the proportion has been about 1 percent, and I would describe it as stable.

GOHEEN--Robert F. The Trustees and staff of the Woodrow Wilson national Fellowship Foundation are deeply saddened by the death of Robert F. Goheen. One of the first four Woodrow Wilson Fellows, Bob Goheen served as national director of the Woodrow Wilson Fellowship Program from 1953 to 1956, returned to the Foundation from 1982 to 1992 as founding director of the Mellon Fellowships in the Humanities, and served as a Trustee of the Foundation from 1992 until his retirement from the board in 2001. Brilliant, visionary, the personification of integrity, decency, and humility, Bob was both an extraordinary force in American higher education and an exceptional human being. We were privileged to know him, serve with him, and benefit in so many ways from his boundless wisdom. The Foundation's Trustees, staff, and friends extend heartfelt condolences and deepest sympathies to his family. Nancy Weiss Malkiel, Chair, and the Members of the Board of Trustees. Arthur Levine, President The Woodrow Wilson National Fellowship Foundation Princeton, N.J.

GROSS--Linda. Atlantic Theater Company's Board of Directors, Staff and Ensemble mourn the passing of our beloved board member, and dear friend, Linda B. Gross. Linda had a passion for life that was second to none. Her knowledge and love of theater was unprecedented. In honor of Linda and her loving husband Daniel's years of dedication and support, Atlantic renamed its Main Stage Theater the Linda Gross Theater on May 14th, 2007. We are thrilled to have her name so closely associated with Atlantic, and fortunate to have known her. We extend out heartfelt sympathies to her soul mate and beloved husband Dan, their entire family, and their vast network of friends. We will miss her dearly. GROSS--Linda. The Trustees of Chess-in-the-Schools express their deepest sorrow at the passing of Linda Gross. Linda's husband Dan is the Chair of Chess-in-the-Schools and together they have dedicated countless hours and resources so that others will benefit. May memories of Linda serve as a comfort to Dan during this difficult time. GROSS--Linda B., Ph.D, December 15, 1944--March 30, 2008. Linda will be remembered as a beloved wife, an accomplished psychoanalyst, a wonderful friend, a patron of the arts, a splendid human being and a true life force. She is survived by her husband, Daniel, who loved her completely, as well as by family and friends who were privileged to know her intelligence, warmth and deep generosity. Her distinguished career in Psychoanalysis comprised a private practice in Manhattan, numerous instructorships, service as a board member of the Philadelphia School of Psychoanalysis and the American Board of Certification of the National Association for the Advancement of Psychoanalysis. Linda's passion for the theater began when she was four years old and her parents took her to see ''Where's Charley?''. Afterwards, she visited Ray Bolger in his dressing room. As an adult, she attended eighty to one hundred shows a year, collected an estimated 2500 playbills and served on the boards of the Atlantic Theater Company and the Shakespeare Society. On May 14, 2007 the Atlantic Theaters Main Stage was re-named in her honor as the ''Linda Gross Theater'' in a tribute to her tireless support, and this day was proclaimed Linda Gross Day by the City Council. She was special and she will be missed. Memorial services will be held on Tuesday, April 1st at 11:00am at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St., New York, NY 10023. Donations in honor of Dr. Linda B. Gross may be made to: Atlantic Theater Company at the Linda Gross Theater, 76 Ninth Avenue, Suite 537, NY, NY 10011.

A Defense Department official pleaded guilty to disclosing classified military information that was later passed on to China. The official, Gregg Bergersen, 51, faces up to 10 years in prison when he is sentenced in June, the Justice Department said. Prosecutors said Mr. Bergersen, a weapons policy analyst at the Defense Security Cooperation Agency at the Pentagon, gave a New Orleans businessman secret documents related to military sales to Taiwan without knowing they were bound for Chinese officials. In return, court papers say, he was given gifts, dinners and money for gambling in Las Vegas.

An article on Friday about vehicles that were struck by gunfire on I-64 in Virginia misspelled the surname of a gunman involved in highway shootings in the Washington area in 2002. He is John A. It is about two hours' drive, not about an hour's drive. (The error was repeated in an article on Saturday about the arrest of two teenagers in the Virginia shootings.)

FRIEDMAN--Herbert A., Rabbi, 89. Our beloved Herb, Dad, Pop, Saba died peacefully at home on March 31, 2008 surrounded by love. We can not imagine how we will miss him. With his passing our world tilts. His wife Francine (nee Bensley), his children Judith Unice, Daniel and Margery (Sinder) Friedman, Joan Bentsen and Erik Olsen, David and Sally (Braver) Friedman, Charles Friedman, his grandchildren Deborah Levenson, Rachel Unice, Ben and Lizzie Friedman, his greatgrandchildren Matthew and Ryan Levenson, his brothers and sisters-in-law Stanley and Sydell Friedman, Sam and Brena Friedman and his brother-in-law Norman Bensley. Funeral service on April 2, 2008, 11am at Temple Shaaray Tefila, 250 East 79th St. FRIEDMAN--Rabbi Herbert. Temple Shaaray Tefila records with profound sorrow the death of our longtime, cherished member. Heartfelt condolences are extended to his wife, Francine, to his children and grandchildren. May his memory be for blessing and may his loved ones be comforted amidst the mourners of our people for Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Jonathan A. Stein Lois S. Nyren, President FRIEDMAN--Herbert A. The Wexner Foundation mourns the passing of our beloved friend and teacher, Rabbi Herbert Friedman. Together with his friend and partner Leslie H. Wexner, Rabbi Friedman created the Wexner Heritage Program, a fitting capstone to a brilliant career in Jewish leadership. Beginning with his years as an Army Chaplain in World War II and his recruitment into the Haganah by David ben Gurion, Herb devoted his life to the survival and strengthening of the Jewish people and the State of Israel. A passionate advocate of Jewish education, Jewish peoplehood, and Jewish values, Herb was a visionary on the cutting edge of Jewish life. A tireless, passionate and forceful leader, through his partnership with the Wexner family, Herb changed the face of adult Jewish learning in North America and brought leadership development to an entirely new plateau. Joining us in mourning his loss are many thousands of students and leaders in the Jewish community worldwide who have been touched by Rabbi Friedman's manifold contributions to Jewish life. There will never be another Herb. Our sincere condolences go out to his beloved wife Francine, his five children, four grandchildren, and two great-grandchildren. The Wexner Foundation Leslie and Abigail Wexner, Chairmen Larry S. Moses, President

KOHEN--Beverly, on March 30th, 2008. Beloved wife of the late Stanley, loving mother of David and Roni, dear motherin-law of Susan and Robert, devoted grandmother of Rachel and husband Josh, Douglas and wife Amy, Amanda, Zach and Joanna. Services private.

KKR Financial Holdings, an affiliate of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, said on Monday it would sell a controlling stake in a real estate subsidiary and refinance notes to complete its exit from the mortgage-related business. KKR Financial agreed to sell a controlling interest in the subsidiary, KKR Financial Corporation, a real estate investment trust, to Rock Capital 2 for an undisclosed price. The deal, which is scheduled to close in the second quarter, will complete KKR Financial's conversion to a limited liability company from a real estate investment trust.

BERNARD--Frederic L., M.D., 95, on March 28, 2008. Retired physician, Holocaust survivor, Renaissance man. He loved music, art, theater, literature, history, geography and, most of all, people. He read widely and was interested in all the world, as well as all things Jewish. Born on August 7, 1912 in Czernowitz, Austria (later Romania), he earned his medical degree in Pisa, Italy in 1937. He married his first wife, Gusti Klier in 1940, survived the Holocaust with her, and came to the United States in December 1949. His memoir of their survival, In the Eye of the Storm, was published in 1998 and is in permanent collection of the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum in Washington, DC. He lived in Queens, New York for 36 years and was the Director of Anesthesiology at Hillcrest General Hospital (later St. Josephs) for 30 years. His first wife died in 1970. He remarried in 1977 and moved to Sarasota, Florida when he retired in 1986. He was a member of the Congregation fro Humanistic Judaism. He is deeply mourned by his beloved and loving wife of 31 years, Adelle Jacobs; his adored and adoring children Robert and Angela Bernard, Linda Bernard and Richard Kolmer, Lawrence and Connie Jacobs, Jonathan and Cristiana Jacobs; his grandchildren, Thomas, Chloe, and Montague Jacobs; and greatgrandson, Asher Jacobs. He was cherished by them all. He had many friends who were dear to him, and he was loved and respected by them in return. His loss will be deeply felt.

Newbold (William) of St. Thomas, V.I., Elizabeth E. Miller (Gerald) of Piedmont, CA, James M. Earle III (Gerardine) of Malvern, PA, and Murray Earle II of St. Thomas, V.I. CLUB Paul Ince, one of only two black managers in English soccer, led the Milton Keynes Dons to a 2-0 victory against Grimsby in the Johnstone's Paint Trophy final Sunday at Wembley Stadium. The competition is for teams in Leagues 1 and 2, the sport's third and fourth tiers in England. The Dons are on course for promotion to League 1. PLAYER In Italy, Francesco Totti, the captain and leading scorer (14 goals) for Roma, will miss the team's Champions League first-leg quarterfinal match against visiting Manchester United on Tuesday after injuring his left thigh Saturday in a 1-1 draw against Cagliari.

BONJEAN--Emile. The Trustees and staff of Greentree Foundation will always remember Emile with deep respect, profound gratitude, and abiding affection. He was the indispensable person in the transformation of Greentree from a private home to a unique, welcoming environment in which visitors from around the world came to negotiate agreements and discuss issues of peace, social justice, and international cooperation. Through his extraordinary dedication, attention to detail, and exacting standards, he created an atmosphere conducive to conversation in which visitors sought greater understanding of critical global issues and their own common humanity. This remarkable man was a perfectionist who demanded much of himself and no less of those who worked with him. He had the uncommon ability to make visitors from all over the world immediately feel welcome and at ease. He was the embodiment of Greentree and his example, standards, and spirit will continue to guide us for years to come. All who knew him will always remember the indelible image of Emile opening the front door, smiling, extending his hand in friendship, and saying ''welcome to Greentree.'' For further information please contact Ms. Nicole Ward at Greentree Foundation (212)888-7755. BONJEAN--Emile. Beloved Emile, native of France, and resident of Long Island, NY, was a tender and treasured part of our family for 50 years. His dedication and brilliance transformed Greentree from a personal home into a ''House of Peace,'' where he welcomed visitors from all over the world for Greentree Foundation as they came to negotiate agreements and discuss global issues. His influence will continue to be felt through the extraordinary atmosphere he helped create by all who continue to meet at Greentree to pursue issues of social justice and international harmony. Our family will miss him terribly, and remember him always with love. Kate Whitney and Franklin Thomas and their family Sara and Ronald Wilford and their family

Might the Republicans want to drink until 4 a.m. at their convention in St. Paul in the summer? Some legislators there think so. In a proposal being considered in the Minnesota House, the last call for alcohol would be pushed back two hours from the usual 2 a.m. for all establishments within a 10-mile radius of the convention site.

BENEROFE--June, died March 31, at her home, spending her last days with her children, Dale and Mark, sister Louise and loved ones at her bedside. Mrs. Benerofe was a beloved mother, adopted mom, sister, wife, aunt, and loving friend. A partner with her husband in the Dan Benerofe Agency, she also helped spearhead the successful effort to build Blind Brook High School and served as executive officer of B'nai Brith and Tamar Haddassah in Westchester. An avid reader, theatergoer, gourmet cook and tennis player, she traveled the world with friends and family, and entertained hundreds at her homes in Westchester and Bolton Landing, NY. As a Director of the Lake George Association, she worked to protect the environment of the Adirondacks. She leaves behind a legion of adoring friends and family. The family will sit shiva at 551B Heritage Hills, Somers, NY from 1pm to 9pm on April 1st and 2nd. In lieu of flowers, June asked donations be made to www.lakegeorgeassociation .org, and requested friends and family do something with those they love to nourish mind, body and heart in her honor.

With a boost from its afternoon coverage of the N.C.A.A. college basketball tournament, CBS eked out a slight ratings victory on Sunday, edging past ABC as the night's most watched network. According to Nielsen's overnight estimates, the 23-minute college basketball overrun into the 7 p.m. time slot meant that more than 17 million viewers were tuned in to CBS during the first half-hour of prime time. Directly after the live coverage ended, CBS drew about 12.3 million viewers for ''60 Minutes,'' followed by an above-average audience of 8 million viewers for CBS's ''Big Brother.'' Despite its second place finish, ABC outpaced CBS among adults 18 to 49 thanks to ''Extreme Makeover: Home Edition'' at 8 (12.8 million) and ''Oprah's Big Give'' at 9 (11.3 million). Fox was third for the night in that demographic, trailing both ABC and CBS with its animated comedy lineup. NBC, which drew slightly more total viewers than Fox, finished a distant fourth in the 18-to-49 set. NBC broadcast repeats from 9 to 11, following a special showing of MSNBC's ''Countdown With Keith Olbermann'' at 7 (3.4 million) and ''Dateline'' at 8 (6.7 million).

“He shot me,” Joseph Guzman told the rapt courtroom. “I’m looking in his eyes, man. He shot me. Everything slowed down. But I’m looking at him shooting me. He’s continuing to shoot.” With bullets slamming into the passenger side, Mr. Guzman said he desperately propelled himself across the lap of the car’s driver, Sean Bell, while urging Mr. Bell to get them out of there. He addressed his friend by his initial. “I’m like: S., let’s do it, let’s do it. This is not a robbery. They’re trying to kill us. This is not a robbery.”

Was Sacha Baron Cohen’s 2006 film “Borat” a pure slapstick comedy? Does it have a measure of redeeming value as a societal commentary? A federal judge considered these questions before dismissing a lawsuit filed by a man who was randomly accosted — and touched — by Mr. Cohen on a Midtown street. The judge concluded that the movie “appeals to the most childish and vulgar in its viewers” but does make an effort to offer a critique of American society.

It seems that some lawmakers in Washington have been listening to all our talk about the disastrous situation around health insurance for small businesses and the self-employed. On Wednesday, a bipartisan group of senators -- Olympia Snowe, Republican of Maine; Dick Durbin, the majority whip who is a Democrat from Illinois; Blanche Lincoln, Democrat of Arkansas; and Norm Coleman, Republican of Minnesota -- proposed legislation that seeks to reduce the cost and improve coverage options for small businesses. The bill is supported by the National Federation of Independent Businesses, the National Association of Realtors and the Service Employees International Union.

I.B.M. and Linden Lab, the creator of Second Life, are placing a stake in the ground today for corporate virtual worlds. The two companies have started a joint project to run Second Life technology behind corporate firewalls.

Minnesota sports teams are not known for coming in first. But the Twin Cities are now out in front in at least one respect: Comcast plans to announce Thursday that it is beginning the introduction of a new broadband Internet technology in the Minneapolis-St. Paul region, starting this week.

It's an elegant proposition, but one plagued by the kind of glitches that keep physicists from coming up with a grand unified theory.
Soft Serve scans newspapers, magazines and Web sites for "soft news" - coverage of products, trends and matters of style. Just the fluff, ma'am.

The Bruins, Flyers and Hurricanes are on the ice tonight in must-win situations. With wins, Boston and Philly go to 93 points and take Buffalo out of the picture. However, they'd still have to worry about Washington and Carolina, who could get to 94 points by winning their last two. (One of the Caps and Canes gets the division title; the other dukes it out for eighth place.) And Ottawa? Don't get me started ...

In his last post, James Collins describes how "Bonfire" portrayed the angry feelings of victimization felt by white New Yorkers. Lest anyone think that the fictional rage - among the Jews, Italians, Irish and Poles of the "outer boroughs" - was an exaggeration, here is the perspective of Dave Smith, the deputy editor of the Week in Review section, who grew up in the Bronx, from the mid-1950s through the mid-1970s. -KATY ROBERTS

The Insider is a recurring profile of emerging tastemakers in the fields of fashion, design, food, travel and the arts. Here Kim Ann Foxman, a vocalist for the alt-disco group Hercules and Love Affair, shares a few of her stylish essentials with The Moment. Hot off the heels of their self-titled debut, Hercules and Love Affair are about to go on their first UK and European tour. (They kick off in Brighton on May 23rd.) No word on any U.S. dates just yet, but we've got our dancing shoes on in anticipation.

BRIEFS As fiery debates over a lawmaker's anti-Islam film continue, the Dutch parliament decided to send a frigate to stop pirates from hijacking United Nations food shipments to Somalia, a Muslim nation desperate for aid.

In response to my black bean spare ribs recipe last week, Judith Liebman, a retired professor of engineering from the University of Illinois, sent along her recipe. She says that spare ribs were traditionally steamed or fried because the classic Chinese kitchens had no ovens, but she believes roasting is far easier. And this is about as easy as it gets, as long as you have the Szechwan peppercorns. Ms. Liebman notes that you can add Chinese Five Spice powder to the mixture, but "the simple mixture of Szechuan pepper and salt lets the true essence of pork shine through." 1:56 p.m.: Ben Silverman, the co-chair of NBC Entertainment, stepped up to debut his "dream schedule." It's a small world, and that can mean big problems for Wall Street. A blowup at a superleveraged fund in Japan can quickly reverberate to New York and much further afield; a bank collapse in London can leave trading counterparties around the world twisting in the wind.

The success of "Mad Men" on AMC seems to have inspired TNT to try its hand at a modern-day drama about life in the advertising world.

The discovery of a buried parachute last month may have stirred the imagination about finally solving the famous D.B. Cooper skyjacking-and-vanishing act, but it turns out that was not to be. The F.B.I.'s latest lead on the 1971 case, provided by children who found it while playing in rural Washington state, turned out to be a false one: it couldn't have been Mr. Cooper's.

A commentary in this week's issue of the journal Nature adds to the chorus of economists, climate scientists and experts in energy policy saying that the major approaches to combating global warming are deeply flawed.

Three news reports about Iraq war casualties were among the winners of the 2007 Peabody Awards. Announced Wednesday by the University of Georgia's Grady College of Journalism and Mass Communication, the awards are meant to honor the "best in electronic media."

As computer-based technologies, Voice over Internet Protocol telephone systems (VoIP) are as vulnerable to attacks as PCs. The problem is, says one telecommunications security company, few people ever think that their voice conversations -- and their user accounts -- can easily be spied upon, recorded, and stolen.

Anti-Beijing protests have erupted in the Xinjiang region in the far West of China, home to Uighurs and other Muslims of ethnic Turkish origin. Reports are sketchy, but the protesters in the town of Khotan may have been seeking independence from China.

A few weeks ago, my colleague David Kelly wrote a post for Paper Cuts about overrated books. Anyone who knows David, or has been reading his posts, wasn't surprised that it was smart, witty and elegant. Indeed, it elicited an enormous response. Yet I was troubled by it. David chose as his overrated books D.H. Lawrence's "Women in Love" and the Bible. I'm not about to offer a defense of the Bible, but I do want to speak up for "Women in Love."

The season is only two games old, and the Mets are already facing their first crisis. We are expected to learn about the severity of Pedro Martinez's hamstring strain later today, after he takes an MRI exam in New York. It is possible that he will only miss a few weeks. But there is a chance Pedro's absence may be measured more in months because it could be imprudent to treat him with anything but an uber-conservative approach.

On Tuesday, Max Mosley, president of the F.I.A. apologized for his recent sex romp with five prostitutes and denied the sadomasochistic orgy, in which he was caught on video counting loudly in German, had anything to do with Nazis or concentration camps. He is planning to take legal action against News of the World, the British tabloid that started the uproar with an article published on Sunday.
Syracuse Coach Jim Boeheim said Tuesday that the star freshman forward Donte' Greene still had not 100 percent confirmed to him that he was coming back for his sophomore season.

Now that the major presidential candidates have all promised action against global warming, environmentalists are hoping that Washington will finally do something next year. But in addition to the well-known obstacles -- the reluctance of voters and industries to make sacrifices -- there's also another big stumbling block: the federal environmental bureaucracy.

A recent survey by the Web site Brandchannel.com, run by the branding consultancy Interbrand, asked which brands readers wanted revived. Less lamented was Plymouth at 14.

But that has not been enough to create bullet-proof investments. Some technologies thought to have been among the most promising, including biofuels, solar energy and those aimed at energy efficiency, have turned out to be the worst affected.

Jared Kushner, owner of the weekly New York Observer, is among those considering buying or entering a partnership with Newsday, The Wall Street Journal reported.

Stocks started the second quarter with a soaring rally on Tuesday that sent the Dow Jones industrial average up nearly 400 points, its best performance in two weeks, as investors found reasons to take heart in a fresh round of mortgage-related write-offs at UBS and Deutsche Bank and a capital infusion at Lehman Brothers, the brokerage firm.

A Web site created by Fabrice Wantiez has an incredible assortment of photographs and images of Bobby Fischer, the late American chess champion. Since Fischer died in January, there have been a number of commemorations of his life, including one on March 9, Fischer's 65th birthday, at the Marshall Chess Club in Manhattan.
Tennessee and Connecticut advanced to the Final Four with victories on Tuesday.

Carolina hold the tie-breaker because they have more wins, but who'd bet against Alexander Ovechkin? The Democratic presidential candidates made their way around the eastern part of the state on Tuesday.

Joe Girardi was named Yankees' manager on Nov. 1, and he has spent every day since then preparing. He won his debut in the Yankees' dugout on Tuesday, 3-2 against Toronto, and I found one comment of his especially interesting.

While the California weather recently has been conducive to ripe, rich pinot noirs, the 2005 vintage in Northern California was an exception.
Pedro Martínez strained his left hamstring in the fourth inning Tuesday, walking off the field unaided.
A veteran legislator from South Jersey said that he would challenge New Jersey Senator Frank R. Lautenberg for the Democratic nomination.
The maker of the BlackBerry device said that its fourth-quarter profit and sales more than doubled as it increased its subscriber base and shipped about 4.4 million of its smart phones.
TJX Companies said that it would pay up to $24 million as part of a settlement with MasterCard over a security breach that put credit card data for tens of millions of shoppers at risk.
In the first sizable layoffs in its history, Google is cutting about a quarter of the American operations of DoubleClick, the advertising technology company that it acquired recently.
A House panel approved a bill Wednesday that would give the F.D.A. sweeping new regulatory authority over the tobacco industry, clearing the way for a House floor vote on the legislation.
Wall Street turned lower as investors worried that a jump in oil prices could be another signal that consumers are under stress in an economy that is showing signs of a recession.
The package of legislation is designed to help homeowners facing foreclosure.
Managers of the International Space Station on Wednesday cleared Europe’s new Jules Verne cargo ship for its first docking with the orbiting research outpost.
The European Commission opened a formal investigation into the bailout of the British lender, a process expected to set a precedent on government aid within the 27-nation bloc.
The mortgage buyer has told lenders that it will require a minimum credit score for the loans it buys as it tries to protect itself from record foreclosures sweeping the country.
United Airlines temporarily removed its fleet of Boeing 777 aircraft from service to allow for inspections, resulting in the cancellation of 31 flights, the airline said.
The airline said it was testing the Boeing 777s to make sure components of a cargo fire suppression system were operating effectively.
In Beijing, the Treasury secretary urged Chinese leaders to press ahead with changes to their financial market but acknowledged that the tight credit markets might make them hesitant.
Orders to American factories fell for a second consecutive month, a worse-than-expected performance that reinforced worries that the risk of recession is rising.
The announcement by WestLB comes after problems stemming from credit markets turmoil forced its owners to step in with a 5 billion euro ($7.8 billion) rescue.
The news of the protest in Xinjiang underscored the breadth of China’s problems with ethnic and religious minority groups.
The chairman of the Federal Reserve warned a Congressional committee that the economy could contract in the first half of this year.
Tuesday’s rally on Wall Street continued in Asia on Wednesday, as investors found reasons to believe that the drumbeat of subprime woes may be coming to an end.
It is unclear what the move to make Donnie Walsh the team’s president of operations means for Isiah Thomas.

A man hijacked a Con Edison van after shooting a woman in the Bronx on Tuesday night, then shot and killed himself as the police closed in on him while he was stuck in traffic outside Yankee Stadium, the police said.
The sluggers in the Angels’ outfield gave Jon Garland quite a welcome.
The No. 1-ranked Huskies advanced to their first Final Four since winning the 2004 title with a 66-56 victory over Rutgers.
At a point in the season where they can ill afford any mistakes, the Nets lost their third straight game on Tuesday.
Pedro Martínez left an already-disappointing game with a strained left hamstring, and it was unclear how much time he would miss.
Zach Randolph returned to the Knicks’ lineup on Thursday and scored 19 points, but it wasn’t enough to avoid the team’s 15th loss in 17 games.
Colorado:
A panel has approved a plan to provide taxpayer-subsidized health coverage for the domestic partners of state employees and retirees.
A group of third graders plotted to attack their teacher, bringing a broken steak knife, handcuffs, duct tape and other items for the job to school.
Three of 32 mobile homes tested for use in Arkansas had levels high enough to put possible residents at an increased risk of cancer and respiratory illnesses.
Gov. Christine Gregoire signed into law some of toughest restrictions in the nation on chemicals used in children’s products.
Asian stocks jumped after a write-down by Swiss bank UBS reinforced the view that the banks were scrubbing their books of soured subprime investments.
The Yankees won their final home opener at Yankee Stadium, edging the Toronto Blue Jays.
UMass and Ohio State won on Tuesday, and will play in the N.I.T. championship on Thursday.
Zach Parise’s deflection 29 seconds into overtime clinched a 2-1 victory over the Islanders, and a playoff berth for the Devils.

The architecture column on Tuesday, about a development proposal by St. Vincent’s Hospital Manhattan and the Rudin Management Company, misstated the number of buildings they are seeking to raze to make way for a new hospital and residences in Greenwich Village. It is nine, not eight.

The architecture column on Thursday, about the choice of a developer for the West Side railyards, referred incorrectly to the Atlantic Yards project in Brooklyn in citing major developments that have been delayed or altered. The Atlantic Yards plan has been approved by New York State, not New York City.
INTERNATIONAL.

An article on March 20 about a decision by Iraq’s Presidency Council to withdraw objections to legislation on provincial elections referred incorrectly to the effective date of any Iraqi legislation passed into law. Under Iraq’s constitution, if the effective date is not specified in the legislation, then it is the date the legislation is published in the newspaper of the Ministry of Justice — not 15 days after publication.
A television review on Saturday about “Sense and Sensibility,” on PBS, misstated the name of the family home the Dashwood women are forced to leave. It is Norland Park, not Noland Park.

An article in some editions on Saturday about the resolve of New York Democrats to pursue control of the State Senate despite the resignation of the Democratic governor, Eliot Spitzer, gave an erroneous spelling in some copies for the surname of a spokesman for Joseph L. Bruno, the Republican Senate majority leader. The spokesman is John McArdle, not McCardle.

An article on Monday about the Washington Nationals’ first game in their new stadium referred incorrectly in some editions to Bob Feller and Honus Wagner, who are among former ballplayers featured on outsized photographs in the stadium’s corridors. Feller and Wagner are part of the Nationals’ salute to Hall of Famers from other cities; they never played for the Washington Senators. (Feller played for the Cleveland Indians, and Wagner mostly for the Pittsburgh Pirates.).

An obituary on Tuesday about the filmmaker Jules Dassin misspelled part of the title of the Broadway musical he directed and misstated the Tony Award history of Melina Mercouri’s performance in the show. The title is “Illya Darling,” not “Ilya Darling,” and Ms. Mercouri, who was Mr. Dassin’s wife, was nominated for a Tony as best actress in a musical; she did not win the award. (It went to both Patricia Routledge, in “Darling of the Day,” and Leslie Uggams, in “Hallelujah, Baby!”).

An article on Thursday about Western Kentucky University’s history in basketball and the breaking of racial barriers misstated the name of the university whose five African-American starters won the 1966 N.C.A.A. men’s tournament by defeating Kentucky’s five white starters. It was Texas Western — not the University of Texas in El Paso, which has been Texas Western’s name since 1967.

A film review on Monday about “Roman Polanski: Wanted and Desired” misstated the date in 1977 that Mr. Polanski was arrested in California and charged with raping a 13-year-old girl. It was March 11, not March 13.

The fine for a disorderly conduct summons can be as little as $25. But Waheed Saleh, originally from Jenin in the occupied West Bank and now living in Yonkers, did not want to pay it because, he contends, a principle was at stake.
State lawmakers passed the first piece of New York’s budget, agreeing on a health care package but remaining at an impasse over several thorny questions, including ones over taxes and schools.
Peja Stojakovic hit a 3-pointer and three free throws in the final minute Tuesday night to lift the New Orleans Hornets to a 98-97 victory over the host Orlando Magic.
DETROIT (Reuters) — O’Reilly Automotive said Tuesday that it had reached a cash-and-stock deal worth $528 million to buy a rival, the CSK Auto Corporation.

CLEVELAND (AP) — The National City Corporation, a Midwestern bank heavily exposed to the worsening mortgage and housing market, confirmed Tuesday that it was reviewing its options amid rumors that it wants to find a buyer.

Ben Gordon, the Chicago Bulls guard, is the latest N.B.A. player to be selected by the fledgling British basketball team that is trying to qualify for the 2012 Olympics. Gordon, who turns 25 on Friday, moved to the United States shortly after he was born in London. A college star at Connecticut, he was one of two Bulls players to appear in all 82 games last season, averaging 21.4 points.
Officials said the United Arab Emirates were failing to keep U.S. technology from slipping into the wrong hands.

Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates may shutter the Counterintelligence Field Activity office as part of a larger effort to overhaul the nation’s intelligence architecture.
Many Democrats are calling on Howard Dean to be more aggressive in bringing the nominating battle to a close.

The City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, said on Tuesday that she opposed the demolition of the large number of hospital buildings called for by a controversial new development proposal for St. Vincent’s Hospital Manhattan.
Candace Parker returned to the game after dislocating her shoulder to lead Tennessee to a 53-45 win over Texas A&M.
Critics claim Hope Now, a White House-backed group formed to help struggling homeowners, supports the interests of lenders, not homeowners.
The toll of civilian deaths in the Iraqi capital last month reached its highest point since September 2007.

Oscar Pistorius, the double-amputee sprinter who was barred from competition with able-bodied athletes in January, will present his appeal to the Court of Arbitration for Sport at a hearing on April 29 and 30, he announced Tuesday.

Serena Williams made the world’s top-ranked woman look like a beginner, beating her nemesis Justine Henin, 6-2, 6-0, in the quarterfinals of the Sony Ericsson Open on Tuesday in Key Biscayne, Fla. Williams won the final 10 games by playing nearly flawless tennis, while Henin unraveled after she double-faulted three times.
The Olympic 100-meter champion Justin Gatlin will have his appeal of a four-year doping ban heard next month by the Court of Arbitration for Sport. The hearing will take place May 28 and 29.

When it comes to publicity, being denied entry into the United States may be the best thing that ever happened to Sebastian Horsley, right, unless you count being hung on a cross in the Philippines. Mr. Horsley, the British author of “Dandy in the Underworld” (Harper Perennial) — a rollicking memoir of his rampant drug use, abundant encounters with prostitutes and that trip to the Philippines to be crucified for an art exhibition — was turned back at Newark Liberty International Airport last month on the grounds of “moral turpitude.” He was here for a book party and media tour. Now PEN American Center, the writers’ organization, has invited Mr. Horsley to speak at its annual festival of international literature at the end of this month and written a letter to Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice and Homeland Security Secretary Michael Chertoff, asking them to admit Mr. Horsley to the country. Francine Prose, president of PEN American Center, said that Mr. Horsley was not originally invited as a speaker, but that his deportation made him a cause célèbre. “PEN supports freedom of speech and freedom of expression on the most basic level,” she said. “Writers should be able to enter our country regardless of what they’ve written.” Mr. Horsley, in a telephone interview from London, said he would “absolutely” accept PEN’s invitation if American authorities would let him into the country. “The pen is mightier than the sword,” he said. “And it’s considerably easier to write with.” So far his book has sold only a thousand copies in the United States, according to Nielsen BookScan, which tracks about 70 percent of retail sales.
