Carol Hogel, an American philanthropist who has given more than $40 million to the arts in Britain, said she was returning to the United States in protest of a government tax on foreign citizens and the “hostility” toward foreign donors she has encountered, The Times of London reported. “After 24 years of working and paying taxes in the U.K., I am heading back to North America, where an individual with involvement in, and charitable contributions to, visual arts and classical music is valued, not punished,” she wrote in a letter to Robert McNeil, a humor columnist for the newspaper The Scotsman who mocked rich foreign residents. Through the Dunard Fund, financed by her family’s business, Ms. Hogel has supported the Edinburgh International Festival, major productions by the Scottish Opera, the London Philharmonic, the Scottish Chamber Orchestra, the Royal Scottish National Orchestra and refurbishment of the National Galleries of Scotland.

“The Nine: Inside the Secret World of the Supreme Court” (Doubleday), a portrait of the Supreme Court since the Reagan administration written by Jeffrey Toobin, below, has won the $10,000 J. Anthony Lukas Book Prize, the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism and the Nieman Foundation at Harvard University announced. The other winners of this year’s J. Anthony Lukas Prize Projects Awards were Peter Silver, recipient of the $10,000 Mark Lynton History Prize for “Our Savage Neighbors: How Indian War Transformed Early America” (W. W. Norton), and Michelle Goldberg, recipient of the $30,000 J. Anthony Lukas Work-in-Progress Award for “The Means of Reproduction,” to be published by Penguin Press in 2009. Mr. Lukas, a journalist and author who won two Pulitzer Prizes, died in 1997. The awards will be presented on May 13 at the Neiman Foundation by Patricia Nelson Limerick, faculty director of the Center of the American West at the University of Colorado at Boulder.

ABC was the most-watched network on Monday night, as roughly 20.3 million viewers tuned in to an extended 96-minute edition of “Dancing With the Stars” at 8 p.m., Nielsen estimated. Although ABC averaged more total viewers, CBS, the runner-up, edged ahead among adults 18 to 49, thanks to its popular half-hour sitcoms, including “Two and a Half Men” at 9 p.m. (14.4 million), which led the night among the 18-to-49 set. CBS also dominated the 10 p.m. time slot with “CSI: Miami” (15.5 million), easily outpacing both NBC’s “Medium” (9.5 million) and the last hour of ABC’s “Bachelor,” which averaged just over 8 million viewers from 9:36 to 11 p.m. NBC ranked third for the night, delivering its largest audience at 9 with “Deal or No Deal” (10 million) but struggling at 8 with “My Dad Is Better Than Your Dad” (4.4 million). Fox, fourth in total viewers, tied NBC for third among adults 18 to 49, broadcasting a repeat of “House” at 8 (7.5 million) followed by “New Amsterdam” at 9 (6.6 million). On Saturday night Nickelodeon’s “Kids’ Choice Awards,” with Jack Black as host and a performance by Miley Cyrus, drew 7.4 million viewers, the cable channel said on Tuesday. That audience — an increase of 1.3 million viewers, or more than 20 percent, over last year — was the largest in the show’s 21-year history.

Seven historic aboriginal paintings, valued at $460,000, were stolen from a museum in Darwin, Australia, before dawn on Tuesday but recovered undamaged about seven hours later after the thief apparently changed his mind, The Associated Press reported. (One of the recovered works is above.) Six of the paintings taken from the Northern Territory Museum and Gallery exemplified the early work of the Papunya Tula movement. Named for an artists’ collective in central Australia, it is credited with being the first to paint aboriginal tribal motifs on board or canvas, creating a style in the 1970s that became world-renowned. The police said a blood-spattered broken window, security footage and other clues indicated that the thief had smashed into the museum with a rock and spent 15 minutes inside while alarms sounded. The paintings were found in parkland. A 37-year-old man was detained and questioned.

Sovereign wealth funds have emerged in recent months as the world's power brokers. They have used their tremendous wealth to make big cross-border investments and prop up some of Wall Street's best-firms. The increased activity comes as other kinds of acquirers have been sidelined by the credit crisis. These funds are state-sponsored investment vehicles and have combined assets of $2 trillion. With that much dry powder, sovereign funds dwarf the formerly booming private equity industry -- and in some cases, compete directly with it. The Investment Government of Singapore Corporation has been the most active among the world's sovereign funds, making its deputy chairman, Tony Tan, a major center of gravity. Wall Street veterans always follow the money, so many of the big-name advisers in New York and London have found themselves traveling the globe playing international matchmaker to these funds. But sovereign funds have also learned the downside of deal-making: some of their blockbuster transactions have been big money losers so far. The question is where all that money will go next.

He will be very much missed by friends and family.

WATERBURY--Marion R., of Woburn, Massachusetts, formerly of Redding, Connecticut, died Tuesday, March 19, at Hearthstone Alzheimer Care following an illness of three years. She was 87 and the wife for fifty-three years of Frederick S. Waterbury who died in 1996. Born in Bridgeport, daughter of the late Walter Reynolds Waterbury and Marion Boyland Waterbury. Brought up in New Town, Connecticut. She was educated at Danbury State Teachers College, now Western Connecticut State and began teaching primary education in the Weston, Connecticut Public School System and later spent the balance of her teaching career at the kindergarten level. She met her future husband in Weston and the couple moved to Redding where they raised their family; following which she resumed teaching. Mr. and Mrs. Waterbury loved to go camping as they traveled from East to West and North to South covering 48 states and Canada on their various trips; first in their truck mounted camper and later in a large fifth wheel travel vehicle. On their excursions they established many close and lasting friendships throughout the country. Over the years they established homes at Lake Candlewood in Connecticut and in Lakeland, FL. Mrs. Waterbury enjoyed 21 years of retirement and four and one half years ago she sold her homes and moved to Woburn, Massachusetts to be close to family members. She leaves her son Daniel Waterbury of Oceanside, CA, son Reverend Doctor George ''Skip'' Waterbury and his wife Victoria of Winchester and her son David Waterbury, Esq. of Middle Village, NY. She leaves five grandchildren. A celebration of the life of Marion R. Waterbury will be held at a Memorial Service Saturday, April 5, at 1:30pm at the First Church of Danbury, Connecticut.

McCRACKEN--Ursula Naylor Eland, 66, died at home in Baltimore, March 17. A Wellesley College graduate (BA 1963, cum laude, Wellesley Scholar), held two MAs from Johns Hopkins University. A career in arts and education: Albright Knox Gallery; Walters Art Museum and College of Notre Dame in Baltimore. For 18 years she was Director of the Textile Museum in Washington DC where she brought the Museum up to current standards in every area from collections management to financial management while diversifying the exhibitions and educational programs, and building local, national and international audiences and membership. She increased the endowment seven-fold to over $17 million. Survived by her husband, Edward; siblings: Timothy Eland of New York City, Jane Donahue of Wellesley, MA and Faith Shepard of New Canaan, CT. Family and friends will hold a gathering of remembrance from 2:00 to 4:00pm, May 10th at The Textile Museum in Washington. Ursula requested contributions to the American Pain Foundation, Suite 710, 201 N. Charles St. Baltimore, MD 21201 or the Textile Society of America, P.O. Box 193, Middletown, DE 19709.

REICH--Edward Stuart, age 71, of New York City and Poughkeepsie, passed away on Monday, March 31, 2008. Beloved husband of Arlene, devoted father of Dawne, Heidi and Evan. Adored grandfather of Logan. Son of the late Herman and the late Frances Reich. He held the following positions at various times in his career: President of the Brooklyn Bar Association, Vice-President of the New York State Bar Association, President of the Lawyers Torah Club, Co-chair of the MIT Parents Fund, Parliamentarian Emeritus of the New York State Trial Lawyers Association and Fellow of the American Bar Foundation. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to the Jewish National Fund of Greater New York.

For one brief, shining moment -- actually four days, which is brief enough -- the New York Philharmonic will put on semistaged concert performances of the Lerner and Loewe musical ''Camelot'' at Avery Fisher Hall, and the cast is (mostly) set. Gabriel Byrne, left, will play King Arthur, with the rising opera star Nathan Gunn as Lancelot, Christopher Lloyd as Pellinore and Marc Kudisch as Sir Lionel. A spokesman for the Philharmonic said Marin Mazzie was in ''advanced negotiations'' to play Queen Guenevere. The performances, under the direction of Lonny Price, are scheduled to run from May 7 through May 10, with the May 8 performance to be broadcast nationally on PBS.

JACOBS--Herbert, on March 30, 2008 of natural causes. Former Director of Underwriting New York State Insurance Fund. Friend, mentor and sage to three generations. Services Friday 11:30am at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

PARKER--Frank L., III, of Rye, New York, died March 30 in Stamford, CT. He was 54 years old. The cause of death was heart attack. Mr. Parker was a graduate of Northfield Mount Hermon School and Denison University. Mr. Parker was an entrepreneur, starting a refillable custom glass bottled spring water business in New York and California. He was the president of So Clear Beverages LLC which also markets and distributes artisinal snack foods from Maine. Prior to that, he was an Anheuser Busch wholesaler in Bronx and New York counties. He is survived by his wife, Anna, and his daughters, Emily and Sarah, who loved him deeply and will miss him greatly. Calling hours at the Graham Funeral Home, Rye, Wednesday between 4-8pm. Mass of Christian Burial, Church of the Resurrection, Rye, Thursday 10:00am. Donations to Denison University Alumni Memorial Scholarship Fund, P.O. Box 716, Granville, OH 43023

GOHEEN--Robert F. Ph.D. The Board of Trustees of the American University of Beirut regrets the death of Trustee Emeritus Dr. Robert F. Goheen. Dr. Goheen, who was President Emeritus of Princeton University and former U.S. Ambassador to India, was elected to AUB's Board in 1983, and served as chairman from 1987-1994. He advised the University during some of the most violent years of the Lebanese Civil War. When he was appointed Trustee Emeritus in 1994, Goheen said, ''My years here have been a rewarding experience, particularly because of the inspirational performance of the faculty, staff, students and parents who sustained the University during the years of Lebanese national upheaval. I am thankful that my time here saw the return of peace to Lebanon, and of harmony and growth to AUB.'' GOHEEN--Robert F. The Trustees and staff of the National Humanities Center are deeply saddened by the death of Robert F. Goheen on March 31. In 1976 he joined other distinguished leaders from higher education to found the National Humanities Center as a residential institute for advanced study in the humanities. He was a Trustee of the Center from 1984 through 1996, serving as chairman of its board from 1991 through 1996. Upon his retirement from the board, he was elected Trustee Emeritus. In 1996 the Center recognized his leadership by naming the collection of books written by its Fellows The Robert F. and Margaret S. Goheen Collection, and in 2000 the Robert F. and Margaret S. Goheen Fellowship was permanently endowed at the Center. Throughout his long association with the National Humanities Center, Robert Goheen unfailingly brought wise counsel and clarity of vision, reminding its Trustees, staff, and Fellows by his salient example that the ultimate purposes of good scholarship are not confined to the academic world. Carl H. Pforzheimer III, Chairman, Geoffrey Harpham, President and Director, and members of the Board of Trustees

FRIEDMAN--Rabbi Herbert. United Jewish Communities (UJC), its Board of Trustees and staff mourn the passing of Rabbi Herbert Friedman, a dear friend to Israel and the global Jewish community. Rabbi Friedman served the United Jewish Appeal (UJC's predecessor organization) for 35 years, from 1947 to 1982, including as both a volunteer leader and as CEO and executive chairman (from 1954 to 1971.) During his tenure at UJA, Rabbi Friedman helped transform and grow Jewish communal fundraising to new heights, providing urgent help to Israel and to Jews around the world. He also founded the national Young Leadership program, nurturing the next generations of Jewish leaders. Rabbi Friedman was a dependable, righteous and charismatic leader. UJC plans to establish a National Young Leadership Cabinet fund in memory of Rabbi Friedman. Donations may be sent to United Jewish Communities c/o UJC National Young Leadership Dept., 111 8th Ave., Suite 11E, New York, NY, 10011. UJC extends our deepest sympathies and heartfelt condolences to the entire Friedman family. May his memory be a blessing.

BELMONT--Joseph (Jim). You were my brother, lifelong friend and a treasured link to our shared past. It is devastating to lose you. Love, Fern BELMONT--Joseph (Jim). Our Uncle Jim was wise, witty, honest and sincere. He exemplified the family man. We will miss him dearly. Myles/Jo, David/Beth, Mark/Susan BELMONT--Jim. The Hewlett-East Rockaway Jewish Centre mourns the loss of its esteemed member Jim Belmont and extends heartfelt sympathy to his wife Paula and the entire family. Rabbi Andrew Warmflash Liz Kislik, President
CONVERY--Robert. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Robert Convery, associated with The Times from September 30, 1975 until the present.

Does the world need any more Beethoven recordings? That question has been raised time and again to indicate the folly of companies that continue to record his works. Our digitized Toscaninis, Szells and Karajans, after all, should last a lifetime. But in the '90s recordings by period-instrument ensembles provided new insight into how revolutionary Beethoven's music might have sounded in his day. Lately, conductors like Osmo Vanska and Paavo Jarvi have been applying lessons learned from those performances to important discs made with modern orchestras.

KRAVAT--Jerry. With great sorrow we note the passing of our dear friend. At the Music and Art School, over 50 years last past we sang ''Now upward in wonder, our distant glance is turning, till dull and lifeless things have caught a beauty that daring dreams hath wrought.'' Jerry found his dreams and was such a beauty, quiet and tender to all, he will be deeply missed. Our heartfelt sympathy to Marty, his loving wife, his children, and Mimi his sister. Mel and Meg Knyper Aspen, Colorado KRAVAT--Jerry, on March 31, 2008. Ubiquitous jazz and cabaret obsessed man-abouttown who nurtured ''talent'', lived to serve them and while doing so, savored good music, good laughs, good wines, devouring every day of his life with gusto...left this week for another venue, to visit with old friends in smart clubs and funky, smoky jazz joints without us. The Four Musketeers miss him and celebrate him...although we are saddened by losing Jerry we are all better for having known him and his darling pistol packin Marty--partner/wife/ muse/and co-conspirator, encouraging him to pursue irreverent mischief and venture into the outre humor he adored...as much as he adored her...by his side...to the very end. Jerry, you're in our hearts with every toast we make, in every trip we plan (and never take), in every laugh, guffaw and giggle that make us shake. The Four Musketeers: Myrna Gershon Freddie Gershon Lynn Jacobson Geert Flammersfeld

Douglas Merrill, a vice president for engineering at Google, is leaving the company to become a president for digital at EMI Music, the recorded music division of EMI Group, according to an executive briefed on his move. Mr. Merrill is the second senior executive to leave Google in two months. In March, Sheryl Sandberg, who was vice president for global sales and operations, left to become chief operating officer at Facebook.

HASSON--Esther. We mourn the loss of our Aunt Esther whose presence made the world a better place. Stuart, Anne, Jeffrey, Lori, Barry and Children HASSON--Esther. With deepest sorrow I mourn the loss of my sister, Esther Hasson. Her loving and caring nature touched all who met her. Esther's greatest pleasures came through the happiness of her family. Her light will forever shine in our hearts. I will love you always, Rae.

A federal judge in Denver gave a preliminary victory to a rapidly growing Christian church that wants to expand on land designated for decades as open space. The judge, Robert E. Blackburn of Federal District Court, refused to dismiss a lawsuit by the group challenging a Colorado county's refusal to allow the expansion. The lawsuit, filed against Boulder County by the Rocky Mountain Christian Church in Niwot, is an important test of a federal statute intended to protect houses of worship from discriminatory zoning. The church says it has outgrown its current home, on a 54-acre site in one of the buffer zones the county established decades ago to preserve open space. In February 2006, the county refused to permit the church to double the size of its buildings. Judge Blackburn scheduled the case for trial in November. DIANA B. HENRIQUES

GROSS--Linda. The Board and Staff of the Shakespeare Society are deeply saddened by the loss of our dear friend, great supporter and Board member, Linda B. Gross. Linda embraced the Shakespeare Society with a vigor and enthusiasm inspired by a love of Shakespeare on the stage and a settled determination to help introduce others to the glories of the Bard. The Shakespeare Society was proud to have established the Linda Gross Playing Shakespeare Award for young actors in honor of Linda's lifelong love for the theater and its players. We will never forget Linda's life-affirming laughter, generous mind and enormous heart. We will always be grateful to have known her and send our sincerest sympathy to her beloved husband Dan and all of Linda's family and friends. Truly, ''There's a great spirit gone!'' MANN--Elias. The Mann family notes with sadness the passing of Eli Mann on March 31, 2008, at age 89. Eli was a respected lawyer and the loving father of Ronni and Philip Mann, devoted grandfather of Emma, Jacob and the late Abigail Brodsky, and beloved husband of Lou Mann and the late Gertrude Mann. Poor Detroit. First the scandal and resulting criminal charges involving the city's mayor, and now ''DEA,'' the new Spike TV series that begins on Wednesday. It follows a unit of the Drug Enforcement Administration's Detroit division, and here is how the opening narration sets the scene: ''Half a million guns loose on the street. The highest murder rate in the country. It is a deadly city that the D.E.A.'s Group 14 calls home.'' Not the kind of thing the city's tourism bureau would put on a billboard.

KEISMAN--Elaine Mann. Wife of Francis B. Mann, died on March 26, 2008, at home in Pittsboro, NC. Born on April 18, 1927, she attended Indiana University. Before retiring to North Carolina in 1985, Elaine and Francis lived in New York, Connecticut, Delaware, and Michigan. She is survived by her husband of 60 years, her sister Ruth Nicholson, five children and five grandchildren. Donations may be made to the North Carolina Museum of Art Docent Library, Ovarian Cancer National Alliance or the National Pediatric Myoclonus Center.

BONJEAN--Emile. The Trustees and staff of Greentree Foundation will always remember Emile with deep respect, profound gratitude, and abiding affection. He was the indispensable person in the transformation of Greentree from a private home to a unique, welcoming environment in which visitors from around the world came to negotiate agreements and discuss issues of peace, social justice, and international cooperation. Through his extraordinary dedication, attention to detail, and exacting standards, he created an atmosphere conducive to conversation in which visitors sought greater understanding of critical global issues and their own common humanity. This remarkable man was a perfectionist who demanded much of himself and no less of those who worked with him. He had the uncommon ability to make visitors from all over the world immediately feel welcome and at ease. He was the embodiment of Greentree and his example, standards, and spirit will continue to guide us for years to come. All who knew him will always remember the indelible image of Emile opening the front door, smiling, extending his hand in friendship, and saying ''welcome to Greentree.'' For further information please contact Ms. Nicole Ward at Greentree Foundation (212)888-7755.

COSTAS--Carl E., M.D. The administration, trustees, and staff of St. Francis Hospital, The Heart Center in Roslyn, New York, mourn the passing of Carl Costas, M.D., Attending Physician in the Department of Anesthesiology since 1986. Dr. Costas was part of the institutional fabric of St. Francis and part of the team that helped make St. Francis Hospital the special place that it is today. Throughout his entire career at St. Francis Hospital, Dr. Costas always demonstrated a boundless love of and commitment to St. Francis Hospital, its staff, patients and employees. His wonderful spirit and good humor will be greatly missed by the entire St. Francis Hospital community.

For 20 years, top deal makers have flocked to Tulane’s annual mergers and acquisitions conference. (DealBook’s Andrew Ross Sorkin once described the gathering as “the equivalent of Davos for the rainmaker crowd.”)
Few things give deal lawyers more heartburn these days than these three letters: MAC.

As he finished up his opening presentation at Tulane’s Corporate Law Institute conference on Thursday, Mark Shafir, Lehman Brothers‘ head of mergers and acquisitions, called out a fellow banking bigwig, Robert Kindler. “I want to kill him,” he declared.

Good morning from Tulane University’s Corporate Law Institute, where the mergers-and-acquisitions crowd congregates in the Big Easy every year to talk shop for two days. For M&A legal wonks, it’s the ultimate place to debate the merits of reverse breakup fees and go-shops. For us, it’s an opportunity to get a ringside seat as the people behind the deals hash out the big issues — and occasionally make actual deals in the hallways.

Updated, 5:30 p.m. |Police Officer Michael Carey, 27, testified this morning that he heard Detective Gescard F. Isnora shout, “Police, show your hands, police, show your hands,” as he approached Sean Bell’s Nissan Altima with his gun drawn. The Altima surged out of its parking spot on the curb, “the fastest it could from a parked position,” and struck the detective’s leg before hitting Officer Carey’s van, he said.“I still heard Detective Isnora yelling and there were other police commands,” Officer Carey testified.

Speaking of Starbucks, now comes another big, embarrassing dispute for the coffee chain. A former barista filed a lawsuit on Thursday in United States District Court in Manhattan, accusing Starbucks of cheating thousands of baristas in New York State by giving a share of their tips to shift supervisors. Lawyers for the barista, Jeana Barenboim, of Brooklyn, point to a state law that says no employer or agent of an employer can accept, directly or indirectly, part of an employee’s tips.
“Oh, my God!”

Updated, 6:30 p.m. |Pope Benedict XVI has added a new stop to his New York itinerary this month, the first papal visit to a synagogue in the United States and only the third such visit by a pope to any synagogue. The United States Conference of Catholic Bishops announced today that the pope will visit Park East Synagogue at 164 East 68th Street between Third and Lexington Avenues on the afternoon of April 18, the day he arrives in the city. (Laurie Goodstein of The Times has more details in this article for Friday editions.)Pope Benedict was invited by Rabbi Arthur Schneier, the leader of Park East Synagogue. This would be only the third papal visit to a synagogue anywhere. The pope visited the Cologne Synagogue in his native Germany in April 2005, and Pope John Paul II visited the Rome Synagogue in Italy in April 1986.

Susan Kim has sparked a nail salon rebellion of sorts in the New York metro region. Ever since word of her victorious labor lawsuit against her former employer in October (which awarded her more money than she asked for) spread in the immigrant press, nail salon workers have been approaching advocacy groups and speaking up about their working conditions.Among those who were motivated by her case were three Latino manicurists in Connecticut, including Irma Karina Vivar, who said she heard Ms. Kim speak at a meeting organized by the National Mobilization Against Sweatshops.

ALBANY — Kristine Hamann, the state inspector general under Gov. Eliot Spitzer, has resigned, effective April 10. (The Buffalo News reported the move earlier today.)Ms. Hamann was prominent in the so-called Troopergate scandal, which involved the Spitzer administration’s effort to discredit the State Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, by disseminating records of his travels on State Police cars and helicopters.

New York City may be surrounded by oceans, bays and rivers, but given the scarcity of real estate and swimming pools, surprisingly few children know how to swim. (Yes, there are public pools, some of which even float, but still…)Jack Lund, the president and chief executive of the Greater New York Y.M.C.A., said he was shocked when he was talking to a group of teenagers at the Y, and only about a quarter of them knew how to swim. “That was startling to me, I was really surprised,” he said.

For all that Americans love a good Eve Harrington story, the mundane and heartening truth among writers is that young Turks are less likely to destroy their forebears than to pay them generous tribute: witness Jonathan Franzen celebrating Paula Fox in the Harper's essay that revitalized her career, or Jonathan Lethem propelling the canonization of Philip K. Dick with his recent intro to the Library of America's four-novel collection. It's a nice impulse, and it maintains the vitality of literature as a conversation across generations. Writers learn from the past and talk to the future, and if they're lucky, the future sometimes talks back.

From the first moment I logged onto CompuServe, I've been in love with the potential of online services to turbocharge comparison shopping by combing through all the options to find the very best deals. This is a mindset, I've discovered, that I share with many engineers and technically minded business people who also see shopping as a great optimization equation. And I've spent many hours talking with excited idealist entrepreneurs who have just started companies that are meant to empower consumers in some market or another. Tonny Yu of ComputerESP, Farhad Mohit of BizRate and Doug Lebda of LendingTree, are just some that come to mind.

Even John McCain isn't old enough to remember the presidential race of 1908, which featured two highly distinguished nominees: William Howard Taft, the appointed governor-general of the Philippines, and William Jennings Bryan, the famed Nebraska populist, who was making what would be his third and final doomed run at the White House. For all their accomplishments, though, what neither of these men could claim was any service as an elected executive - that is, as mayor or governor or vice president or president. I mention this only because in the 100 years since, at least as far as I can tell (though perhaps one of you history buffs can prove me wrong), America has never faced a choice between two candidates who lacked any previous executive experience. (Some might argue, of course, that the vice presidency shouldn't really count as an executive office, given the limited roles accorded many running mates, but most vice presidents do have to deal with Congress as representatives of the executive branch at one time or another.)

Eating at the decent fish joints in Liguria, you're virtually guaranteed of one thing: local fish, caught that day. At La Prua, a seaside restaurant in Alassio, I had a plate of raw seafood, just brought in by a boat, that had on it tuna; gamberi (shrimp); langoustine; rascasse (the classic bouillabaisse fish); and clams and an oyster. All of which was fine, and all drizzled with good oil, of course. The most delicious -- and unusual -- of the lot were the raw shrimp, where were unbelievably creamy in texture. Could've eaten a dozen, easily.

What in the world is the point of Daisy? I have rarely smelled a perfume with a personality so impossible to pin down. Chimerical. Start with the most basic question: Is it good or bad? Hard to say. What do you consider good? A perfume with a clear character? Then no. Daisy, a 2007 launch that the perfumer Alberto Morillas crafted under the creative direction of Marc Jacobs and Coty's vice president of marketing, Michael D'Arminio, is almost mesmerizing in its violent resistance to being mesmerizing. A perfume built to play a specific role? Then emphatically yes. Floral without flowers, sweet without sugar, somehow a pretty face without allowing a single feature of that face ever to come into distinct focus. (The only distinct aspect here is its demographic appeal: the perfume skews young.) It seems to have a peculiar engineering that allows it to melt into any background, to speak with a female voice emanating from invisible speakers somewhere over your head, to travel under any door like smoke and occupy, comfortably if spectrally, any space.

Last season the Buffalo Sabres were the toast of the N.H.L., a small-market team that had returned from the brink of bankruptcy to lead the league in merchandise sales, TV ratings and, most significantly, the standings. But then their owner, Tom Golisano, the Rochester payroll-processing tycoon, simply stopped spending money. Result: the Sabres’ two captains left over the summer and their top defenseman, Brian Campbell, was dealt away at the February trade deadline and promptly sparked San Jose to win 17 of its first 19 games since his arrival. And the Sabres, whose fans are now thoroughly disaffected? They’re one loss from becoming only the eighth team in the 80 years of NHL playoffs to fail to qualify for the post-season after finishing first the year before. Here are the other seven:.

The Major League Soccer season opened last Saturday, and the league hopes to build on some of the momentum created by David Beckham’s arrival last year. But as Taylor Twellman, a striker for the New England Revolution and U.S. National team, tells Jeffrey Marcus of The Times, a couple of factors continue to hurt the league’s credibility: the quality of its television broadcasts, especially the announcers, and the inappropriateness of some of its playing surfaces. “I can’t tell you how many times I get phone calls making fun of my sport because of the announcing,” says Twellman, who lauded ESPN’s decision to have J.P. Dellacamara and former U.S. national team captain John Harkes take over the broadcast from Dave O’Brien and the uber-loquacious Eric Wynalda this season. But Twellman still laments the presence of football hash marks in some stadiums and the artificial turf that can produce a different roll and bounce than natural grass. “If the game is on turf, with football lines, I’ll tell you right now, I’m not watching the game," he told Marcus.

Federal prosecutors in St. Louis say eight workers for a get-out-the-vote effort in the city and the county have pleaded guilty to federal election fraud for submitting false registration cards for the 2006 election. A United States attorney, Catherine Hanaway, said that eight former temporary workers for the Association of Community Organizations for Reform Now admitted submitting cards with false addresses and names and forged signatures. Acorn has said the workers most likely turned in the false applications to try to increase their wages.

Michael McGee Jr., a Milwaukee alderman who faces charges of extortion and bribery, lost his bid for re-election. Mr. McGee, left, who had been the top vote-getter in a February primary, received 2,244 votes from his mostly black district on the city’s North Side, losing to Milele Coggs, a consultant from a political family, who won 3,098 votes, election officials said. Mr. McGee has been held behind bars for 10 months while he awaits his trials.
Randi Weingarten, head of New York City’s teacher’s union, is expected to announce her candidacy to become the president of the American Federation of Teachers.

Three construction workers were presumed dead after falling 100 feet from the Interstate 430 bridge into the swollen Arkansas River in North Little Rock, the authorities said. The men were working on installing 30-inch-diameter waterlines under and across the bridge when their scaffolding platform collapsed, officials said. Divers could not enter the water because the current was too swift.

A lawsuit by the families of six men killed in August in a mine cave-in claims the collapse occurred because the mine’s owners were harvesting coal unsafely. The suit, filed in Salt Lake City, says the Murray Energy Corporation performed risky retreat mining last summer. It seeks unspecified damages. Three men trying to reach the miners died 10 days after the collapse in another cave-in at the Crandall Canyon Mine.

A 14-year-old girl gave birth to a full-term baby in a bathroom at her Houston-area junior high school, then tried to flush it down the toilet, killing the infant, the police said. The incident at Cedar Bayou Junior High in Baytown came just three days after another 14-year-old girl delivered a stillborn fetus in the lavatory of an airplane on her way back to Houston from a middle-school field trip. The Harris County district attorney’s office decided not to pursue charges against the girl on the airplane.

The older brother of Representative William J. Jefferson, who is facing trial on bribery and racketeering charges, has been indicted on unrelated corruption charges, the United States attorney’s office in New Orleans announced. Mose Jefferson, 65, is accused of bribing a former president of the New Orleans school board, Elleneese Brooks-Sims, in order to obtain a lucrative contract for educational software approved. Some $14 million in contracts for the “I Can Learn” software of JRL Enterprises Inc. was bought; Mr. Jefferson’s firm earned about $913,000 in consulting fees from JRL. Ms. Sims has pleaded guilty to taking $140,000 in bribes.

An article on Tuesday about the death of a Brooklyn mother of three who was shot while talking to neighbors at a memorial for a local rap artist misspelled, in some editions, the given name of the director of a community foundation dedicated to stopping violence. He is Geoffrey Davis, not Jeffrey.

An article on Tuesday about Joe Torre’s first regular-season game as manager of the Los Angeles Dodgers misstated, in some editions, the year in which Dave Roberts stole second base for the Boston Red Sox in the ninth inning to start their comeback from a three-games-to-none deficit in the American League Championship Series against Torre’s Yankees. It was 2004, not 2003.

A picture caption on Tuesday with an article about military-uniform-style patches for secret Pentagon programs, using information from a new book about the patches, misspelled the name of a historic patch from the Civil War. It is Kearny (for Gen. Philip Kearny), not Kearney.

A picture caption on Tuesday with an article about the understanding of mechanics in antiquity misstated which oarsmen were most effective in moving the ships called triremes. As the article noted, they were the midships oarsmen, not the end oarsmen.

An article on Wednesday about diversity among political pundits who appear on cable television coverage of the presidential campaign misspelled the given name of a Fox News anchor who is the host of a show on which Leslie Sanchez, a Mexican-American Republican strategist, recently appeared. He is Shepard Smith, not Shepherd.

Because of an editing error, an Associated Press article on Wednesday about a judge’s order that Representative Jim McDermott of Washington pay Representative John Boehner of Ohio about $1 million in legal fees in a dispute over an illegally taped telephone call misstated the nature and timing of a Supreme Court ruling on the case. The court let stand a lower court ruling that Mr. McDermott had acted improperly; it did not rule so itself. Also, the court acted in December, not last month.

Three news reports about Iraq war casualties were among the winners of the 2007 Peabody Awards. Announced on Wednesday by the Grady College of Journalism and Mass Communication at the University of Georgia, the awards are intended to honor the best in electronic media. CBS received two Peabody awards for war coverage, one for a Scott Pelley report on “60 Minutes” about the killings of civilians in the Haditha, Iraq, and another for the report by Kimberly Dozier, above, on “CBS News Sunday Morning: The Way Home” about two female veterans who lost limbs in Iraq. Ms. Dozier was wounded in Iraq in May 2006. Similarly, the ABC News correspondent Bob Woodruff, injured in Iraq in January 2006, received an award for “Wounds of War,” a series about wounded veterans. Among entertainment series, awards went to “30 Rock,” the NBC sitcom inspired by “Saturday Night Live”; “Mad Men,” the AMC drama about a 1960s advertising agency; “The Colbert Report,” the cable news satire on Comedy Central; “Project Runway,” the fashion reality show on Bravo; and “Nimrod Nation,” a d Sundance Channel documentary series. The Discovery series “Planet Earth” and PBS’s “Nature: Silence of the Bees” also received awards.

David Cook, an “American Idol” finalist, was treated at a Los Angeles hospital after Tuesday’s show for heart palpitations and high blood pressure and was released, said Nigel Lythgoe, an executive producer of “Idol.” Mr. Cook performed as usual, but skipped the rest of the show.

Sotheby’s said on Wednesday that it would postpone the sale of an early photographic print known as a photogenic drawing because some scholars now believe that the print — an image of a leaf — may have been produced much earlier than previously thought, making it the earliest existing photographic image. For many years the image was attributed to William Henry Fox Talbot, one of the fathers of photography, and was thought to have been made in 1839. But Larry J. Schaaf, an expert on Talbot’s work, questioned that attribution in an essay in the catalog for the photography auction, which will still be held on Monday but without the leaf image, above. Mr. Schaaf wrote that there is evidence to suggest that the work titled “Leaf” — made by placing a leaf on photosensitive paper exposed to light — could have been created by the early photographic experimenters Thomas Wedgwood, James Watt or Humphry Davy. They are known to have produced photogenic drawings, also called photograms, as early as the 1790s, though no examples have ever been found. Denise Bethel, director of Sotheby’s photograph department, said the auction house and the image’s owner, an investment firm called the Quillan Company, had decided to postpone the sale of the print indefinitely until more research could be done.

American Ballet Theater settled an age-discrimination case brought on behalf of a trumpet player in its orchestra, agreeing to give him $18,277 in back pay, but making no admission of wrongdoing. The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission sued the company after the player, Henry Nowak, was released in 2005 at age 74. The commission said that his playing had never been criticized and that a conductor had been heard to say it was time for the orchestra’s older players to go, including Mr. Nowak. Ballet Theater agreed not to discriminate on the basis of age or to retaliate against those who make age-discrimination complaints, the commission said in announcing the settlement late Tuesday. It also agreed to provide antidiscrimination training to senior staff members, the commission said.

This week on the Billboard charts one act from MTV’s “Making the Band” supplants another for the No. 1 album, and Mariah Carey and Madonna both nudged past Elvis Presley for historical standings on the singles chart. In a week busy with new albums, the all-male Day26 reached No. 1 with its self-titled debut, selling 190,000 copies, Nielsen SoundScan reported, bumping Danity Kane — the all-female “Making the Band” group that topped last week’s chart — to No. 4, with 89,000. (Both were released by Bad Boy/Atlantic.) Panic at the Disco’s “Pretty. Odd.” (Fueled by Ramen/Atlantic) moved 139,000 to reach No. 2. Counting Crows’ “Saturday Nights & Sunday Mornings” (Geffen) is No. 3 with 106,000, and the Raconteurs sold 42,000 copies of “Consolers of the Lonely” (Third Man/Warner Brothers) for No. 7. ... Ms. Carey’s “Touch My Body” becomes her 18th No. 1 single; only the Beatles have more, with 20. Madonna’s new “4 Minutes,” at No. 3, becomes her 37th single in the Top 10, beating Presley’s record for the most Top 10 songs.

Fox trounced its competitors Tuesday thanks to the combination of “American Idol” and a strong showing for the start of “Hell’s Kitchen,” with Gordon Ramsay, left. Nielsen estimated that the fourth season premiere of the reality cooking show drew 12.6 million viewers, a considerable improvement over the 8.4 million the series averaged last summer. That 9 p.m. show also delivered the night’s second-highest ratings among adults 18 to 49, outpacing a direct competitor, the results episode of “Dancing With the Stars,” even though that ABC show delivered more total viewers in the hour (16.9 million). Fox’s “American Idol,” meanwhile, achieved the top ratings over all with 25.2 million viewers at 8 p.m. ABC ranked second in total viewers, but fourth among the 18-to-49 set behind CBS and NBC, which tied for second. CBS led the 10 p.m. hour with “CSI: Miami” (14.3 million), easily outperforming ABC’s Barbara Walters special “Live to be 150 ... Can You Do It?” (10.2 million).

Leaders of the Screen Actors Guild said on Tuesday evening that they had agreed to open formal contract talks on April 15 with representatives of Hollywood’s movie and television companies. The current contract for the 120,000-member actors’ union expires on June 30, and much of the entertainment industry, hoping to avoid a strike similar to a three-month walkout by writers that began in November, has been eager for bargaining to begin. Last weekend the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists, which has bargained jointly with the guild in the past, broke off its alliance and said it, too, expected to begin negotiating a new contract on its own soon.

United Airlines temporarily grounded 11 percent of its fleet and canceled 31 flights Wednesday while it tested dozens of Boeing 777s to make sure components of a cargo fire suppression system were operating effectively. The inspections are the latest to affect the United States airline industry and its passengers. Other carriers have taken similar actions in recent weeks as carriers review their maintenance records in an atmosphere of increased regulatory scrutiny.

WINTERTHUR is full of lessons like these on planting bulbs and low-growing perennials beneath trees and shrubs: Ferns and woodland phlox, planted in drifts among snowdrops and narcissus, will not appear when the early bulbs are blooming, but rather just in time to cover up fading foliage and welcome summer with a soft carpet of green and blue.

An Associated Press report in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column on March 24 about a suit filed by lawyers for the Beatles to block distribution of recordings of the band in Hamburg in 1962 referred incorrectly to the recordings and misstated the history of Ringo Starr's performances with the band. They were made in December 1962, four months after Mr. Starr joined the Beatles; thus they were not made during his first performance with the band.

BONJEAN--Emile. The Trustees and staff of Greentree Foundation will always remember Emile with deep respect, profound gratitude, and abiding affection. He was the indispensable person in the transformation of Greentree from a private home to a unique, welcoming environment in which visitors from around the world came to negotiate agreements and discuss issues of peace, social justice, and international cooperation. Through his extraordinary dedication, attention to detail, and exacting standards, he created an atmosphere conducive to conversation in which visitors sought greater understanding of critical global issues and their own common humanity. This remarkable man was a perfectionist who demanded much of himself and no less of those who worked with him. He had the uncommon ability to make visitors from all over the world immediately feel welcome and at ease. He was the embodiment of Greentree and his example, standards, and spirit will continue to guide us for years to come. All who knew him will always remember the indelible image of Emile opening the front door, smiling, extending his hand in friendship, and saying ''welcome to Greentree.'' For further information please contact Ms. Nicole Ward at Greentree Foundation (212)888-7755.

SALLY BOWLES had nothing on the decadent flappers, modern aesthetes and dandies fanning out their plumage at the Pussycat Lounge in Manhattan last week. The occasion, Dances of Vice, was part celebration of dark Edwardiana and part homage to the Weimar era, drawing devotees of fancy dress tricked out in spit curls, fishnets and spats. The entertainment at these monthly cabaret nights consists of the music -- a medley of tango, jazz and blues -- but mostly in checking out one's fellow guests.

SOME swimmers joke that the only way to fight the boredom of laps is to get a good song stuck in their heads. The first generation of waterproof MP3 players didn't always offer sweet distraction, because the devices held too few songs and sometimes shorted out in water. Now that second-generation MP3 players offer better technology, fitness swimmers can listen to Maroon 5 and the Bravery instead of recreating a song in their heads.

This week on the Billboard charts one act from MTV's ''Making the Band'' supplants another for the No. 1 album, and Mariah Carey and Madonna both nudged past Elvis Presley for historical standings on the singles chart. In a week busy with new albums, the all-male Day26 reached No. 1 with its self-titled debut, selling 190,000 copies, Nielsen SoundScan reported, bumping Danity Kane -- the all-female ''Making the Band'' group that topped last week's chart -- to No. 4, with 89,000. (Both were released by Bad Boy/Atlantic.) Panic at the Disco's ''Pretty. Odd.'' (Fueled by Ramen/Atlantic) moved 139,000 to reach No. 2. Counting Crows' ''Saturday Nights & Sunday Mornings'' (Geffen) is No. 3 with 106,000, and the Raconteurs sold 42,000 copies of ''Consolers of the Lonely'' (Third Man/Warner Brothers) for No. 7. ... Ms. Carey's ''Touch My Body'' becomes her 18th No. 1 single; only the Beatles have more, with 20. Madonna's new ''4 Minutes,'' at No. 3, becomes her 37th single in the Top 10, beating Presley's record for the most Top 10 songs.

Leaders of the Screen Actors Guild said on Tuesday evening that they had agreed to open formal contract talks on April 15 with representatives of Hollywood's movie and television companies. The current contract for the 120,000-member actors' union expires on June 30, and much of the entertainment industry, hoping to avoid a strike similar to a three-month walkout by writers that began in November, has been eager for bargaining to begin. Last weekend the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists, which has bargained jointly with the guild in the past, broke off its alliance and said it, too, expected to begin negotiating a new contract on its own soon.

Three news reports about Iraq war casualties were among the winners of the 2007 Peabody Awards. Announced on Wednesday by the Grady College of Journalism and Mass Communication at the University of Georgia, the awards are intended to honor the best in electronic media. CBS received two Peabody awards for war coverage, one for a Scott Pelley report on ''60 Minutes'' about the killings of civilians in the Haditha, Iraq, and another for the report by Kimberly Dozier, above, on ''CBS News Sunday Morning: The Way Home'' about two female veterans who lost limbs in Iraq. Ms. Dozier was wounded in Iraq in May 2006. Similarly, the ABC News correspondent Bob Woodruff, injured in Iraq in January 2006, received an award for ''Wounds of War,'' a series about wounded veterans. Among entertainment series, awards went to ''30 Rock,'' the NBC sitcom inspired by ''Saturday Night Live''; ''Mad Men,'' the AMC drama about a 1960s advertising agency; ''The Colbert Report,'' the cable news satire on Comedy Central; ''Project Runway,'' the fashion reality show on Bravo; and ''Nimrod Nation,'' a d Sundance Channel documentary series. The Discovery series ''Planet Earth'' and PBS's ''Nature: Silence of the Bees'' also received awards.

It became clear this week in Pennsylvania that Senator Barack Obama is not much of a bowler (cable television has run scenes of his gutter balls all week). But basketball -- ah, that's another matter, or so says Mr. Obama. His latest campaign gimmick is meant to show off those hoops skills in a match-off with teenage supporters, while also engaging Indiana voters, whose primary is May 6. Here's the plan: High school students who will turn 18 before the November election are being urged to register 20 others to vote. One of the student organizers will then be chosen and allowed to pick two friends to play on their home court against Mr. Obama when he makes a swing through Indiana, a hotbed of hoops, later this month.

Angus Fairhurst, one of the group known as Young British Artists, or Y.B.A.'s, who stirred up the art scene in London and beyond in the 1990s, died on Saturday in Scotland. He was 41 and lived in London. He committed suicide while walking in a remote area, according to an announcement by Bolton & Quinn, a public relations agency in London; no further details were given.

For someone supposedly in a heap of trouble, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton is looking pretty relaxed these days. She hopped out of her motorcade at the Scranton-Wilkes-Barre airport on Tuesday afternoon, chatted with some residents and then took a relatively long stroll across the tarmac to her plane. The sun was out for the first time in days. Her bright fuchsia jacket -- gone was the dark coat of winter -- drew the eye, and she gave a jaunty nod as she bounded up the stairs of her plane.

PRAN--Dith. The Board of Directors, Overseers and staff of the International Rescue Committee are saddened by the death of Dith Pran, a member of our board of directors from 1987 to 1996. Like many others around the world, we were inspired by Dith Pran's personal courage in surviving Cambodia's Killing Fields and by his tireless efforts to protect the rights of his people and to ensure that the Cambodian genocide not be forgotten. A refugee himself, Pran worked for the cause of refugees everywhere, through the IRC and as a goodwill ambassador for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to family and loved ones. Alan Batkin and Jonathan Wiesner, Co-Chairs of the Board. Tom Brokaw and Maureen White, Co-Chairs, IRC Overseers. George Rupp, President.

The fallout over the endorsement of Senator Barack Obama by Gov. Bill Richardson of New Mexico continues, with The San Francisco Chronicle reporting Wednesday that mention of it set off a red-faced, finger-wagging tirade from former President Bill Clinton on Sunday. According to The Chronicle, the eruption occurred behind the scenes at the California Democratic convention, during a private meeting between Mr. Clinton and about 15 superdelegates. When Rachel Binah, a former Richardson delegate who now supports Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, brought up the Richardson endorsement, Mr. Clinton grew red with anger.

An Associated Press report in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column on March 24 about a suit filed by lawyers for the Beatles to block distribution of recordings of the band in Hamburg in 1962 referred incorrectly to the recordings and misstated the history of Ringo Starr's performances with the band. They were made in December 1962, four months after Mr. Starr joined the Beatles; thus they were not made during his first performance with the band.

Ubiquitous jazz and cabaret obsessed man-abouttown who nurtured ''talent'', lived to serve them and while doing so, savored good music, good laughs, good wines, devouring every day of his life with gusto...left this week for another venue, to visit with old friends in smart clubs and funky, smoky jazz joints without us. Jerry, you're in our hearts with every toast we make, in every trip we plan (and never take), in every laugh, guffaw and giggle that make us shake. An obituary last Thursday about the actor Richard Widmark referred incorrectly to the genesis of the movie ''Cheyenne Autumn'' and misstated other aspects of his work. The film, in which he played an Army captain, was suggested by the 1953 book ''Cheyenne Autumn,'' by Mari Sandoz, according to the film's credits; it was not based directly on Mr. Widmark's research. Also, the film was released in 1964 -- not 1963 -- as an accompanying picture caption correctly noted. In the film ''Panic in the Streets,'' the epidemic confronting a public-health doctor played by Mr. Widmark was pneumonic, not bubonic, plague. In ''Kiss of Death,'' the character played by Mildred Dunnock, who is bound to her wheelchair and pushed down a flight of stairs by an ex-convict played by Mr. Widmark, is the mother of an underworld informer -- not the mother of an informer played by Victor Mature. The obituary also omitted two survivors: a stepson, Marc Weisgal, and a stepdaughter, Amy Fonda Ivers.

MELTZER--Cecile. Born to Jacob and Rebecca Meltzer on April 16th, 1937 in the Bronx, NY, Cecile Meltzer died peacefully in her sleep on the morning of March 25th after a long illness. A vibrant, creative woman, she will be sorely missed. Cecile was a graduate of the City College of New York, and spent most of her years working in New York City until she became a permanent resident of Woodstock, where she pursued a variety of artistic and craft endeavors and was an active member of the community since 1976. Cecile is survived by her loving and beloved identical twin sister Betty, with whom she shared her life and passions. She is also survived by her devoted sisters and brothers-in-law Miriam and Toby Olson, and Evelyn and Melvin Stark, as well as four nieces and nephews and their children. Donations in Cecile's name may be sent in behalf of her late niece (Marcia Stark Scholarship Fund, EAC Development Programs, 382 Main St., Port Washington, NY 11050). A memorial gathering is planned for Woodstock, NY in the early Spring.

LANG--Roger, The Board and Staff of The New York Landmarks Conservancy mourn the death of Roger Lang, our Director of Community Programs and Services for the past 16 years. Roger's knowledge of architecture, passion for preservation, and eloquent writing and speech, earned him wide respect. He was the Conservancy's voice at the Landmarks Commission, before the City Council, and in numerous meetings with sister organizations. Roger was instrumental in the Landmarks Conservancy's efforts to stabilize and save the South Side of Ellis Island. He was a trusted advisor to Save Ellis Island, Inc., St. Bartholomew's Church, the Jay Heritage Center in Rye, and other institutions. He also organized the Conservancy's annual Lucy G. Moses Preservation Awards and relished honoring preservation accomplishments. A popular Adjunct Professor at the University of Vermont and Boston University and Visiting Lecturer at Columbia University, Harvard Graduate School of Design, Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Pratt Institute, Roger instilled countless students with a dedication to the profession he loved. Roger's love of preservation was matched by his love of people. His wit and joy at living made him more than a colleague. He was a thoughtful and engaging friend. Roger's legacy is found in the architectural treasures he defended, protected and preserved and the numerous lives he touched. The family is planning a public memorial to be announced at a later date. Frank J. Sciame, Jr., Chair Peg Breen, President.

HARRIS--Joanna Primrose Cochrane, of New York, NY and Port Royal, Nova Scotia, died in New York at the age of 86 on March 31, 2008. She was predeceased by her husband of 49 years, George DeLancey Harris, Jr., who passed away only three months earlier. She is survived by their son, James Harris, and her brother-inlaw, Thomas L. Harris. Joanna was born and raised in London, England, the third child of Frank Cochrane and Eve Titheradge, both of whom were actors on the London stage. Joanna was a writer and poet, who published several childrens books and a collection of poetry. After serving with the Czech Relief Fund during WWII, she moved to New York in 1952, working as a junior editor at G. Putnam and Sons and CBS News, and appearing as a singer on the Arthur Godfrey Show in 1953. Joanna was a long-time member of the Louise Bogan Poetry Society, and appeared in Oprah Winfrey's ''O'' Magazine in May 2002 in a photographic essay entitled, ''Silver Girls.'' Spending her summers in Nova Scotia, and her winters in New York, Joanna was blessed to have, as she put it, ''the best of both worlds,'' and a remarkable circle of friends in both locales. She will be interred, along side her recently-departed husband, in the Harris family plot at Woodlawn Cemetery, in Annapolis Royal, Nova Scotia. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in her memory to the Coalition for the Homeless. A memorial gathering will be held in early May.

REICH--Edward Stuart, age 71, of New York City and Poughkeepsie, passed away on Monday, March 31, 2008. Beloved husband of Arlene, devoted father of Dawne, Heidi and Evan. Adored grandfather of Logan. Son of the late Herman and the late Frances Reich. He held the following positions at various times in his career: President of the Brooklyn Bar Association, Vice-President of the New York State Bar Association, President of the Lawyers Torah Club, Co-chair of the MIT Parents Fund, Parliamentarian Emeritus of the New York State Trial Lawyers Association and Fellow of the American Bar Foundation. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to the Jewish National Fund of Greater New York.

It was the $2 bill that told Myrta Gschaar what she did not really want to know with such certainty: that her husband had been killed at the World Trade Center on Sept. 11, 2001.Long after the 9/11 attack, Mrs. Gschaar had no tangible evidence of the death of her husband, Robert J. Gschaar, who worked at the Aon insurance company. He simply disappeared after calling her Tuesday morning to say that there had been an accident in the north tower. He was safe in the south tower, he told her, and would call again once he reached the street. But no second call ever came.

Updated, 4:55 p.m. |A city-financed program created to provide mortgage counseling services appointed its first executive director this week as local leaders continue to combat the foreclosure crisis hitting New York and nationwide. The Center for New York City Neighborhoods, which was announced by the mayor in December, will be headed by Michael Hickey, the current vice president for community development for Deutsche Bank.One of every 40 homes with a mortgage in New York City had a foreclosure filing as of the end of September 2007, more than twice the rate for the rest of New York State. While that is not as bad as high foreclosure rates as other cities across the country, individual boroughs are being hit with a wave of foreclosures.

At the start of his run for the presidency, Barack Obama would explain the positive reaction he was getting from admirers by saying "this is more about you than about me." Now that Mr. Obama is the front-running Democratic candidate, an in-depth look at how voters are reacting to him - and the reasons for those reactions - lends considerable credence to his characterization of public opinion. It turns out, however, that the "it's about you" phenomenon is a little broader than the Mr. Obama might have imagined. It pertains not only to reasons for liking and supporting him, but is also relevant to reasons for disliking him and for supporting Hillary Clinton.

This long weekend marks Ching Ming, a significant Chinese festival, but one that few tourists would notice unless they happened to see people burning offerings on the sidewalk. It is a private observance held mostly at home shrines, ancestral villages or cemeteries, as the living give gifts of food and fresh flowers to the dead, and sweep and clean their graves. You may also see stands selling paper replicas of everything from yachts and cars to mobiles and MP3 players. In modern, materialistic Hong Kong, these can be burned as offerings, too, in case your ancestor would like having a new Mercedes or Motorola in the afterlife. A traditionalist would warn you against buying one as a kitsch souvenir, though.

While the overwhelming dissatisfaction of Americans on the "direction" of the country in the latest New York Times/CBS poll would seem to bode well for the Democratic nominee, a less-noticed section of the data has a more ambiguous message for the party's frontrunner: "Senator Barack Obama's support among Democrats nationally has softened over the last month - particularly among men and upper-income voters - as voters have taken a slightly less positive view of him than they did after his burst of victories in February," report Adam Nagourney and Megan Thee of The Times. "The survey suggests that Mr. Obama, the Illinois Democrat, may have been at something of a peak in February, propelled by a string of primary and caucus victories over Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton of New York, and that perceptions of him are settling down."

It's hard to bring a fresh perspective to photographic portraiture, but Paul Mpagi Sepuya proves that sometimes the simplest approach yields the most rewarding results. His book, "Beloved Object & Amorous Subject, Revisited," (Envoy) is straightforward enough: a series of shirtless young men - Sepuya's friends, boyfriends and collaborators - pose deadpan against a plain white wall in his bedroom. The images are technically impeccable, but it is the subtle changes in mood and expression that draw us in: who exactly are these guys, and why do we care?

Yuri Foreman, the North American Boxing Federation light middleweight champion who is also studying to become an Orthodox rabbi, remained undefeated by unanimously outpointing Saul Román of Mexico in a dazzling 10-round title defense at Aviator Sports Complex in Brooklyn. Foreman (25-0) outboxed the plodding Román (24-5, 20 knockouts). The judges scored the bout in favor of Foreman, 98-92, 98-92, 97-93.

Adam Scott, the defending champion, took advantage of placid early conditions to shoot a course-record nine-under-par 63 to earn a share of the lead at the PGA’s Houston Open in Humble, Tex. Johnson Wagner matched Scott late in the day, and Charley Hoffman was two strokes behind the leaders. Scott, who has had a fever and swollen glands around his throat since arriving in Houston, went straight to the clubhouse for medical treatment after his round.

Jacksonville Jaguars Coach Jack Del Rio signed a five-year contract extension, a reward for winning his first playoff game. Del Rio’s salary was not disclosed, but it was believed to be a significant jump from the original five-year, $6.5 million contract he signed in 2003.

Rich Rodriguez may present evidence to try to prove his claim he was fraudulently induced to sign a coaching contract with West Virginia that included a $4 million buyout clause he now refuses to pay. Monongalia County Circuit Judge Robert Stone granted key victories for both sides in a two-hour pretrial hearing. Rodriguez was not present at the hearing. Rodriguez resigned in December after seven seasons with the Mountaineers to take the coaching job at Michigan.

Colonel John, the winner of three of five starts and second in the other two races, will start from the No. 5 post position in Saturday’s Santa Anita Derby. Colonel John, a Tiznow colt, was made the early 2-1 favorite in the one-and-one-eighth-mile Santa Anita, which drew a field of 11. El Gato Malo will start from the No. 8 post and was the second choice at 5-2.

Mino Auletta, an Italian lawyer, was elected the president of the Court of Arbitration for Sport, defeating the former World Anti-Doping Agency chief Dick Pound. Auletta, the acting president of the court, said by telephone from Monaco that he received a majority of the votes at a meeting of the court’s governing body. Auletta will oversee the appointment of arbitrators for the sports world’s top appeals body.
The remains of an early Mormon leader killed 151 years ago in Arkansas can be disinterred and moved to Utah for burial as long as other grave sites are not disturbed, a judge has ruled.

A Web site that matches roommates can be sued for violating fair housing laws by helping users describe their preferences, an expanded panel of the federal appeals court in San Francisco ruled. Chief Judge Alex Kozinski, joined by seven judges, ruled that the site, Roommates.com, was not protected by a 1996 federal law that gave immunity to Internet service providers that transmit unlawful materials supplied by others, because the site may have participated in unlawful conduct by asking users for information through a series of menus. Judge M. Margaret McKeown, dissenting with two other judges, said the decision “threatens to chill the robust development of the Internet.”.

Two gang-affiliated inmates rushed and stabbed three guards at a state prison in Southern California, officials said. The victims, two sergeants and an officer, were stable at hospitals, said Terry Thornton, a spokeswoman for the Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation. All state prisons were locked down as a precaution after the stabbing at the California Correctional Institution in Tehachapi, Ms. Thornton said. The attackers rushed the guards in an office on the general population yard, she said, and two weapons were recovered. State prisons will remain locked down until the corrections staff can determine whether the stabbing was an isolated incident, Ms. Thornton said.

A plane carrying 19 people crashed near Benzdorp, a mining village along the border with French Guiana, killing everyone on board. Civil aviation authorities said on Surinamese radio that the twin-engine Antonov-AN28 operated by a local carrier, Blue Wing Airlines, descended to land at Benzdorp but veered upward to avoid a plane on the landing strip and crashed after hitting a tree.

Ford’s marketing campaign is recruiting Ford owners to invite friends, relatives, neighbors and co-workers into their homes this weekend and talk up their cars.

A NATO patrol shot at a vehicle and killed one civilian in southern Afghanistan, NATO officials said. The patrol shot at the fast-approaching vehicle in Kandahar Province after its driver did not heed soldiers’ warnings to stop, the alliance said in a statement. Three other civilians were wounded, it said. NATO said an investigation into the incident had begun.

In the latest blow against Mexican drug traffickers, authorities seized $6 million and arrested six men who the police say are members of the Zetas drug gang in Nuevo Laredo, just across the border from Texas. The men were guarding eight suitcases stuffed with cash when federal agents arrested them, the attorney general’s office said in a bulletin. The Zetas are the armed enforcers of the Gulf Cartel, which controls the border crossings into south Texas. Greek and Turkish Cypriots tore down the Ledra Street crossing, which has kept the island’s communities divided for decades. Hundreds of people watched the event; Cypriots also lined up (left) to cross once the checkpoint was opened. Although Turkish Cypriots have opened five other checkpoints in recent years, the Ledra Street crossing was considered especially symbolic because it sat in the heart of the island’s divided capital, Nicosia. Both sides agreed last month to restart talks on uniting the island, the first serious effort in two years to erase the 1974 division.

An obituary on Tuesday about Robert F. Goheen, a former president of Princeton, misspelled the name of his birthplace in India. It is Vengurla, not Venguria. Because of an editing error, the obituary misstated the timing of the answer he gave — “Fire the football coach” — when the Rev. Theodore Hesburgh, then the president of Notre Dame, asked how his university could get the reputation for scholarship that Princeton had. The remark was made early in Father Hesburgh’s 35-year tenure as president, which began in 1952; it was not made in 1987 (The Times reported the remark in an article that year). And the obituary misstated the year that Mr. Goheen became director of the Woodrow Wilson Fellowships. It was 1953, not 1963.

An article on Monday about the release of transcripts of secretly recorded conversations in advance of the sentencing of Agron Abdullahu, one of six men arrested after the authorities uncovered what they said was a plot to kill soldiers at the Fort Dix Army base in New Jersey, referred incompletely to the government’s case against him. As the article noted, he pleaded guilty last October to a charge of conspiring to provide firearms and ammunition to illegal aliens. That was a lesser charge than the initial charge he faced: aiding and abetting the illegal possession of firearms by illegal aliens.

The DealBook column in the special DealBook section on Wednesday, about local decision-making in an increasingly interconnected business world, referred imprecisely to a secret conference call held with the leaders of the world’s biggest financial firms about the sale of Bear Stearns to JPMorgan Chase. The call began just after JPMorgan’s announcement of the deal, not just before. And the call was led by the president of the New York Fed, Timothy F. Geithner, and Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. — not by Ben S. Bernanke, the Fed chairman.

A film review last Friday about “Chapter 27,” a portrait of John Lennon’s killer, Mark David Chapman, referred incorrectly to the movie’s depiction of an encounter between Mr. Chapman and Lennon’s son Sean and the character who introduces them. The encounter did in fact happen; it was not one of the film’s “silly flights of fancy.” And the character, a Beatles fan named Jude played by Lindsay Lohan, is based on a real person; the character is not fictional.

A dance review on March 18 about the Kazuko Hirabayashi Dance Theater, at the Merce Cunningham Studio, omitted the designer of the projections seen during “Guernica” and referred incorrectly to the program. She is June Kosloff, and she was in fact credited on the program.

A music review on Tuesday about the soprano Kate Royal, at the Frick Collection, omitted part of the title of one song she performed, by Enrique Granados, and misspelled part of the title of another, by Joaquín Rodrigo. The Granados song is “Quejas, o la Maja y el Ruiseñor” (the review omitted the “y”). The Rodrigo song is “Vos me matásteis,” not “matésteis.”.

A headline on a report in the World Briefing column on Tuesday about a posthumous Medal of Honor for Michael A. Monsoor, a member of the Navy Seals who threw himself on a grenade in Iraq to save his colleagues, misstated his rank. He was a petty officer second class; he was not a commissioned “Navy Officer.” Because of an editing error, the report also misstated the number of people who have received the honor since the beginning of the Afghanistan and Iraq wars. Petty Officer Monsoor became the fourth, not the fifth.

GATTI--Joseph, Jr. Joe Gatti was born on April 12, 1929 in New York City, New York and died as a result of complications of prostate cancer, on April 2, at the age of 78. After he graduated from Columbus High School in the Bronx, Joe attended the New York Maritime Academy at Fort Schuyler, graduating with a B.S. in Engineering. He served as First Lieutenant in the U.S. Navy and the U.S. Air Force, responsible for managing delivery of supplies to U.S. troops stationed in Europe and serving as a navigator in Strategic Air Command (SAC), before retiring into civilian life. Joe worked briefly at Gatti & Lopez, a family business, then entered the financial world as a stock broker for Merrill Lynch in 1963. Over the next 45 years, he held management positions at many of the top investment banks and financial companies in New York, including Merrill Lynch, Hornblower, Weeks, Hemphill & Noyes (where he was their youngest partner), Oppenheimer, Inc., and most recently Spencer Trask, Inc. Much of his work had to do with finding investors for new technologies and new products. Joe's first love was his family. He is survived by his wife of 48 years, Anne Hawkins Gatti, his daughters, Madeline Gatti, Barbara Gatti Mayer, Ph.D., and Elizabeth Gatti; their spouses, Steven Tappen, James Mayer, M.D., and Ken Larson, respectively; his three grandchildren, Morgan Paige Mayer, Ursula Larson, and Vincent Larson; and his brother John George Gatti, his sister Sr. Patricia Gatti, and many friends. He loved to travel, explore new places and to connect with friends, old and new. We will miss his lovely flowers and vegetable garden that he tended each spring and summer. Anne wishes to express her gratitude to friends and others who have helped and supported them throughout the years. Contributions may be provided in his memory to Hope in Bloom, 1001 Watertown Street, West Newton, MA, 02465-2145 or hopeinbloom.org to create gardens for those recovering from breast cancer. Viewing hours will be held on Sunday April 6 from 2-5pm at BallardDurand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Avenue in White Plains, New York, 10601. A Funeral Service will be held on Monday April 7 at 10am at Sacred Heart Church on Lawton Avenue at Central Avenue in Hartsdale, New York, 10530. Burial to follow at Calverton National Cemetery, Calverton, NY.

The Japanese police arrested a United States Navy seaman suspected of killing and robbing a taxi driver, taking him into custody from an American naval base in Yokosuka, south of Tokyo. In the latest case involving a United States serviceman in Japan, the sailor, identified by the Japanese police as Olatunbosun Ugbogu, 22, reportedly admitted to the killing during a day of interrogation by the police at the base. According to Japanese news reports citing the police, Mr. Ugbogu is suspected of stabbing the taxi driver, Masaaki Takahashi, 61, in the neck with a kitchen knife on the night of March 19 and running off without paying a $170 fare. Mr. Ugbogu, a Nigerian citizen, was being sought for desertion at the time of the killing, according to American and Japanese officials.

A Chinese public fund has been building a stake in the French oil major Total since the end of 2007, the company confirmed on Thursday. Total declined to say whether the fund was China Investment Corporation, the $200 billion sovereign wealth fund that has taken stakes in the American private equity firm Blackstone Group and the investment bank Morgan Stanley.

Wei Wei, visiting New York from the Michael Schultz Gallery in Beijing, showed up on Tuesday morning at the blocklong Barnes & Noble on the Avenue of the Americas, between 21st and 22nd Streets, in the old Ladies' Mile shopping district. ATLANTA SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA While at the helm of the Brooklyn Philharmonic and since becoming music director of the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra in 2001, the energetic conductor Robert Spano, above, has championed contemporary composers, including Osvaldo Golijov, Jennifer Higdon, Michael Gandolfi and Christopher Theofanidis, promoting their works in concerts and recordings. On Saturday Mr. Spano will lead the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra, as well as the ensemble's chorus (directed by Norman Mackenzie, Robert Shaw's successor), in the New York premiere of Mr. Theofanidis's ''Here and Now.''

'SYNESTHESIA' Do kids today even play Telephone? Maybe not, but experimental arts groups do. ''Synesthesia,'' a work conceived and produced by Electric Pear Productions, a two-year-old multimedia theater group, is based on that childhood game. For the second year, Melanie Sylvan and Ashlin Halfnight, founders of Electric Pear, have brought together a dozen artists from various genres, including theater, music, dance, art, comedy and spoken word. Over five and a half months, each had two weeks to create a work based on the preceding artist's piece. The jumping-off point for the entire process was a message in a fortune cookie: ''New people will bring you new realizations, especially about big issues.'' That sentence was turned into a 10-minute short by the filmmaker Gregory Stuart Edwards, who handed it over to the writer Damian Lanigan, who created a monologue based on it, which went to the photographer Peter Hapak, and so on.

This four-year-old house built by its owner, a stonemason, is on 1.23 acres bordering the Monongahela National Forest. 'PIGS, BEARS AND BILLY GOATS GRUFF' To children a kitchen is much more than a place for cooking and eating. Forks and spoons double as percussion instruments; pans serve as warriors' helmets; a tabletop is a cottage roof. Where grown-ups see only mealtime, the young see playtime. But the adults of the Patch Theater Company have no such limited vision. Now presenting ''Pigs, Bears and Billy Goats Gruff,'' an adaptation of four traditional tales at the New Victory Theater, this Australian troupe performs on a set that is essentially a kitchen, with a plain table and chairs, French doors and a big metal pot on the shelf. But it doesn't stay a kitchen for long. The chairs stand in as houses in ''The Three Little Pigs''; the table becomes the planks of an old bridge in ''The Three Billy Goats Gruff''; the gleaming pot is transformed into a queen's crown in ''The Three Feathers.'' (Conveniently, these objects also play themselves in ''Goldilocks and the Three Bears.'') The show may not have the production values of its neighbor ''The Lion King,'' but it too creates a world of animals, some good, some not, whose fortunes unfold across savannas created only in the imagination.
