BONJEAN--Emile. The Trustees and staff of Greentree Foundation will always remember Emile with deep respect, profound gratitude, and abiding affection. He was the indispensable person in the transformation of Greentree from a private home to a unique, welcoming environment in which visitors from around the world came to negotiate agreements and discuss issues of peace, social justice, and international cooperation. Through his extraordinary dedication, attention to detail, and exacting standards, he created an atmosphere conducive to conversation in which visitors sought greater understanding of critical global issues and their own common humanity. This remarkable man was a perfectionist who demanded much of himself and no less of those who worked with him. He had the uncommon ability to make visitors from all over the world immediately feel welcome and at ease. He was the embodiment of Greentree and his example, standards, and spirit will continue to guide us for years to come. All who knew him will always remember the indelible image of Emile opening the front door, smiling, extending his hand in friendship, and saying ''welcome to Greentree.'' For further information please contact Ms. Nicole Ward at Greentree Foundation (212)888-7755.

FOR CHILDREN 'THE BAD BOY OF AMERICAN MUSIC' (Sunday) If that title doesn't pique interest, nothing will. This concert, the last of the season in the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center's Meet the Music! series for ages 6 and older, will focus on George Antheil (1900-1950), who liked to emulate machines in his works and loved to rebel against his elders. HIRAM--A. (Tony) Bingham, the eldest son of 11 children, was born September 24th, 1935 in London, England to Rose and Hiram Bingham, a US Vice Consultant. Tony's early childhood years included living in Marseilles, France and Buenos Aires, Argentina, before the family finally settled in Salem, CT. He attended the Groton School and later graduated from Yale University. After a three year stint as an Air Force officer stationed in Wurzburg, Germany, he acquired his law degree from Columbia Law School. He then joined the Wall Street law firm Sherman & Sterling before going on to an international business career in several emerging industries. In 1977 he joined Caithness Energy, where he became its President, building the business together with his partners into a leading private investment firm in the renewable energy sector. In 1995 he founded Davenport Resources, a private equity firm and in 1997 founded Davenport Power, a renewable energy developer. In 2008 he launched the 120 MW Newberry Geothermal Project. Throughout his life, he studied and supported anthroposophical endeavors, taking particular interest in Waldorf education and biodynamic farming. He is survived by his loving wife of 42 years, Anne Elizabeth, three children and four grandchildren. We all will miss this exceptional Renaissance man. In lieu of flowers, gifts can be given in his memory to: Waldorf Schools Fund. Mail to: Gloria Kemp, 1124 Route 21 Ghent, NY 12075. Tel. 518672-4844.

HOROWITZ--Harry, on April 3, 2008. Passed away soon after celebrating his 92nd birthday. He was surrounded by his loving wife of 62 years, Dorothy (Dall) and by family and friends. Harry had two loves, music and Dorothy. Mr. Horowitz had been a Math and Science teacher at Stevens Institute. However, for most of his teaching career he was a talented Music teacher; Assistant Principal; an inspiring conductor of the Orchestra and Band at Joseph Pulitzer (145 Middle School). He was also the pianist for the All City Chorus. His love of music resonates in the hearts of his dear family, admiring friends, attentive aides and caring nurses and doctors and students whom he inspired to become musicians, and of course his dear wife. South, NY on Monday April 6th from 7-9pm; and Tuesday April 7, from 3-5pm. A memorial service is to be announced.

DAVID DORFMAN AND DAN FROOT Almost 20 years ago the choreographer David Dorfman, above right, and the jazz musician and performance artist Dan Froot, left, made a dance called ''Horn.'' Dressed in kilts and not much else, they muscled through exhausting dance maneuvers, all the while playing saxophones. This weekend they will reprise ''Horn'' (also performing ''Bull,'' from 1994, and a new work, ''Wolf''), and audiences will have the rare treat of seeing how such a duet might age -- something its creators are still figuring out themselves. ''Even thinking about 47- and 50-year-old bodies doing what 30-year-old bodies made up,'' Mr. Froot said, ''even that really gives one pause.'' Laughing, Mr. Dorfman corrected his age to 52. ''I feel a little bit of boyishness coming out,'' he added, along with ''the challenge of 'Wow, can we really get through these pieces?' ''

BASIL TWIST In most cases it's safe to say that actual people outrank puppets as performers. If, however, the strings are being pulled by the third-generation master puppeteer Basil Twist, all bets are off. His ''Dogugaeshi,'' seen several years ago at Japan Society, ranks among the most magically charged experiences I've ever had in a theater. For others, Mr. Twist's version of the ballet ''Petrushka'' fits this bill; luckily for those of us who missed it at its Lincoln Center premiere seven years ago, the institution has brought it back for another limited run, as part of the Stravinsky Onstage series. Stravinsky's score is performed in the fittingly delicate two-piano version by the Russian identical twins Julia and Irina Elkina; they begin the show with his Sonata for Two Pianos. Normally, of course, the hero, Petrushka, is played by a person; half the fun is in seeing how this dancer morphs into a puppet, albeit one who yearns to experience the richness of human emotion. What's wondrous about Mr. Twist's art (and especially poignant, given the subject matter) is to see how marvelously real his Petrushka is, along with his rival, the Moor, and the object of his ardor, the Ballerina (above, with Petrushka).

Forget our odd tendency to keep big dogs in small apartments. Or the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's ban on dogs on the subway unless they are ''enclosed in a container and carried in a manner which would not annoy other passengers'' (service animals and police dogs are excepted). Or the fact that taxi drivers are not required to allow dogs to ride along with their owners. Or the perennial brouhaha over off-leash rules governing when dogs can roam free in the parks. Or the out-of-the-way nooks and crannies where the city places its dog runs.

ASHLEY BICKERTON This artist's blisteringly vivid new works look as if they were collaboratively hallucinated by Joseph Conrad and Hunter S. Thompson during an all-night psychedelic drug binge. In colorful digital photographs printed on canvas, partly overpainted and presented within wide, wooden frames elaborately decorated to resemble Indonesian tourist kitsch, Mr. Bickerton stars as a decadent Ugly American living in a South Pacific paradise. (He actually lives in Bali.) His skin is painted Blue Man Group blue, and he is accompanied by voluptuous female islanders whose partly nude bodies are painted in tropical hues. In various scenes he boozes, smokes pot and poses in a sarong in a garish family portrait with a native consort and two children. One especially lively piece, ''The Dream,'' right, has him howling in bed with a bright red demon squatting on his chest, and green snakes writhing about, each with a screaming head that's a small version of Mr. Bickerton's own.

More than 2,000 pipers and drummers in kilts will march up the Avenue of the Americas on Saturday afternoon for the 10th annual Tartan Day Parade. A celebration of Scottish culture, the parade is the culmination of Tartan Week in New York.

My Sunday column is on the impact in this election cycle of our unconscious minds, particularly toward race and gender. I would strongly encourage you to take some tests that measure your own attitudes. Joshua Correll at University of Chicago has created an on-line test called "the police officer's dilemma," in which you encounter 100 pictures of black and white men, some armed and some unarmed. The idea is to shoot those who are armed and holster your gun when you see someone unarmed -- and the program measures how fast you do these things. Try it -- if you're like most whites and many blacks, you're quicker to shoot blacks than whites.

Toughest job in hockey? Goalie. Toughest place to play? Montreal. But win for them and they'll love you more than poutine or the smoked meat from Schwartz's. So, here comes this Carey Price kid. He's big, he's calm, he's very good and, yes, he's all of 20 years old. He wins the No. 1 job and keeps winning, and tonight, he can lead Les Habitants into the Eastern Conference penthouse by putting the Maple Leafs out of their misery. But Price's biggest victory may have been winning over Red Fisher, Montreal's Living Legend of Sports Journalism, still a must-read in The Gazette after 52 seasons. When the Habs dealt Cristobal Huet to the Caps in late February, Red said, "It's a mistake." But yesterday, Red credited Price for being the main reason Montreal has its first division title in 16 years. If Red loves him, it's official -- they all love him.

PARIS - During Fiat's largely forgettable stint in America, the running joke about the automaker's woeful build quality was that the company name was actually an acronym for Fix It Again Tony. That gag resurfaced this week with the news of Jerry Seinfeld's accident. Though cars carrying the Fiat nameplate haven't been sold in the United States for some two decades, the failing brakes in Mr. Seinfeld's vintage Fiat put the company's mechanical standards back front and center.

A confessed serial killer, Timothy Krajcir, has pleaded guilty to killing five women nearly 30 years ago in Cape Girardeau. Mr. Krajcir received several life sentences after pleading to five counts of murder and several lesser counts. He was spared the death penalty because he agreed to confess to the crimes if his execution was not sought. Mr. Krajcir, 63, has admitted to killing nine women in four states. He has already received life sentences for two killings in Southern Illinois. He has not been charged for killings he confessed to in Pennsylvania and Kentucky.

One of two suspects charged in a series of random shootings that killed seven people in the Phoenix area has pleaded guilty to first-degree murder. The suspect, Samuel Dieteman, also pleaded guilty to conspiracy to commit murder. The authorities said Mr. Dieteman and a former roommate, Dale Hausner, randomly shot and killed seven people, wounded 17 more and killed several animals.

Immigration officials said they were extending the duration of on-the-job training for immigrant students who are recent graduates with advanced degrees in science, technology and engineering. The training period will be extended to 29 months from 12 months for immigrants on student visas employed in jobs related to their field of study. Training will also be automatically extended for students who are waiting to shift to temporary work visas known as H-1B. The measure, which officials said would benefit about 25,000 students, is designed to close visa gaps that had forced some highly skilled graduates to leave the country.

A State Department official in charge of passport services is stepping down two weeks after the agency said files of the three presidential candidates had been improperly accessed. A department spokesman said Ann Barrett, the deputy assistant secretary of state for passport services, was stepping down and being replaced by Lawrence Baer, a senior management official. Ms. Barrett will leave the post effective April 7 but will remain employed in the department’s consular affairs bureau. The department is investigating the improper breach of confidential passport files of Senators Barack Obama, Hillary Rodham Clinton and John McCain.

A woman was sentenced to death for killing a mother-to-be and cutting the baby from her womb. Lisa Montgomery becomes the third woman on federal death row. She was convicted in October of kidnapping resulting in death in the Dec. 16, 2004, killing of Bobbie Jo Stinnett. Ms. Montgomery was arrested at her farmhouse a day after showing off Ms. Stinnett’s baby as her own. Since 1927, only two women have been executed under the federal system, both in 1953. Ethel Rosenberg was sent to the electric chair after she and her husband, Julius, were convicted of conspiracy to commit espionage for passing atomic secrets to the Soviet Union. Bonnie Heady was sent to the gas chamber with her accomplice, Carl Hall, for the kidnapping and murder of a 6-year-old Kansas City boy.

A fire caused by an electrical problem destroyed a house trailer in the northwestern town of Ada, killing a family of five, the authorities said. In Colerain Township west of Cincinnati, two firefighters died after becoming trapped in the basement of a burning house. It appeared they died when a floor or stairwell collapsed, said Capt. Steve Conn of the Fire Department. The cause of the fire was being investigated.

Residents assessed the damage from a tornado that hit central Arkansas, damaging businesses, felling trees and knocking out power to thousands of customers. One person was reported dead in a traffic accident, and there was a report of a missing woman in Pulaski County. In Kentucky, the authorities said a 2-year-old girl died after her mother drove into a flooded roadway. A strong thunderstorm struck the area around Denton County, Tex., producing wind as high as 50 miles an hour and damaging some homes. Storms also downed trees, toppled power poles and peeled shingles off buildings in northern Alabama. In Little Rock, Ark., and its suburbs, many homes and businesses were damaged. Near Benton, Ark., a dozen homes were destroyed at the Hurricane Creek Mobile Home Park, including one that burned after a felled tree caused a gas leak that ignited.

HOROWITZ--Harry, on April 3, 2008. Passed away soon after celebrating his 92nd birthday. He was surrounded by his loving wife of 62 years, Dorothy (Dall) and by family and friends. 9 P.M. (VH1) ROCK DOCS: THE NIGHT JAMES BROWN SAVED BOSTON The power of music, proved. On April 5, 1968, the day after the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was killed, James Brown, left, was scheduled to give a concert at Boston Garden. Other cities had been hit by violence, and officials in Boston feared rioting there. Others feared there would be even worse violence if the concert were canceled at the last second. It was decided that the show would go on but that it would also be televised, and ticketholders were urged to stay home and watch it. That decision, and Brown's cooperation, are credited with helping to avert chaos in the city. This documentary includes rarely seen film from the concert and interviews with band and audience members. 6 P.M. CUMMINGS--Frank, of Riverdale, NY died April 4 of pneumonia at the age of 85. A retired businessman, he was a lifelong athlete who starred at both soccer and tennis. As a teenager he escaped from German forces and fought with the Russian Partisans during World War II. After the war he attended the University of Padua and came to the US in 1949 where he launched a successful business career. He spoke eight languages and was an avid supporter of Israel. He is survived by his loving wife of 54 years, Jeanette, two children, Allan H. Cummings (Terri J. Cummings) and Gail Cummings Levan (Richard A. Levan), and three grandsons, Ryan J. Levan, Andrew M. Levan and Ian A. Cummings. A ceremony will be held on Sunday at the chapel at Mount Moriah Cemetery, Fairview, New Jersey. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Anti-Defamation League.

CALLENDER--Robert Lewis, 77 of Southampton, NY and Manhattan, passed away with his family by his side on April 3 following his brave battle with cancer. He is survived by his devoted wife Cathy, his beloved son Will (Anne), the grandchildren he adored, Madeleine and Robert, and so many individuals he called close friends for over 50 years. Born in Scranton, PA, Bob was a proud member of the class of 1953 at Dartmouth College and the class of 1954 at The Tuck School of Business. Following service in the U.S. Navy and careers with Chase Manhattan Bank, General Foods, The Continental Bank of Illinois, and Computer Property Corporation, he joined the Fairfield Communities as Vice Chairman, retiring in 1988. Devoted to family and friends, Bob's life and character were defined by integrity, loyalty, generosity, and laughter. A celebration of his life will be held in New York City on April 16 from 5:30 to 7:30pm -for details please call 631-283-7210. In his memory, contributions may be made to the Dartmouth Class of 1953 Trust c/o Robert C. Simpson, Pres., 1626 Sweet Bay Circle, Palm City, FL 34990-8015.

SAN ANTONIO - Bad news for the Memphis Tigers today. Their star freshman guard Derrick Rose has an upset stomach and has left the arena to head back to the hotel. No other details are available right now, but we'll keep you updated as they're available.
More campaign-related opinion for Sunday, April 6:

A scratchy-voiced Joe Girardi said he would return to the dugout on Sunday and manage the Yankees. Girardi did not manage the Yankees in the last two games because he had an upper respiratory infection. "It's the worst I've ever felt for a two-day period," Girardi said. While Girardi felt strong enough to manage, he cancelled the first "Joe Girardi Show." Girardi was supposed to tape the show on Sunday morning for airing on the YES Network after the game, but he decided against doing it. "I didn't think it was in my health's best interest to try and do a half hour show and be coughing all the time," Girardi said. As Girardi quarantined himself off in his office at Yankee Stadium, Rob Thomson, the bench coach, managed the Yankees to two losses. Girardi said that he communicated with Thomson during games, but hated sitting in the dugout and managing. "It was hard," Girardi said. "You feel bored. You feel somewhat worthless."

For six days and 23½ hours, the auxiliary locker room at Yankee Stadium is exactly that. It is on the lowest level of the Stadium, between the home and the visiting clubhouse. It is the place where the Yankees stage some press conferences, like Manager Joe Girardi's pregame and postgame sessions. But when the Yankees play at home, a Catholic Mass is held in the locker room from 10 a.m. to 10:30 a.m. on Sundays. The first Mass of the season was held on Sunday. The service is attended by stadium employees, police officers, reporters and, sometimes, visiting players and team executives. I have seen Brian Cashman, the general manager of the Yankees, there. Bob Sheppard, the Yankees' public address announcer since 1951, often does the Scripture readings, which, on its own, is a reason to attend the Mass. Sheppard is still recuperating, but there was an announcement made during the service about how he hopes to return by June. The Mass is quick because most attendees are working, but, for those whose Sundays feel vacant without a spiritual experience, it is enjoyable. A half hour after the Mass was over, the makeshift altar was gone and Girardi was doing his pregame news conference. The next Mass at the Stadium will be much different. It will be celebrated by Pope Benedict XVI in two weeks and will attract more than 50,000 worshipers.

PASPA--Alexander, M.D., of Longboat Key, FL died March 29th, 2008. Beloved husband of Isabella, father and grandfather fought bravely to the end after a long illness and accepted his death with dignity. He was born in Zagreb, Croatia and immigrated to the US in 1955. He completed his training in Anesthesiology at NYU-Bellevue Hospital. He was Director of Anesthesia at NY Downtown Hospital and Associate Professor of Medicine at NYU Medical School. Everyone he touched respected and loved him. He helped many people in his long life. In accordance to his wishes, and properly so, we do not mourn unnecessarily, but rather celebrate a full, happy and productive life. Memorial services April 12th, 2008, 11am St. Mary Star of the Sea Catholic Church, 4280 Gulf of Mexico Dr., Longboat Key, FL.

''My family goes back six generations in Texas,'' says Andy Coolquitt, a sculptor, cleaning out the fountain in the courtyard of his home. ''I came to Austin for art school and bought this property in 1994. This part of the courtyard is facing the apartment I built. When I first moved in I'd have parties -- artists would come and cover these walls in sgraffito. In the backyard is a stand-alone kitchen and porch, a big pole barn that I use as a studio with a residence above it. There are also three trailers on the property, so there are about five full-time residents here. I've always imagined having a compound filled with people -- not a family with kids but a group of like-minded individuals. This was a typical day for us -- some friends over, hanging out, drinking beer, doing whatever.' Camille Sweeney

To the Editor: In reading ''On the Lam with Kesey'' (March 23) about Lawrence Downes's mostly fruitless search for signs of Kesey in Manzanillo from more than 40 years ago, I found myself wondering if he had thought of taking his quest to San Miguel de Allende. True, Kesey had returned to the United States by the time I dropped out in '67, but Neal Cassady and friends were well established in this town of expatriate artists and potheads. Neal was the featured guest at most parties, entertaining us all with his perpetual-motion silver hammer act and dazzling us with his washboard abs. (He was always bare-chested, regardless of the temperature!) We'd all read Kerouac and Burroughs, but few of us knew that Cassady, too, was something of a poet. By the time I met him, drugs and booze had taken their toll. In 1968, he was found dead on the railroad tracks outside of town. At least, that was the story that made the rounds of our hippie community. Thanks for the memories. Linda Martin Port Townsend, Wash.
LISKIN--Elliot, April 5th. The memories remain, on his birthday and everyday. Family and Joyce

LIEBERMAN--Dr. Jerrold S., of New York City, died Thursday, April 3 in Manhattan after a long illness, at the age of 85. A physician and cardiovascular researcher, Dr. Lieberman served as Associate Professor of Clinical Medicine at the Weill Medical College of Cornell University in New York until 2000. A graduate of Cornell University in Ithaca, Dr. Lieberman went on to earn his M.D. degree from Cornell University Medical College in New York City. In the midst of internship at Michael Reese Hospital in Chicago, and at Bellevue Hospital in New York City, Dr. Lieberman spent two years in the U.S. Army serving as a regimental surgeon in the 31st Infantry Regiment in Korea. After completing his internship, he went on to establish a private practice in internal medicine while holding academic appointments at Cornell over five decades. In addition to treating private patients, Dr. Lieberman pursued medical research and authored many publications in the fields of peripheral vascular disease and management of anticoagulant therapy. His extramural professional responsibilities included committee and council work with the New York Heart Association and the American Heart Association. Dr. Lieberman was an avid photographer, jazz aficionado, world traveler, home chef and loving father and grandfather. He is survived by his wife Dr. Janet E. Lieberman, his stepson Randolph Hugh Chase, M.D., two daughtersin-law Marilyn Chase and Carol Weisman, two grandsons Alexander ''Sandy'' Chase, Jordan Andrew Chase M.D., a granddaughter Rebecca Claire Chase and step-granddaughter Sarah Weisman. His stepson Dr. Gary A. Chase predeceased him in October 2007. Funeral service, Tuesday April 8th, 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St. LIEBERMAN--Jerrold S. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York expresses to the family of our devoted and longtime member, Dr. Jerrold S. Lieberman, our deepest sympathies on the occasion of his passing. It is our hope and prayer that beautiful memories will linger as a legacy to his life. May all who loved him be comforted. Rabbi David M. Posner, Senior Rabbi; Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel, Senior Rabbi Emeritus; Marcia Waxman, President; Robert A. Calinoff, Secretary

ONCE, in the late 1970s, Norma Kamali bought gray fleece to make a swimsuit cover-up, then proceeded to make an entire collection out of it: blazers, rah-rah skirts. ''I was like, 'Oh, my God. Let's do an evening gown!' '' she recalled. But her novel idea of ''sweatshirt dressing,'' which preceded the '80s fitness craze, proved immensely influential, cropping up through the years in collections from Vivienne Westwood, Martin Margiela and Calvin Klein. (It also earned her the unfortunate title ''Queen of Sweats.'') This season, Stefano Pilati of Yves Saint Laurent took a stab at it. The result was a collection so strong it made the idea of reworking the comfortable, inexpensive fabric in clever, elegant ways seem absolutely right again. He used gray fleece to construct an impeccably tailored jacket, trousers and one covetable nipped-waist cocktail dress. He also proved that with proper styling, the mundane sweatshirt can indeed look chic.

Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., Tom Brokaw retraces the steps of the civil rights leader through music, images, historic speeches and interviews with confidants, including Andrew Young, John Lewis, Harry Belafonte, Walter E. Fauntroy and the Rev. C. T. Vivian. Dr. King's son Martin Luther King III, above with Mr. Brokaw, speaks for the first time in a film about his father. Performers like Bono, Chuck D, BeBe Winans and Forest Whitaker also ruminate on Dr. King's legacy in this two-hour documentary. 8 P.M. A suicide bomber attacked the opening ceremony of a marathon outside Sri Lanka's capital on Sunday, killing a government minister and 11 other people, authorities said. Officials blamed the bombing, the second this year resulting in the death of a government minister, on Tamil Tiger rebels.

IT is true that many people who are marrying register for Baccarat tumblers or Tiffany flatware. For horticultural types, though, nothing induces a swoon like good gardening gear. Think about a sturdy trowel or a foot-operated weeder wrapped with a bow. And there is plenty to please gardeners of the indoor variety: handmade vases for garden cuttings or terrariums. 1. For many people gardening means caring for small indoor plants. A tabletop terrarium, shaped like a glass conservatory, will contain and nurture a few pots. It is $99 at smithandhawken.com or (800) 940-1170.

Mitch Rapoport and Margaret Sapir did not have a midlife crisis so much as a midlife bread moment. One fateful night in Vermont six years ago, they sampled Gérard Rubaud's locally famous pain au levain, and their new career as bakers started to rise. Today, Mr. Rapoport and Ms. Sapir, who came to apprentice with Mr. Rubaud, own a sunny commercial bakery in Wilton, Conn., called Wave Hill Breads, where they make just one product: a rustic pain de campagne with a sturdy crust and a wonderfully chewy sponge. (To say that they make just one bread is a little like saying that Château Pétrus makes just one wine.)

CALLENDER--Robert Lewis, 77 of Southampton, NY and Manhattan, passed away with his family by his side on April 3 following his brave battle with cancer. He is survived by his devoted wife Cathy, his beloved son Will (Anne), the grandchildren he adored, Madeleine and Robert, and so many individuals he called close friends for over 50 years. Born in Scranton, PA, Bob was a proud member of the class of 1953 at Dartmouth College and the class of 1954 at The Tuck School of Business. Following service in the U.S. Navy and careers with Chase Manhattan Bank, General Foods, The Continental Bank of Illinois, and Computer Property Corporation, he joined the Fairfield Communities as Vice Chairman, retiring in 1988. Devoted to family and friends, Bob's life and character were defined by integrity, loyalty, generosity, and laughter. A celebration of his life will be held in New York City on April 16 from 5:30 to 7:30pm -for details please call 631-283-7210. In his memory, contributions may be made to the Dartmouth Class of 1953 Trust c/o Robert C. Simpson, Pres., 1626 Sweet Bay Circle, Palm City, FL 34990-8015.

Carol And Keith Kendall Share Their 4,000-Square-Foot House In Rural Virginia With 11 parrots of various sorts, including two types of cockatoo and a peach-faced lovebird. Carol, 57, does bookkeeping at home; Keith, 60, works for the county. They bought their first bird, who no longer lives with them, on a whim in 2004. Most of the current flock were rescued birds. The Kendalls spend about five hours a day on the parrots. The good-night ritual alone takes two hours. These are long-lived animals; cockatoos can easily outlive their owners. Ms. Kendall, who has four grown children, is now arranging to have the birds cared for when she's gone. ''This is going to be the rest of my life,'' she says, ''and I am ready, willing and able to do it.'' SHOWERED WITH AFFECTION

LATE AFTERNOON AT THE RED SEA IN HURGHADA, OCT. 21, 2007 Kristin Steindorsdottir, 32, a clothing-store owner, originally from Iceland, now living in Copenhagen, on a family vacation with her husband, Adalsteinn Palsson (not pictured), and their children, Rokkvi, 4, Logi, 5, and Birta, 11. ''Every day we enjoyed the warm sea and the sun from morning until sunset -- this is something we cannot experience where we come from. The kids had just discovered the small fish in the sea, and you can maybe see that they have made a big shark in the sand. When it was dark that night, we went back to the beach to feed the small fish with some bread. It is interesting that this picture was taken in the twilight, because all of our children carry Icelandic names related to the daylight and darkness: Birta means bright, Logi means flame, and Rokkvi means dark. The picture reminds us how full of life our kids are, how much fun it was to play with them on the beach, even though everyone else had left, and the sun almost had set. These are the moments giving you the most out of life.'' As told to J. R. Romanko

ZOOM Critics argue that the use of re-enactments in documentaries suggests a callous disregard on the part of a filmmaker for what is true. I don't agree. Some re-enactments serve the truth, others subvert it. There is no mode of expression, no technique of production that will instantly produce truth or falsehood. There is no veritas lens that provides a ''truthful'' picture of events. There is cinéma vérité and kino pravda but no cinematic truth. The engine of uncovering truth is not some special lens or even the unadorned human eye; it is unadorned human reason. It wasn't a cinéma vérité documentary [''The Thin Blue Line''] that got Randall Dale Adams out of prison. It was a film that re-enacted important details of the crime. It was an investigation -- part of which was done with a camera. The re-enactments capture the important details of that investigation. It's not re-enactments per se that are wrong or inappropriate. It's the use of them. I use re-enactments to burrow underneath the surface of reality in an attempt to uncover some hidden truth. ...

McCRACKEN--Ursula Naylor Eland, 66, died at home in Baltimore, March 17. A Wellesley College graduate (BA 1963, cum laude, Wellesley Scholar), held two MAs from Johns Hopkins University. A career in arts and education: Albright Knox Gallery; Walters Art Museum and College of Notre Dame in Baltimore. For 18 years she was Director of the Textile Museum in Washington DC where she brought the Museum up to current standards in every area from collections management to financial management while diversifying the exhibitions and educational programs, and building local, national and international audiences and membership. She increased the endowment seven-fold to over $17 million. Survived by her husband, Edward; siblings: Timothy Eland of New York City, Jane Donahue of Wellesley, MA and Faith Shepard of New Canaan, CT. Family and friends will hold a gathering of remembrance from 2:00 to 4:00pm, May 10th at The Textile Museum in Washington. Ursula requested contributions to the American Pain Foundation, Suite 710, 201 N. Charles St. Baltimore, MD 21201 or the Textile Society of America, P.O. Box 193, Middletown, DE 19709.

Composed of safraline (a derivative of saffron), pepperwood, curcuma, coriander, geranium, amber and patchouli, the fragrance has a bright, fresh scent that fades into a warm, woodsy musk. THE NEWS The superstar rapper Jay-Z was reported to be close to a deal with Live Nation, the concert promoter, that rivals the biggest music contracts ever awarded. BEHIND THE NEWS As CD sales plunge, record labels and promoters are racing to secure deals that cut them in on all of an artist's revenue streams -- from recordings, tours, publishing and licensing rights, endorsements and other endeavors. The deal is worth about $150 million and, as Jay-Z, who is 38, put it, the multifaceted venture with Live Nation will help him reach consumers ''in so many different ways.'' He added: Everyone's trying to figure it out. I want to be on the front lines in that fight.''

NIEMANN--Mary Jane, age 80 of Stow, Massachusetts, died peacefully on Wednesday, April 2nd at Emerson Hospital. Her daughter, Nan Mary, and son-in-law, Carl, were with her. Born in Burlington, Vermont in 1927, she was the daughter of Charles H. W. Farnham and Mary Canney Farnham. In 1951, she married Alfred Paul Niemann of Queens, New York at the Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception in Burlington, Vermont. She will be greatly missed by her daughter, Nan Mary Stutz, of Stow, Massachusetts, her son-in-law, Carl A. Stutz, her brother, Dr. John E. Farnham of Burlington, Vermont, as well as by many friends, nieces and nephews. She was Aunt Janie to many. She graduated from the University of Vermont and was a teacher for 41 years, primarily in Garden City, New York. She was an avid choral singer and gardener and was very active in the Waldorf School of Garden City, NY. She loved music, birds, and flowers and supplied the birds with dryer lint and ribbons for their nests. She was predeceased by her husband, Alfred P. Niemann, her brothers Charles H. W. Farnham, Jr. and Richard E. Farnham, her sister-inlaw, Grace Niemann Goot, and her brother-in-law Andrew Goot. A mass of Christian burial will be celebrated at 10am on Monday, April 7th at the Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception, 20 Pine Street, Burlington, Vermont. Visiting hours will be from 14pm on Sunday, April 6th at the LaVigne Funeral Home, 132 Main Street, Winooski, Vermont. Donations in her memory may be made to Stow Conservation Trust, P.O. Box 397, Stow, MA 01775.

Your March 23 art issue promises both a ''redrawing'' and a comprehensive look at a place that mystifies and confuses many people. What we are shown is a collection of war horses and their anointed successors and a fetishistic group of pretty-boy workhorses who work low-paying jobs in the hope of getting into a group show. The audience for this stuff is getting both more affluent and smaller. This world is built on a shaky foundation, namely hedge-fund collectors and the nouveau riche. When it comes crashing down, as it did in the 1980s, what will there be to show for it?

Donations can be made to The University of Michigan Undergraduate Scholarship Fund.

A scintillating first weekend of the N.C.A.A. men's basketball tournament has given way to two weekends of lopsided scores. ''One Shining Moment'' has changed from a theme song to more of a plea. But the matchup for the national championship leaves optimism for a compelling game. Memphis and Kansas love to run and score -- each averages more than 80 points a game, among the nation's top 15.

THE shrapnel from the subprime explosion continues to scatter. Lenders are experiencing a surge in losses from mortgage fraud, according to recent reports from law enforcement agencies and industry research groups. The ripples are reaching borrowers in new ways, as mortgage banks seek to stanch the flow of dollars to con artists. ''It's looking like a record-breaking year already,'' said Stephen Kodak, a spokesman for the Federal Bureau of Investigation, which fields fraud complaints from federally chartered financial institutions. Mr. Kodak said that in first half of the 2008 fiscal year, which ended last month, the F.B.I. received nearly 30,000 ''suspicious activity reports.'' The 2007 fiscal year ended with 46,000 reports and 260 convictions.

There is an American rite of passage that for most of us comes well after our first car, first love or first steady job: buying a first home. Most of the news about homeownership these days is decidedly grim -- foreclosures spreading, adjustable-rate mortgages rising, values falling. But for the people on these pages, homeownership still brings with it some joy, if also, in some cases, sizable mortgages and little equity. In this country, the median age for a first-time home buyer in 2006 was 32, by which time many people have married, started having children and perhaps managed to save up for a down payment. The first-time home buyers on these pages -- some of them with their dependents, extended family, cats and dogs -- all recently shared in that rite of passage, closing on their first home in the past 24 months, at the age of 32. Their paths to homeownership were varied: some were all-consuming quests; others almost happenstance. Their homes, too, differ, ranging from a fixer-upper in Portland, Ore., which cost $195,150, to a brand-new luxury condo on Manhattan's Upper West Side that cost more than four times as much. But one thing holds true for these buyers: If this first home is not the one they always dreamed of -- not the ideal size or layout, location or price -- it is still one they are proud to call their own. Names: Tessa Brady, 33, a hairstylist at Mark's Barbershop, and her sons, Sebastian, 7, and Silas, 5. Location: Oregon, Wis. Home: A 1,725-square-foot duplex with three bedrooms and an attached garage. Cost: The house is valued at $160,000; it was built by the nonprofit organization Habitat for Humanity. Financing: $500 down payment (from savings); 350 hours of sweat-equity work; 30-year no-interest mortgage for $78,000; two mortgages for $22,000 and $56,000 that will be repaid only if she sells the house. Favorite feature: The living room. Least favorite feature: The basement is unfinished.

First seen last month in Paris, two novelty shaped pants are being worn by young women who have narrow hips. An artfully seamed jodhpur has fullness at the hip accentuated by flaring flap pockets -- these from the house of Balenciaga. The second is a revival of the 1960s bell-bottom that hugs the leg and then falls into flairs over the shoe. Both shapes introduce fullness, one at the top of the leg, the other at the bottom.

AT first glance, Agnès b. and Harmony Korine make an unlikely pair. She, the 67-year-old Parisian designer of classic, wearable clothing; he, the 35-year-old filmmaker known as much for his past drug abuse (he's now clean) as his movies (''Kids,'' ''Gummo,'' ''Julien Donkey-Boy''). But Agnès b. (which stands for Bourgeois, the last name of her former husband, though she now goes by Troublé, her maiden name) has always been drawn to outsiders. After meeting at the Venice Film Festival in 1999 and bonding over a love of old film posters, she and Mr. Korine became friends and later business partners, forming an art and book production company called O'Salvation.

T: DESIGN An article on March 16 in T: Design magazine, about glassLAB, a glass-design workshop that was part of the Design Miami fair in December, misstated the role that the architect Paul Haigh played in its formation. Haigh developed the program concept for glassLAB and designed its installation in Miami; he did not design its mobile glassblowing equipment (the Corning Museum of Glass did). The article also referred incorrectly to Liquid Fusion, Haigh's workshop at Domaine de Boisbuchet, a design retreat in France. The workshop existed before glassLAB; glassLAB did not lead to its creation. The article also referred incorrectly at one point to the museum as ''the company.'' Corning Inc., the glass company, is a separate entity.

WHEN it comes to Lanvin's spring collection of silk, suede, mesh and metallic patent leather high-tops, an outlandish $700 price has not been a deterrence. Snoop around the sneaker-centric chat rooms of Fashion Spot, Hypebeast and Superfuture, and it's clear that Lanvin has replaced Dior Homme as the brand of cult necessity. ''I'm definitely getting two or three pairs in leather,'' wrote a fellow by the name of God Save Hedi. ''Need them in my life right now,'' Yoh05 announced. ''It has,'' as someone calling himself Style Expert succinctly put it, ''become an addiction.''

HE SLEEK, HIGH-TECH watches on these pages are the real deal, but the equally sleek, high-tech environment in which they appear is completely virtual. Designed by the architect Mark Foster Gage, the spaces are inspired by actual projects that his firm, Gage/Clemenceau, has worked on -- from a pedestrian bridge in New Zealand to a residence in Long Island. ''We took the bones of that house and just tricked it out,'' Gage explains of the surfaces, materials and finishes meticulously rendered for this story. ''It's kind of like 'Pimp My Ride. '' To accurately simulate elements like the 18-karat-gold chandelier or the titanium staircase took countless hours, not to mention the brain power of a massive bank of computers in Paris. ''Making a solid titanium staircase this way sets you back a couple of days' work,'' Gage says. ''If you were to do it in real life, it would cost you millions of dollars -- but worth every penny!'' ALIX BROWNE

SHAPIRO--Nathan. Natie, my irreplaceable husband and friend, there will never be another you. The love and strength you gave me will accompany me till the end of all time. He was an Icon of the New York Fashion Industry, Honored member of the Friars Club and a prominent symbol of the ''Old New York community''. He is survived by his wife of 60 years, Edith Leslie, his daughter Gabrielle Shapiro, M.D., his grandchildren Jacob and Angelica Shapiro Perricone and a niece Jamie Shapiro Goldhagen. We will strive to follow your example of generosity, sharing, kindness and a life full of style and grace.

ORDONEZ--Jose A.G., of Coral Gables, FL, formerly of Concord, NH, died peacefully at his home on February 26, 2008, aged 85. Born in Havana, Cuba on May 4, 1922, eldest son of the late Dr. Jose A.G. Ordonez and Gloria Montalvo, he is survived by his brothers, Raoul and Carlos, both of Miami, and numerous nieces and nephews. Educated at Ridley College, Canada, he served with the Canadian Third Division in Europe in the latter stages of WWII. Thereafter, he graduated with Honors from Trinity College at the University of Toronto, where, in 1964, he also obtained a MA in History. In 1952 he began his long career as a Master and History teacher at St. Paul's School (SPS), Concord, NH. Concentrating on European History, his classes were taught with flair and humor, his Victorian History course being among the most remembered. In addition he introduced Cross Country to the School as a recognized sport and founded the Shavian Society, dedicated to the study of the works of George Bernard Shaw. For the 1977-78 academic year, he was a visiting teacher at Eton College, England an experience which much enriched his teaching career. In 1991 he complied and edited ''St. Paul's School, a Pictorial History'' and in 1998 his memoir, ''The Education of a Schoolmaster: My Years at St. Pauls School'' was published to considerable acclaim. A vigorous outdoorsman and traveler, he enjoyed, cross-country skiing, running, hiking and biking and took delight and comfort in being in the natural world. His annual train journeys in England and Scotland achieved epic proportions. In his retirement years, he was a frequent visitor to the Adirondacks. Devoted to his students, he made a concerted effort to stay in touch with them and their families as their lives evolved, teaching numerous sons and daughters of his earlier pupils. His retirement dinner in 1987 was attended by over 250 guests, testimony to the affection and esteem in which he was held by generations of SPS students. Following his retirement, he remained in Concord working as an archival consultant for SPS for many years, until moving to Florida to be near his family. Funeral services were private. Gifts in his memory may be made to: The Ordonez Library Fund, St. Paul's School, 325 Pleasant Street, Concord, NH 0330l or to the Adirondack Nature Conservancy, P.O. Box 65, Keene Valley, NY 12943.

To the Editor: The Explorer column ''Zermatt, Switzerland: A famed Alps Resort Schusses Into the Future'' (March 16) does not describe the place I visited in 1956. My travel diary entry brought back vivid memories of the one main street lined with chalet-style architecture. A horse-drawn carriage took us to the Breithorn Hotel, third class but comfortable, where we had a dinner that included boiled tongue. A walk took us up into a meadow where we watched elderly women, wearing heavy boots and, on their heads, kerchiefs, pitching hay in the fields. My diary entry ended with the words ''so quiet, peaceful.'' Were I to be there once more, I suspect I might not recognize what I referred to then as a very quaint Heidi-land. Lucille Blocksom Cincinnati

CUNNINGHAM--John William, of Weston, CT, passed away peacefully at his home, on April 1, 2008 at the age of 76. Cunningham was a carpenter and joined the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners of America Local 210 in 1956. He was an active member and was first elected as a business representative, then General Agent of Local 210, and also served as President of the New England Regional Council of Carpenters. Throughout his career, Cunningham was committed to improving the lives of his members and the communities in which they worked. He was active in local and national politics fighting for policies to support working men and women. Mr. Cunningham, born in Stamford, CT is survived by his loving wife and partner of 58 years Virginia Ward Cunningham; his sister Kathleen Gibbons; six children Kimberley, Devon, Bill, John, Caroline, and Diana; daughters-, and son-in-law Vicki, Kathryn and Barry; and seven grandchildren, Chalan, Maevereen, Conor, Brennen, Makena, Sam, and Geneva. A celebration of his life will be held on Monday, April 7th at 11:00am at the Unitarian Church, 10 Lyons Plains Road, Westport, CT. Donations in his memory can be made to the Local 210 Scholarship Fund, c/o Carpenters Local 210, 427 Stillson Road, Fairfield, CT 06824.

HOW do you get people really riled up about the environment? That is the challenge faced by Al Gore, who this year donated his $750,000 Nobel Peace Prize award (and personal matching funds) to the Alliance for Climate Protection, a nonprofit advocacy group he founded to prevent further global warming. To create a promotional campaign, which started last week, Mr. Gore commissioned the Martin Agency, a Richmond, Va., advertising firm known for its clever campaigns for Geico insurance. It asked Brian Collins, whose strategic branding firm in New York -- Collins: -- created the identity and overall design program for the campaign. Here is the logo, which is the centerpiece of the campaign. A logo is routinely the most difficult component to design because it is so important, and usually the client wants to be closely involved. An effective logo is a kind of calculus, the sum of disparate parts that adds up to a memorable image or icon. In this case, the logo is something of a risk because it is neither the name nor initials of the organization but a visual pun on the words We and Me.

QI am working on a biography of Edward Kemeys, whose sculptures were used on the Vanderbilt stable, which once stood at 44 East 58th Street. Is there a photo of the stable entranceway showing Mr. Kemeys's work, which included a bulldog, Tom Cribb; a bloodhound, Brutus; and what was apparently a Scotch collie, Laddie? ... Robert McGann, Manhattan A There is a beautifully sharp image of this remarkable building at the New York Public Library. Although the photograph was taken after 1916, when the stable was converted to a nightclub, it shows in excellent detail the French Renaissance styling of the two-story building, built in 1880 for Cornelius Vanderbilt II.

Updated, 2:15 p.m. | Glass blowing out of Sean Bell’s passenger window as bullets passed inside could have made it appear to officers that someone in the car was shooting at them, a crime scene analyst testifying for the detectives charged in the case said today.The phenomenon is known as “blowback,” in which some glass fragments from a bullet fly straight back toward the shooter. Blowback would explain why Detective Michael Oliver, facing Mr. Bell’s car, may have believed, as he said he did, that someone inside was shooting at Detective Gescard F. Isnora, when in fact it was broken glass caused by Detective Isnora’s 11 gunshots, the witness, Alexander Jason, testified.

Last week my colleague Barry Gewen, replying to a post of mine, mounted a sturdy, well-reasoned defense of "Women in Love." I don't want to drag out the discussion here, other than to say that I am right and Barry is wrong. But it does raise a larger issue. Many defenders of "Women in Love" acknowledge the frequent terrible prose but nevertheless view it as a great book. I would argue that a poorly written or even just indifferently written novel cannot be a great one, but admirers of Lawrence, Dreiser or Zola might disagree. James Dimon, JPMorgan Chase's chief executive, must have been really angry about the problems in the terms of the first version of his deal to buy Bear Stearns -- because he isn't taking any chances this time around.

KANSAS CITY-Senator John McCain painted a highly positive picture of American progress in Iraq today as he implicitly criticized his Democratic competitors, Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama, for what he called a policy of "withdraw and re-invade" and for basing their positions on the war on political ambition.
Ed passes on this fascinating link to an eGullet discussion of making soy sauce at home. Interesting viewing for some, and fanatics may want to join in.

Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton appeared on "The Ellen DeGeneres Show" Monday morning and said it was all those years fighting off the "boys" that gives her the strength to resist calls to drop out of the presidential race.
The Nielsen Company is making another acquisition in a deal that underlines the growing interest in gauging how well advertising works - or fails to work.
I was delighted that among the Best New Chefs named by Food & Wine magazine last week, both Jeremy Fox of Ubuntu and Tim Cushman of O Ya appeared.

The corporate love of buying back stock -- which Wall Street encourages as much as it can -- reached new heights late last year. Standard & Poor's, which has been tracking buyback data for the S.&P. 500 since 1998, reports that in the fourth quarter of last year, companies in the index had net reported profits of $68 billion -- and spent $141 billion buying back stock. That was the first quarter in which the companies managed to spend double their net income in buybacks. The third quarter of 2007 had been the first time that buybacks exceeded profits for the companies.

Greubel Forsey's Double Tourbillon 30° Bruce Pask, T's men's fashion director, is in Switzerland at Baselworld, the top trade show for the watch industry, to report on the styles and technological breakthroughs that will be worn on stylish wrists in the months ahead. He calls it "a luxe trade show on steroids."
Two Major League Soccer teams reversed their dismal first-week results by showing the moxie and panache that is expected from the league's two most successful franchises.

Last week's deal between NBC and DirecTV, a subscription satellite television service, to keep "Friday Night Lights" on the air could become a model for other television shows, today's New York Times reports.
A Sunday afternoon of Gaelic football and beer in the Bronx.
John Harwood, of The New York Times and CNBC, discusses the challenges facing Hillary Rodham Clinton.
Ukulele lovers from all over the world converged at the Theater for New York City for a four-day extravaganza of concerts, workshops and seminars.

Should sovereign wealth funds be feared? Analysts, lawmakers and reporters have mined that topic for nearly six months now, as these government-owned investment firms propped up ailing Western banks during the brunt of the subprime mortgage crisis.

Microsoft is talking tough these days. Far from signaling it might raise its bid for Yahoo, it dangled the threat over the weekend that it could lower its offer and formally go hostile -- and possibly both at the same time. For good measure, Steven Ballmer, Microsoft's chief executive, also set the clock ticking on a three-week deadline for Yahoo to agree to a deal.
More on Starbucks and tips (see this previous post), from the New York Post, via Grub Street.
Apple announced last week that its iTunes Music Store is now the leading music retailer in the country, ahead of Wal-Mart and Best Buy.

From experience, I generally start with a column idea that can be covered, more or less, in the space available (roughly 805 words, including hed and blurb). But often the first draft runs long, and needs to be tightened; in addition, sometimes it turns out that the vagaries of typesetting (where the line breaks fall, and which layout I've got -- long and skinny has the most room, across the page the least) ends up forcing some more cuts.
The wrong golf swing can ruin your game and your back, but some new gadgets for golfers may help.

If you have ever worked with someone who has complete mastery of an arcane subject yet bungles anything that has to do with interacting with people, then you know the importance of soft skills. I think of these skills -- time management, communications ability, leadership -- as the bedside manner of the workplace.

The webcast of "Bush's War," a two-part "Frontline" documentary timed to the fifth anniversary of the United States' invasion of Iraq, has set a record for PBS.org, Elizabeth Jensen reports. The documentary has received 1.5 million views to date.

The sun rises this morning and 16 teams survive. For them and their fans it is cause for celebration. The playoffs are upon us, a chance for renewal, for rebirth, for optimism. Yes, thrills await. Passions ignite. Suspense hangs in the air. It's another opportunity for players to make their mark on the season -- and for fans to invade the nearest supermarket and buy all the aluminum foil in sight (a couple of those heavy duty 200-foot rolls should do) so they can construct Stanley Cups.

Reuters reports: "Nielsen Co, a provider of market research and media services, said it agreed to acquire IAG Research Inc, a television and Internet audience research firm, for $225 million to strengthen its media business."
Union leaders were concerned about Mark Penn's impact in Pennsylvania.
Updated | 2:26 p.m. More details are emerging on how the Clinton camp came under pressure from unions before Mark Penn stepped down as the campaign's chief political strategist.
Stuart Emmrich, travel editor, is answering questions this week.

You can mix your own, but blended curry powder is one of the original convenience foods, a venerable spice rub containing cumin, turmeric, coriander, cardamom, ginger, fenugreek and black pepper that can improve the flavor of almost anything, even the ultimate contemporary convenience food -- boneless, skinless chicken breast.
Despite its defiant tones, Yahoo's response to Microsoft Monday morning looks like the letter of a defeated company.

We have a winner in the Worst Bad Name Contest. And after talking to the woman who has this name, I'm happy to report we have new anecdotal evidence to go with the psychological studies supporting the Boy Named Sue theory: good things can indeed come from a bad name.

It was not a revolutionary managerial decision: Joe Girardi, the still scratchy-voiced, still groggy-looking manager of the Yankees, returned to the dugout on Sunday and made one major change in the batting order. He moved Hideki Matsui into the fifth spot.

Having enjoyed some publicity for an eight-minute online encapsulation of "Lost" in January, ABC is rolling out short summaries of other shows this week, aiming to get people to turn to the network's Web site to get caught up with shows that have been on hiatus.
Motorola said on Monday that it has agreed to nominate two of Carl C. Icahn's director candidates for its board, marking another victory for the activist investor at the struggling phone company.

Facebook is close to resolving a legal dispute about who really came up with the idea for the popular social-networking site, which sold a minority stake to Microsoft last October in a deal that valued the entire company at about $15 billion.

The notion of turning coal into liquid fuels on a big scale has simmered for decades, but only the trade sanctions against apartheid in South Africa resulted in anyone reviving the Nazi-era technology -- until now.

Sunday's New York Times: How has the production of "Deadliest Catch," the popular Discovery Channel series about "the boring, repetitive and sometimes brutal job of crab fishing in the Bering Sea, changed the small fishing port of Dutch Harbor, Alaska? Charles McGrath found out.
Of all the companies building advertising systems based on data gathered from Internet service providers, the one that is farthest along in the United States is NebuAd.

The Los Angeles Times has expanded an apology for an article about the 1994 shooting of the rapper Tupac Shakur into a retraction, saying it "relied heavily on information that The Times no longer believes to be credible." The offending article and the documents posted with it have now been removed from the newspaper's web site.

Citigroup said Monday that it has hired Mark Rufeh as the chief administrative officer for its institutional clients group, putting him in charge of maximizing productivity at its investment banking and alternative investments unit.
Facebook is close to putting an uncomfortable and embarrassing legal episode behind it.

Reaction to Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's decision to dump her chief strategist, Mark Penn, recalled highlights of her campaign's stumbles during the primary season, with some Democrats wondering whether this resignation should have occurred months ago.

Some readers scolded me in comments below the previous post for suggesting that sexism is more a problem in this election cycle than misogyny. Frankly, I'm trying to think through these issues -- in part because of a book my wife and I are writing on women in the developing world -- and so I'd welcome some more discussion on this issue.

Responding to Microsoft's threat to lower the price of its buyout offer over the weekend, Yahoo said Monday that it continues to believe that Microsoft's takeover bid is too low, as do many of its shareholders. Yahoo also countered Microsoft's assertions that its business has deteriorated since Microsoft made its unsolicited bid on January 31.

Kinetic Concepts, a medical technology company, said Monday that it has agreed to buy Lifecell, a maker of tissue repair products, for $1.7 billion in cash via a tender offer. At $51 a share, the deal represents an 18 percent premium over Lifestyle's closing stock price on Friday and a 26 percent premium over its 90-day volume-weighted average trading price.

In today's column, I suggested a parallel between the vulnerability of today's low-inventory world food markets to crisis and the vulnerability of our high-leverage, securitized financial markets. (Incidentally: yes, I reused a blog post title. I just thought it was appropriate.)

RealNetworks is quietly introducing a version of Scrabble on Facebook, despite pledging to save Scrabulous, the wildly popular, unauthorized online version of the board game, The New York Times reported.

Sumner M. Redstone, the chairman and controlling shareholder of Viacom and CBS, has left a trail of tattered relationships - with family members, executives and, in his case, one very famous movie star.

Normally, St. Jakob's Hall is Basel Switzerland is home to soccer tournaments or the occasional hockey game. But on a sunny morning in February, the stadium offered a corporate face-off every bit as contentious as any athletic event.

U.S. private equity firm TPG and other investors are near a deal to invest $5 billion in Washington Mutual, sources familiar with the matter told DealBook. The potential deal was first reported by the The Wall Street Journal, which said the other investors include large shareholders of the Seattle-based lender and may also involve other buyout firms.

As investors stepped up pressure on UBS to consider a breakup after more write-downs this week, the departing chairman, Marcel Ospel, said Friday that dividing the Swiss bank's investment arm from its booming wealth management business would be a mistake.

Electronic Arts' $26 a share hostile bid for rival video game maker Take-Two Interactive could get a whole lot pricier if a report last week predicting blockbuster sales for Take-Two's upcoming release of "Grand Theft Auto IV" proves correct.

After inking a deal to take control of the Tribune Company last year, Samuel Zell told told the company's flagship paper, The Chicago Tribune: "We didn't do this deal to figure out what to get rid of."

The China Investment Corporation, the country's $200 billion sovereign wealth fund, has signed a deal with the U.S. firm J.C. Flowers to start a $4 billion private equity fund to focus on investments in U.S. financial assets, despite increasing worries over the snowballing credit crisis, Reuters reported.
Facing activist pressure to put itself on the block, struggling electronics retailer Circuit City Stores has hired Goldman Sachs for advice, The Deal.com reported.

J.C. Flowers is working on a revised 3.5 billion pound ($7 billion) takeover proposal for Britain's Friends Provident, in an attempt to coax the life insurer's board to the negotiating table, The Times of London reported.

Thee California State Teachers' Retirement System has withheld votes for eight Morgan Stanley directors, including the chairman, John J. Mack, because the company has underperformed both the market and peers.

The checks to taxpayers from the first federal economic stimulus bill aren't in the mail yet, but Democrats are increasing their pressure for a second round of financial aid.

Marin Software, which makes an in-browser application to manage paid search ad campaigns, has raised $7.25 million in a second round of funding led by Benchmark Capital. As part of the financing, Bruce Dunlevie, a General Partner at Benchmark, will join Marin Software's board of directors.

The Children's Investment Fund, the British hedge fund that has been pushing for changes at CSX, has hit back at the railway operator in a countersuit that accuses the company and its chief executive officer of violating security laws, including using insider trading to benefit its leadership.
Drug development firm Vivus said Friday it is turning to Deerfield Management to pump $30 million into the clinical trial of a next-generation compound that aims to compete with Viagra.

Major Chinese banks have looked at buying a stake in CIT Group or forming a partnership with the U.S. commercial lender, but they have backed away because of concerns about CIT's ability to finance itself, according to Reuters.

Peter G. Peterson, the co-founder and senior chairman of the Blackstone Group, announced earlier this year that he is stepping back from the private equity giant that he helped start. His goal now, as The New York Times reported, is to tend to his personal foundation, which aims to raise awareness of "selected key sustainability challenges that threaten America's future."
On the way up, financial toxic waste was sold as "a new paradigm." Now, on the long way down, the response is "Help, the sky is falling!"

The judges leading the investigation of Jérôme Kerviel, the Société Générale employee blamed for trading losses of nearly 4.9 billion euros ($7.2 billion), are expected to conclude their work by summer, with a trial likely to begin in early 2009, lawyers said Friday.

To be safe, a column or blog post bearing the headline "Warren Buffett Invests Like a Girl" needs two things: it has to be written by a woman, and it has to be backed up with plenty of details.
A dire first quarter for Asian hedge funds has cooled but not quelled demand from international investors, one manager looking to launch new offerings in coming months said on Monday.

Société Nationale des Chemins de Fer, the French national railroad company, said Sunday that it had offered to buy the transport and logistics company Geodis at a premium of more than 30 percent to Geodis's last traded stock price.

Australia's Consolidated Media Holdings said a proposed A$3.3 billion ($3.1 billion) buyout offer from Rupert Murdoch's son, Lachlan Murdoch, and Australian gaming tycoon James Packer, would not proceed because they failed to agree on terms.
Novartis has agreed to buy Nestle's majority stake in Alcon, the United States-based eye care business, in a deal worth up to $39 billion.

Appaloosa Management's decision Friday to terminate its $2.55 billion deal to invest in Delphi agreement is not only setback for Delphi but is also a blow to General Motors, which spun off the bankrupt auto-parts maker nearly a decade ago and has been paying for it since.

The chief executive of Landry's Restaurants, Tilman J. Fertitta, cut his offer to buy out the company by more than 10 percent to $21 a share, citing tightening credit market conditions that has made it difficult to finance a possible deal valued at about $1.3 billion.

EDP Energias de Portugal could opt to sell stakes in its renewables unit directly to one or two investors if market conditions do not allow it to proceed with the initial public offering of the unit in June as planned, Diario de Noticias reported.
Shareholders of BEA Systems approved the company's acquisition by Oracle at a special meeting Friday.

Citing lower-than-expected sales across its business, A.M.D. estimated revenue for the first quarter at about $1.5 billion, well below the average analyst estimate of $1.62 billion.
Shares ended the day mixed on Monday in light trading as many investors moved to the sidelines ahead of quarterly profit reports.

Natasha Kai scored twice and Abby Wambach added a goal in the United States women’s team’s 3-1 victory over host Mexico that moved the Americans a victory from securing a spot in the Beijing Olympics.
A federal judge in Houston will hear arguments Wednesday on a motion to disqualify Roger Clemens’s lead lawyer, Rusty Hardin, from representing him in a defamation lawsuit.
It was the the latest twist in a Senate race in New Jersey that has featured an avalanche of rumors about candidates and would-be candidates.

The teenager Graham Rahal overcame a spinout and came back to win the Honda Grand Prix of St. Petersburg on Sunday in Florida, holding off the veteran Hélio Castroneves to become the youngest winner in major open-wheel history.

Cardiff reached the F.A. Cup final for the first time since 1927, beating Barnsley, 1-0, at Wembley on Joe Ledley’s ninth-minute goal. Cardiff, which plays in Britain’s second-tier League Championship, will face the Premier League club Portsmouth in the final on May 17. On Saturday, Portsmouth edged another Championship club, West Bromwich Albion, 1-0. Cardiff has won the F.A. Cup once — in 1927, when it defeated Arsenal, 1-0.

Ferrari’s Felipe Massa scored his first points of the season by winning his second consecutive Bahrain Grand Prix, edging his teammate and the new overall Formula One leader Kimi Raikkonen by 3.339 seconds in Sakhir.

Gregory Bourdy tapped in for par on the third extra hole and won the Estoril Open in Cascais, Portugal. Bourdy, Alastair Forsyth and David Howell were tied at 18-under 266 after four rounds, with Bourdy carding a seven-under par 64 to pull into a tie and set up the playoff. It was Bourdy’s second European Tour title.
Isiah Thomas, relieved of his team presidency last Wednesday, is still the coach and probably will be for at least another nine days, or until Donnie Walsh completes his review process.

Mark Wiebe completed a wire-to-wire victory in the inaugural Cap Cana Championship, closing with a five-under-par 67 for a four-stroke victory over Vicenté Fernández in Punta Cana, Dominican Republic. Wiebe finished at 14-under 202 and earned $300,000 for his second victory in 12 career starts on the Champions Tour. Wiebe was the only player to post three straight rounds in the 60s.

Alan Webb, who holds the American record in the mile, dropped out of the Carlsbad 5000 in California about a half-mile before the finish of the 3.1-mile road race, his legs hurting too much even to jog in. Terefe Maregu Zewdie of Ethiopia sprinted the final 50 meters to win the race in 13 minutes 34 seconds, slow for a race billed as the world’s fastest 5K.

A housing complex used by foreigners in the upscale Haddah neighborhood of Sana, Yemen’s capital, came under attack Sunday. Nobody was injured.

Sunday’s victory was Lorena Ochoa’s first major championship on North American soil, her second consecutive major title and her third victory in four starts this year.

PHOENIX (AP) — A hobbled Dirk Nowitzki brought the offense. Jason Kidd triggered the defense. The result was a fourth-quarter rally that might have saved the season for the Dallas Mavericks.

An article on Tuesday about the Olympic torch ceremony in Beijing misstated the name of the street where traffic was blocked for security during the ceremony. It is the Avenue of Eternal Peace, not the Avenue of Heavenly Peace.

An article on Wednesday about a dispute between the American Civil Liberties Union and its South Carolina affiliate misspelled the surname of the A.C.L.U.’s deputy executive director. She is Dorothy M. Ehrlich, not Erlich.
A front-page obituary and a headline in some editions on Sunday about the actor Charlton Heston misstated his age and the year of his birth. He was 84, not 83, and was born in 1923, not 1924.

An obituary on March 15 about Louis Olah, the former jockey who became keeper of the silks at several New York racetracks, misspelled the name of the horse on which he won the 1947 Interborough Handicap at Jamaica. It was Tavistock — not Tavstock, the spelling used by Mr. Olah and listed on the New York Racing Association’s Web site. (The error also appeared in a sports article on Jan. 13.).

An obituary on Thursday about the architect and designer Ralph Rapson misstated, at one point, the name of the university where he was dean of the school of architecture from 1954 to 1984. It was the University of Minnesota; there is no University of Minneapolis.

An article on Thursday about a proposed congestion-pricing plan for New York City becoming the latest skirmish in a centuries-old battle between New York State and New Jersey included erroneous information from a political science professor about a monopoly granted by New York in the 19th century to run ferries across the Hudson. The monopoly was granted to Robert Fulton and Robert R. Livingston, not to Cornelius Vanderbilt.

Charlton Heston, who appeared in some 100 films in his 60-year acting career but who is remembered chiefly for his monumental, jut-jawed portrayals of Moses, Ben-Hur and Michelangelo, died Saturday night at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 84. His death was confirmed by a spokesman for the family, Bill Powers, who did not specify a cause. In August 2002, Mr. Heston announced that he had received a diagnosis of neurological symptoms ''consistent with Alzheimer's disease.''

LEONA LEWIS ''Spirit'' (J Records/SyCo Music/Sony BMG) Moments after performing her breakout hit, ''Bleeding Love,'' on ''The Oprah Winfrey Show'' last month, the British R&B singer Leona Lewis fielded a question from the admiring host. ''Obviously everybody compares you to, you know, all the greats,'' Ms. Winfrey said, citing Mariah Carey and Whitney Houston. ''What does that feel like for you?''

Thomas Wolfe wrote, ''You can't go home again.'' But Madonna will, if Mayor Charles M.Brunner of Bay City, Mich., has his way, The Associated Press reported. The mayor wants to give the key to the city to Madonna, below right, who grew up there and in the Detroit suburb of Rochester Hills. The problem is that in 1985, according to The Bay City Times, Madonna was considered for the honor but some people thought then that her entertainment was too risqué. To make matters worse, the newspaper reported, the city refused to accept a sculpture of Madonna from an Italian artist in the late 1980s on the grounds that her popularity would fade. Now Mayor Brunner has written to Madonna to offer her the key, saying, ''We have always been proud of your accomplishments, but recently your induction into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame reminded us that we need to honor you with the highest honor that Bay City can offer.'' What's more Guy Greve, president of the Bay Arts Council, wants to commission a sculpture of Madonna, andCity CommissionerChristopher J. Shannon,who fronts arock band, plans a Madonna tribute album, using local musicians to cover her hits, including ''Like a Virgin'' and ''Express Yourself.''

EBEL--Henry, Ph.D., 69, of West Hartford, CT, husband of Linda Ericson-Ebel, died on April 4, 2008. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, April 13, 2pm, at the Unitarian Meeting House, 50 Bloomfield Ave., Hartford, CT carmonfuneralhome.com.

On Jan. 2, oil prices hit a milestone when a trader on the New York Mercantile Exchange bid $100 a barrel for crude oil futures. Since then, oil has risen and fallen and risen again. On Friday, it was $106 a barrel. The effect of such turbulence on public confidence (as well as on prices at the pump) has prompted increased interest in oil trading. And, perhaps because they are more photogenic than numbers on a screen, the oil traders themselves, whose bizarre gesticulations (known as ''open outcry'' trading) have become a metonym for the market. Some suggest that open outcry -- trading via shouts and hand signals -- is a dying art, threatened by electronic systems. Yet Raymond Carbone, who trades energy options on the New York exchange, is sanguine: ''People have been saying that these signals will only be around for another couple of years. But they've been saying that for a decade.'' And, he notes, ''I can signal a trade faster than you can type it.''

Britain's Border Agency plans to challenge a court ruling that would admit the hip-hop star Snoop Dogg into the country, The Associated Press reported. He was barred from Britain after his arrest with five others in 2006 at Heathrow Airport in London on charges of violent disorder in an incident that injured seven officers. But Snoop Dogg, above right, whose real name is Calvin Broadus, appealed, and in January an asylum and immigration tribunal granted him clearance to enter. Last year he was forced to cancel a tour of Britain with Sean Combs after he was refused a visa.
