Memorial service was held at Beth Israel in Del Ray Beach, Florida.

SANDLER--Frances (Geller), of Swampscott and Boston, MA on April 4. Beloved wife of the late Albert J. Devoted mother of Leslie Kowal, Dorie Shub and Alan Sadler. Cherished grandmother and great-grandmother.

PAULY--Philip, a historian of science, died on April 2 in New York City, at age 57. The cause of death was complications stemming from Lymphoma. He was Professor of History at Rutgers University, New Brunswick, NJ. He received his doctoral degree from the Johns Hopkins University. His work dealt with the interplay between academic science, social interpretations of scientific phenomena, and popular interest in science. His last book, ''Fruits and Plains: The Horticultural Transformation of America'', was published in December 2007 by Harvard University Press. He published two other books, along with many articles, which elucidated the histories of American biology, ecology, psychology, and medicine. He is survived by his wife Michele Bogart, his son Nicholas Bogart Pauly, his parents Vincent and Edyth Pauly, his brother Mark Pauly, four sisters, Janet Steinmann, Linda Van Volkenburgh, Alice Rethlake, and Rita Verderber, and his mother-in-law Agnes Bogart. A memorial service is to be announced. Donations in his memory may be sent to the History of Science Society, PO Box 117360, 3310 Turlington Hall, University of Florida, Gainesville, FL 32661-7360.

SOLOMON--Adam. With love in our hearts, we mourn the sudden passing of our dear and caring friend. Adam, you will always be with us. Our profound sympathies to the family. Theresa and Rick Petree Ann Kern and Jerry Gotkin Diana Burroughs Georgette Bennett, Leonard Polonsky and Joshua Tanenbaum Licia Hahn Linda Bernstein and Edward Brock Faith and Mark Hochberg Claudia DeMonte and Ed McGowin SOLOMON--Adam. The partners, colleagues and associates of StoneWater Capital LLC express profound sorrow at the tragic and sudden death of our Founder, Chairman, friend and colleague, Adam Solomon. We express our deepest sympathy to his wife Vicki, his sister Tracy, his sons James and Peter, his stepchildren Jessica and David Rosen, and to all other members of the Solomon family. Adam was a renaissance man who early on predicted the surge in emerging Asian markets, but more than that, he was a philosopher and optimist. He believed fervently in progressive politics and was a founder of the Third Way, the Washington, D.C. non-partisan strategy center, which has influenced scores of American leaders and policy planners. Among Adam's diverse passions, his global philosophy led him to the Tanenbaum Center for Interreligious Understanding as a founding member. Donations in his memory may be made to The New York Women's Foundation, The Third Way Institute, or the Tanenbaum Center.

Rabbi Herbert A. Friedman, who as chief executive of the United Jewish Appeal raised more than $3 billion to support the fledgling state of Israel and led efforts to close the educational gap there between European Jews and those from other lands, died Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 89. His death was confirmed by Joe Berkofsky, a spokesman for United Jewish Communities, the organization into which the U.J.A. was merged in 1999.

CALLENDER--Robert Lewis, 77 of Southampton, NY and Manhattan, passed away with his family by his side on April 3 following his brave battle with cancer. He is survived by his devoted wife Cathy, his beloved son Will (Anne), the grandchildren he adored, Madeleine and Robert, and so many individuals he called close friends for over 50 years. Born in Scranton, PA, Bob was a proud member of the class of 1953 at Dartmouth College and the class of 1954 at The Tuck School of Business. Following service in the U.S. Navy and careers with Chase Manhattan Bank, General Foods, The Continental Bank of Illinois, and Computer Property Corporation, he joined Fairfield Communities as Vice Chairman, retiring in 1988. Devoted to family and friends, Bob's life and character were defined by integrity, loyalty, generosity, and laughter. A celebration of his life will be held in New York City on April 16 from 5:30 to 7:30pm -for details please call 631-283-7210. In his memory, contributions may be made to the Dartmouth Class of 1953 Trust c/o Robert C. Simpson, Pres., 1626 Sweet Bay Circle, Palm City, FL 34990-8015.

SUCOFF--Martin. Please note the passing with great honor and dignity of proud Marine Martin Sucoff of Tamarac, Florida. Marty was 83. The recipient of two Purple Hearts for wounds incurred on Okinawa during the taking of Mobutu Peninsula and the battle for Sugar Loaf Hill in May 1945. A member of the 29th Marines, 6th Division, 3rd Battalion, Company ''I'', Commander of Broward Chapter 674 of the Military Order of the Purple Heart, a proud volunteer at the Oakland Park VA Clinic for 15 years. Marty is survived by his loving wife (and childhood sweetheart) of 61 years, Millicent, three sons (and daughters-in-law) six grandchildren (and one granddaughter-inlaw) and one great-grandson, Drew Logan Sucoff.

ANTI-FLAG ''The Bright Lights of America'' (RCA/Sony BMG) Anguished, earnest, adrenalized: such is the emotional palette of Anti-Flag, a Pittsburgh punk band with a method nearly as subtle as its name. On ''The Bright Lights of America,'' its eighth full-length release, the group rails against the Iraq war, suburban blight and ''neo-Christian theocrats,'' among other things. In the spirit of adolescence (and yes, a strain of punk), the album's tone combines bitter irreverence with ardent idealism.

MIDNIGHT (21) IN THE LIFE In this month's episode of the gay and lesbian newsmagazine, Kathleen Turner interviews Edward Albee, above, while other segments look at coming out in Poland, rural campgrounds and ''And Tango Makes Three,'' a book -- about two male penguins that hatch an egg of their own -- that was one of the American Library Association's most challenged books in 2006. 5:30 P.M. (Sundance) ACTUALITY: THE ART AND LIFE OF ALLAN KING The channel pays tribute to the Canadian filmmaker Mr. King, a pioneer of cinéma vérité, starting with this profile directed by John Haslett Cuff. It traverses Mr. King's career from the 1956 documentary ''Skidrow,'' about vagrants in Vancouver, British Columbia; to films like ''Warrendale'' (1967), which ventures inside a treatment center for emotionally disturbed children; and ''A Married Couple'' (1969), a look at a modern marriage on the brink of destruction. The salute continues with two of Mr. King's own films: ''Memory for Max, Claire, Ida and Company,'' at 6:30, in which he looks at the effects of aging among residents of the Baycrest Center for Geriatric Care in Toronto, and ''Dying at Grace,'' at 8:30, in which he visits the Salvation Army Toronto Grace Health Center to capture the final days of five terminally ill patients.

EHRLICH--Eugene, 85, died at home in Mamaroneck, NY, April 5. Teacher and author, co-author, and editor of more than 40 books on language, writing, and studying. Best known for ''Amo, Amas, Amat, and More.'' Taught for many years at Columbia School of General Studies, and at Fairleigh Dickinson. Consultant for Bell Labs, Sikorsky Aircraft and other companies. Graduate of Townsend Harris High School, City College, and Columbia Teachers College. Served in the Pacific in World War II. Husband of Norma, father of Anne, Henry, Richard and Jonathan. Proud grandfather of Sam, Mickey, Rebecca, Alice, Margaret, Ruth, Daniel, and Jason Ehrlich, and Hazel and Harry Wodehouse. Funeral at Zion Memorial Chapel, 785 E. Boston Post Rd., Mamaroneck, NY; Tuesday April 8 at 12 noon. A memorial service will be held in late spring.

Just about anyone who has tuned in ''American Idol'' this season has seen video clips of Randy Jackson, Paula Abdul and Simon Cowell touring slums in Africa or working with victims of poverty in the United States as part of the program's ''Idol Gives Back'' charity. Ryan Seacrest, the show's host, has repeatedly extolled the charity for the $76 million it raised last year. But even as ''American Idol'' and Fox Broadcasting prepare for their second annual star-studded ''Idol Gives Back'' appeal on Wednesday, officials at the charity have declined to release a formal accounting of last year's effort. A spokesman for the Charity Projects Entertainment Fund, the organization that oversaw the fund-raising and distribution, said its financial statements were being audited and would be released by the federal financial reporting deadline for charities in May.

A music review on Thursday about ''Paul Simon: Songs From 'The Capeman,' '' at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, misstated the timing of the release of the recording by the original cast of ''The Capeman,'' a musical on Broadway in 1998. It became available on iTunes in 2006; it was not released before the show opened.

ELLIS MARSALIS QUARTET ''An Open Letter to Thelonious'' (Elm Records) Thelonious Monk's songs leave no place for a musician to hide. They're pointless if the harmonies aren't properly brought out, or if they're played dishonestly or glibly. They're like little teachers, hectoring you to do your best, and that's probably why other musicians playing Monk's music -- including Steve Lacy, Alexander von Schlippenbach, Jerry Gonzalez, Danilo Perez, Randy Weston, Tommy Flanagan and lots of others -- have made some of their own best work in the process.

FOALS ''Antidotes'' (Sub Pop) Foals make hard, trebly, uncomfortable, spiky, anxious, uptight, straining-to-be-different music, and for all that, it's rather good. Fumes of energy and ambition roll off ''Antidotes,'' this Oxford band's first album, though it's important to say up front that depending on your nervous system -- and your tolerance for English post-punk mannerism -- you might find it grating. There's a huge emphasis on upbeats, adenoidal chants, ropy or stabbing or twinkly guitar lines, tempos and arrangements that are claustrophobic and too fast, all for reasons of style.

Blessed with rave reviews, the revival of ''South Pacific'' at the Vivian Beaumont Theater at Lincoln Center plans to stay around for a while. Formerly a limited run scheduled to play through June 22, the Rodgers and Hammerstein musical, starring Kelli O'Hara and Paulo Szot, will continue indefinitely. Tickets are on sale through Jan. 4. ... The singer Beyoncé Knowles and the rapper Jay-Zwere married on Friday, People.com reported, citing a friend of the longtime couple. ... For 14 performances on Monday and Tuesday nights beginning April 20 John Lithgow, right, will appear at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater at Lincoln Center in his one-man show ''John Lithgow: Stories by Heart.'' A meditation on the art and essence of storytelling, it concludes with a 40-minute performance of the P. G. Wodehouse story ''Uncle Fred Flits By,'' in which Mr. Lithgow portrays nine characters. ... The mahogany desk and chair where Charles Dickens wrote ''Great Expectations'' and where he attended to his correspondence hours before his death at 58 in 1870 will be sold at a Christie's auction in London in June, Reuters reported. The sale of the furniture, expected to bring $100,000 to $160,000 on June 4, will benefit the Great Ormond Street children's hospital in London.

An article on Feb. 19 about a surge in demand for wood stoves misidentified the stove company that employs Chris Foster, who commented on an increase in sales of wood and pellet stoves. He works for Fisher's Hearth and Home in Roseburg, Ore., not Maupin's Stoves-n-Spas in The Dalles, Ore. The owner of Maupin's pointed out the error in an e-mail message on Feb. 25, and this correction was delayed to confirm Mr. Foster's employment.

ABC, NBC and CBS have planned layoffs in their news divisions in 2008, with an announcement by CBS News just last week. Most of the evening shows produced by the news divisions have had ratings declines since March 2007. ABC World News (above) and Primetime had gains, as did the Dateline NBC series, which reconfigured its schedule. In the Internet news wars, where television news organizations compete with print journalists, in February MSNBC bested ABC and CBS, which came in behind Fox News. CNN had the top news Web site.

Dr. Charlotte T. C. Tan, who for many years was a driving force behind the testing of drugs that proved effective in treating children with leukemia and other cancers, died on March 22 at her home in Brookline, Mass. She was 84. The cause was pneumonia, her family said.

A 3-D Viewfinder for Digital Photos A photo-sharing service developed by a group of researchers and digital artists at the University of Southern California with the help of a research grant from Google aims to make it easier to place images in 3-D virtual reality.

RAMBACH--Harvey W., owner and president of The Rambach Company for fifty-four years, philanthropist, and respected collector of 20th Century Art, died in his home in Wellington, Florida on April 3, at the age of 82, following a brief illness. Always enlivened by competition, his business thrived throughout the years and he finished every workday with a game of squash. Mr. Rambach was as comfortable surrounded by paintings by Marsden Hartley, Joseph Stella, and Georgia O'Keeffe, as he was in his trailer-office beside his Newark, NJ warehouse, and would have chosen a Nathan's hot dog over lunch at the 21 Club any day. A veteran of WWII, he lied about his age to qualify to join the U.S. Navy in 1942 and fought in the Pacific, though he would say he mostly mopped the decks. Dapper, and a little showy, he favored bow ties and hats, and had a beautiful voice that he used most often to sing Sinatra songs. He read widely and travelled all his life, always for the greater acquisition of knowledge in art and culture, history, politics and nature. And in good times and bad, he made others laugh. His humor, both clever and bawdy, was his most enduring gift. He treasured his wife, Francoise Rambach who survives him. He also leaves his sister and brother-in-law, Frances and Howard Gaynes, his niece and nephew, his three daughters from his first marriage, Wendy Moore of Snowmass, CO, Janet Solomon of Carmichael, CA, Peggy Rambach of Andover, MA, his sons-in-law, Peter Moore and Jason Solomon, and his seven grandchildren and greatgrandchild. A private memorial service was held at his home in Florida on April 5th. Contributions in his name may be made to the Anti-Defamation League (ADL).

CURRIE--Teresita Sparre, died April 1, 2008 of heart failure in Middletown, CT. She was 86. She was Director of Admissions, Spence School, New York, for 25 years. Lovingly remembered by her five children and their spouses, Teresita Schaffer (Howard), Julie, Frank (Christine), Patrick (Angela), and Peter (Betsy); nine grandchildren; and one greatgranddaughter. Mass of Christian Burial April 12, 10:30am, Christ the King Church, Old Lyme, CT. Donations may be sent to Bryn Mawr College, Bryn Mawr, PA, 19010.

ELLIS MARSALIS QUARTET ''An Open Letter to Thelonious'' (Elm Records) Thelonious Monk's songs leave no place for a musician to hide. They're pointless if the harmonies aren't properly brought out, or if they're played dishonestly or glibly. They're like little teachers, hectoring you to do your best, and that's probably why other musicians playing Monk's music -- including Steve Lacy, Alexander von Schlippenbach, Jerry Gonzalez, Danilo Perez, Randy Weston, Tommy Flanagan and lots of others -- have made some of their own best work in the process.

LEVINE--Edward J., on April 4th, 2008. Beloved husband of Denise (nee Stavis), cherished son, brother, uncle, friend to Fred and Cleo. A teacher, administrator and author, lover of Central Park. Avid sports fan and soft ball player and all around good guy. Celebration of his life will be held on Monday, April 7th, at 11:30am from Frank E. Campbell the Funeral Chapel, Madison Ave. at 81st Street. Contributions in Ed's memory to the Central Park Conservancy or Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital.

TOBIAS--Arty, 64, died suddenly playing golf, the game he loved best, on March 31. Wife Sandy; children Robin, Jeff, Scott and Holly; grandchildren Ashley and Matt; and many friends, mourn him. Before retiring to Delray, he was a distinguished member of NYMEX. He was brilliant, witty, funny, kind and generous. New York services. Memorial in Delray to be announced. Donations to the Cardiac Care Program at Boca Raton Community Hospital.

BETHENCOURT--Robert Keane, of New York City, on April 5th, 2008. Son of the late Luis and Florence Bethencourt, brother of Anne Bethencourt Mertens and Luise F. Bethencourt, uncle of John, Michael, Peter, Christopher, Timothy, Thomas and Paul Mertens. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 1-5 Sunday and 2-4 and 7-9 Monday. Mass of Christian Burial at Annunciation Church, Crestwood, on Tuesday, April 8th at 11am.

The collapse of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s congestion pricing plan at the hands of the State Assembly has prompted an inevitable round of second-guessing and speculation. Having managed to secure support from the City Council, the governor and leaders of the State Senate, why was Mr. Bloomberg unsuccessful at persuading the Democratic-controlled Assembly and its powerful speaker, Sheldon Silver?
A day after the defeat of his congestion pricing proposal at the hands of the State Assembly, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has turned his attention to an environmentally related topic: solar energy.

Paul Lacy, 50, has lived in Brooklyn for all but two years since 1983. He has worked as a factory night watchman and an apprentice furniture maker. Now he does freelance page layout for publishers of science and technical books. But Mr. Lacy’s real passion — like that of so many New Yorkers who are defined as much by their hobbies as their day jobs — is street photography. He has just published his first book, “Brooklyn Storefronts,” a collection of 75 color photographs of small, independently owned stores throughout the borough.

WASHINGTON — In a speech at Georgetown University this morning, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg lashed out at the leadership of the Democratic-controlled New York State Assembly for refusing to bring his New York City congestion pricing plan to a vote on Monday, effectively killing it. He said the chamber had failed to act despite support from other leaders, including Gov. David A. Paterson; the State Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno; and the Assembly minority leader, James N. Tedisco.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg today announced the appointment of the Rev. Joseph P. Parkes, a Jesuit educator, as chairman of the New York City Campaign Finance Board and the appointment of Preeta D. Bansal, a nationally known litigator, to the board. Father Parkes will succeed Frederick A. O. Schwarz Jr., an eminent lawyer who works at the Brennan Center for Justice, and Ms. Bansal will succeed Father Parks as one of the board’s four other members.

Testimony is expected to end as early as this afternoon in the Sean Bell case with the sixth and possibly last witness for the defense, a ballistics expert, facing cross-examination after the lunch break.If the defense rests its case today, on the 26th day of trial, closing arguments are expected to begin early next week, after which Justice Arthur J. Cooperman, who is hearing the case without a jury, will consider verdicts in the manslaughter, assault and reckless endangerment case against Detectives Gescard F. Isnora, Michael Oliver and Marc Cooper.
These days, even those who don’t drink Starbucks coffee know that the sleek green-logoed chain is blighted by the business blues.

Eleven New York City high schools have been newly identified as failing under the federal No Child Left Behind law, the State Education Department said today. Fourteen city high schools have improved enough to be removed from the list, which is released each year.In December, the state added 60 city elementary and middle schools to the list of those failing under the federal law. Of the more than 1,400 schools in New York City, 374 are now deemed failing under the federal law, including 81 high schools — up from 335 last year. (An additional 69 city schools have similarly failed to meet standards, but they were not placed on the failing schools list because they do not receive federal Title I antipoverty money.)

The last time David A. Paterson attended an Association for a Better New York breakfast was little more than a month ago, and he was there as a member of the audience listening to a speech by Gov. Eliot Spitzer. This morning, Mr. Paterson was there again, but this time he was the governor and the featured speaker.

A few months ago I interviewed Dan Pink, fresh off a two month stay in Japan, where he had immersed himself in the study of manga, a Japanese form of print cartoons and a $2.4 billion -a-year publishing niche. In Japan manga books cover a wide range of topics -- from retirement to sexuality -- and they are read by people of all ages. Mr. Pink studied manga while in Tokyo on a fellowship sponsored by the Japan Society. Once he got home, he applied his newfound expertise to publish the first manga business book for the American market, The Adventures of Johnny Bunko: The Last Career Guide You'll Ever Need.

I'd like to introduce you to one of my favorite animals: the shrimp goby. These pretty little fish lead lives of enviable indolence. As their name suggests, they live with shrimp (often, a pair). The shrimp build and maintain a burrow, which the goby and shrimp live in together. Each shrimp works hard, shoveling sand out of the front entrance like a miniature bulldozer. As soon as it's delivered the rubble to a suitable distance, it shoots back into the burrow.

We are considering a trip to Tuscany including Florence, Siena and other places. From everything we have heard, driving in this area is a nightmare. Is it feasible to see this part of the world using safe public transportation or should we shift our dreams somewhere else?

The Russian team championships are held each year in Dagomys, a resort near the southern Russian city of Sochi, on the Black Sea. This year, the championships are being held from April 1-14. Although there is a Web site for the championship, it is only in Russian, making it a bit harder to follow. Chessbase.com has published a report and The Week in Chess is giving semi-regular updates.

In the last two days, two amusing videos have popped up on the Internet. One is on YouTube and recounts a demonstration by Derren Brown, a British illusionist. In it, Brown, not much more than an amateur chess player himself, gave a simultaneous exhibition against nine players, including several of Britain's strongest grandmasters, and emerged with a score of four wins, three losses and two draws. How he did it was rather easy to understand, but how he knew how many pieces there would be on each board at the end is rather perplexing.

One of the greatest things about the Web is that -- as opposed to, say, the letters section of the New York Review of Books -- the allotted space for literary and ideological feuds is more or less infinite. One of the more interesting recent running dramas has involved two men who say they are old friends: Time magazine bigshot and "Primary Colors" author Joe Klein and former Bush White House staffer Peter Wehner, who writes at Commentary.

Pressure is mounting for the European Parliament to take action against Spain for demolishing homes owned by foreigners.

It has long been understood that many fish species crave complexity. Flat stretches of sea floor offer no nooks in which to hide or lay eggs, less surface area providing a home for algae, invertebrates, and other potential food sources, and no eddies in which fish can take shelter from strong currents. In 2000, I wrote about how deep-water trawling was bulldozing cold-water corals and turning variegated stretches of the sea bed into the ecological equivalent of a plowed field.

It is impossible to miss the hulking presence of the Mets' gleaming new home in 2009, Citi Field, that looms behind the outfield wall, just as it is impossible to look at the Phillies and not think of their eight straight victories over the Mets that closed out last season.

Joe Girardi said he expects Derek Jeter to miss all three games this week against the Kansas City Royals with a strained quadriceps. Jeter, who had ice on his upper left thigh as he walked around the clubhouse today, said he is shut down at least for the day.

CBS's coverage of the men's college basketball championship led the network to a ratings victory on Monday, while "Dancing With the Stars" put ABC in second place.

Bill Buckner, a long lost member of the Red Sox family, returned to Fenway Park on Tuesday to throw out the first pitch as part of the team's championship celebration. Reuters: "Comcast Corp. urged a U.S. appeals court on Tuesday to overturn a decision by federal regulators, who refused to a waive a rule designed to open up the market for cable TV set-top boxes."

Robert Fagles, the noted translator of Greek and Latin classics - above all, the three big epics, the "Iliad," the "Odyssey" and most recently the "Aeneid" - died on March 26 in Princeton, N.J., where he was an emeritus professor of the university. The Times has run several good articles about Fagles and his work, including his obituary; an interview by Charles McGrath, the former editor of the Book Review, after the publication of Fagles's "Aeneid" in 2006; and the Book Review's own cover review of the same work, written by Brad Leithauser.

While much of the talk has been about the battle for white men in the remaining states to weigh in on the Democratic nomination battle, Senator Barack Obama is out with a new spot in Pennsylvania that appears to go after his rival's most loyal constituency: women.

Scotty Bowman is the most successful coach in NHL history. He holds virtually every record for coaching excellence, including nine Stanley Cup championships as a coach with Montreal, Pittsburgh and Detroit, a 10th as a director of player personnel in Pittsburgh and 13 coaching appearances in the Stanley Cup final, his first in 1967 with the first-year expansion St. Louis Blues. He also was the winning coach for Team Canada in the inaugural 1976 Canada Cup international tournament. He is currently a consultant for Detroit.

Updated | 3:56 p.m. With a few exceptions, decorum ruled the public gallery as General David H. Petraeus and Ryan C. Crocker, the American ambassador to Iraq, presented their assessments of the war to members of the Senate Armed Services Committee this morning.

We knew it was too good to be true. The Mets had gone a full six days without putting anyone on the disabled list before Matt Wise landed there this morning with a contusion of his right forearm. I wonder how one can get a contusion (a fancy term for a bruise) without banging into something (neither Wise nor Willie Randolph recalled it happening), but that's the official diagnosis.

Aired Monday night on NBC: France has made contact with those pirates that hijacked a French luxury yacht off the coast of Somalia last week. Did you know about this story? Negotiations are going very slowly. So far, the only thing the pirates have said is "Arrrrgh!"
There's no pleasure in beating up on China, a country of much promise whose political, economic and military capabilities will shape the world for years to come.
T Magazine's Senior Editor Sandra Ballentine opens up her little black book of tips on where to go, what to buy and whom to know.
As Microsoft continues to press its takeover bid for Yahoo, Microsoft's shareholders might be interested to know more about the deal-making history of Microsoft's chief executive, Steven Ballmer.

A U.K. study declared that some artificial food colorings -- specifically those with the prefix "E" -- could be as damaging to children's health as leaded gasoline. According to the FDA's site, these chemicals are "generally" approved for use in human food in the United States.
Forbes loves lists. The latest one looks at the best emerging property markets, the "up-and-comers" in the world property horse race.

We've been talking about the nefarious effect of the guaranteed point, especially in light of the way it makes teams play not to lose in the third period of close regular-season games, as several players told Dave Caldwell in this article in February. Now the final report is in for the season just completed, and the statistical evidence of just how much it makes teams dog it at the end of regulation was reconfirmed -- the third straight year that regulation ties skyrocketed in the final third of the season.

The Democratic presidential rivals, once again, have returned to Washington today for a series of appearances on Capitol Hill. But before arriving at committee hearings to hear testimony from Gen. David H. Petraeus, the top American commander in Iraq, Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama crossed paths at a union rally.

A brief outburst from the crowd stalled Senator John McCain briefly during his opening statement to the Senate Armed Services Committee, but he quickly bounced back with a joke ("I have had this experience previously") . Citing improvements to security and political reconciliation, Senator McCain declared: "We've come a long way since early 2007."
Aired Monday night on NBC: Yesterday, true story, Hillary Clinton's top adviser abruptly left her campaign, yeah. Yeah, when he heard about it, Bill Clinton said, "Wait, we can leave?"
In a Mediterranean spirit, this dish combines fish with four common ingredients to produce wonderful flavor, texture and even elegance.

Just when you thought it was safe to go back to the bookstore, questions are being raised about the nonfictional status of another best seller. In a story in Sunday's Boston Globe Ideas section, Drake Bennett writes that Ben Mezrich's 2002 book "Bringing Down the House" - a tale of whiz-kid gamblers from MIT that was the basis for the new Kevin Spacey movie "21" - is so heavily embellished as to verge on fantasy.
I keep thinking that online video will be a boon to social sciences like linguistics and sociology. People will get to see all those wacko subway studies or gender tests for themselves.

Apparently they've modernized the best scoreboard in baseball, sadly, but I hope they still play "Kansas City"/"Hey, Hey, Hey, Hey" (one of the Beatles' best covers) if the Royals win.

The three presidential candidates have their chance to grill General David H. Petraeus, the top officer in Iraq, and Ryan C. Crocker, the American ambassador to Iraq, on Capitol Hill today while the men are in town for Congressional hearings.

Four years ago on TSN, Canada's all-sports cable network, someone got an idea to juke up their playoff preview show. After all, this business of predicting winners (and not just in hockey, or sports, but everywhere, for Pete's sake) is rather overblown. You could ask a monkey to spin a wheel and probably get as good a result as a panel of experts. So that was the idea: They got a monkey to spin a wheel before each round and the monkey did better than most of the panel.

Despite shareholder fury over Morgan Stanley's fourth-quarter loss, John J. Mack and 10 other directors are set to win re-election to the firm's board, Bloomberg News reported Tuesday citing an unnamed source.

Microsoft delivered a threat to Yahoo over the weekend, indicating that if the search giant doesn't start playing ball it may lower its offer and formally go hostile, there is plenty of speculation about whether or not Microsoft's chief Steven Ballmer may be playing a game of chicken.
The job market looks bleak for Bear Stearns employees swamping Wall Street with their résumés as the larger rival JPMorgan Chase acquires the firm, investment bankers and recruiters said.
Merrill Lynch does not plan to raise more capital and will continue to shrink its balance sheet amid the global credit crunch, the investment bank's chief executive, John Thain, said on Tuesday.
Hedge-fund titans James H. Simons and Stephen Mandel are showing the biggest losses of their careers in the $1.9 trillion industry's worst start in more than a decade, Bloomberg News reported.
The Carlyle Group has formed a $1.35 billion fund to troll for bruised companies and securities less than a month after the failure of one of its own investments.

Wireless chip developer SiBeam stuck with longtime backers for the third time, on Monday, April 7, announcing that it closed a $40 million Series C round of funding to support commercial production of low-cost chips used to power high-bandwidth video transmission.
Richrelevance, a new San Francisco company offering personalized recommendations for online shopping businesses, has raised $4.2 million in a second round of financing.
Canadian hedge fund manager Eric Sprott is planning an initial public offering of Sprott Asset Management in the midst of the worst I.P.O. market in a decade, The Globe and Mail reported.

J.C. Flowers & Company, a financial services-focused private equity firm, renewed its attack on London insurer Friends Provident, making an unchanged 3.5 billion pound ($7 billion) takeover proposal and brandishing a financing package that it said would be underwritten by major banks.

With the credit squeeze having all but shuttered the private equity industry, buyout moguls anxious to spend the money they raised are investing in publicly-traded companies. The latest example is David Bonderman's TPG, which is expected to invest $5 billion to help keep Washington Mutual afloat.

Eric Dinallo, New York State's insurance superintendent, has had a hectic first year on the job. In its latest issue, Investment Dealers' Digest interviewed him about the situation at various bond insurers and his thoughts on the credit crisis.
Leon Black's buyout firm, Apollo Management, is considering the idea of a "pre-packaged" bankruptcy plan for ailing home furnishings retailer Linens 'n Things, The New York Post reported.
Anda Networks, which provides Ethernet services to telecommunications providers, has canceled its proposed initial public offering, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing Friday.

The chairman of Citigroup's audit and risk committee, C. Michael Armstrong, who has overseen more than $22 billion in write-offs, is poised to resign from that post under pressure from shareholders, The New York Times reported.
Advent International raised $10.4 billion for its sixth and biggest private equity fund amid a dearth of leveraged buyouts.
Not long ago the market police at the Securities and Exchange Commission gave JPMorgan Chase the Wall Street equivalent of a traffic ticket. The penalty: $25 million.
British private equity firm Permira gave a rare glimpse into its inner workings Monday as it published its first-ever annual report in an attempt towards increased transparency.

The chairman of a U.S. congressional committee is questioning the Federal Reserve's unilateral decision to let BlackRock manage $30 billion in assets as part of the government-orchestrated rescue of Bear Stearns.

In the second half of 2007, many hedge-fund wizards seemed to lose their magic -- but not John Paulson. According to estimates in the latest issue in Trader Monthly, Mr. Paulson earned about $3 billion last year, thanks in large part to his firm's bets that the subprime mortgage market would collapse.
Discover Financial Services said Monday it would buy Citigroup's Diners Club International for $165 million in a deal that expands Discover's global presence and allows Citi to streamline operations.

Motorola's peace treaty Monday with investor Carl C. Icahn is emblematic of a trend this spring: Proxy battles could reach record levels. But many companies are finding it's not worth the time and expense of a fight, particularly when dissident shareholders have the upper hand amid a weak landscape for companies.

TPG Capital, the private equity firm that is reportedly close to inking a deal to lead a $5 billion investment in Washington Mutual, said Tuesday that it had paid around $800 million for a 50 percent stake Russia's largest pharmaceuticals distributor, in what it said is the largest private equity investment in Russia to date.

W.R. Grace, the chemical company, announced a deal to settle outstanding asbestos-related claims, which it hopes will allow it to move toward emerging from seven years of bankruptcy protection. The company said the total value of the settlement was about $3 billion.

The liquidators of two Bear Stearns mortgage hedge funds that collapsed last year, filed suit on Monday against the company and its auditor, Deloitte & Touche, seeking to recover over $1 billion in losses.

Merger talks have ended between the U.S. Federal Home Loan Bank of Dallas and its sister bank in Chicago, they said on Monday, after more than eight months of talks to partner the lenders, which specialize in home mortgages.

Delta Air Lines has agreed to revive merger talks with Northwest Airlines despite the pilots of the two companies not having reached agreement on the transfer of seniority in a merger, according to press reports.
The Nielsen Company is making another acquisition in a deal that underlines the growing interest in gauging how well advertising works - or fails to work.
The Securities and Exchange Commission on Monday filed fraud complaints against five former San Diego city officials who played roles in the city's financial crisis in 2002 and 2003.

The KfW Group of Germany said Monday that its chief executive, Ingrid Matthaeus-Maier, was stepping down, and it set aside 1.8 billion euros more ($2.8 billion) in reserves for the bailout of a German lender, IKB Deutsche Industriebank.

The Tampa Bay Lightning landed the No. 1 pick in the N.H.L.’s draft lottery. The Lightning had the best chance (48.8 percent) of winning the top pick after earning 71 points (31-42-9) in the regular season. Tampa Bay became only the fourth team in 14 lotteries to have the fewest points and win the lottery. The Los Angeles Kings will pick second.

New England signed the free-agent linebacker Victor Hobson away from the Jets on Monday, bolstering its aging linebacker corps. Hobson, 28, spent all five of his seasons with the Jets, starting 58 games. He joins a linebacking group that had Tedy Bruschi, Mike Vrabel and Junior Seau as starters last season. Hobson, a second-round draft pick out of Michigan in 2003, started 14 games last year and had 62 tackles and 2 sacks. His best season was 2006, when he had 100 tackles, 6 sacks and an interception.

An art review on Friday about “The Genius of Japanese Lacquer: Masterworks by Shibata Zeshin,” at Japan Society, referred incorrectly to inro, the small, nested boxes displayed in the exhibition that substituted for pockets in traditional Japanese clothing. They were made to be hung from a waist sash, not around the neck.

An article on Saturday about Larry Brown’s ties to the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball Final Four teams misstated one of his career moves. He left U.C.L.A. in 1981 to coach the Nets in the N.B.A. — not to coach Kansas, where he went in 1983 after leaving New Jersey.

The Sports of The Times column on Friday, about the potential impact of changes to the women’s tennis calendar on Serena and Venus Williams, misspelled the given name of a player Serena Williams defeated at the Sony Ericsson Open and misstated the day of their match. She is Justine Henin, not Justin; the match was last Tuesday — not Monday, March 31.

A picture caption on Sunday with an article about the military service of Senator John McCain’s son referred imprecisely to the candidate’s father. At the time the photograph of Senator McCain and his father, John S. McCain Jr., was taken, the senator’s father was a Navy captain, not an admiral. (He was promoted to admiral later in his career.).

An article on Thursday about the closing of a television station in the former Soviet republic of Georgia, which is affiliated with the News Corporation, misspelled the surname of a News Corp. spokeswoman who declined to comment on accusations that the station was involved in a coup plot. She is Teri Everett, not Everette.

An article on Saturday about the pianist who helped found the Beaux Arts Trio, which gave its final New York performance on Sunday evening, misspelled his given name. He is Menahem Pressler, not Menachem. (The error also appeared in two picture captions and in capsule summaries about the article and about related information at nytimes.com/music.).

An article on Friday about HarperCollins’s formation of a new publishing group that will substitute profit-sharing with authors for cash advances and try to eliminate the practice of allowing booksellers to return unsold books misstated the usual basis of royalty payments. After authors have paid off their advances, their royalties are typically 15 percent of the hardcover price for each book sold, not 15 percent of the profits.

"Valkyrie," in which Tom Cruise plays a German officer who tried to assassinate Hitler, will have its release delayed until early next year, MGM and United Artists said on Monday. The film was originally scheduled for release in July 2008, then was bumped to an October date, which would have dropped it into the thick of Hollywood’s awards race. The new date is Feb. 13, 2009.

Radiohead, Rage Against the Machine, Nine Inch Nails and Kanye West will be among the performers at the Lollapalooza music festival, scheduled for Aug. 1 to 3 in Grant Park, Chicago. ... The rapper Jay-Z is scheduled to appear on July 3, the first night of the four-day Wireless Festival in Hyde Park, London, the BBC reported. Performing on the same bill will be Mark Ronson, Hot Chip and Roisin Murphy. Other headliners at the festival include Morrissey, Fatboy Slim and Counting Crows.

David Hockney, below, has donated his biggest painting to Tate Britain. Composed of a grid of 50 small canvases and measuring 40 feet by 15 feet, the work is “Bigger Trees Near Water,” a Yorkshire landscape that was first exhibited last year at the Royal Academy, the BBC reported. Nicholas Serota, the director of the museum, said, “Standing before David Hockney’s ‘Bigger Trees Near Water,’ the viewer is overwhelmed by the beauty of the winter trees and the energy of the Yorkshire landscape.” The painting will go on view next year.

On the lowest-rated Sunday for the five broadcast television networks since Christmas Eve 2006, ABC and CBS finished in a tie for first place over all. According to Nielsen’s estimates, ABC got a lift as usual from “Extreme Makeover: Home Edition” and “Oprah’s Big Give,” which drew 9.9 million and 9.4 million viewers, respectively, at 8 and 9 p.m. The two shows, along with ABC’s “Here Come the Newlyweds” at 10 (7.7 million), delivered the night’s top ratings among adults 18 to 49; but they trailed CBS’s 9 p.m. drama “Cold Case” for the largest audience over all (11.8 million). CBS, despite matching ABC in total viewers, finished third in the 18-to-49 set behind both ABC and Fox, which broadcast mostly repeats. NBC ranked a distant fourth for the night in that demographic, attracting just 5.7 million and 4 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m. with back-to-back debuts of two USA Network cable series, “Monk” and “Psych.”.
A revival of David Mamet’s “American Buffalo” is scheduled to open on Broadway in the fall.

“48 Hours,” the CBS newsmagazine usually known for investigating murder mysteries, is about to tackle a very different subject: teenagers who are training to be Christian missionaries. On Tuesday the network is expected to announce a collaboration with two Oscar-nominated filmmakers for a one-hour report titled “The Lord’s Boot Camp.” Heidi Ewing and Rachel Grady, the producers of the acclaimed 2006 documentary “Jesus Camp,” gained access to an evangelical camp in Florida last year and followed three teenage girls. The resulting report will be shown on Saturday at 8 p.m., Eastern and Pacific times, on CBS. Susan Zirinsky, the executive producer of “48 Hours,” said she hoped the project would open the door to future collaborations with filmmakers. “We love the crime genre, but this is another interesting way to expand our base,” she said.

SCHARF--Anita. The board of directors of the Dr. Bernanrd and Helen Sheftman foundation sadly acknowledges the passing of Anita Scharf, who had a true passion for charity. She was a board member for the past 40 years and will be greatly missed. The Sheftman Foundation Jack L. Scharf, President SCHARF--Anita, of Riverdale, NY passed away April 7th 2008. A wife, mother, motherin-law, grandmother, greatgrandmother and retired teacher, she will be deeply missed by all who knew her. Anita is survived by her loving husband of 60 years, Jack, son Kenneth and daughter Donna Hoenig. Other family members include her brother Dr. Charles Marcus, her seven devoted grandchildren Robert, Jay, Daniel, Andrew, Dr. Sandra Yahalom, Laura Silbermann and Michael Hoenig and her loving greatgrandchildren Nili, Alex, Yakir, Kayla, Hanna and Orli. She will live in our hearts forever.

ANDERSON--Robert D., of Southold, NY on April 7, 2008 at the age of 77. President and Founder of Robert D. Anderson Co., Inc. Graduate of Cornell University School of Engineering 1952. Beloved husband of Lois (nee Thompson). Loving father of Thomas, Mark, Bruce, John, Dr. Jeffrey and David. Cherished by 13 grandchildren. Fond brother of the late Betty Anderson King. Caring uncle of Robert Turner, Bill King and Susan King. Friends may call on Tuesday from 2-4pm and 7-9pm at the DeFriest-Grattan Funeral Homes, Inc., 51400 Route 25, Southold (19 miles East of L.I.E., Exit 73). The Liturgy of Christian Burial, Wednesday at 11am, St. Patrick's R.C. Church. Interment St. Patrick's Cemetery.

ECKER--Robert, D.D.S. With love in our hearts we mourn the passing of our dear friend and partner. Everyone he touched loved and respected him. You will always be with us. David & Leslie Engelson and Family

8 P.M. (13, 49) CRACKING THE MAYA CODE The Maya of Central America inscribed their intricate hieroglyphic script on monuments and pottery and in bark-paper books, only four of which survived destruction by European conquerors. One is pictured above. The language remained a mystery until a recent series of breakthroughs allowed scholars to decipher the New World's most highly developed ancient writing system. This ''Nova'' episode looks at the research of modern-day experts like David Stuart and Simon Martin as well as that of earlier scholars. 9 P.M. DOREAU--Winnie D. ''Dixie'' Reynolds, beloved wife of the late Bernard Doreau, passed away on Saturday, March 22nd at the Village House in Newport, RI. She was born in Durant, Oklahoma on February 13, 1906 and led a long, very interesting life. Her first job was for Vogue Magazine as a member of the Fashion Department. She then moved into photographic assignments at the magazine. This assignment served as a springboard into a very successful career as a well-known portrait photographer under the name of Dixie Reynolds in New York City. She met her husband in New York and they were married in 1960. She collaborated on several books with him (he wrote under the penname of Max Dorian) by providing the photographic contents. She was also an associate member of the Foreign Press Association. She is survived by her stepson Michel Doreau of Carlisle, Massachusetts and her great-niece Mary Ann Fitzpatrick of Dallas, Texas. Per Winnie's request, all services are private. For a complete obituary please visit www.onhfh.com

David Hockney, below, has donated his biggest painting to Tate Britain. Composed of a grid of 50 small canvases and measuring 40 feet by 15 feet, the work is ''Bigger Trees Near Water,'' a Yorkshire landscape that was first exhibited last year at the Royal Academy, the BBC reported. Nicholas Serota, the director of the museum, said, ''Standing before David Hockney's 'Bigger Trees Near Water,' the viewer is overwhelmed by the beauty of the winter trees and the energy of the Yorkshire landscape.'' The painting will go on view next year.

With a $10 million contribution from Cantor Fitzgerald, the institution that suffered the greatest loss of human life on 9/11, the National September 11 Memorial and Museum at the World Trade Center has reached the $350 million construction fundraising goal, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced Wednesday. Mr. Bloomberg is the chairman of the memorial and has personally donated at least $15 million to the project.“To honor our colleagues and all those who lost their lives on that tragic day, we are privileged to provide this gift to help realize the dream of building our country’s national 9/11 memorial,” said Howard W. Lutnick, chairman and chief executive of Cantor, where 658 employees — including Mr. Lutnick’s brother, Gary — died in the terrorist attack.

As the most-high profile Olympics in a generation approaches, just four months away, the world has simultaneously cast one eye toward the violent Tibetan clashes in China and the other toward the roving (and lately also violent) path of the Olympic torch, which has drawn the ire of protesters.In New York City, home to a broad range of Chinese immigrants and their children, the attitudes of Chinese-Americans toward the conflicts are as diverse as the people themselves, depending upon how they feel about the government of China, the sense of an uber-Chinese identity, and the mixing of politics and sports. Attitudes range from indifference to patriotism to harsh criticism of the Chinese government.

Faced with a deluge of children vying for coveted slots in gifted-and-talented programs and a shortage of top-scoring applicants, ­ Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein said that he intended to change the city’s new, standardized policy for admitting children to the programs.The chancellor proposed today that students scoring in the top 10th percentile on admissions tests would be guaranteed a slot in kindergarten or first-grade gifted and talented programs; last fall, he announced that only those scoring in the top 5th percentile would be admitted.

The top 1 percent of New York City tax filers now receive more than a third of the city’s adjusted gross income, according to an analysis released today that looked in part at tax returns.This reflects an overarching trend that income inequality in New York State continues to be the worst in the country, echoing previously released census figures, according to a new edition of the report by the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities and the Economic Policy Institute, Pulling Apart: A State-by-State Analysis of Income Trends [pdf].

With the Freedom Tower headed steadily skyward (though not yet in view of sidewalk superintendents), the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is looking ahead to the moment when the public will want a slice of that sky.It said Wednesday that it has begun searching for a private operator for the observation area planned on the 102nd floor of the tower, also known as 1 World Trade Center. Early next month, the authority will ask prospective candidates for their qualifications. Qualified bidders will be asked to submit proposals at the end of 2008. A firm will be chosen in early 2009. The observation area is expected to open in 2012.

Updated, 5 p.m. | The New York State Senate and Assembly have approved the bills making up the state’s new $122 billion budget. The budget, which relies on an array of taxes and fees for smokers, banks, hair salon patrons and others to keep the state’s 200,000-person government running, comes as New York faces one of the most uncertain economic outlooks in recent years.Gov. David A. Paterson and lawmakers struck a deal on the spending plan late Tuesday night.

The Mets' best-case scenario was that Orlando Hernandez would return to the rotation in about a week to 10 days. Hernandez, who was evaluated in New York on Wednesday after complaining of discomfort in his right foot, has been shut down for the next two weeks, and I would bet a bag of Blow Pops that we do not see him again until the middle of May. He'll need time to recuperate, to rebuild arm strength, to make rehab starts in the minors -- add all that together and we're talking at least another month, folks. Just saying.

It happened, after a few days of nearly nonstop eating, that Fred and I decided to sightsee. First we hiked to the understated, 900-year-old abbey of Sant' Antimo, not far from where we were staying near Montalcino. We walked for a couple of hours before coming upon the striking and by then familiar view (it's widely publicized) of the Norman-style abbey with its distinctively tall, slender cedar tree alongside. We hung out for a while -- the weather was gorgeous -- ate some fruit, and went inside in time to hear the monks chant a bit.

(From left,winston, concord, chanel, maccanico)Bruce Pask, T's men's fashion director, is in Switzerland at Baselworld, the top trade show for the watch industry, to report on the styles and technological breakthroughs that will be worn on stylish wrists in the months ahead. He calls it "a luxe trade show on steroids."

No doubt everyone has seen Victoria Beckham in the Marc Jacobs ads, and some of you may have caught Juergen Teller's show at the Lehmann Maupin Gallery. I went to the opening-it was during Fashion Week, a nice diversion-and I saw Juergen at the back of the gallery. He seemed constantly surrounded by young Asian girls waiting to take his picture with their cell phone cameras. I was struck by the portrait of Beckham, the half-nude (and maybe fully nude) picture of Marc sitting at a desk, and Juergen's photos from Kiev and other places, many of them of Lara Stone. I was struck by how much Marc's ideas, the personality of Marc, seemed to feed Juergen's work-and vice versa-and I thought it would be interesting, I told Juergen, to write about their collaboration, already a decade on. There isn't another like it in fashion at the moment.

The Insider is a recurring profile of emerging tastemakers in the fields of fashion, design, food, travel and the arts. Here Julie Trotta, owner of Fake Estate gallery, shares a few of her stylish essentials with The Moment. Trotta is gearing up for spring with new works from the artist (and granddaughter of Jimmy Carter) Sarah Chuldenko and a group show organized by the photographer Glynnis McDaris. But come fall, Trotta is keeping things closer to home with an upcoming show curated by her grandmother, the feminist art historian Linda Nochlin.Name: Julie TrottaAge: 25Occupation: Director and owner of Fake Estate Retail standbys: Albertine in the West Village, John McWhinnie at Glenn Horowitz Bookseller and Art Gallery for books, John Derian and Moon River Chattel for home.Music: Priestbird, Free Blood, Helene Smith.Provisions: Max Delivery, Rocco's, Nuts About Nuts.For gifts: Vintage perfume bottles from Bond No. 9, white cotton nightgowns from Laina Jane.Restaurant: Blaue Gans, Bacaro, Banjara in the East Vilalge for delicious Indian. L'Epicerie in Brooklyn does great private dinners.Cocktail: Dirty martiniMomentary style obsessions: Right now I'm into mixing menswear with silky florals. I also always love Rachel Comey shoes, Acne jeans, Epice scarves and Kelly Bergin skirts and cocktail dresses. Kelly is a dear friend and I absolutely love her line.Reading material: The New Yorker. I'm currently reading a biography of Aby Warburg.Art picks: I love this show at Lisa Cooley called "Gut of the Quantifier." Also Corbet at the Met, Peter Coffin at Andrew Kreps Gallery, Megan Pflug at the V&A gallery, and there's a good self portrait show at James Fuentes.Museums: Tate Modern and the Met.Movie: 3 Women, La Cienega, and the upcoming Silent Light by Carlos Reygadas.Vacation destination: I like to head upstate for a quick getaway, but hoping to make a big trip to Buenos Aires soon.Something you are looking forward to this spring: My upcoming shows! The Book Review's special issue on Islam (Jan. 6) ran an essay by the controversial scholar Tariq Ramadan called "Reading the Koran." Many were puzzled by it, but then how often do readers of the Book Review come upon a piece on Islam's holy book by a believing Muslim? The essay led in many directions, one of them being this: How do we happen to hold the particular religious beliefs we have? For sure, not through a process of reasoned thought and careful comparison. How many Christians and Jews have bothered to read the Koran, not to mention the Book of Mormon or the writings of L. Ron Hubbard before deciding what to believe? How many Muslims have read the Bible?

Leon Black generally avoids the public eye -- so why did his buyout firm, Apollo Management, just file to go public? And why now, when private equity deals are in a credit-crunch-induced coma? Well, it had to: As part of its debut last August on Goldman Sachs's private market, GSTrUE, Apollo agreed to register for a public offering in 240 days. The deadline was just about now. As we lace 'em up for The Morning Skate, getting ready for the playoffs, one thing pops out at us. Is it the parity of regular season? Is it the geographical proximity of the first round match-ups? Is it the unprecedented impact young players have had throughout the NHL? Is it that if we live in the US and want to watch Alexander Ovechkin lose his playoff virginity in the first round, we'll have to listen to Joe Beninati on Versus? No, non, nje, nyet. It's the totally self-promoting fact that yesterday's Q&A with Scotty Bowman is in the Top 10 most emailed sport stories in the Times. Last night it was eighth, at one point this morning it was sixth and now it is seventh.

An article in some editions last Wednesday about a Justice Department legal memorandum on interrogation methods misstated the day the memo was released in 2003 and referred incorrectly to the resignation of Jay S. Bybee, who signed the memo, in relationship to the memo’s release. It was issued on March 14, a Friday, not a Saturday; and that was two weeks before Mr. Bybee resigned as the head of the Office of Legal Counsel, not the day after he left.

Because of an editing error, an article in some editions on Saturday about testimony by Javier Inclán, an aide to Gov. Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey, in an extortion case against the mayor of Guttenberg, N.J., misspelled the surname of the executive of Hudson County, where Mr. Inclán, a former county clerk, began his political career. The county executive is Thomas A. DeGise, not DeGuise.

An article on Saturday about a shortage of primary care physicians in Massachusetts misstated a word in a quotation by Katherine J. Atkinson, a doctor who said that her insurance reimbursements often do not cover her costs. She said, “I calculated that every time I have a Medicaid patient, it’s like handing them a $20 bill when they leave;” she did not say “Medicare” patient.

The Public Lives column in some editions on Friday, about Ian McKeever, a horse-and-carriage driver who is fighting efforts to ban the business in New York City, misstated the county name in Ireland where he grew up. It is Meath, not Meade.

An article on Friday about the Penn Center, a school for freed slaves on St. Helena Island, S.C., that the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King used as a retreat center misstated the age of Joseph McDomick, a former staff member. He is 69, not 72.

An article on Friday about a disclosure by Speaker Christine C. Quinn that the New York City Council had for years been appropriating city funds to organizations that did not exist misspelled, in some editions, the surname of a top finance staffer of Ms. Quinn who has since left her office. He is Michael Keogh, not Keoug.

An obituary in some editions on Sunday and in some copies on Monday about the actor Charlton Heston misstated his given name at birth. It was John Charles Carter, not Charlton Carter. The obituary also referred incorrectly to the character played by Orson Welles in the film “Touch of Evil,” in which Mr. Heston had a starring role. The character, Quinlan, is a police captain, not a sheriff. And a list of Mr. Heston’s films accompanying the obituary on Monday misstated the relationship between two characters in the film “Midway,” in which Mr. Heston played a Naval officer. The characters, the officer’s son and a woman of Japanese descent, are hoping to marry; they are not already married.

The byline for the E-Commerce Report column on Monday, about fishing as an online fantasy sport, was omitted. It was by Bob Tedeschi.

An article on Monday about the growing number of foreigners in Italy who have excelled as professional chefs of Italian cuisine referred incorrectly to the preparation of guanciale, or pig cheek, an ingredient used in carbonara, a pasta dish. Most guanciale is cured, by salting and drying; it is not smoked.

Hundreds of employees were evacuated from a nuclear power plant for several hours because a clerk at a nearby convenience store misunderstood a comment by a new plant worker. A man entered the store about 7:15 a.m. and asked for directions to the Point Beach nuclear power plant, the clerk told the police in Two Rivers. As the man was leaving, the clerk heard him say he “came to blow up the place,” the authorities said. The clerk called the police, who tracked down the man’s rental car at the power plant. He told F.B.I. agents he was a contractor reporting for his first day at the plant, and said that what he told the clerk was that he “hoped he wouldn’t blow up the place” because of his inexperience, the police said.

Federal immigration officials said they had received enough applications for three-year visas for high-skilled immigrants, known as H-1B, to meet the quota of 65,000 for the year beginning Oct. 1. Officials at Citizenship and Immigration Services said they closed the application period, which started April 1, after the pre-set minimum of five days. The agency also received enough applications to surpass an annual quota of 20,000 work visas for immigrants with a master’s degree or higher from an American college or university. The agency has not finished counting the applications, but they are expected to greatly exceed the quotas. In coming days, officials said, the agency will run an electronic lottery to select immigrants who will receive visas, in a process that prompted calls from technology businesses to raise the visa limits.

A deputy prison warden’s wife who disappeared with a convicted murderer in 1994 and spent a decade on the run with him has been charged with helping him escape. Three years after Bobbi Parker and Randolph Dial were found, a prosecutor charged Ms. Parker with assisting in Mr. Dial’s escape from the Oklahoma State Reformatory in Granite. Mr. Dial died in prison at age 62 last year. After his 2005 capture, he said he had kidnapped Ms. Parker at knifepoint and forced her to live with him. But a court affidavit alleges that the two were romantically involved before the escape. Ms. Parker, now 45, left behind her husband, Randy, who was then deputy warden at the Granite prison, and two daughters, then 8 and 10. She was reunited with them after she was found in April 2005 in East Texas.
An insurance company is not obligated to pay for water damage from the failure of New Orleans area levees after Hurricane Katrina, Louisiana’s highest court ruled.

Working in secret, federal archaeologists have dug up the remains of dozens of soldiers and children near a Civil War-era fort in south-central New Mexico after an informant tipped them off about widespread grave looting. The exhumations, above, conducted from August to October, removed 67 skeletons from the desert soil around Fort Craig — 39 men, 2 women and 26 children, according to two federal archaeologists who helped with the dig. They also found scores of empty graves and determined that 20 had been looted. The government kept its exhumation of the unmarked cemetery near the historic fort out of the public’s eye for months to prevent more thefts. The investigation began with a tip about an amateur historian who had displayed the mummified remains of a black soldier, draped in a Civil War-era uniform, in his house. Investigators say the historian, Dee Brecheisen, may have been a prolific looter who spotted historical sites from his plane. Mr. Brecheisen died in 2004, and although it was not clear whether the looting continued after his death, the authorities exhumed the unprotected site to prevent future thefts. The remains are being studied by Bureau of Reclamation scientists, who are piecing together information on their identities. They will be reburied at other national cemeteries.

How does Marta Eggerth, above, plan to celebrate her 96th birthday? By singing at the Café Sabarsky at the Neue Galerie. The cabaret performance on April 17 will be her second there this month. The other performance will take place on Thursday. Ms. Eggerth, whose career has embraced operetta, opera, lieder and European and American film, gave sold-out performances in October at Café Sabarsky, where she has been appearing since 2005. She will be accompanied by the pianist David Maiullo.

CBS’s coverage of the men’s college basketball championship led the network to a ratings victory on Monday, while “Dancing With the Stars” buoyed ABC in second place. Nielsen’s overnight estimates suggested that CBS’s live broadcast attracted slightly fewer viewers than the championship game a year ago, which drew 19.6 million. Even so, the basketball game, which followed repeats of CBS’s “Big Bang Theory” at 8 p.m. (10.2 million) and “Two and a Half Men” at 8:30 (12.2 million), still dominated its time-slot competitors. ABC earned its highest ratings early in the night thanks to “Dancing With the Stars,” which averaged 19.5 million viewers from 8 to 9:30. The rest of ABC’s lineup, “Samantha Who?” at 9:30 (11 million) and “The Bachelor” at 10 (7.2 million), struggled to attract comparable ratings. NBC ranked third over all, drawing its largest audience for “Medium” at 10 o’clock since May 2006 (10.7 million). Fox finished fourth for the night.

Mr. Diamond begins a monthlong European tour in Rotterdam, the Netherlands, on May 24 and is expected to tour North America in the summer.

American Ballet Theater will salute the centennial of the birth of the choreographer Antony Tudor (1908-1987) in its fall season at City Center, from Oct. 21 through Nov. 2. His works will be presented at each performance, and the Oct. 31 program — the Tudor Centennial Tribute, with special guest appearances and films of Tudor at work — will be devoted entirely to his dances. The evening will include “Continuo” (1971), “Jardin aux Lilas” (1936) and pas de deux from “Romeo and Juliet” (1943) and “The Leaves are Fading” (1975), as well as “Judgment of Paris” (1938) and “Pillar of Fire” (1942).

Viewer complaints prompted a Venezuelan television channel to banish the satirical animated sitcom “The Simpsons” and replace it with “Baywatch Hawaii,” The Associated Press reported. Elba Guillen, a spokeswomen for the station, Televen, said on Monday that the decision to change offerings in its 11 a.m. time slot followed viewer protests to the National Telecommunications Commission. Referring to “The Simpsons,” she said, “They consider it to be a series that isn’t appropriate for that time because it isn’t appropriate for children.” The commission did not specify what was deemed offensive but said that broadcasting the series at 11 a.m. could violate national regulations barring “messages that go against the whole education of boys, girls and adolescents.” “Baywatch Hawaii,” with its lifeguarding bikini-wearing beauties and muscle-bound hunks, took over the time slot on Friday.
The London-to-Broadway transfer of “Equus,” starring Daniel Radcliffe, will begin performances on Sept. 5 at the Broadhurst Theater.

The trouble-prone British rocker Pete Doherty, right, was sentenced on Tuesday to 14 weeks in jail for violating the terms of his probation, Reuters reported. The punishment cost Mr. Doherty, the 29-year-old Babyshambles frontman, a major solo engagement at the Royal Albert Hall on April 26 and an appearance the next day at the “Love Music Hate Racism” concert in London. He is also scheduled to perform at the Glastonbury Festival, June 27 to 29. In a statement about the Royal Albert Hall postponement, his record label, Parlophone, said, “Peter was very much looking forward to the show and would like to offer his sincerest apologies to all his fans and all those concerned.” At a hearing in West London Magistrate’s Court Mr. Doherty was jailed for violating probation and using drugs, the BBC reported. In earlier proceedings he was given a suspended jail sentence for drug possession and driving illegally last October. His supervision order required him to visit court regularly to make progress reports and to take part in a rehabilitation program. The BBC reported that he had missed one appointment with his probation officer and was late for another.

The Grammy Award-winning Stone Temple Pilots, after a five-year breakup and a nearly eight-year absence from concerts, plan to reunite for a 65-city North American tour that will begin on May 17 in Columbus, Ohio, The Associated Press reported. “The story’s not finished,” the singer Scott Weiland said. “There’s more to be revealed and more to be told.” Founded in 1992, the rock band, including the brothers Dean DeLeo (guitarist) and Robert DeLeo (bass) and the drummer Eric Kretz, has sold more than 35 million albums worldwide.

It wasn't enough, apparently, for Zora Neale Hurston to write a great American novel and to blaze trails for black women as a scholar and an artist. In ''Zora Neale Hurston: Jump at the Sun,'' an ''American Masters'' documentary on Wednesday night on PBS, we learn that she also pioneered a very 21st-century genre: the unreliable memoir. In her speeches and writings -- including her autobiography, ''Dust Tracks on a Road,'' which is liberally quoted by the film's narrator, S. Epatha Merkerson -- Hurston shaved a decade from her age and substituted the all-black town of Eatonville, Fla., where she grew up, for her actual birthplace in Alabama. The film doesn't speculate about her reasons, but we can: perhaps when being a black woman in the Jim Crow South means that you finish high school at 27 and don't become the first black graduate of Barnard College (with a bachelor's degree in anthropology) until 36, you find it practical to obscure your age.

Drenched in emotion and suffused with good intentions, ''Body of War'' is impossible not to like, but difficult to admire. Produced and directed by Ellen Spiro and Phil Donahue (yes, that Phil Donahue), the movie uses the wrenching story of one American soldier to mount an angry if unfocused jeremiad against the war in Iraq. In March 2004, Tomas Young, a 24-year-old new Army enlistee from Kansas City, Mo., arrived in Iraq. Almost immediately he was in the Walter Reed Army Medical Center (''Home of Warrior Care,'' as its Web site puts it), on the unfathomably difficult mend from a bullet that left him paralyzed from the chest down. This, then, is the body of war of the movie's title, a body ravaged by physical and psychological wounds, a body hunched and writhing in pain. Over the course of the movie, you become extraordinarily acquainted with this body, which Mr. Young offers up to the camera -- to us -- with remarkable intimacy and trust, largely as a cautionary example, though also because this body is itself damning evidence against the war.

On Ellis Island, a giant autoclave was used to disinfect the mattresses of tuberculosis victims in the hospital on the south end of the island, where 700 beds awaited ill would-be immigrants. The hospital closed along with the rest of the immigration center in 1954, but it has not been restored and is closed to the public.

KELLY--Thomas E., passed away on March 20, 2008 at Cottage Hospital in Santa Barbara, California. He was born at The Flower Fifth Avenue Hospital, New York City, on March 5, 1924 to Edward Thomas Kelly, an Alderman for the City of New York, and Anastasia Cecilia Kane. Tom Kelly was a graduate of Regis High School, a Second Lieutenant Pilot assigned to the 486th Bomber Group, 833rd Bomber Squadron of the 3rd Division of the U.S. 8th Air Force, a graduate from N.Y.U. College of Engineering where he played on the varsity basketball team, and a Boston Celtic. Tom was inducted into the N.Y.U. Athletics Hall of Fame at N.Y.U. in 1991. Tom spent four decades with The Trane Company, building the KellyTrane Service Agency, a successful business in commercial HVAC sales. Tom served as President of the Board of Education for the Syosset, L.I. Central School District No. 2 from 1954 to 1958. Tom retired to Santa Barbara, California in 1994. He was predeceased by his first wife Irene and is survived by his wife, Joanie, and six sons and four daughters, John of New York City, Jed of New Rochelle, NY, Thomas of New Canaan, CT, Christopher of Stamford, CT, Matthew of Nyack, NY, Kirk of Lakewood, NY, Ann of Milford, CT, Irene of New City, NY, Stacy of New York City, and Deirdre Shaffer of Stamford, CT; and fourteen granddaughters, eleven grandsons, and two Greatgrandchildren. He is also survived by a stepson, Jon Williamson of Los Angeles, a step daughter, Lizbeth Williams of Los Angeles, and a step grandson. A mass of Christian burial was celebrated in Our Lady of Mount Carmel Church in Montecito, California, on March 25, 2008. Internment was in Santa Barbara Cemetery. A memorial service for friends and family will be held in Our Lady Star of the Sea Church, Stamford, Connecticut, on April 19th at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, donations to Cancer Center at Santa Barbara Cottage Hospital, P.O. Box 689, Santa, Barbara, CA 93102-0689.

LITTLEJOHN--Mercedes Daly, of Locust Valley, NY, age 88. Beloved Wife of the late Angus C. Littlejohn. Died peacefully at home on April 6th, 2008. Known as Mimi, She was a loving, creative and energetic force who inspired her extended family of five children, seven grandchildren, a sister, and innumerable friends in the United States, Europe, and South America. GREENBERGER--George, M.D., 1925-2008. Dr. Joseph Cunningham and the Department of Surgery at Maimonides Medical Center, Brooklyn, New York, mourn the passing of one of the founding surgeons of the Department. Dr. Greenberger was not only one of the most eminent and proficient of surgeons in Brooklyn but he was also both a teacher and a student of the art and science of surgery. He was affiliated with Maimonides for 43 years (1949-1992) and was a partner of the most prominent surgical group of the time, the SGFS Surgical Group in Brooklyn. His contributions to this Department and to its many generations of surgeons, whom he mentored and educated, will be remembered for many years to come. He was a source of wisdom and compassion for both his patients and his colleague

9 P.M. (13) ZORA NEALE HURSTON: JUMP AT THE SUN Today Hurston -- novelist (''Their Eyes Were Watching God''), cultural anthropologist, chronicler of folk and ethnic traditions -- stands at the forefront of African-American literary history, partly through the resurrection of her voice by Alice Walker. But after becoming one of the most celebrated figures of the Harlem Renaissance in the 1920s, Hurston, standing above, died penniless and forgotten. This ''American Masters'' documentary traverses her life, including her childhood in Eatonville, Fla., the country's first incorporated all-black town; her years at Barnard (where she was the first black graduate); her assignment with the Works Progress Administration; and her collaboration with Langston Hughes. Dorothy West, Henry Louis Gates Jr., Maya Angelou and Ms. Walker discuss Hurston's accomplishments; Kim Brockington portrays Hurston in dramatic re-enactments. S. Epatha Merkerson narrates. 7:30 P.M. (Fox) AMERICAN IDOL: IDOL GIVES BACK 2008 Simon Cowell puts the wisecracks and pained expressions on hold as Bono, Brad Pitt, Reese Witherspoon, Annie Lennox, Snoop Dogg, Maroon 5, Robin Williams, Celine Dion, Forest Whitaker, Billy Crystal, Jennifer Connelly, Amy Adams and Fantasia, among other celebrities, use their star power to raise awareness and money for charities around the globe. Last year ''Idol Gives Back'' raised more than $76 million and won a Governors Award Emmy.

RIGGIO--Melissa Ann, 20-year old beloved daughter of Steve, CEO of Barnes & Noble, Inc., and wife, Laura, died peacefully on April 7, 2008 at University Hospital of Columbia and Cornell in Manhattan, after a courageous battle with leukemia. She was surrounded by her parents, sisters 22-year old Laura and 16-year old Christina, both of Bernardsville, New Jersey, and other members of her loving family. Born March 25, 1988 in Brooklyn, New York, she lived in Bernardsville, New Jersey, since 1999. Melissa, who was born with Down Syndrome, lived a full and extraordinary life. She was a strong and optimistic young woman and was an inspiration to everyone who had the opportunity to know her. In May 2003, Melissa received the Self Advocate Award from The National Down Syndrome Society (NDSS) at their annual spring luncheon in Manhattan, which also honored Senator Hillary Rodham-Clinton. A graduate of Bernards High School, Class of 2007, Melissa was crowned Prom Queen at her senior prom. She was employed by Somerset Hills YMCA in Basking Ridge, where she was an office worker. Melissa had plans to enter a post secondary program so that she could become a counselor at the YMCA. She loved to read and listen to music and she loved to write. A poet and a songwriter, Melissa was taking voice, drama, and dance lessons and aspired to become a singer one day. Some of Melissa's songs were recorded by acclaimed singer/ songwriter Rachel Fuller. Melissa is also survived by her paternal grandmother, Lena Riggio, of Brooklyn, New York and many aunts, uncles and cousins. Viewing at the funeral home is for family only. A Mass of Christian Burial, open to the public, will be offered on Friday, April 11 10am, at Church of St. James, 184 South Finley Avenue, Basking Ridge, New Jersey. In lieu of flowers, the family has asked that donations be made to The Valerie Center at Morristown Memorial Hospital, Morristown Memorial Health Foundation, P.O. Box 1956, Morristown, New Jersey 07962. When making a donation, please indicate that it is in memory of Melissa Riggio. Services provided by Gallaway & Crane Funeral Home: www.gcfuneralhome.com or 908-766-0250.

2:30 p.m. | ALBANY — The state’s top judge, Judith S. Kaye, will file a lawsuit on Thursday seeking pay increases for New York judges, who have gone a decade without a raise. When the State Legislature approved the $122 billion budget on Wednesday, it authorized spending $6 billion more than was spent on last year’s budget. But much to the annoyance of the state’s judicial branch, none of that $6 billion was set aside for judicial raises. Because it has been so long since the state’s judges received a pay increase, the issue has resurfaced repeatedly in budget negotiations. Judges are currently paid $136,700 a year; a 2007 proposal called for a 21 percent raise to $165,200.
Senator Charles E. Schumer has officially endorsed one of his former aides, Daniel Squadron, in a Democratic primary against State Senator Martin Connor.
