Both sides of the trial in the shooting death of Sean Bell offered glimpses at elements of their closing arguments on Thursday, with attorneys for the three detectives charged in the shooting unsuccessfully urging the judge to throw out several of the charges that they argued do not meet the legal standards required before deliberations over a verdict begin.Justice Arthur J. Cooperman rejected the defense motions Thursday afternoon. The motions are standard in any criminal trial, when the defense, after the prosecution has presented its case, argues that the charges should be dismissed. In the vast majority of cases, the motion is denied, as the law states that the prosecution should get the benefit of all doubt in the testimony before the “fact finder” in the case, usually a jury, begins deliberating.

The annual rite of raising water rates is set to begin Friday, and ratepayers are in for another shock. Word is circulating around City Hall that the Water Board of New York, which sets rates, is going to come in asking for a 14.5 percent increase, several percentage points higher than projected at last year’s go-around. That despite the fact that the city has started to crack down on water deadbeats and recently started cutting off service to delinquent homeowners for the first time in memory.

(Last week, I wrote about re-enactments and the intentions behind their use. Why re-enact the past? Different kinds of re-enactments were discussed: re-enactments that purport to be real and re-enactments that re-focus our attention on specific details, in some instances details that have been overlooked or misunderstood. That essay also suggested that the real problem might be the brain: how we look at and perceive images. This essay continues where I left off and takes it a bit further. -- E.M.)

"I don't know how many ways she can say no," was how Sean McCormack, Condoleezza Rice's spokesman at the State Department, tried to defuse rumors this week that his boss was campaigning for the vice presidential spot on the Republican ticket. Clearly these diplomatic types don't understand the rules of vice presidential speculation, where everyone knows that saying no is another way of saying yes. That's because every politician in America will look you in the eye and tell you point blank (even off the record) that he wouldn't accept the vice presidency, and yet, when the offer comes, no one ever seems to turn it down.

TVNewser: "The judge in Dan Rather's lawsuit against CBS has issued a motion to dismiss most of the case." CBS had sought dismissal of the suit late last year. "What remains is the contract dispute," TVNewser reports: "whether Rather was utilized appropriately in the remaining months of his deal as a correspondent on 60 Minutes."

A third of all food purchased for household consumption winds up in the dustbin (as we say), according to The Times of London. Not only an incredible waste, but significant generator of greenhouse gases. One can only assume our numbers are similar. Here's the full story, via The Food Times.

Gurk. The TED spread is up again. So is the LIBOR-OIS spread. (One is the spread between Libor and Treasuries, the other the spread between Libor and the futures price of the Fed funds rate; I tend to prefer TED spread, because fears of bank defaults should affect Fed funds as well as Libor; but I know that Fed officials prefer OIS. Anyway, both pointing in the same direction.) And the flight to safety is back, with the interest rate on one-month Treasuries -- which should be about the same as Fed funds -- back down to 1%.

So far, there's no indication on The Ontario Review's Web site that this estimable literary journal plans to call it quits despite the death in February of its editor and publisher, Raymond J. Smith. (Smith and his wife, Joyce Carol Oates, founded the magazine in Canada in 1974, then relocated it when they moved to Princeton, N.J.) But I hear from writing friends that the next issue will be the last. And over at Crossing the Border, a comprehensive blog devoted to all things JCO, Randy Souther heard the same thing last month.

Twenty years ago, Sandy Lyle stood in a fairway bunker on Augusta National’s 18th hole, 145 yards from the pin, just a bogey away from handing the Masters to Mark Calcavecchia. The rest is now history: An approach shot that finished 10 feet from the hole, and a single putt to win the green jacket, for one of the most dramatic finishes in the tournament’s history. Dave Anderson summed it up in The Times the next day: “In their betting games, duffers define a ’sandy’ as getting up and down in two shots from a bunker for a par. But now there’s a new term. Call it a Big Sandy, as in Sandy Lyle himself: getting up and down in two shots from a fairway bunker for a birdie.”.

By YUANXI.

I have played golf a total of five times in my life. The first was when I was about 13 years old, and my Uncle Lotsi informed me that I was a perfectly fine player, “other than your putting, chipping and driving.” The other four times were at bachelor parties. Because I write about sports professionally, everyone assumes I play golf regularly. I don’t. I don’t like golf. I think it’s a waste of valuable land. I think it’s an elitist, exclusionary sport invented so capitalists will have time to relax and muse on their next hostile takeover or farm foreclosure. (I haven’t studied much economics since 1986; I assume they’re still foreclosing on farms, right?) I think John Daly is the world’s only interesting golfer. I think golf stinks.

An Ohio man has been indicted on charges that he threatened to blow up the United States Supreme Court and attack well-known black men, including Justice Clarence Thomas , according to an indictment. The man, David Tuason, singled out black men known to affiliate with white women, well-known white women who had relationships with black men, and mixed-race children, federal authorities said. A spokeswoman for the Supreme Court, Kathy Arberg, confirmed that a threat had been made against Justice Thomas. A spokesman for the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Scott Wilson, said the threats began in Cleveland and branched out across the nation. He said that Mr. Tuason sent the communications as far back as 20 years. According to the indictment, Mr. Tuason sent a letter to the Supreme Court building in July 2003 in which he threatened to blow it up. The letter was addressed to an associate justice of the court referred to as “C.T.”.

Bell Canada received the final regulatory approval for its acquisition by a private investment group led by a branch of the Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan and valued at about 52 billion Canadian dollars. Industry Canada, the government department responsible for radio frequencies used by mobile phone networks, approved the sale provided that the new owners document changes that will ensure Canadian control of the company. Two issues still stand in the way of the deal’s scheduled closing at the end of June. An appeals court in Quebec must hear a challenge to the transaction raised by some bondholders. More important, the financing for the transaction must be completed. Ontario Teachers’ has repeatedly dismissed speculation by some investors that credit market turmoil may cause banks to back away from their lending commitments.

Gazprom of Russia, the natural gas producer, and Eni of Italy are preparing to join forces to pipe natural gas from Libya across the Mediterranean to Southern Europe. The deal would enable Russia to increase Europe’s dependence on Gazprom, which is state controlled. Paolo Scaroni, left, chief executive of Eni, said the deal with Gazprom would involve “the swap of assets outside of Russia.” Russia already supplies more than a quarter of Western Europe’s energy needs. Some analysts said that if Gazprom succeeded in Libya and in Algeria, where it is competing for contracts, it could end up dominating the supply routes to Southern Europe.
The chief executive of the French bank Société Générale said it expected to spend up to 100 million euros this year to improve its risk-management systems.

Shortly before a meeting Friday of finance ministers and central bankers from the Group of 7 nations, the Institute for International Finance, a global association of financial institutions, said new measures on openness, ratings agencies and valuation of complex securities were priorities for industry action, not government fiat. “We are resolved to do the utmost to clean our houses first and not to let regulators do it for us,” said Josef Ackermann, chief executive of Deutsche Bank and chairman of the group.
Albert Pujols hit his first two home runs of the year for visiting St. Louis and the Cardinals beat the Houston Astros, 6-4, on Wednesday.

Gov. Timothy M. Kaine signed into law a package of legislation intended to tighten the state’s mental health system and improving campus security in response to last year’s deadly Virginia Tech shootings. The new laws, which go into effect in July, are intended to improve oversight and accountability of a mental health system criticized after a disturbed student killed 32 people and himself at the university last April. The changes relax the standard for involuntary commitment to a mental health facility and allow better sharing of mental health records. They also extend the time a person can be detained for observation, and require representatives of local community services boards to participate in commitment hearings. Universities will be required to develop written emergency management plans and establish threat-assessment teams and must establish comprehensive emergency notification systems.

An alarming outbreak of the mumps two years ago has raised questions about whether an additional vaccination is needed. A report in The New England Journal of Medicine on Thursday tracks the 2006 epidemic, the largest outbreak in two decades. Mumps had virtually disappeared in America since the 1990s, when doctors began using a second dose of measles-mumps-rubella vaccine among schoolchildren. But most of those who became infected in 2006 were college students who had received the double-vaccination, raising questions about whether a third dose may be needed. The outbreak appeared to start in January 2006 on college campuses in Iowa, and by April the outbreak peaked with 40 states reporting 2,786 cases. By the end of the year, a total of 6,584 cases and 85 hospitalizations had been reported. The researchers noted that the virus probably came from students or other travelers from Britain, where there was a larger outbreak of the same strain. Above, Mandi McClue, got a mumps immunization in 2006 at the health center at Drake University in Des Moines.

Six Michigan State University students have been suspended after what the police characterized as a riot near campus last weekend, the school said. A party involving 3,000 to 4,000 people had to be broken up by tear gas after the police were pelted with bottles and rocks early Sunday. The event was held at Cedar Village, a student housing complex bordering the campus. The students, who were not identified, violated a disorderly conduct policy, the school said. They were suspended pending resolution of their cases, it said. Of 11 cases referred to the school so far, 7 have been reviewed for possible interim suspension. Six students were suspended, and one was not. Of the 52 students and non-students arrested, 38 face disorderly conduct charges. Others face traffic, drug, alcohol and noise charges.

A former Senate aide defeated a former city councilwoman in a runoff election on Tuesday as Houston-area Republicans chose a nominee for the former Congressional seat of Tom DeLay, the former House majority leader. The winner, Pete Olson, overpowered Shelley Sekula Gibbs with 68 percent of the vote to 31 percent. The winner will face Representative Nick Lampson, a Democrat. In the race for district attorney of Harris County, which includes Houston, Pat Lykos, a former police officer and judge, defeated Kelly Siegler, a flamboyant prosecutor, with 53 percent of the vote to 47 percent to gain the Republican nomination. The Harris County district attorney, Charles A. Rosenthal Jr., resigned amid a contempt of court charge and a scandal involving e-mail messages found on his county computer. Ms. Lykos will face C.O. Bradford, a Democrat and a former police chief in Houston whom Rosenthal once charged with perjury.

The state prison agency fired eight more correctional officers on Tuesday, bringing the number to 17 in an investigation into accusations of brutality against inmates at two western Maryland institutions. The latest firings occurred at the medium-security Roxbury Correctional Institution near Hagerstown, where nine officers were fired Friday. All were terminated amid accusations of excessive force during the weekend of March 8, the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services said. Meanwhile, internal and criminal investigations continue at the maximum-security North Branch Correctional Institution near Cumberland. Eight officers there were placed on paid administrative leave on March 27 amid accusations that as many as seven inmates were abused after they were transferred from Roxbury on March 6.

George Strait beat R.E.M. for the top spot on the Billboard album chart this week, while Van Morrison finally reached the Top 10 with his 33rd studio disc. Mr. Strait’s “Troubadour” (MCA Nashville) moved 166,000 copies, Nielsen SoundScan reported, earning that country star his fourth No. 1. R.E.M.’s “Accelerate” (Warner Brothers), hailed as a return to form, opened at second place with 115,000, the band’s best sales week and highest chart position in 12 years. “Now That’s What I Call Music, Vol. 27” rose two spots to No. 3; and Day26’s self-titled debut on Bad Boy/Atlantic fell two to No. 4. Van Morrison’s “Keep It Simple” (Lost Highway) sold 37,000 copies to bow at No. 10 — his highest position ever — and the soundtrack to the Rolling Stones’ “Shine a Light” concert film, released by Interscope, opened at No. 11.

A lonely newt, a strong-willed Scottish princess and modern-day elves are among the stars of 10 new animated movies from Walt Disney Studios and its boutique animation unit, Pixar. On Tuesday Disney unveiled its animation plans for movie theater owners and the news media. The message of the presentation: Disney’s acquisition of Pixar has rejuvenated the company’s entire animation business. The slate, not entirely a surprise to Disney followers, is certainly ambitious. During the next five years Disney’s offerings will include four straight-to-DVD animated features starring Tinker Bell and her friends; the company’s first hand-drawn musical in nearly two decades, “The Princess and the Frog”; a 3-D retelling of “Rapunzel”; and installments of the “Cars” and “Toy Story” franchises. Among the original features Pixar is attempting are “Newt,” a summer 2011 film about a lizard cooling his heels in a community college science lab; “The Bear and the Bow,” a holiday 2011 fantasy about an impetuous Scottish princess; and “King of the Elves,” a 2012 offering focusing on elves and trolls living in modern-day Mississippi.

A vandal chopped off the head of Ringo Starr from a life-size topiary of that former Beatle over the weekend in Liverpool, England, above, while leaving his band mates untouched, The Liverpool Daily Post reported. The attack occurred a few weeks after the topiary figures, created by the Italian sculptor Franco Covill, were unveiled at the South Parkway train station. “This is a huge disappointment for us,” said an unidentified spokesman for Merseytravel, which coordinates mass transit. “Public art is important, and the topiary was put there to bring a bit of life and soul to the public-transport network.” He said that Merseytravel and the British Transport Police were analyzing surveillance tapes. The topiary tribute celebrates Liverpool’s status as a 2008 European Capital of Culture. Mr. Starr outraged some residents of his native Liverpool when, after opening the European Capital of Culture events, he said he missed nothing about the city.

A lawyer for the owner of a group of rare, early prints by the photographer Diane Arbus said on Wednesday that the auction house Phillips de Pury canceled the sale because of concerns about a recent lawsuit filed by a man who claims he was duped out of the prints. Peter R. Stern, the lawyer for the prints’ owner, Bob Langmuir, a Philadelphia book dealer and collector, said the auction house told him that a private sale of the photos — estimated to be worth up to several hundred thousand dollars — was still a possibility. Phillips officials have not returned calls seeking an explanation for the cancellation of the auction, which was to be held on Tuesday. The photographs, from the late 1950s, show performers at Hubert’s Dime Museum and Flea Circus, a basement freak show on 42nd Street in Manhattan, where Arbus honed her stark signature style. Mr. Langmuir was sued in federal court in Brooklyn by another collector, Bayo Ogunsanya, who claimed he was unaware of the value of the photographs when he sold them to Mr. Langmuir for $3,500 in 2003. Mr. Stern has argued in court that Mr. Ogunsanya’s lawsuit is frivolous.

Kurt Andersen has won the 2007 David J. Langum Sr. Prize in American Historical Fiction for his best-selling novel “Heyday” (Random House). Mr. Andersen, a columnist for New York magazine and host of “Studio 360” on public radio, will receive $1,000. ... The Czech novelist Arnost Lustig has been named the eighth winner of the Franz Kafka award for literature, Agence France-Presse reported. Previous winners include Harold Pinter, Philip Roth and Haruki Murakami. ... At a ceremony in Washington the jazz pianist Dave Brubeck received the State Department’s Benjamin Franklin Award for Public Diplomacy from Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice.

Purple rain will sweep the desert. Organizers of the Coachella Valley Music and Arts festival, a perennial rock event staged in the California desert, said on Wednesday that Prince would join its lineup and perform on the second night of the annual concert, April 25 to 27. The addition of Prince, rumored online last month, came as the festival addressed the emergence of rival events nationwide and a sense among some rock fans that its existing lineup lacked punch. Coachella’s previously announced headliners this year include Jack Johnson, Portishead and Roger Waters. Prince, who performed a run of sold-out shows at the O2 arena in London last year, is considered one of the most reliable live-music draws.

In the Guggenheim Museum’s latest venture to expand overseas, the architect Zaha Hadid was selected on Wednesday to design a proposed museum, above, in Vilnius, Lithuania. The competition is part of a feasibility study by the Guggenheim Foundation and the State Hermitage Museum of St. Petersburg, Russia. The directors of both institutions participated in the jury selection. In addition to Ms. Hadid of London, Daniel Libeskind of New York and Massimiliano Fuksas of Rome submitted designs. The Guggenheim said that it was by no means certain that the museum would be a Guggenheim. Its satellites — including the Guggenheim Bilbao in Spain and the Deutsche Guggenheim in Berlin — have largely been spearheaded by the Guggenheim’s director, Thomas Krens, who announced in February that he would step down. An exhibition of all three submissions — “Imagining the Future: Design Proposals for a New Museum in Vilnius” — will open on Thursday at the Jonas Mekas Visual Arts Center in Vilnius. Additionally, the Guggenheim Hermitage Museum in Las Vegas will close in May. Its closing was first reported on Wednesday by The Art Newspaper Web site, theartnewspaper.com.

A GROWING number of organizations help people donate or buy previously installed kitchens. In New York City, the nonprofit organization Build It Green! offers kitchen items as well as other recycled materials. Justin Green, its program director, said a Valcucine kitchen, a Dada kitchen and a Sub-Zero refrigerator are currently available. The organization will not dismantle kitchens for donors but hopes to do so by midsummer. Profits go to the Solar One Education Center in Manhattan. Build It Green! is at 3-17 26th Avenue at 4th Street in Astoria, Queens, www.bignyc.org.

Kasthall, the Swedish company founded in 1889 and known for its chunky, updated shag carpets, has opened its first American showroom in New York. In addition to its linen-and-wool-blend shag rugs, the company sells handmade carpets like the Negative Text Rug hanging on the wall above ($6,091), which is covered in writing done with a pneumatic yarn gun. (“I feel like everyone is walking over me,” it reads. “I feel so low. Like someone is standing on me. I feel as I am flat on the floor.”) There are also four new collections of traditional wall-to-wall carpeting on display in the showroom, which start at $40 a square foot and meet environmental criteria of the International Orgnization for Standardization. Kasthall, 200 Lexington Avenue (32nd Street), (212) 421-0220 or kasthall.com. STEPHEN TREFFINGER.

In the 1920s, Mildred and Robert Bliss, art collectors who owned Dumbarton Oaks, an early 1800s Georgian house in Washington, brought in a team of renowned designers to renovate it. The Parisian interior designer Armand-Albert Rateau, the New York architectural firm of McKim, Mead & White and the classical muralist Allyn Cox collaborated on the project, adding wings to the house, covering walls and ceilings with images of foliage and mythological creatures, and installing mirrored shutters and gilded pilasters shaped like palm trees.

8 P.M. (TCM) COME LIVE WITH ME (1941) ''Any girl can be glamorous,'' Hedy Lamarr said. ''All you have to do is stand still and look stupid.'' Turner Classic Movies continues its monthlong tribute to the Austrian-born Lamarr, above, sometimes called the most beautiful woman in the movies, with this fine romance starring her as a Viennese refugee who marries a struggling writer so that she can stay in the United States. The salute continues with ''Ziegfeld Girl'' (1941), at 9:30, with Lamarr, alongside Judy Garland and Lana Turner, as a showgirl; ''H. M. Pulham, Esq.'' (1941), at 11:45, in which she plays an Iowa farm girl deserted by a Boston blue blood (Robert Young); ''Crossroads'' (1942), at 2:15 a.m., with Lamarr as the mischievous wife of a diplomat (William Powell) with a shady past; and ''I Take This Woman'' (1940), at 3:45, in which she plays a suicidal woman whose new husband (Spencer Tracy) decides to make her happy with money. 8 P.M. (13) GREAT PERFORMANCES AT THE MET The series presents the Metropolitan Opera's production of Verdi's ''Macbeth,'' directed by Adrian Noble and starring Zeljko Lucic, left, and Maria Guleghina. Reviewing the production last fall, Anthony Tommasini of The New York Times called it ''stylistically eclectic, grimly effective and, at times, intriguingly playful.''

HEILBRUN--James, 83, died peacefully on April 8th at home in New York, the city he loved and lived in all his life. Devoted husband of the late Carolyn, beloved father of Emily, Margaret and Robert and grandfather of Penelope Duus and Matteo Heilbrun, cherished brother of Betty H. Benjamin. Professor of Economics at Fordham University and author of books on urban economics and the economics of the arts. Devotee of the New York City Ballet for over 50 years. We will always love you. Services private.

KELLOGG--Jack, lifelong partner of Howard O. Field, has passed away March 30, 2008. Jack's tremendous sense of style dressed many luminaries on both coasts at his menswear stores, the Shirttail on Lexington Ave. in New York and Jack Kellogg Stores in Palm Springs and on Sunset Plaza in Los Angeles, California. Many customers became a part of his extended family. Jack and Howard lived a glorious life, full of style and adventure in New York, Los Angeles, Palm Springs and Laguna Beach. Creating beautiful gardens, enjoying the ocean, basking in the sun, and restoring temples in far-off lands were some of Jack's many passions. Born in Indiana, he spent his boyhood in a small farm town but quickly grew to love the big city. He attended the Indiana University School of Music and was a soloist with the singing Hoosiers which traveled abroad entertaining US Troops in Japan and Korea during the mid 1950s. Jack had a ready wit and a sharp eye. Jack's presence was an inspiration to so many and he will be deeply missed by his extended family and friends, nieces and nephews. Private services will be held Sunday April 13, the first anniversary of his partner Howard's passing at the Hollywood Forever Mortuary in Los Angeles. In lieu of Flowers donations should be made to a Charity of choice. A Celebration of his Life will be held at a later date in Laguna, California.

FERRI--Nelson Carlos, of Necochea, Argentina, on March 31st, 2008 at age 81, New York City tailor of Nelson Ferri Tailors, passed away. Beloved father of Maria, Jessica, Cynthia and Judy. Loving grandfather to Christian, Justin, Nelson, Lauren and Isis. Cherished brother of Luisa, Adina, Ester, Luis, Armando, Enrique, Irma and Nelly. As per Nelson's final wishes, he was cremated with no services. A private family memorial will follow.

RIGGIO--Melissa Ann. The Board of Directors of the National Book Foundation extends its sympathies to the family of Melissa Ann Riggio, daughter of our Board member Steve. Our thoughts are with you. RIGGIO--Melissa Ann, 20-year old beloved daughter of Steve, CEO of Barnes & Noble, Inc., and wife, Laura, died peacefully on April 7, 2008 at University Hospital of Columbia and Cornell in Manhattan, after a courageous battle with leukemia. She was surrounded by her parents, sisters 22-year old Laura and 16-year old Christina, both of Bernardsville, New Jersey, and other members of her loving family. Born March 25, 1988 in Brooklyn, New York, she lived in Bernardsville, New Jersey, since 1999. Melissa, who was born with Down Syndrome, lived a full and extraordinary life. She was a strong and optimistic young woman and was an inspiration to everyone who had the opportunity to know her. In May 2003, Melissa received the Self Advocate Award from The National Down Syndrome Society (NDSS) at their annual spring luncheon in Manhattan, which also honored Senator Hillary Rodham-Clinton. A graduate of Bernards High School, Class of 2007, Melissa was crowned Prom Queen at her senior prom. She was employed by Somerset Hills YMCA in Basking Ridge, where she was an office worker. Melissa had plans to enter a post secondary program so that she could become a counselor at the YMCA. She loved to read and listen to music and she loved to write. A poet and a songwriter, Melissa was taking voice, drama, and dance lessons and aspired to become a singer one day. Some of Melissa's songs were recorded by acclaimed singer/ songwriter Rachel Fuller. Melissa is also survived by her paternal grandmother, Lena Riggio, of Brooklyn, New York and many aunts, uncles and cousins. Family and friends may visit at the Gallaway & Crane Funeral Home, 101 South Finley Avenue, Basking Ridge, New Jersey on Thursday April 10th from 2-4pm and 7-9pm. A Mass of Christian Burial, open to the public, will be offered on Friday, April 11 10am, at Church of St. James, 184 South Finley Avenue, Basking Ridge, New Jersey. In lieu of flowers, the family has asked that donations be made to The Valerie Center at Morristown Memorial Hospital, Morristown Memorial Health Foundation, P.O. Box 1956, Morristown, New Jersey 07962. When making a donation, please indicate that it is in memory of Melissa Riggio. Services provided by Gallaway & Crane Funeral Home: www.gcfuneralhome.com or 908-766-0250. RIGGIO--Melissa. The Board of Directors, staff, participants and friends of AHRC New York City wish to convey our heartfelt condolences to Steve and Laura Riggio and their family on the loss of Melissa, their beloved daughter. AHRC New York City will always hold dear the memory of Melissa, and her gentleness. She was an individual of tremendous courage and wisdom, facing challenges that many older than she could not have met with such grace. Melissa was a member of the AHRC family, attending our Annual Dinners, where she shared her beautiful, original songs. The funeral will be held at St. James Catholic Church, at 184 South Finley Avenue in Basking Ridge, New Jersey on April 11 at 10:00am. Laura Kennedy, President Michael Goldfarb, Exec. Dir.

MORE CHAOS AHEAD Air travelers, whose plans have already been disrupted by thousands of canceled flights recently, may face continued chaos as regulators and the airlines expand their scrutiny of planes. STRAKER--Dolores Y. The City University of New York mourns the loss of Dr. Dolores Straker, former University Associate Dean for Academic Affairs, whose 30 years at CUNY included extraordinary service at York College and the Central Office as SEEK Program Director and Chair, Associate Dean for Academic Affairs, and Associate Dean for Enrollment Management. Her profound commitment to educational development and opportunity and dedication to student success will endure. We offer our deepest sympathy to her son Brian Taylor, her mother Christine Birch and her entire family. Benno C. Schmidt, Jr., Chairman Matthew Goldstein, Chancellor

BESSIE--Simon Michael. The Trustees, staff, and volunteers of Educational Broadcasting Corporation (EBC), licensee of Thirteen/WNET and WLIW New York, express our deep sorrow at the passing of Simon Michael Bessie. A passionate supporter of public television, Mike served on EBC's Board of Trustees since 1983, becoming a Life Trustee in 1996. Known for asking the tough questions, Mike could be counted on never to back down in his defense of public television and its mission. His contributions played a vital role in advancing our work in the New York community and nationwide, and we are deeply grateful for his many years of leadership, wise counsel and dedication. We offer our heartfelt condolences to Mike's wife, Cornelia, and his children, Nicholas and Katherine. We join them in mourning the loss of an American literary pioneer, a great friend to public broadcasting, and a wonderful man in every regard. James S. Tisch Chairman Neal Shapiro President and CEO

FOR outdoorsy parents who have been cooped up with their children all winter, the light at the end of the Gymboree tunnel is here. Camping season is just around the corner. And a new generation of portable, durable baby cribs makes it easier than ever to enact fantasies of campfires and crystal-clear constellations, even with the tiniest of tent-dwellers. In the past, families had to fumble with fussy play yards when taking babies camping, said Scott Graham, the author of the 2006 book ''Extreme Kids'' (Wilderness Press). ''There was no such thing as lightweight,'' he said. But in the last two years a few manufacturers have stripped portable cribs to the traveling essentials, with features like mosquito netting, UV protection and slim storage profiles. Weighing less than most tots, they can be used as containment devices for newborns and as sleeping areas (for daytime naps and nights inside a tent) for both infants and toddlers. ''They're also stylish enough to use indoors,'' Mr. Graham said, ''even among cool single friends.'' David and Erin Hughes of Durango, Colo., who regularly hike and raft, tested five models on a camping trip in southern Utah with their four children: Sophie, 7; Jed, 4; Truman, 2; and Jonas, 6 months. ''Kudos to all the makers for their ingenuity and craftsmanship,'' Ms. Hughes said. ''Where were these when we were starting out?'' SARAH TUFF

There is no plaque, sign or anything else marking the spot in the Audubon Ballroom where Malcolm X was shot to death in 1965. It would be hard to get such a memorial just right, said Zead Ramadan, chairman of the Malcolm X and Dr. Betty Shabazz Memorial and Education Center , which now controls the space. Besides, Malcolm X, as a Muslim, was “not really fond of symbolism too much,” said Mr. Ramadan, a fellow Muslim.

The lavishly ornamented New York Central Building of 1929, by Warren & Wetmore, lost its place in the early 1960s as the Beaux-Arts pinnacle of Park Avenue with the construction of the gigantic Pan Am Building. “Its enormous mass sitting astride Grand Central Terminal completely blocked out the New York Central tower from the south and was a huge, boring backdrop for it from the north,” Paul Goldberger wrote in 1978, when he was architecture critic of The New York Times. (After the older building was renamed Helmsley and before the newer building was renamed MetLife.)

It was no surprise to anyone who has paid attention to education politics lately: Randi Weingarten, the leader of the New York Citiy teachers union, announced Friday that she will run for president of the American Federation of Teachers, the national union.Ms. Weingarten, currently president of the United Federation of Teachers, the local chapter of the national union, made the announcement this afternoon at the Hilton in Midtown for the annual convention of the state teachers’ union, the New York State United Teachers. She is virtually assured to win, as she is widely expected to be the only candidate for the elections this summer. That didn’t stop one delegate from suggesting that the state teacher’s union should hold off on backing Ms. Weingarten. And while the group voted to endorse her, several dozen voted “nay” on the resolution.

Michigan's senior captain proved it on the national stage Friday night when he accepted the Hobey Baker Award as college hockey's most outstanding player, a night after seeing his college career end with an overtime loss to Notre Dame. But tucked into an otherwise uninspiring patch of Madrid, just north of the centre, is the elegant, Andalusia-inspired house and studio of Joaquín Sorolla y Bastida (1863-1923), the Spanish "luminist" painter of sun-dappled bathers and shimmering waters who captivated European and American audiences in the early 20th century.

Corporations, unions and other interests spent a record $2.79 billion in 2007 on lobbying Washington officials, said a study from a watchdog group. The group, the Center for Responsive Politics, said spending in 2007 eclipsed the previous record in 2006 by $200 million, with health care interests, Wall Street, the real estate industry and insurers among the biggest spenders. Sharply higher spending was seen on other fronts, with the private equity firm Blackstone Group increasing its expenditures 477 percent to $5.4 million. The private equity industry halted an effort in Congress recently to raise taxes on the profits of its senior partners.

A rugged tract of state-owned land known as the Christmas Mountains is now open to hikers and campers visiting Big Bend National Park. Jerry Patterson, the Texas land commissioner, granted an easement that allows public access to the state land via a mile-long boundary with Big Bend. Mr. Patterson said that the access was the same that would be allowed if the National Park Service owned the tract. He was alluding to a debate between his office and conservationists over who should control the property. Mr. Patterson has sought a private bidder for the land, but conservationists want it to go to the National Park Service. He has been reluctant to turn the property over to the Park Service in part because federal parks are generally off-limits for hunting.
Most families of victims of the shootings last year at Virginia Tech have agreed to an $11 million state settlement.

Fasig-Tipton, the oldest thoroughbred auction company in North America, announced it was being sold to a company from Dubai, a move that further cements Dubai’s influence in the American horse business. The buyer, Synergy Investments, is headed by Abdulla Al Habbai, a close associate of Dubai’s ruler, Sheik Mohammed bin Rashid al Maktoum, who is a regular participant at American horse auctions.

Guillermo Roberto Cabrera, a star player on Cuba’s national team, has left the squad and asked Mexican immigration officials to let him stay in the country. Cabrera and his father were staying at immigration offices in the southern state of Chiapas while their request for a 30-day transit permit was considered, an immigration agent said.

The N.C.A.A. is no longer considering a fourth division for its smallest members. A committee last fall proposed the creation of a new division or a subdivision of the current Division III because of an expected increase in membership over the next decade. But almost 82 percent of the active and provisional Division III members who responded to a recent survey opposed the idea, the N.C.A.A. said Thursday.

An article in some editions on April 1 about New York legislators’ difficulty in holding spending in the state budget to an agreed-upon limit referred incorrectly to a legislative proposal regarding taxes on online purchases. The legislation, which was part of the $122 billion budget passed on Wednesday, will augment existing law by requiring online merchants without a physical presence in New York to collect sales taxes from state residents. It is not a new tax on online purchases.
With a derby and a blond wig stashed in his getaway car, a New York City police officer robbed a bank in Pennsylvania and made off with $113,000 before he was arrested, the police said.
FRONT PAGE.

An article in some editions last Friday about a New York City Council hearing on the presence of pharmaceuticals in city water referred incorrectly to an Associated Press investigation of nationwide drinking water supplies, which reviewed tests conducted by various agencies. None of the cities or metropolitan areas included in the report were in fact notified of test results by The A.P.; many were already aware of the presence of a small amount of drugs in their watersheds — the reservoirs, rivers and streams that are the natural source of drinking water. Of the 28 metropolitan areas that had detected drugs in their watersheds, 22 went on to test their tap water after it had been treated — not their watersheds. The other six, including New York, did not.

An article in some editions on Thursday about the Mets’ 8-2 victory over the Phillies misstated the score in the third inning when the Mets’ Mike Pelfrey stepped to the plate with his team in the lead. It was 2-1, not 3-1.

An article on Tuesday about the noisiness of some species of fish misstated the educational affiliation of the Narragansett Marine Laboratory, where researchers worked on a 1973 book about undersea sounds. It is the University of Rhode Island; there is no Rhode Island University.

An article on March 21 about a case of sexual blackmail in which a federal immigration agent on Long Island is accused of demanding sex from a Colombian woman in exchange for a green card misidentified the device the woman used to secretly record the agent’s demand. It was a digital camera, not a cellphone.

An article on March 8 about Senator John McCain’s impatience with continuing questions about talk of a Kerry-McCain ticket in 2004 misidentified a Texas televangelist who has endorsed Mr. McCain and whose controversial views Mr. McCain repudiated. He is John C. Hagee, not James. An editor discovered the error on Monday while doing research.

ROSENBLOOM--Harriette. Loving wife for 55 years of Samuel Rosenbloom, mother of Barry (Gail), Robert (ZC) and Michael (Karen), grandmother of Steven, Sara, Jonathan, A.J., Max, Ariel, Eytan, Talia and Ayelet, and sister of Estelle Rudolph passed away on Thursday April 3, 2008 at the age of 74. Harriette was active in various Jewish causes and institutions including United Jewish Appeal, Israel Bonds, The Kingsbridge Heights Jewish Center and, presently, The Riverdale Jewish Center and along with her husband, Samuel, was honored by both Synagogues. She served as Co-President of the Riverdale Jewish Center Women's Organization and was one of its founders as well as on several committees of that Synagogue's Board of Trustees. Harriette was larger than life, a cheerful woman of great charm and beauty, with a ready smile, loving disposition and great friend to anyone who had the privilege of knowing her. Her passing leaves an aching void in the hearts and souls of her devoted husband, children, grandchildren, sister, and her many friends. We will never forget her! The Family

HILARY HAHN AND JOSH RITTER There has recently been an admirable trend toward classical musicians performing in unorthodox spaces, like Brooklyn bars. There they eschew rigid formality for a more intimate and congenial atmosphere similar, in some ways, to that of a 19th-century salon. The charismatic young violinist Hilary Hahn, above, says it should be a two-way street, with musicians outside the classical tradition invited to appear alongside classical musicians in concert halls. Ms. Hahn has been touring with Josh Ritter, an indie folk singer-songwriter whose romantic songs and intelligent lyrics are vibrantly illuminated by his earthy, unaffected voice. Ms. Hahn says that ''what audiences value in me and him should be compatible,'' and that she and Mr. Ritter are ''two people on the same kind of turf.''

HAMILTON--Helen, 83, passed away April 6, 2008, of cancer of the pancreas in NYC. She is survived by her devoted husband of 67 years, Chico Hamilton, and beloved daughter Denise. Born in Hendersonville, NC, she lived in Los Angeles, CA, and then NYC where she worked at the investment firm AEA. Memorial service will be held May 1 at 6:30pm at Marble Collegiate Church, One W. 29th St., NYC. In her memory, contributions may be made to the Alzheimer's Foundation of America, 322 8th Ave., 7th Floor, NY, NY 10001.

BOSSABRASIL FESTIVAL Jazz and Brazilian music have a history far deeper and more complicated than popular perceptions would suggest. The legacy of jazz-inflected bossa nova, as epitomized by the ageless 1964 album ''Getz/Gilberto,'' has often eclipsed myriad other options: Brazilian jazz with a sharper thrust, a fuller sound, a flashier application of technique. Next week's second annual BossaBrasil Festival, produced by Pat Philips and Ettore Stratta, is likely to encompass this broader range of styles, even as it flirts with a familiar brand of lyricism. The festival, really a high-profile club engagement, features two celebrated artists from Brazil: the pianist and composer Cesar Camargo Mariano, above, and the guitarist and singer João Bosco. Both are dynamic, charismatic performers with a healthy regard for jazz harmony. Both have applied a crossover sensibility to the art of improvisation, delving into funk-based fusion as well as rhapsodic classicism. And both have been crucially involved in bossa nova, working closely and consequentially in the 1970s with the legendary singer Elis Regina. (Mr. Mariano was Ms. Regina's second husband; their daughter, who goes by Maria Rita, has enjoyed great success as a singer herself.)

ROBOFEST NYC In science fiction robots don't have much fun. If they're not determinedly trying to conquer humankind, they're officiously serving it. But the real robots invading Sony Wonder Technology Lab on Saturday will be much more playful: they swing, they wave, they gyrate to music, they rock out. These robots are literally dancing machines. Created by children ages 6 to 12, they are part of the first RoboFest NYC: Dancing With the Robostars, a competition as much about sizzle as it is about science. Although it features the same building materials -- the Lego Mindstorms Robotics system -- as many other robotics contests, it is far less regimented, said Laura Allen, the festival's founder and president of Vision Education & Media, a New York company whose programs introduce children to technology. ''We're more like Woodstock,'' she explained.

Paul Lacy, 50, has lived in Brooklyn for all but two years since 1983. He has worked as a night watchman and an apprentice furniture maker. Now he does freelance page layout for publishers of science and technical books. But Mr. Lacy's real passion -- like that of so many New Yorkers who are defined as much by their hobbies as their day jobs -- is street photography. He has just published his first book, ''Brooklyn Storefronts,'' 75 color photographs of small, independently owned stores. City Room first noticed the book, which W. W. Norton published as a paperback last month, on sale in the gift shop at the Whitney Biennial. More than merely documenting the great variety of small businesses in Brooklyn, it provides a glimpse of the often rapid social and economic change that many residents fear is transforming Brooklyn neighborhoods and threatening the unique enterprises that have long made them distinctive.

'TOMU UCHIDA: DISCOVERING A JAPANESE MASTER' Like its American counterpart, classical Japanese cinema is turning out to be richer than anyone imagined, continuing to yield discoveries as critics and scholars dig into its depths. The director of some 50 features, Tomu Uchida was barely known outside of Japan until recent film festival retrospectives in Tokyo and Rotterdam, the Netherlands, refocused attention on his work, a highly varied body that extends from left-leaning social films in the 1920s and '30s to experimental dramas and stylized genre pieces in the '50s and '60s. BAMcinématek's 11-film series, which begins on Friday, offers an intriguing sample of Uchida's work, ranging from one of his few surviving silent films (''Policeman,'' from 1933, screening on April 29) up to the audacious ''Fugitive From the Past'' (1964, screening on Sunday), a crime film structured in three acts of roughly one hour each, tracing the ramifications of a murder committed in 1946 through its final tragic convulsions 10 years later.

Q Please advise what the process is for enrolling a child in the local elementary school for kindergarten. We are zoned for Public School 117 in Briarwood, Queens, and would like to enroll our son there for kindergarten. --A. B. A Kindergarten registration is currently being conducted for children born in 2003 who live in New York City. Students can be preregistered at a neighborhood (zoned) school until the end of the school year. If you don't know your zoned school, call 311 or visit the Department of Education Web site, schools.nyc.gov. (Look for ''Find a School.'') If your home address is not zoned for an elementary school, contact a D.O.E. enrollment office in your borough of residence for assistance. When you know your zoned school, call to find out if it is scheduling appointments for registration. If your local school is very busy, this can save you time and unnecessary visits. To preregister your child, you should bring the following: your child; your child's birth certificate, passport or baptismal certificate; immunization records; and verifiable proof of address.

UNIVERSOUL CIRCUS There are many tricks you can expect from an elephant that has stepped into a ring at a circus. Placing an outsize foot on a stool is standard. So is sitting up, front legs in the air. Doing a shuffle to the unyielding beat of Rhianna's ''Don't Stop the Music,'' however, is not your everyday circus fare. The same can be said for many elements of the UniverSoul Circus, the rollicking show that bills itself as the sole African-American-theme option in a domain dominated by international acts of every hue save black. In this one-ring spectacular featuring mimes, aerialists, acrobats, contortionists (Twisted Soul, above, from Guinea) and a small zoo's worth of animals, feats are performed to a custom-made soundtrack that seamlessly shifts from R&B to jazz to reggaetón.

China's currency, the yuan, rose against the dollar on Thursday, reaching a milestone that is just the latest sign of this country's growing economic power. For the first time in more than a decade, the dollar bought less than 7 yuan, ending the day close to 6.992 yuan, a situation that specialists say will probably make Chinese-made goods more expensive for American consumers and possibly contribute to inflation in the United States.

LUIS CAMNITZER This pioneering Conceptual artist, who exhibits infrequently in New York City, has something new and something old in this concise solo. The new piece, ''Last Words,'' right, is a series of six large posterlike sheets of paper with a stream of printed text made up of hundreds of short, direct-address sentences: ''Tell Mom I love her. I love you all. Goodbye to my family. Don't forget me. I love all of you.'' And so on. The valedictory words suggest dire situations: I thought of cellphone calls made from the World Trade Center on 9/11. In fact all the phrases are from final statements made by death row prisoners, which Mr. Camnitzer found on the official Web site of the Texas Department of Criminal Justice. The sentiments subtly change in tone as the series progresses, shifting from loving farewells to giving thanks to helpful friends, including lawyers, to verbal displays of bravura. The final sentences in the piece are: ''I am ready. Tell the guys on Death Row that I'm not wearing a diaper. I can't think of anything else.''

My Sunday column is about climate change, through the prism of research that suggests that disruptions in weather patterns lead to social upheavals such as civil wars or, more sensationally, the killings of witches. My wife and I came across the study by Edward Miguel that illuminates this in the course of our work on a forthcoming book about women in the developing world, and then at about the same time I ran into the study by Emily Oster suggesting that witch-burnings in Europe correlated closely to unusually cold winters.

Pondering the G.E. earnings miss yesterday leaves me with a handful of observations:

A bit more reason to be concerned about the financial markets. Before the Bear Stearns rescue, there was a huge flight to safety in the markets, which pushed short-term Treasury yields to bizarrely low levels. After the rescue, those yields rose, as people began to think that maybe there were other assets that wouldn't implode. But the flight to safety seems to have resumed.

What apparently was an explosion showered bricks on a dense residential neighborhood in Pittsburgh and shattered windows blocks away, leveling two row houses and damaging at least two dozen other homes. No injuries were reported. The cause was not immediately known, but a blast appeared to have originated in one of the two collapsed houses, said Robert McCaughan, the city’s chief of emergency medical services. The house was owned by the city and had been condemned, according to property records.

Investigators ruled out arson as the cause of a fire that destroyed the Terre Haute campaign office of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton. A Terre Haute Fire Department spokesman, John Gardner, said investigators were focusing on two possible causes: lightning or a wiring malfunction. Two people in the office when the fire broke out escaped unharmed, Mr. Gardner said. Former President Bill Clinton, who stopped outside the burned building on his way to a speech, laughed when asked if the fire was a bad sign for his wife’s campaign for the Democratic presidential nomination. “No, I think this is a good omen,” he said. “We’ll rise from the ashes like the phoenix.” The Indiana primary is May 6.

A federal district judge has ordered a property owner to let the government survey her land for a border security fence, the latest round in a series of skirmishes to arise from the immigration-control measure. The landowner, Eloisa Tamez, is a leading figure in the resistance to the 670-mile fence, which is deeply unpopular in border areas. Ms. Tamez is a nursing professor who owns a small plot with two modest houses near the border close to Brownsville. The land is the remnants of a ranch that has been in her family since the 1700s. She filed a suit against Homeland Security Secretary Michael Chertoff in February in which she claimed the fence would “virtually complete destruction of the character and use of the lands for hundreds of years.” The court said that there was no way to tell what the government would do to her property and that it had no way of knowing what it might do without access to her land.

Just as in the first trial, jurors in Miami hit a stalemate in the case against six men accused of scheming to destroy the Sears Tower in Chicago and bomb F.B.I. offices. They were told to continue deliberating. The jury said in a terse note issued on their 10th day of deliberations that members could not agree on the guilt or innocence of any of the accused men. The first trial ended in a mistrial in December because of a hung jury for the accused ringleader, Narseal Batiste, left, and the five other defendants. One man was acquitted by the first jury, but the Bush administration intends to deport him to Haiti. Mr. Batiste’s lawyer, Ana M. Jhones, unsuccessfully asked Judge Joan Lenard of Federal District Court to declare a second mistrial. Instead, Judge Lenard replied with a note reading, “Please continue deliberating.”.

Two road workers in Erie Township jumped onto a moving school bus carrying 31 young students and steered it safely to a stop after the driver apparently suffered a medical problem. The workers, Aaron Pierce and Ken Lambert, were returning from their shift patching potholes when they saw the Monroe Public Schools bus swerving at 5 to 10 miles an hour. Mr. Lambert, a volunteer firefighter, had heard over his emergency radio that the bus driver had gone into diabetic shock. Mr. Pierce hoisted himself through a window to steer the bus to a stop.

Lindsay Davenport and Maria Sharapova set up a semifinal showdown Saturday in the Bausch & Lomb Championships at Amelia Island, Fla., winning quarterfinals Friday. The top-seeded Sharapova beat No. 10 Alona Bondarenko, 6-7 (9), 6-3, 6-2. Davenport, the No. 16 seed, advanced with a 6-4, 7-6 (3) victory over No. 8 Agnes Szavay. Sharapova is 5-1 lifetime against Davenport but has never faced her on clay, the surface at Amelia Island.

An 85-year-old legally blind golfer from southern Arizona made a hole in one this week on a par-3 course. Robert Dunham accomplished the feat on the third hole at Tortuga in Green Valley. Dunham played with a group of fellow blind veterans enrolled in a Veterans Affairs health program. A volunteer assistant lined him up with the ball, handed him a 9-iron and stepped back. “I thought they were kidding me,” said Dunham, a World War II veteran who lost his vision about 10 years ago. “I told them, ‘You guys better not be pulling my leg.’  ”.

Inbee Park was second after a nine-under 64 that tied the course record set by Ochoa in 2006. If the 26-year-old Ochoa wins Sunday, she will earn the last of the 27 points needed to qualify for the L.P.G.A.’s Hall of Fame, making her the youngest player to qualify.

Yang Tongyan, right, a Chinese writer serving a 12-year prison term for posting antigovernment articles on the Internet, will receive the 22nd annual PEN Freedom to Write Award, Bloomberg News reported. The $10,000 award is made to an imprisoned or persecuted writer in jeopardy because of health or other reasons. It is underwritten by Barbara Goldsmith, the author and historian, and presented by the PEN American Center, the United States chapter of the international writers organization. Mr. Yang, an essayist, poet and novelist who suffers from diabetes and arthritis, was arrested in December 2005 on charges of “subverting state authority ” and later sentenced to jail. Also known by his pen name Yang Tianshui, Mr. Yang previously spent a decade in prison for his opposition to the treatment of protesters in Tiananmen Square in 1989. Mr. Yang, who turns 47 on Saturday, is one of 38 writers now imprisoned in China, according to PEN. The award will be presented to Mr. Yang’s lawyer, Li Jianqiang, on April 28 at the American Museum of Natural History in New York.

A university student’s satirical musical about Diana, Princess of Wales, below, has been banned from opening to the public over fears of causing offense, the BBC reported. The University of Brighton has decided the controversial performance of “Diana, the Musical” should be open to invited guests only. The show, to be performed in a university-owned theater bar, depicts Diana living in Mexico with dead celebrities. Rupert Dannreuther, who wrote the musical for a university course, said he had not meant to cause offense; the show, he said, was intended to highlight the nature of celebrity and the media. But Margaret Funnell, a founder of Diana’s Circle, a group dedicated to preserving the memory of the princess, said, “This is a distasteful, disgusting thing, really.”.

Tavis Smiley, the radio and television host, will quit at the end of June as a commentator on Tom Joyner’s syndicated radio program. Mr. Joyner told his listeners on Friday that Mr. Smiley had quit, citing his workload as the reason. But Mr. Joyner said, and reiterated in a message posted on BlackAmericaWeb.com, that he believed the real reason for Mr. Smiley’s departure was that “the hate he’s been getting hurts.” Mr. Smiley has received a harsh reaction to his criticism of Senator Barack Obama for skipping Mr. Smiley’s annual State of the Black Union gathering of black opinion-makers in February. Mr. Smiley said in a statement Friday that “contrary to what has been suggested,” he left the radio show to devote time to other projects.

The West-Eastern Divan Orchestra, led by the conductor Daniel Barenboim, will share top billing with the television character Doctor Who at this year’s BBC Proms, the classical concert festival that runs from July 18 to Sept. 13, Bloomberg News reported. Divan, a mix of Israeli and Arab players, is scheduled to perform at Royal Albert Hall in London on Aug. 14. On July 27, a Sunday family Prom will feature music from the popular BBC series “Doctor Who.” Among other musicians in the Proms schedule are the bass-baritone Bryn Terfel, the conductor Simon Rattle, the tenor José Carreras, the violinist Nigel Kennedy and the pianist Murray Perahia. There will also be anniversary celebrations of the music of Ralph Vaughan Williams, Olivier Messiaen and Karlheinz Stockhausen.

“CSI” overtook “American Idol" as the most-watched show on Thursday, lifting CBS to a ratings victory for the night. Nielsen estimated that “CSI” had 19.9 million viewers at 9 p.m., while 19.6 million watched a special results edition of Fox’s “American Idol” at 8. “Idol” remained the highest-rated show among adults 18 to 49, though, giving Fox the lead in that market ahead of CBS. CBS also earned a first-place finish at 10 p.m. as “Without a Trace” (14.6 million) easily outdrew NBC’s “ER” (7.6 million) and ABC’s “Eli Stone” (5.9 million). NBC ranked third over all for the night, followed by ABC.

Madonna is expected to appear in a court in Malawi later this month for a final ruling on whether she can adopt a child from that African nation, Reuters reported. A court clerk said the case was tentatively expected to be heard on April 22, 23 and 25. Malawi’s government recommended earlier this month that its high court approve Madonna’s adoption of David Banda, the child she met in a Malawian orphanage a year and a half ago. Madonna began adoption proceedings in late 2006; the boy has been living with her and her husband, the filmmaker Guy Ritchie, in London since then. Critics have accused the government of skirting laws that ban nonresidents from adopting children in Malawi, where AIDS has left more than one million orphans.

Italian police have recovered a rare statue of Lucius Verus, a Roman emperor who ruled alongside Marcus Aurelius in the second century and was known for his reluctance to sit for portraits, The Associated Press reported. Police officials said the marble head was among more than a dozen looted ancient artifacts hidden in a boat garage near Rome. The bearded visage of Lucius Verus, above, is believed to have been unearthed in the Naples area and was probably destined for the international market, the police said. There are only four other known portraits of Lucius Verus. Ceramic vases stolen from an Etruscan tomb in central Italy were also among the items recovered last month in the port town of Fiumicino. Officers said they were traced to an antiquities dealer in Rome. No arrests have been made.

GROSSMAN--Jerome H., M.D., of Boston, April 1, age 68, after a valiant battle with cancer. Beloved and admired husband, father, brother, friend, and colleague. He was Director of the Health Care Delivery Program at the Kennedy School at Harvard University, past Chairman and CEO of New England Medical Center, and past Chairman of the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston. He is survived by his wife, Barbara; daughter and son-in-law Elizabeth Grossman and Josh Boorstein of Washington, DC; daughter and son-in-law Kate and Tai Sutliff of Newton, MA; daughter and son - in - law - to - be Amelia Grossman and Mike Mattler of Washington, DC; brother and sister-in-law Sy and Bonnie Grossman of Berkeley, CA; a nephew, a niece, and several cousins. A memorial service will be held on Friday, April 18 at 2:30pm at Trinity Church (206 Clarendon St.) in Boston.

RICH--Lewis Charles, husband, father, troubleshooter, great host, and darn good cook, died April 10, 2008. Born in the Bronx on April 11, 1927, he earned his degrees in electrical engineering and met the love of his life, Marianne Wachsner at City College of the City of New York. He worked as an engineer and manager for Ford In strument, Sperry Gyroscope, and Unisys. He is survived by his wife, Marianne, three children, James, David, and Katherine, and three grandchildren, Stephanie, Dina, and Leila, as well as his brother Roy, cousins, nieces and nephews. He will be sorely missed by them as well as by his friends and neighbors. A memorial service will be held this Sunday, April 13 Sinai Chapel 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway from 4-6pm, service at 5pm. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to the Macular Degeneration Foundation at www.eyesight.org. There will be a graveside service Monday, April 14 at Mount Pleasant cemetery Hawthorne, NY at 11:00am.

MURPHY--Lois. The Department of Pediatrics and Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center deeply mourn the passing of Lois Murphy, M.D. who died on April 8, 2008, at the age of 91. There will be a wake for Dr. Murphy at the John Krtil Funeral Home at 1297 First Avenue (70th Street), on Sunday from 24pm and 7-9pm. Her funeral mass will be at St. Monicas Church at 413 East 79th Street (First Avenue) at 10am Monday, April 14th. MURPHY--Dr. M. Lois, (91) died April 8, 2008 at her home. From 1965 until 1976 she was Chairman of the Department of Pediatrics at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, the first woman to be promoted to such a prestigious position. She was Professor Emeritus of Pediatrics in Therapeutic Research at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center and at Cornell University Medical College. Vogue magazine profiled her in its May 1967 ''The American Woman'' issue that featured other great American women of the day: Jacqueline Kennedy, Martha Graham, Mrs. William Paley and Judge Constance B. Motley. The full page article described Dr. Murphy's illustrious career in medicine and research and the impact that her ground - breaking re search had on the field of pediatric oncology. Literally thousands of patients owe their lives to Dr. Murphy and her efforts to develop pediatric oncology into a viable field where a diagnosis of cancer no longer meant a death sentence. In 1951, trained as a board certified pediatrician, she obtained a fellowship in medicine at Memorial Hospital for Cancer and Allied Diseases and in experimental chemotherapy at Sloan Kettering Institute for cancer in New York. Thus began a career in ground breaking chemotherapy research that resulted in the establishment of innovative treatment protocols that essentially created pediatric oncology 25 years before its formal creation as a field in 1971. At a time when pediatric cancer mortality was 99% Dr. Murphy used her background in chemistry and pediatrics to create treatments for children with cancer, particularly leukemia. Her development of a multidisciplinary treatment of cancers using chemotherapy, surgery and radiation and later pre-operative chemotherapy became a model for departments of pediatric oncology around the world that were later used in treatment of cancers in adults. She pioneered the idea of a day hospital for administering chemotherapy in 1968 for children and their families at a time when beds for children were in short supply. Visits to the day hospital increased from 6,000 in 1969 to 12,000 by 1974 and the cure rate of most of the cancers approached 80%. She is survived by nine nieces and nephews and thousands of grateful individuals and families around the world. ROSENSTOCK--Alice, 95, of Palm Beach, Florida, and Loudonville, New York, beloved wife of the late Hon. Simon Rosenstock, mother of Joan Rosenstock and Lawrence Rosenstock, mother-inlaw of Laura Rosenstock, on April 7, 2008. She was born on June 16, 1912, in Holyoke, Massachusetts, and grew up in Albany, New York. She graduated from Cornell University in 1933. An ardent supporter of the State of Israel from its founding, she was active in many Jewish organizations. She was an avid reader, a lover of ballet and the symphony, and a fine bridge player, a game she continued to play until the last weeks of her life. In addition to her children and daughterin-law, she is survived by her brothers, Dr. Alfred M. Freedman of New York City and Dr. Aaron D. Freedman of Estes Park, Colorado. Her sister, Sylvia Krant, predeceased her. She was loved and cherished by all who knew her for her warmth and unselfish generosity and kindness. The musician, poet, artist and dreamer Patti Smith brings all facets of her persona to “Land 250,” her solo exhibition at the Fondation Cartier in Paris, through June 22. Using drawings, Polaroids, films and favorite objects, Smith chronicles her relationships in one way or another. “The idea of friendship is really valuable to Patti,” says Grazia Quaroni, the foundation’s curator, “whether it’s real people she’s shared her life with,” like Robert Mapplethorpe, “or the references she has in her literature and other things,” such as Arthur Rimbaud. Smith’s world is also captured in the documentary “Patti Smith: Dream of Life,” currently making the film-festival circuit. The photographer Steven Sebring spent 11 years traveling with Smith to create a collage-like tribute. For information, go to dreamoflifethemovie.com. CHRISTINE MUHLKE.

1913: At age 2, posing at my childhood home in Choisy-le-Roi, outside Paris.for close to a century, the sculptor Louise bourgeois has been a beautiful provocateur. 1926: Wearing a dress designed by Paul Poiret. My parents competed over who could outfit me in better fashions. 1934: My student card from the University of Paris, where I studied art history. 1980: I wrote my name in the back of my town house in Chelsea, where I’ve run a Sunday salon for more than 30 years. 2007: Still working, at 96, and exhibiting around the world. 1996: Posing in front of one of my spider sculptures in Brooklyn. 1975: In an amoebalike latex suit that I designed and made.

1. England may be a nation of shopkeepers, but it probably doesn’t have many as savvy as Nicky Kinnaird, the founder of Space NK Apothecary. Fifteen years — and 52 stores — after first opening in Covent Garden, she still has an uncanny knack for making even the most au naturel women covet the cult beauty products that line her shelves. “It’s not about newness for the sake of newness,” she says. “Innovation is what does it for me. Kinnaird recently opened Space NK Soho, at 99 Greene Street. Go to spacenk.com.

When you experience self-loathing (and if you crave perfection, you will), fashion is the ideal mode of expression. Obviously, you can display your self-contempt no matter what you wear. Tacky slogan tees admit, “This shirt’s wittier than I am.” Bespoke suits whisper, “Inside my shiny carapace, I’m just another bug.” But adventuresome self-loathers look to the DILFIT (Do I Look Fat in This?) Awards for sartorial inspiration.

It’s a hard sell, asking readers to muster sympathy for the congenitally gorgeous whose job it is to wear designer clothes and walk. In “Model: A Memoir” (Simon Pulse), Cheryl Diamond pulls it off, as does Melissa Walker in “Violet on the Runway” (Berkley Jam) — both books intended for the young-adult audience that aspires to the life they describe. The plots are remarkably similar: a suburban ingénue whose long limbs and high cheekbones are underappreciated by her classmates back home is anointed by some cartoonish, hardhearted booker and ventures into the dog-eat-dog world of Seventh Avenue go-sees and fashion-week catwalk shows.

I have been wearing caftans for as long as I can remember. I started wearing them on the beach because I burn very easily, only this was in the ’80s, when everybody wore sarongs — you never saw a caftan. I used to buy them in India and Morocco and Turkey; each had their own version, and I’d adjust them in some way, but they always looked ethnic. Like that wonderful 1969 photograph of Talitha Getty sitting on a balcony in Morocco wearing a caftan. That was the fashion then, and she exemplified it. But I am Italian, I lived in London, and it was no longer 1969.

He is survived by his wife, Barbara; daughter and son-in-law Elizabeth Grossman and Josh Boorstein of Washington, DC; daughter and son-in-law Kate and Tai Sutliff of Newton, MA; daughter and son - in - law - to - be Amelia Grossman and Mike Mattler of Washington, DC; brother and sister-in-law Sy and Bonnie Grossman of Berkeley, CA; a nephew, a niece, and several cousins. BUILDING A SKI PARK IN THE SAND, SEPT. 28, 2007 André Holzer, 24, foreground, from Engelberg, Switzerland, along with fellow Swiss ski instructors, Bernadette Beer, rear center, and Stefan von Kanel, rear right, builds miniature ski slopes in the sand at Lalomanu Village in Samoa. ''I was in New Zealand for almost four months working as a coach for little kids who do ski competitions. It was good that I could work and learn English. I met a lot of people, and even had a job offer to be a coach in South Korea. One of the coaches I worked with had been to Samoa -- he showed me some pictures and I decided, 'O.K., when I go home, I want to go to Samoa for one week.' In the picture, we were building a snow park with jumps, pipes, quarter-pipes. It was the first time I'd been on a tropical island like Samoa with beaches and blue water. It was really, really beautiful.''

KELLY--Thomas E., passed away on March 20, 2008 at Cottage Hospital in Santa Barbara, California. He was born at The Flower Fifth Avenue Hospital, New York City, on March 5, 1924 to Edward Thomas Kelly, an Alderman for the City of New York, and Anastasia Cecilia Kane. Tom Kelly was a graduate of Regis High School, a Second Lieutenant Pilot assigned to the 486th Bomber Group, 833rd Bomber Squadron of the 3rd Division of the U.S. 8th Air Force, a graduate from N.Y.U. College of Engineering where he played on the varsity basketball team, and a Boston Celtic. Tom was inducted into the N.Y.U. Athletics Hall of Fame at N.Y.U. in 1991. Tom spent four decades with The Trane Company, building the KellyTrane Service Agency, a successful business in commercial HVAC sales. Tom served as President of the Board of Education for the Syosset, L.I. Central School District No. 2 from 1954 to 1958. Tom retired to Santa Barbara, California in 1994. He was predeceased by his first wife Irene and is survived by his wife, Joanie, and six sons and four daughters, John of New York City, Jed of New Rochelle, NY, Thomas of New Canaan, CT, Christopher of Stamford, CT, Matthew of Nyack, NY, Kirk of Lakewood, NY, Ann of Milford, CT, Irene of New City, NY, Stacy of New York City, and Deirdre Shaffer of Stamford, CT; and fourteen granddaughters, eleven grandsons, and two Greatgrandchildren. He is also survived by a stepson, Jon Williamson of Los Angeles, a step daughter, Lizbeth Williams of Los Angeles, and a step grandson. A mass of Christian burial was celebrated in Our Lady of Mount Carmel Church in Montecito, California, on March 25, 2008. Internment was in Santa Barbara Cemetery. A memorial service for friends and family will be held in Our Lady Star of the Sea Church, Stamford, Connecticut, on April 19th at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, donations to Cancer Center at Santa Barbara Cottage Hospital, P.O. Box 689, Santa, Barbara, CA 93102-0689.

BROWN--Robert Utting. Editor and President of Editor & Publisher from 1953 until 1999, passed away at his home in Greenwich, CT on Thursday, March 20, 2008. He was 95 years old. Born into a publishing family in Yonkers, New York, he graduated from Dartmouth College in 1934 and immediately went to The Empire State School of Printing, where he learned all aspects of printing, from hand type-setting to press and linotype operating. After working as a reporter for The Trenton Times (NJ), The United Press and The Auburn Citizen-Advertiser (NY), he joined Editor and Publisher, his family's weekly news magazine which covered the newspaper industry; widely known as the newspaperman's Bible. Mr. Brown was elected President of Editor & Publisher Corporation in 1953 and became publisher and editor in 1958 Mr. Brown gained enormous respect from his peers in the newspaper business and was considered an expert in the field. Among his honors were: Election to The American Society of Newspaper Editors (ASNE), the only editor of a weekly to be so honored; founding member and later president of The Inter American Press Association (IAPA); board member of The International Press Institute (IPI); governing board member of The Overseas Press Club; Elected a fellow of Sigma Delta Chi for Distinguished Achievements in the Profession of Journalism; recipient of Columbia Universitys Maria Moors Cabot Prize with Special Citation for Service in the Cause of Press Freedom; recipient of The Crain Award of the Association of Business Publishers (ABP) in 1989. Mr. Brown was predeceased by his wife of 50 years, Susan Steele Brown. They were widely regarded as the paragon of a happy and devoted couple. He is remembered with affection and admiration by his family, friends, and even his employees; who considered him to be a rare true gentleman of the old school possessing wit, intelligence and grace. Mr. Brown is survived by his two daughters, Robin Brown Woods of Darien, CT and Elizabeth Brown Phillips of Houston and Dallas, Texas; his sons-in-law Richard M. Woods, and John W Shannon, five grand children, Richard S Woods of Keystone, Colorado; Whitney S. Woods of Fairfield, CT; Ashley E Woods of Boulder, CO; D. Colin Phillips of Los Angeles, CA; and Christopher L. Phillips of Riverside, CT and two greatgrandchildren, Michael and Christopher Phillips of Riverside, CT. A Celebration of the life of Robert Brown will be held on Tuesday, May 20, 2008 at 11:00am at the Talmadge Hill Community Church, Talmadge Hill Rd., New Canaan, CT. Friends are invited to join the family, immediately following the service, at Wee Burn Country Club, 410 Hollow Tree Ridge Rd, Darien, CT. Donations in his memory may be made to: Greenwich Hospital Home Hospice Care.

GREENBERGER--George, M.D., 1925-2008. Dr. Joseph Cunningham and the Department of Surgery at Maimonides Medical Center, Brooklyn, New York, mourn the passing of one of the founding surgeons of the Department. Dr. Greenberger was not only one of the most eminent and proficient of surgeons in Brooklyn but he was also both a teacher and a student of the art and science of surgery. He was affiliated with Maimonides for 43 years (1949-1992) and was a partner of the most prominent surgical group of the time, the SGFS Surgical Group in Brooklyn. His contributions to this Department and to its many generations of surgeons, whom he mentored and educated, will be remembered for many years to come. He was a source of wisdom and compassion for both his patients and his colleague

THE six Roman Catholic elementary schools in Bridgeport, Conn., had struggled for more than a decade to meet enrollment goals. Tuition kept them out of reach for at least the one in five local families who lived below the poverty line, and their rising operating costs strained the finances of parishes already finding it hard to make ends meet. In 2004, Bishop William E. Lori, who had replaced Cardinal Edward M. Egan as head of the Diocese of Bridgeport, issued a call to action. He enlisted the help of retired chief executives and fund-raising specialists, who then recruited patrons for the schools or school projects, like maintenance and library renovation. He met with pastors of African-American churches and told them that their children were welcome in the Catholic schools. And he advertised to Latino families on Spanish-language radio.

9 P.M. (13, 49) A ROOM WITH A VIEW ''Masterpiece Theater'' presents E. M. Forster's lighthearted romance about a young Englishwoman who falls in love but doesn't realize it. Elaine Cassidy stars as Lucy Honeychurch, above with Laurence Fox as Cecil Vyse; she's an innocent abroad in Italy with her tightly laced chaperone, Charlotte Bartlett (Sophie Thompson). When they find less-than-suitable accommodations at their pensione, a father and his son (played by the father-and-son actors Timothy and Rafe Spall) offer to exchange rooms. Then Lucy is kissed in a field of violets. The screenwriter Andrew Davies adds a coda imagining what might have happened after the Forster novel ends. 8 P.M. (13, 49) WHAT MALES WILL DO ''Nature'' continues its inquiry into the birds and the bees with a look at the rather peculiar mating habits of species including lizards (the males do push-ups), gelada baboons (they show off their pectorals) and bowerbirds (they build elaborate nests).
