LEHANE--Dr. Stephen F. A kind, compassionate, and generous soul; a man of ideas; and a man who dedicated his life to making the world a better place for children -both his and the worlds. Dr. L's spirit, works, and one of a kind personality touched so many people in so many ways that he will always be a vibrant, creative, and caring presence. The spirit of Steve, son of Ida and Frances Lehane, lives large in his wife the former Mary Puglisi (''May or Zip''); his son Christopher Lehane (''Smedgie'') and daughter-in-law Andrea Evans; his son Erik Lehane (''Goog'') and daughter-in-law Stephanie Clayton; daughter Erin Lehane (''X'') and son-inlaw Thomas Tureen. Poppy's grandchildren, Brady and Bennett (''The B Boys''), Katelin, Dominic (''Domino') and Quincy, loved nothing better than playing with the oldest, wisest kid they knewfrom water balloon battles to munching on M&M's. Dr. L broke the mold. He made a difference. Although he barely slept and seemingly sustained himself on candy, cold pizza and long runs, he left his mark. His good works were widely recognized and he received many awards--but the most important reward was the love of his family and the happiness of the many children whose lives he touched. Most recently, he served as the Director of the Avant! Foundation, which supported historically underserved children in the Bay Area and beyond. The good doctor was also a teacher, college professor, author, speaker, mentor, and director of various early childhood development not-for-profits. A graduate of Lawrence, MA schools, he attended the Naval Academy, St. Anselm's College, the University of New Hampshire, and received a Ph.D. in Early Childhood Education from Columbia University. Steve lived in Menlo Park, California and Boothbay Harbor, Maine after residing for many years in Kennebunk, Maine. He started his next chapter on April 7th in Menlo Park, California. Steve / Daddy / Dr. L / Poppy will always be loved ''so much'' and his life will be celebrated ''so much'' on April 15th at 1:00pm at the Menlo Park Presbyterian Church, 950 Santa Cruz Avenue, Menlo Park, CA. In lieu of flowers, charitable donations may be sent to the Stephen F. Lehane Memorial Fund -created to honor his memory and continue his lifelong support of disadvantaged children. (Stephen F. Lehane Memorial Fund, c/o 3184 Washington Street, San Francisco, CA 94115).

ADLER--Robert Kerwin, died April 8, 2008. Born 1919, Bronx, NY; lately of Chicago, Illinois. Starting at age 16, after graduating from Madison High School in Brooklyn, he was an active participant in the labor and anti-fascist movements in New York City. He enlisted in the US Army in early 1942, serving for three and a half years in New Guinea and Australia. Following World War II he obtained his undergraduate degree from New York University, where he met, and in 1948 married, Charlotte Scher -his sweetheart for 60 years. He earned a Master's degree at Columbia University and spent his entire career in hospital administration, for 13 years as associate administrator of Brooklyn Jewish Hospital, and then for 20 years at Montefiore Hospital, Bronx, as administrative director of its outpatient medical group. He was instrumental in the early development of hospitalbased managed health care and the implementation of programs for emerging treatments such as kidney dialysis and radiation therapy. The main focus and joy of his life was his family. He is survived by siblings Fred Adler, Harriet Raboy, and Sally Frankel, was predeceased by sister Ruth Fiske, and had a large number of nieces and nephews to whom he was devoted. Father of Dr. Steven Adler (Karen) of Seattle, and Cara Adler (Dr. Douglas Bishop) of Chicago, and grandfather of Nathan and Rachel Adler Bishop and Katherine and Jacob Adler, Robert always considered himself a rich man and regarded his children and grandchildren as his crown jewels. He was a man of brilliance, intellect, marvelous wit and sense of humor; with a life-long passion for history and politics which he loved to discuss and debate. A warm, caring man, he was a forceful presence who ''filled up a room.''

GRAYSON--Cyrus (Lt. Col., USAF Ret.), 93, passed away peacefully on April 10, 2008. Cherished husband of Isabel, father to Roger, Mary, Eric and Jennifer, brother to Helen and ''Colonel'' to grandchildren, Natasha, Parker, Stafford and Barbara. A true son of NY, he attended Boys High, City College and Columbia and while helping the less fortunate by working in the City's orphanages, recalled always being able to get ''the kids'' into the Polo Grounds, Ebbetts Field or Yankee Stadium. In WWII, Cyrus joined the Army Air Corps and sailed on the Mariposa around the Cape of Good Hope to become an integral part of the ''Over-the-Hump Gang'' as a commander in the photo-reconnaissance squadron for the China-Burma-India theater. He was recalled for Korea. Cyrus later served as a Liaison Officer for the Air Force Academy for LI. Also successful privately, he was an EVP for A. Haupt, Inc. and formed The Parochial School Uniform Co. He loved jazz, blues and Hawaiian music and was an accomplished horseman, tennis player and avid reader. He was gentle, pleasant and captivating with his wonderful stories. His love and the love for him is eternal. Services for interment are to be scheduled at Arlington.

MARC JACOBS Whether he's toying with editors by dyeing his hair blue or by starting his notoriously late shows right on time (as he did for fall), the designer Marc Jacobs is no stranger to controversy. In fact, he finds a certain kinship with the gutsy women he designs for, such as the French actress Élodie Bouchez, whom he styled and palled around with for ''Stork Club'' on Page 70. ''She's the kind of girl I relate to on a lot of different levels,'' he says. Having worked with everyone from Dakota Fanning to the artist Richard Prince (his ''Danger Nurse at Work'' is at center), Jacobs is something of a pop-culture buff. ''I just kind of like the cartoony aspect of life today as seen through the media,'' he says. So why did he decide on the madcap idea of his underwear-as-outerwear collection for spring (far right)? ''I don't know, maybe it's because of the news of Britney and all this other stuff,'' he says. Oops, he did it again.

IN the course of writing about Lauren Reilly's DeLorean, I came across a strange dilemma concerning a quote from the movie ''Back to the Future.'' In the scene where Marty McFly tells young Doc Brown the amount of energy needed to power the flux capacitor, Brown has a minor meltdown. ''1.21 JIGOWATTS!'' he says. That's how it's written in the script -- jigowatt. But you won't find the word in the dictionary. What you will find is gigawatt. And because we pronounce gigabyte with a hard g, it seems logical that gigawatt would follow suit.

BILHUBER--Edmund (Ned), of Madison, NJ, Founder of The Milton School. Edmund Bilhuber, 84, died peacefully on April 10th at his home in Madison, New Jersey. In 1969, Mr. Bilhuber founded The Milton School, now in Livingston, NJ, a nonprofit, non-sectarian secondary school to help children with learning disabilities, and served as Chairman. He helped raise funds for the A-T Children's Project, for research to find a cure for A-T Disease. Ned grew up in Douglaston, LI, New York. A member of the class of 1945 at Colgate University, he was president of Phi Kappa Psi fraternity. He graduated in 1947 after serving two years as a combat medic in a rifle company with the 104 Infantry Division in Europe. He was awarded the Bronze Star for valor. He then attended Harvard Business School and New York Institute of Finance. After retiring as co-owner of Economic Benefits Corp. in Springfield, NJ, Mr. Bilhuber then founded and was President of The Solutions Group, Consultants to Management. Surviving him are his wife Janet, son Paul Bilhuber of Millburn, NJ, daughter Pamela Blair of Carlisle, MA, brothers Ernest Bilhuber of Annapolis, MD and Henry Bilhuber of Rosemont, PA, grandchildren Gregory Blair and Allison Blair of Carlisle, MA and eight stepchildren. A private memorial service is being planned for the future. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to AT Children's Project, 668 South Military Trail, Deerfield Beach, FL 33442 (1-800-5HELP-A-T). Services by Wm. A. Bradley & Son Funeral Home, 345 Main Street, Chatham, NJ.

THE NEWS The federal government is trying to develop an early-warning system to alert the authorities to incoming computer attacks. BEHIND THE NEWSMichael Chertoff, the homeland security secretary, asked private-sector experts for help at a conference on cybersecurity. The authorities acknowledge that hackers have broken into government computer systems and are intensifying their attacks. The fear is that they could cripple financial institutions or air traffic control systems. But one expert told The Associated Press that current technology can't detect incoming attacks. ''It's not like a hurricane or missile coming at you,'' he said. ''It's just there.''

He was a ''national treasure''. A humble man, Ira will be remembered by the thousands of lives he touched, for his gentle unassuming manner, his extraordinary intellect, and his courage. Our sorrow and loss are as deep as our commitment to live and work as he tirelessly did for humanity's struggle for emancipation. Donations can be made to The National Lawyer's Guild--NYC Chapter, www.nlgnyc.org. A memorial service will be held at a later date (iragollobin@aol.com).

A Case of the Blues Benjamin Wallace-Wells's erudite analysis of ''the end of Republican America'' did not get to the core of its ascendancy in the first place (March 30). Discounting the gains from persuading lunch-bucket types to vote red, using social-issue wedges, elephant nation took to its heart the maxim of the joke: What's the difference between Democrats and Republicans? Democrats are tax and spend; Republicans are borrow and spend. And borrow and spend is much more politically correct.

COOPER--Robert Joseph, of New York, NY died suddenly April 3, 2008 at his home in Manhattan. A man of uncommon dignity, Robert touched all who knew him with his intelligence, generosity, humor, and nobility of spirit. The unconventional path he followed was profoundly shaped by literature, art, and the rich life of the mind that so inspired him. His tireless resilience, fearless optimism, and elegant bearing will not be forgotten. Born September 9, 1931 in Oak Park, IL, Robert grew up in Pittsburgh, PA, and attended Shady Side Academy. At Yale University he earned an undergraduate degree in Literature, then served in the U.S. Army Artillery as First Lieutenant before returning to Yale for his Master's in Architecture. Robert lived in Europe before settling in Philadelphia where he worked in the office of Louis I. Kahn and then as principal of his own firm, Cooper & Pratt Architects. Known for his exquisite draftsmanship, he received design awards from both Yale University and the Philadelphia Chapter of AIA. In 1985 he moved to New York and, though he continued to work in architecture, embarked on a second career as a writer, sparked off by a transformative 10 year series of dreams which he experienced in his fifties, decisively changing his life. At the time of his death he was working on his third novel, and a collection of furniture designs. Robert's love for his family surpassed all else. He was the beloved husband of Theresa Savage Cooper, the loving father of Brice Beatrix Cooper and Audrey Osborne Cooper, and grandfather of Imogen Cooper Steed. He is survived by his sister, Idamae Rich, of Pittsburgh, PA; his brother, Alexander Cooper, of New York, NY; and his first wife, Elizabeth Osborne, of Philadelphia, PA. A memorial service will be held 2pm Friday, April 25 at the Yale Club of New York City, 50 Vanderbilt Ave.

MANY Internet users are accustomed to going to Zillow.com to see a rough approximation of their home's value. Now the site is offering a way to find mortgages. Baron Pierre de Coubertin, the French founder of the modern Olympic Games, probably didn't have this in mind when he came up with a logo of five interlocking rings in 1913, a logo that was then incorporated into the Olympic flag in 1920. The rings stand for the five continents (North and South America share a ring, and Antarctica lacks eligible bipeds). But how tempting those adaptable rings are when it comes to protest, particularly against China, host of the 2008 Games. Creative alterations of the rings have highlighted grievances as the Olympic torch has made its way from city to city in the last couple of weeks. Many of the doctored-logo signs call for a free Tibet. Some call for an end to the Chinese role as an enabler to Sudan in the genocide in Darfur, and at least one calls for the independence of the Uighurs, a Muslim minority in western China.

MURPHY--Lois. The Department of Pediatrics and Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center deeply mourn the passing of Lois Murphy, M.D. who died on April 8, 2008, at the age of 91. Dr. Murphy was a pioneer in the development of therapies combining multiple antineoplastic agents for children with cancer and a major force in the establishment of a national effort to develop, test and rapidly disseminate improvements in the diagnosis and treatment of malignancies of childhood. Dr. Murphy received her degree in medicine from the University of Nebraska in 1944. She was one of only two women in a class of one hundred. Thereafter, she completed an internship at Women's College of Pennsylvania, residency training in Pediatrics at St. Christopher's Hospital for Children and Children's Hospital of Philadelphia, and additional residency training in Pathology at Children's Hospital, Washington, D.C. Dr. Murphy came to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center (MSKCC) in 1951 and was appointed to the faculty in 1952. With Joseph Burchenal, M.D., she began to examine the biologic and therapeutic effects of the first drugs then being introduced for the treatment of cancer. Over the subsequent 12 years, she and Dr. Burchenal introduced a series of new cancer drugs into the treatment of leukemias in children. In addition, Dr. Murphy pioneered the use of combinations of active cancer drugs in protocols designed to maximize their additive effects on tumors while limiting toxicities, achieving improvements in sustained remissions. In 1956, Dr. Murphy played a major role in the founding of the Cancer and Leukemia Group A, later named the Children's Cancer Study Group, a national multicenter cooperative program of clinical research and treatment for children with cancer. She chaired this program from 1958 to 1965, organizing systems whereby new treatments developed at specialized centers like MSKCC could be tested in national trials and extended to all affected children. Dr. Murphy was also the first woman to lead a clinical department at MSKCC. As Chair of the Department of Pediatrics from 1965 to 1976, she organized its faculty into multidisciplinary disease management teams focused on specific tumors and shepherded the development of multimodality treatment regimens that significantly improved prospects for cure for children afflicted with leukemia, lymphoma, and osteogenic sarcoma. These regimens remain the foundation of the most advanced therapies available today. During her career, Dr. Murphy received many honors, including an honorary Doctor of Science degree from her alma mater, The University of Nebraska. She retired as Member Emerita in 1992 after 41 years of service to MSKCC, but continued to participate in its education programs until shortly before her death. Dr. Murphy was an extraordinary individual who devoted her life to the welfare of children with cancer. She will be deeply missed. MURPHY--Lois. The Department of Pediatrics and Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center deeply mourn the passing of Lois Murphy, M.D. who died on April 8, 2008, at the age of 91. There will be a wake for Dr. Murphy at the John Krtil Funeral Home at 1297 First Avenue (70th Street), on Sunday from 24pm and 7-9pm. Her funeral mass will be at St. Monicas Church at 413 East 79th Street (First Avenue) at 10am Monday, April 14th. MURPHY--Dr. M. Lois, (91) died April 8, 2008 at her home. From 1965 until 1976 she was Chairman of the Department of Pediatrics at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, the first woman to be promoted to such a prestigious position. She was Professor Emeritus of Pediatrics in Therapeutic Research at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center and at Cornell University Medical College. Vogue magazine profiled her in its May 1967 ''The American Woman'' issue that featured other great American women of the day: Jacqueline Kennedy, Martha Graham, Mrs. William Paley and Judge Constance B. Motley. The full page article described Dr. Murphy's illustrious career in medicine and research and the impact that her ground - breaking re search had on the field of pediatric oncology. Literally thousands of patients owe their lives to Dr. Murphy and her efforts to develop pediatric oncology into a viable field where a diagnosis of cancer no longer meant a death sentence. In 1951, trained as a board certified pediatrician, she obtained a fellowship in medicine at Memorial Hospital for Cancer and Allied Diseases and in experimental chemotherapy at Sloan Kettering Institute for cancer in New York. Thus began a career in ground breaking chemotherapy research that resulted in the establishment of innovative treatment protocols that essentially created pediatric oncology 25 years before its formal creation as a field in 1971. At a time when pediatric cancer mortality was 99% Dr. Murphy used her background in chemistry and pediatrics to create treatments for children with cancer, particularly leukemia. Her development of a multidisciplinary treatment of cancers using chemotherapy, surgery and radiation and later pre-operative chemotherapy became a model for departments of pediatric oncology around the world that were later used in treatment of cancers in adults. She pioneered the idea of a day hospital for administering chemotherapy in 1968 for children and their families at a time when beds for children were in short supply. Visits to the day hospital increased from 6,000 in 1969 to 12,000 by 1974 and the cure rate of most of the cancers approached 80%. She is survived by nine nieces and nephews and thousands of grateful individuals and families around the world. Viewing: Sunday April 13th 2-4 pm and 7-9 pm, John Krtil Funeral Home, 1297 First Avenue. Mass 10:00 am Monday, Saint Monica's Church, 413 East 79th Street. No flowers: donations to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center for pediatric oncology, PO Box 27106, NY, NY 10087.

MEASURE FOR MEASURE Just recently I've gotten excited about writing songs again. I didn't get there by a happy epiphany, but by pain of another sort. My friend and great songwriting mentor, John Stewart, died unexpectedly in January. When I heard the news, I pulled out a file I had saved with all the letters and drawings and faxes he had sent me over the years; I noticed that the dual themes of love and madness kept reappearing in his notes. He used to say to me, upon hearing a new song of mine that he thought might be too perfect or careful or contrived, either lyrically or structurally, ''But where's the madness, Rose?'' His belief in songs, and his sense of liberation and expansion when he approached writing, was deeply inspiring. ...When I first began to know him, I felt that I had been speaking with a vocabulary of 200 words, and in a few months he taught me 10,000 more. ... Often, it's true for me that the lyrics come first. I seldom find just melodies on the guitar that come out fully fleshed, and add the lyrics afterward. ... My song ''Seven Year Ache'' began as a long poem, several pages of rambling, and I distilled it down into a lyric. The melody came last.

STEINBERG--Gilbert (Gil) Born in New York City, December 15, 1920 passed away April 4, 2008 at age 87 peacefully, surrounded by his loving family. He was predeceased by his beloved wife of 56 years Ruth (Rickie) by just 7 months. Gil and Rickie are together again. Gil was a student of New York University and captain of the Swim Team when WWII broke out. On December 8, 1941 he joined the Army Air Force. In 1951 he bought Lees Art Shop on W. 57th St., just a few doors East of the Art Student League, measuring just 500 square feet. Gil was the buyer, salesman, wrapper, cashier and janitor. A year later Rickie joined Gil in business, and it flourished. In 1975 the business moved across the street to an old Schrafts Restaurant. Today as a result of their brilliant merchandising skills, and plain old fashion hard work, Lees Art Shop, and Lees Lighting and Furniture Studio and their over 100 employees, occupy a landmark 32,000 square feet at 220 W. 57 St., the ''Gilbert G. Steinberg Building, The House that Ruth Built.'' Gil and Rickie are survived by their three children, daughter Jillian (Jill) Isaacs, sons David and Mitchell, grandchildren Lauren and Brion Isaacs, and Evan, Chloe, and Elisabeth Steinberg and daughter-in-law Elissia. Together they were intensely devoted, generous, and loyal to their family, extended family, and many friends. Gil was an interesting man. He loved to laugh and make other people laugh. He was deeply interested in fine art, fine music, and numismatics. He was handsome, colorful, audacious, and proudly politically incorrect. Gil and Rickie will be sorely missed by the many people whose lives they touched over the 56 years they were together. Contributions in Memory of Gil may be made to the United Jewish Appeal (UJA) NY. Memorial Services were held at Riverside Memorial Chapel Sunday, April 6th 2008.

HOLMES--Richard, beloved teacher at Brooks School in North Andover, MA, died peacefully in Vero Beach, FL on March 30. He was 83. He came to Brooks School in 1948, intending to teach for only one year; forty-three years later he retired as assistant-headmaster of the school and settled in Cape Town, South Africa. His proudest achievement during his tenure was the introduction of the African Exchange Program between Brooks students and their counterparts at Bishops School in Cape Town. Richard hoped to encourage his students to become ''citizens of a larger world community''. The program was ahead of its time and has become a model for several schools since then. A lover of American art and artifacts, Richard befriended Andy Warhol in the 1960s and soon began collecting the artist's work. His entire collection of Warhols was recently given to Williams College, his alma mater. Brooks School will have lending rights. Richard will be sorely missed by the countless Brooks students he mentored and by the many families and friends who shared his love of Africa. A memorial service will be held at 11am on June 15 in the Ashburn Chapel at Brooks School. Gifts may be made in his name to the Richard F. Holmes Memorial Fund to benefit the African Exchange Program.

WENSTRAND--Thomas Edward, 78, on April 5, 2008. Born May 31, 1929 in Chicago and graduate of Hinsdale High, he held B.A. 1951 Northern Iowa University, M.M. 1952 Northwestern University, M.A. 1960 University of Chicago, and Ph.D. 1965 (Stylistics) Columbia University degrees. He served as SSgt., USAF 1952-1956. 1960-1988, he taught Humanities at Northern Arizona University, and in Flagstaff Tom was an avid hiker and played cello in the symphony. He retired Professor Emeritus in 1988 to Roosevelt Island. Tom was a member of the Society of Architectural Historians and the National Trust. He traveled widely in Europe, staying close to family and many friends; all of whom delighted in Tom's humanity, humor, curiosity, and knowledge and appreciation of all things beautiful. He is survived by his brother John of Birmingham, MI.

SHERRERD--John J.F. ''Jay'', 78, died Wednesday, April 9 at home in Bryn Mawr, PA. He was a graduate of Princeton University and the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania. He served in Korea as a 1st Lieutenant in the U.S. Army Artillery. In 1969, he co-founded Miller, Anderson & Sherrerd, a Philadelphia-based investment management firm that was acquired by Morgan Stanley in 1996. Mr. Sherrerd was an active volunteer and philanthropist, though most of his gifts were made anonymously and in honor of others. He was devoted to Princeton, where he was a Trustee Emeritus, having served on the board for twenty years, four as vice chair of the Executive Committee. Mr. Sherrerd was an Annual Giving fundraiser for decades and played leadership roles in Princeton's last three capital campaigns, including cochairing the Anniversary Campaign from 1995 to 2000. He was a director of the Princeton Investment Company (PRINCO) from 1987 to 1997. He was also a trustee of the Robertson Foundation of the Woodrow Wilson School at Princeton from 1982 to 2007 and chaired its Investment Committee for 29 years. Mr. Sherrerd was a loyal member of Princeton's Class of 1952 and attended fifty-five consecutive reunions. His license plate read ''JAY 52''. Mr. Sherrerd was also a trustee of the Gesu School, an independent Catholic school in North Philadelphia's inner-city. He co-chaired Gesu's capital campaign from 2005 to 2007. The school's Sherrerd Gymnasium was dedicated in his honor last spring. Mr. Sherrerd was serving at his death as co-chair of the current capital campaign for the Episcopal Academy in Merion, PA. He has served as the chairman of Smith College's Investment Committee, a member of the Board of Overseers at the Wharton School, and a trustee of the Shipley School in Bryn Mawr. He is survived by his son, Jay of Hood River, OR, his daughters, Anne of Riverside, CT and Susan of Piedmont, CA, his sister, Eve Bogle of Bryn Mawr, and six grandchildren: Alexandra, Michelle, Justin, Casey, Emily and Ellie. He was predeceased by his wife, Kathleen Compton Sherrerd, in 2005. Memorial service at Bryn Mawr Presbyterian Church, 629 Montgomery Ave., Bryn Mawr, PA on Saturday, April 19 at 10:00am. Contributions may be made to the John J.F. Sherrerd Memorial Scholarship Fund, Gesu School, 1700 W. Thompson Street, Philadelphia, PA 19121 or Princeton Annual Giving, P.O. Box 5357, Princeton, NJ 08543.

THE grammar school at St. Lawrence O'Toole Roman Catholic parish here opened in 1926, in a two-story building at the crest of a gentle slope near the train station. For decades, nuns lived in the rooms upstairs and taught their students in classrooms on the first floor.

NOVACK--Phillip. The Mirrer Yeshiva Central Institute mourns the passing of Mr. Phillip Novack. Our heartfelt sorrow and condolences to his wife Renee, his four children and seven grandchildren and brother-in-law Mr. Stanley Smith, longtime member of the Board of Trustees and Chairman of the Mirrer Yeshiva Archives Committee. The A. I. Smith family are builders of The Mirrer Yeshiva in America and have been devoted friends and supporters for over half a century. May the Almighty shield the family from further sorrow. The family requests that any memorial contributions be gifted to the Phillip Novack fund of Mirrer Yeshiva, 1791 Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn, NY 11223.

GRAY--Justin, of Newton, MA, age 90, on Wednesday, April 9, 2008. Beloved husband of Ellen Feingold. Updated, 2:38 p.m. | The defense presented closing arguments in the Sean Bell trial Monday morning with a combination of science and theatrics to make their case that the three detectives charged in Mr. Bell’s shooting were justified in pulling their triggers.The closing arguments of the three defense attorneys lasted about four hours, with prosecutors beginning their summation after the lunch break. The closing arguments were directed to an audience of one, Justice Arthur J. Cooperman, who is hearing the case without a jury and is expected to announce a verdict April 25.

Updated, 3:32 p.m. | A worker who was installing windows in a condominium tower under construction at 400 East 67th Street, near First Avenue, fell to his death around 10:30 a.m. today after a nylon safety strap failed, officials said. The man — who was later identified as Kevin Kelly, 25, of Bayside, Queens — fell from the 21st floor to the 14th floor, but it was not clear what broke his fall, the authorities said. No one else was injured, and it was not clear what caused the fall.

Ural Ekaterinburg, the top-seeded team, easily won the annual Russian team championships in Dagomys, a resort near the southern Russian city of Sochi, on the Black Sea. Athough the 12 teams in the championship had excellent players (93 of the 96 players in the event were grandmasters), Ural Ekaterinburg was almost unfairly stacked. Its four top players were Teimour Radjabov of Azerbaijan, No. 8 in the world, Alexei Shirov of Spain, No. 12, Gata Kamsky of the United States, No. 15, and Alexander Grischuk of Russia, No. 18. And its other four members were not exactly pushovers as even its lowest-ranked player, Alexander Motylev of Russia, is No. 52.

The situation in Tibet cannot be resolved until and unless the future of Chinese individuals is resolved, too; the majority of the citizens of Lhasa, after all, are already Han Chinese. Greil Marcus's "Mystery Train: Images of America in Rock 'n' Roll Music," probably the most widely admired book of rock criticism, has just come out in its fifth edition (it was first published in 1975). This new version has a "completely revised and rewritten" Notes and Discographies section, which is both informative and entertaining - just like the epilogue Marcus provided for his famous anthology "Stranded: Rock and Roll for a Desert Island." (I always thought his annotated list of the best rock music was even more enjoyable than the essays that preceded it.)

AUGUSTA, Ga. -- An unflinching Trevor Immelman won the Masters on Sunday by toughing it out, by staring down all challengers, by laughing at bad breaks and by doing what his lifelong golf idol told him to do. He listened to a voice mail message left by his idol, his fellow South African Gary Player, on Saturday night, and it helped Immelman prepare for what he would see, feel and do Sunday in the crucible of the back nine at Augusta National.

GOWAN--Donald Kingsley II, 61, of Kent, CT died April 12, 2008 in New Milford, CT. He was a history teacher and coach at Kent School, Kent, CT for 38 years. He is survived by his wife, GeorgeAnn Gowan of Kent, CT and three children, Donald, Anna and Andrew and two sisters, Maggie Webster and Ann Lord. A memorial service will be held Friday, April 18, 2008 at 11:00am at St. Joseph's Chapel, Kent School, Route 341, Kent, CT. Memorial contributions may be made to the Kent School, Donald Gowan Fund, P.O. Box 2006, Kent, CT 06757 or St. Andrew's Episcopal Church Capital Fund, P.O. Box 309, Kent, CT 06757.

SPIEGEL--Herman D.J., 83, of Madison, CT died at YaleNew Haven Hospital on April 13, 2008. Professor Spiegel taught Structural Engineering at the Yale School of Architecture from 1955 to 1993 and served as Dean of the School from 1971 to 1976. He was noted for his passionate and animated teaching style. He was a nationally recognized authority on the Spanish architect Antonio Gaudi. In addition to teaching, Professor Spiegel founded the Structural Engineering firm of Spiegel, Zamecnik and Shah in New Haven in 1956 and in Washington, DC., and he remained with the firm until 1990. Professor Spiegel was born in Boston, MA on December 31, 1924, son of Harry and Annie (Gittleman) Spiegel and grew up in Roxbury, MA. From 1943 to 1946 he served in the U.S. Army and saw action in World War II in both the European and Pacific theaters. After the war he attended Rhode Island School of design from which he received a B.S. in Architecture and then earned a Master's in Structural Engineering from Yale University. In 1957 he married Sally Peery of Madison, Connecticut. They lived in New Haven until moving to Madison in 1979. He died from complications from Multiple Myeloma. He is survived by his wife Sally, two sons, Robert and William and their wives, four grandchildren and several nieces and nephews. Funeral services at Temple Beth Tikvah, 196 Durham Rd./Route 79, Madison, CT Tuesday at 11:00am with interment services to follow in the Beaverbrook Cemetery, Clinton, CT. Memorial contributions may be sent to the Cancer Research Institute, One Exchange Plaza, 55 Broadway, Suite 1802, New York, NY 10006, or by calling 1-800-99-cancer. Funeral services in care of Robert E. Shure Funeral Home, New Haven, CT.

KONOVE--Robert, of New York, NY died April 5, 2008. Interment April 18, 1:30pm, Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Konove Memorial Heifer Ranch, 55 Heifer Road, Perryville, AK 72126.

EVANS--Lynne. The faculty, staff, students, and parents of Stuyvesant High School, New York City, mourn the passing of devoted and veteran English teacher Lynne Evans. Lynne taught at Stuyvesant since 1983, imparting her love of the classics to countless loyal and appreciative students. Ms. Evans returned to the classroom each fall term to share her love of books eagerly and selflessly with her classes. She will be greatly missed. Condolences are extended sincerely to members of her family. Funeral services and condolence information can be found at: www.stuy.edu

RUBENSTEIN--Rabbi Jacob S. and Deborah. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn with profound sadness the tragic passing of Rabbi Jacob S. Rubenstein of Young Israel of Scarsdale, and his wife, Debbie, treasured friends who will leave a lasting legacy on the entire community. Rabbi Rubenstein will be remembered as a giant rabbinic figure who combined intellectual and spiritual depth with a conviction to embrace the entire Jewish community. He served as a powerful exemplar of rabbinic leadership in his congregation as well as far beyond. Nationally, he served as chairman of the United Jewish Appeal Rabbinic Cabinet and president of the Rabbinic Council of America. He also served as chairman of UJA-Federation of New York's Rabbinic Advisory Council, receiving the Samuel W. and Rose Hurowitz Award and the Rabbinic Service Award for his sagely pastoral leadership. The precious lives of Debbie and Rabbi Rubenstein have strengthened our ability to serve those in need, making an enduring impact on the Jewish community here, in Israel, and around the world. We extend our deepest sympathies to their daughters, Shira and Yocheved; to their sons Daniel and his wife, Orite, and Jonathan and his wife, Samantha; to their grandchildren; four siblings; Debbie's parents, Sarah and Jerry Powell of Montreal, and to the entire family. John M. Shapiro, President Jerry W. Levin, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO RUBENSTEIN--Rabbi Jacob and Debbie. Young Israel of Scarsdale is brokenhearted at the deaths of its Sr. Rabbi and his wife. The Rubensteins died early Saturday morning in a tragic fire in their home. They are survived by their four children, Shira, Daniel (Orite), Jonathan (Samantha), and Yocheved, four grandchildren, four siblings, Debbie's parents, Sarah and Jerry Powell of Montreal, and a grieving community. Assistant Rabbi Jonathan Morgenstern Co-Presidents Hersh Wolf Michael Freudenstein

NEVINS--Marion Cahn, 93, died April 11, in Hollywood, FL. Her father was a NY Assemblyman, her mother a Manhattan Democratic leader. She grew up surrounded by politicians such as Governor Al Smith. Hunter College graduate, 1935. Married Broadway press agent Bert Nevins, 1936. As part of Nevins' world, she spent three decades with major entertainment and media figures. She loved nights at Palisades Amusement Park, a Nevins client. She worked on Nevins' Mrs. America Pageant. Moved to Hollywood, FL in 1956. After Nevins died in 1966, she married Florida lawyer Ben Salter.

Reported discoveries of lost works by Leonardo da Vinci are almost as common as, well, images of the Mona Lisa. The latest attribution to be proposed involves the design for the illustrations in a chess book from around 1500. The book, ''De Ludo Scachorum,'' or ''The Game of Chess,'' is by Luca Pacioli, a Franciscan friar and Renaissance mathematician who was a friend and collaborator of Leonardo. One of the earliest chess books, it contains 114 diagrams of chess problems drawn in red and black.

9 P.M. (13, 49) WALT WHITMAN In 1841 Walt Whitman, left, then a self-educated 21-year-old, left his working-class family on Long Island and headed for the city. He spent the next 14 years shuttling among Manhattan, Brooklyn, Long Island and New Orleans, working as a newspaper editor, novelist, political pamphleteer and shopkeeper. By the 1850s he began to search for a poetic voice that could speak for the people. The result was his self-published volume ''Leaves of Grass.'' This ''American Experience'' documentary traverses Whitman's life through romantic heartbreak and the Civil War as he nursed wounded and dying soldiers in Washington hospitals and tried to heal and unify the country. Chris Cooper provides Whitman's voice. 8 P.M. (Fox) BONES Brennan and Booth (Emily Deschanel and David Boreanaz) return with a new episode involving murdered motorcycle racers.

After 57 years as chief of the Wagner festival in Bayreuth, Germany, Wolfgang Wagner, 88, plans to step down, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Wagner, right, grandson of the composer Richard Wagner, wrote to donors on April 8 to express his support for his daughters Katharina Wagner, from his second marriage, and Eva Wagner-Pasquier, from his first, as part of a group to succeed him. He had previously rejected the appointment of Ms. Wagner-Pasquier, who is supported by the Richard Wagner Foundation, which supervises the annual Bayreuth Festival. And he had insisted that he would step aside only if Katharina were allowed to succeed him. The German-language television network 3sat reported that Mr. Wagner had suggested that the half-sisters could be part of a team that included the German conductor Christian Thielemann and Peter Ruzicka, the former director of the Salzburg Festival. Mr. Wagner has led the festival since 1951, first with his brother, Wieland, and then by himself after Wieland's death in 1966.

PHILADELPHIA -- The question that buzzes around Michael A. Nutter, the new mayor here, has nothing to do with the looming fiscal crisis, the intractable crime problem or the poverty that plagues the city -- issues that 82 percent of voters in November judged him best qualified to handle. It is the question implied, instead, in the window of a souvenir shop across the street from his second-floor office at City Hall. Barack Obama T-shirts are splayed out there with all the localpride accorded to the Liberty Bell, the Declaration of Independence and Rocky Balboa.

The 2008-9 baseball season has started, after the usual drama of off-season trades and the unusual drama of the Mitchell Report and Congressional hearings. The Nationals beat the Braves in the season opener in their new stadium, and the Yankees and the Mets have begun the long goodbyes at their home fields (Oliver Perez, above, pitched on opening day at Shea). The fantasy baseball season has also begun. Yahoo had the biggest share in the fantasy category for the week ending April 5, with 28 percent, followed by CBS Sportsline (10 percent) and ESPN (8 percent). SHELLY FREIERMAN

To our dear friend, words cannot express our loss. Your friendship is irreplaceable. Our love to Gloria and the family. Carol and Barry Cott and family LIPMAN--Michael, 73, passed away on April 12th, 2008 in Boca Raton, FL surrounded by his loving family and friends. Michael was a devoted and loving husband, father, grandfather and friend to all who knew him. Beloved husband of 50 years to Gloria, father of David and Sheila, Rena and Rick, Carolyn and Alan, grandfather of Lee, Gabrielle, Isabella and Vaughn Lipman, Olivia Lavin and Ryan and Corey Gross. Michael was a University of Pennsylvania and Wharton School of Business graduate who was the President for 40 years of Jameco Industries. He enjoyed his retirement for the last 13 years playing tennis and bridge, and traveling. However, nothing made him smile broader than to be surrounded by his family. Funeral services will be held at 12pm on Monday, April 14th, 2008 at Gutterman's in Rockville Centre, NY. Shiva to be held at the family home through Tuesday evening.

The New York Police Department, as part of a court settlement, has agreed to formalize several changes it has made in its crowd control procedures at political demonstrations. When the shooting stopped at Virginia Tech on April 16, 2007, the air was full of questions. On the simplest level, for almost 24 hours the nation did not know the identity of the gunman who killed 32 students and himself, Seung-Hui Cho. On perhaps the most profound level, the question of why this troubled and angry youth chose to plan and carry out the killings may never be fully answered. But there were a host of other issues that had relevance for other universities and for policymakers in general. They include:* whether Mr. Cho's history of mental illness should have barred him from purchasing the guns he used, and whether the system needed to be tightened* whether campuses would be safer if more students and faculty members could have guns to use to protect themselves* whether concerns over privacy stood in the way of adequate steps being taken to protect Mr. Cho's classmates and himself* and what if any changes needed to be made to emergency response procedures at schools across the country.A group of people with expertise on different aspects of these questions has agreed to discuss these issues. To begin, each will address what has happened - and what hasn't - in the field they know best in the last year.

The Democratic presidential primary in Pennsylvania has drawn attention to troubles in the state's manufacturing sector and to the role played by the North American Free Trade Agreement specifically and by global trade generally. Despite isolated success stories, Pennsylvania manufacturing has experienced job loss and stagnation for over a decade. Not everything that has gone wrong with the Pennsylvania economy is due to trade, but the worries of workers in the state (and throughout the country) about what globalization means for their living standards are well-founded.

Mr. Bush, according to the Associated Press this morning, will specify the need to cut carbon dioxide emissions from power plants within 10 or 15 years (methods unspecified) and will propose that the United States end growth in its greenhouse-gas emissions by 2025. OK, actually I was born in Albany, and grew up on Long Island. But here's my question: I understand why it's political poison to show disrespect for small-town values -- dignity is precious to all of us, and often trumps material interest. But why is it OK to disrespect big city values, even to suggest -- as Bush has -- that big-city dwellers aren't part of the "real America"?

There's a certain irony about Benedict XVI's visit to the United States, and it's this: the fact that from the 1980s right up to the day of his election a not-inconsiderable chunk of those who ran this Church he's visiting wouldn't have put him on their Friend's List for anything. In fact, as someone remarked, it was the era in which "Ratzinger" functioned as something close to a swear word, the punching bag for frustrated progressive church professionals everywhere.

In 2005, there were so many pirates marauding in the Malacca Strait, one of the world's busiest shipping lanes, that Lloyd's of London classified it as a "war zone." But last year, there wasn't a single attack, according to a Malaysian defense official.

Delta Air Lines just announced its long-awaited, much-discussed-though-supposedly-secret deal to merge with Northwest Airlines. Shareholders of Delta, which is the acquirer in the transaction, didn't seem immediately overjoyed: The stock was down 10 percent in midmorning trading Tuesday.

Linens 'n Things, the troubled home furnishings retailer, said on Tuesday that it will defer paying about $16.1 million in interest payments due today, as it works with creditors toward a restructuring of the company's capital.

There is a race afoot between two energy sources that are, in essence, different forms of concentrated sunlight. Coal, of course, is one, forged from the baked, compressed remains of ancient plant life. And coal has a centuries-long head start over the newcomer, capturing the heat of the sun with arrays of mirrors and turning it into electricity.

This isn't the first time we've had a worldwide surge in food prices. There was a huge price rise in 1972-1974 -- bigger, in percentage terms, than the current spike. (The chart has a log scale, so that equal vertical distances are equal percentage increases.) Some of the causes look similar: droughts in the Southern Hemisphere (the Peruvian anchovies disappeared, too) and a period of rapid world growth. It even included some similar panic reactions: Nixon banned soybean exports!
Three reality shows and two dramas will join CBS's schedule this summer, the network announced Monday.

The Associated Press: "The Screen Actors Guild will go it alone in contract negotiations with studios after the other major actors union rejected an invitation for joint talks. In a letter Monday to SAG, the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists said it would not revisit its decision to sever the guilds' longtime unified negotiations."

Three of the most startlingly fast cars around appear in new advertisements for Tommy Hilfiger: belly tank lakesters, built from fighter plane fuel tanks for speed runs at the Bonneville Salt Flats in Utah and other dry lakebeds. The ads feature models draped over the cars, not quite accurately portraying the traditional scene at Bonneville Speed Week.
Susie Madrak says that the airwaves are filled with Obama ads. That hasn't been my experience, even though we're not that far from PA -- in fact, I've mostly heard Clinton ads.

One of the defining features of the last 8 years or so has been the way ideas go from crazy stuff that only DFHs believe to stuff everyone knows, without ever going through a stage in which the holders of conventional wisdom acknowledge that they were wrong. Oh, and the people who were right are still considered DFHs; you see, they were right too soon.
Yesterday Barack Obama was a Marxist, today's he's only a socialist (and that only by blood relation) -- heck, by the time Pennsylvania votes he may be a devout supply sider.
John McCain will once again try to prove he's an able businessman as he lays out his economic plan Tuesday during a speech at Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh.

The markets are speaking at the University of Iowa's Electronic Market, and they are saying that the Democrats have an edge to take the White House in the fall and that Barack Obama is the favored candidate over Hillary Rodham Clinton.

The consumer spending slump and tightening credit markets are unleashing a widening wave of bankruptcies in American retailing, prompting thousands of store closings that are expected to remake suburban malls and downtown shopping districts across the country.

All eyes have been on Apollo Management this week amid reports that the buyout shop's retailer Linens 'n Things is teetering on the verge of bankruptcy. But another big buyout shop is also grappling with a troubled investment, in another sign that the credit crunch may result in a long-awaited shake-up among companies bought by private equity firms.
The government-brokered rescue of Bear Stearns and the trauma of the credit crisis has turned at least one Bush administration official into a convert to the merits of regulation.

Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines agreed to merge late Monday, in a $3.1 billion deal that would create the world's biggest airline and could prompt other airlines to pursue mergers of their own.
From someone who understands Internet attention spans:

Temasek exercised an option to buy an additional $600 million worth of Merrill Lynch shares in February, raising its investment in the U.S. bank to $5 billion, the sovereign wealth fund said on Tuesday.
The Wachovia Corporation kicked off what is expected to be a grim earnings season for the nation's banks on Monday, stunning Wall Street with an unexpected loss.

The British treasury chief made a pitch Tuesday for the China Investment Corporation, that country's $200 billion state investment fund, to invest in Britain as he visited Beijing amid strains over Tibet and China's trade surplus.

Bear Stearns Chief Executive Alan D. Schwartz, who found himself selling the hobbled investment bank to JPMorgan Chase in his eleventh week on the job, has been invited to stay on as a senior dealmaker, Reuters reported.
Lehman Brothers is planning to invest up to $1 billion in a fund it will use to buy stakes in hedge fund managers, Reuters reported.

Goldman Sachs may have emerged relatively unscathed by the epidemic of write-downs of subprime mortgage loans that has hit its investment banking peers. But it appears the banking powerhouse has been hit instead by the market's reluctance to syndicate private equity debt.
A record number of companies canceled initial public offerings in the first quarter as stock markets fell and concerns about a recession sapped demand for new shares.

A hostile bid by Blockbuster, the financially ailing video-rental giant, to acquire Circuit City Stores for more than $1 billion in cash left Wall Street befuddled on Monday, as investors questioned the benefits of an unlikely union of two troubled companies.

Tesla Motors, the Silicon Valley maker of electric sports cars, filed suit in San Mateo Superior Court on Monday against a competing company and two of its employees, saying they stole some of Tesla's design ideas and trade secrets.

It has been a brutal time for companies hoping to go public, with a record number of initial public offerings being withdrawn in the first quarter of 2008. This makes the proposed stock sale of DigitalGlobe, a provider of satellite earth images whose customers include the United States government and Google, all the more interesting. Late Monday, the Longmont, Colo.-based company filed to sell as much as $250 million in stock on the New York Stock Exchange.

The Bear Stearns Companies said Monday that its profit dropped 79 percent in the first quarter, which ended just two weeks before speculation about a liquidity crisis forced its sale to JPMorgan Chase.
Codexis, a biotechnology company whose investors include Shell Oil and Pequot Capital, hopes to raise up to $100 million in an initial public offering of its common stock.
HSBC has been named as the top underwriting bank in global initial public offering rankings for the first time, bolstered by strong deal-flow from Asia and the Middle East.

Move Networks on Monday said it closed a $46 million round of Series C venture investment and cemented key strategic partnerships, as the online television technology developer seeks to develop video services for broadcasters and publishers.
The Treasury Department on Tuesday will bless the release of two hedge fund best practices guides that examine the issues of hedge funds, risk and investor protection, according to press reports.
Realtime Worlds, a 6-year-old videogame developer of massively multi-player online games, has raised $50 million in Series B funding, the company said Monday.

Amid spiking interest in green technology, the head of three shipping and energy companies plans to announce on Tuesday a new investment fund focusing on environmentally friendly developments in the maritime and clean energy sectors.
China has accumulated a stake of just under 1 percent in BP, raising fresh questions about Beijing's strategy for investing its huge foreign currency reserves.
Dell on Monday sold $1.5 billion of debt in three parts, Reuters reported.
Ubisoft Entertainment, Europe's largest video games publisher, said on Tuesday it has agreed to acquire Pune, an India-based video game development studio, from Gameloft.
Special-purpose acquisition companies, whose popularity has surged in the last few years, could be poised to take a breather in 2008, according to new research cited by Investment Dealers' Digest.
